Ishbosheth is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **gone in to**. Depending on what is appropriate in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [slept with]

bsb_verse_text: Abner was furious over Ish-bosheth’s accusation. “Am I the head of a dog that belongs to Judah?” he asked. “All this time I have been loyal to the house of your father Saul, to his brothers, and to his friends. I have not delivered you into the hand of David, but now you accuse me of wrongdoing with this woman!
ult_verse_text: And it burned greatly to Abner concerning the words of Ishbosheth. And he said, “{Am} I the head of a dog that {is} to Judah? Today I am doing kindness with the house of Saul your father, to his brothers, and to his friends, and I have not delivered you into the hand of David. Yet today you charge against me the iniquity of a woman!

notes.note: The author is describing Abner becoming extremely angry by association with the way a person’s skin may become hot when he is angry. Your culture may also associate anger with heat, and if so, you could use its characteristic expression in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [And Abner became steaming mad] or [And Abner became extremely angry]

The author is using the term **words** to represent what Ishbosheth said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what Ishbosheth had said to him]

Abner is using one part of a dog, his **head**, to mean an entire dog. He may be doing this to make his statement more elaborate and emphatic. Your language may have its own way of doing this. Alternate translation: [Am I some kind of dog that is to Judah]

Abner is using the question form to express anger and deny that he is worthless. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for those purposes, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I am not the head of a dog that is to Judah!] or [I am not some kind of dog that is to Judah!]

In this culture, people considered wild dogs dirty and regarded them with contempt. Abner is suggesting that the Judeans are contemptible for not supporting Saul’s son as their next king. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [I am not some contemptible Judean!]

notes.orig_language_quote: הַ⁠יּ֨וֹם אֶֽעֱשֶׂה־חֶ֜סֶד עִם־בֵּ֣ית ׀ שָׁא֣וּל אָבִ֗י⁠ךָ אֶל־אֶחָי⁠ו֙ וְ⁠אֶל־מֵ֣רֵעֵ֔⁠הוּ
notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **kindness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [I am treating your father Saul’s descendants, brothers, and friends kindly] or [I am remaining loyal to the house of Saul your father, to his brothers, and to his friends]

Here, **hand** represents the capability of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I have not delivered you into David’s power] or [and I have not allowed David to overpower you]

Abner is using this possessive form to mean iniquity committed against a woman. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [you charge me with committing iniquity against a woman]
See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of how, if Abner had actually had sexual relations with Rizpah, that would have been a symbolic action asserting a claim to be the king.

bsb_verse_text: May God punish Abner, and ever so severely, if I do not do for David what the LORD has sworn to him:
ult_verse_text: Thus may God do to Abner, and thus may he add to him, if, according to what Yahweh has sworn to David, that thus I will do for him,

notes.note: Abner swears in this verse that he is going to do something, but he does not describe until the next verse what he is going to do. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could create a verse bridge for [verses 9–10](../03/09.md) and have Abner first describe what he is going to do and then swear that he will do it. (That would not change the meaning, only the order of the information.) The UST models one way to do that.

notes.orig_language_quote: כֹּֽה־יַעֲשֶׂ֤ה אֱלֹהִים֙ לְ⁠אַבְנֵ֔ר וְ⁠כֹ֖ה יֹסִ֣יף ל֑⁠וֹ כִּ֗י כַּ⁠אֲשֶׁ֨ר נִשְׁבַּ֤ע יְהוָה֙ לְ⁠דָוִ֔ד כִּֽי־כֵ֖ן אֶֽעֱשֶׂה־לּֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: Following the custom of his culture, Abner is using a conditional statement to swear an oath. What he states as a condition (“if”) is what he is swearing to do. Use a natural way in your language to express an oath. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could put the condition before the consequence. Alternate translation: [I swear that I will do for David according to what Yahweh has sworn to him, and if I do not, then may God do thus to Abner, and thus may he add to him]

notes.orig_language_quote: כֹּֽה־יַעֲשֶׂ֤ה אֱלֹהִים֙ לְ⁠אַבְנֵ֔ר וְ⁠כֹ֖ה יֹסִ֣יף ל֑⁠וֹ כִּ֗י כַּ⁠אֲשֶׁ֨ר נִשְׁבַּ֤ע יְהוָה֙ לְ⁠דָוִ֔ד כִּֽי־כֵ֖ן אֶֽעֱשֶׂה־לּֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: Because he is swearing an oath, Abner is speaking about himself solemnly in the third person. If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this in the first person. Alternate translation: [Thus may God do to me, Abner, and thus may he add to me]

notes.orig_language_quote: כֹּֽה־יַעֲשֶׂ֤ה אֱלֹהִים֙ לְ⁠אַבְנֵ֔ר וְ⁠כֹ֖ה יֹסִ֣יף ל֑⁠וֹ
notes.note: When Abner says **thus may he add**, he is using a common expression of his culture. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Thus may God do to Abner, and may he do even worse]

notes.orig_language_quote: כֹּֽה־יַעֲשֶׂ֤ה אֱלֹהִים֙ לְ⁠אַבְנֵ֔ר וְ⁠כֹ֖ה יֹסִ֣יף ל֑⁠וֹ
notes.note: The word **Thus**: (1) could refer to what Abner describes in the next verse. Abner could be saying that if he does not take away the privileged position of Saul’s family, then he wants God to take away his privileged position as a powerful leader. The UST models one way to express that meaning. (2) could be a general expression introducing the entire statement as a reference to severe punishment. Alternate translation: [May God punish me, Abner, very severely]

bsb_verse_text: to transfer the kingdom from the house of Saul and to establish the throne of David over Israel and Judah, from Dan to Beersheba.”
ult_verse_text: to cause the kingdom to pass over from the house of Saul and to raise up the throne of David over Israel and over Judah, from Dan and to Beersheba.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [to cause the kingdom to pass over from the descendants of Saul]

Abner is using the term **kingdom** to mean a king’s rule over the Israelites, not the Israelites themselves over whom he would rule. Alternate translation: [to cause the kingship to pass over from the descendants of Saul]

Here, Abner is speaking as if the **kingdom** might physically **pass over** from one location to another. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to cause the descendants of Saul no longer to rule as kings]

Abner is speaking as if he would physically **raise up** the **throne** of David to a high position above Israel and Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express his meaning using an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and to establish the rule of David]

Abner is referring to all of the Israelite territory by naming two extremes, **Dan** (a city in the far north) and **Beersheba** (a city in the far south). If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [over the entire territory of Israel and Judah]

bsb_verse_text: And for fear of Abner, Ish-bosheth did not dare to say another word to him.
ult_verse_text: And he was not able to return a further word {to} Abner, because of his fearing him.

notes.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Ishbosheth. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And Ishbosheth was not able]

The author is using the term **word** to represent what Ishbosheth might have said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to say anything further]

bsb_verse_text: Then Abner sent messengers on his behalf to say to David, “To whom does the land belong? Make your covenant with me, and surely my hand will be with you to bring all Israel over to you.”
ult_verse_text: And Abner sent messengers to David in place of him, saying, “To whom {is} the land?” saying, “Cut your covenant with me, and behold, my hand {will be} with you to make all of Israel turn to you.”

notes.orig_language_quote: לֵ⁠אמֹ֖ר לְ⁠מִי־אָ֑רֶץ לֵ⁠אמֹ֗ר כָּרְתָ֤⁠ה בְרִֽיתְ⁠ךָ֙ אִתִּ֔⁠י
notes.note: The term **saying** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this term explicitly. Alternate translation: [saying, “To whom {is} the land? Cut your covenant with me]

Abner is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Abner could mean: (1) that he, not Ishbosheth, actually controls the **land**, so if David makes a covenant **with** him, he can deliver **all of Israel** to David. Alternate translation: [The land is under my control!]; (2) that since Yahweh promised David the kingship, Abner will help him become the king of all of Israel on that basis. Alternate translation: [You are the rightful king of the land!]

Abner is using **Cut your covenant** as a common expression of his culture to mean “make your covenant.” If this phrase would not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Make a covenant with me]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md).

Abner is using his **hand** to represent himself in the act of accompanying and assisting David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will be with you]

In telling David he will be **with** him, Abner is using a common expression of his culture to mean that he will help him. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will support you]

Here, Abner is speaking as if he would physically make the Israelites **turn** in a different direction. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to make all the Israelites accept you as their king]

bsb_verse_text: “Good,” replied David, “I will make a covenant with you. But there is one thing I require of you: Do not appear before me unless you bring Saul’s daughter Michal when you come to see me.”
ult_verse_text: And he said, “Good, I, I will cut a covenant with you. Only one thing I am asking from you, saying, ‘You shall not see my face unless you bring Michal, the daughter of Saul, to my face when you come to see my face.’”

notes.note: The pronoun **he** refers to David. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [Then David said]

David is stating the pronoun **I** separately, even though the verb translated as **I will cut** already includes this meaning. He is doing that to emphasize that he is making a commitment to Abner. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing the meaning here. Alternate translation: [I agree to cut a covenant with you]

notes.orig_language_quote: אַ֣ךְ דָּבָ֣ר אֶחָ֡ד אָנֹכִי֩ שֹׁאֵ֨ל מֵ⁠אִתְּ⁠ךָ֤ לֵ⁠אמֹר֙ לֹא־תִרְאֶ֣ה אֶת־פָּנַ֔⁠י כִּ֣י ׀ אִם־לִ⁠פְנֵ֣י הֱבִיאֲ⁠ךָ֗ אֵ֚ת מִיכַ֣ל בַּת־שָׁא֔וּל בְּ⁠בֹאֲ⁠ךָ֖ לִ⁠רְא֥וֹת אֶת־פָּנָֽ⁠י
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [Only one thing I am asking from you. You will not see my face unless you bring Michal, the daughter of Saul, to my face when you come to see my face.]

notes.orig_language_quote: לֹא־תִרְאֶ֣ה אֶת־פָּנַ֔⁠י כִּ֣י ׀ אִם־לִ⁠פְנֵ֣י הֱבִיאֲ⁠ךָ֗ אֵ֚ת מִיכַ֣ל
notes.note: If it would appear in your language that David was making a statement and then contradicting it, you could reword this as a positive statement. Alternate translation: [You will only see my face if you bring Michal]

Here, **face** represents personal presence. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [You will not come into my presence … when you come into my presence]

David is using **face** to represent his whole person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [back to me]

bsb_verse_text: So Ish-bosheth sent and took Michal from her husband Paltiel son of Laish.
ult_verse_text: And Ishbosheth sent and took her from with {her} husband, from with Paltiel, the son of Laish.

notes.note: Since David refers to Michal as “my wife” in the previous verse, it may not be appropriate in your language and culture to describe Paltiel as **{her} husband** here. If that is the case, you can use a different expression. Alternate translation: [the man to whom her father Saul had given her]

Here the author is introducing Paltiel as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [a man named Paltiel who was the son of Laish]

See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of why this man is called **Paltiel** here but Palti when he first appears in the story in [1 Samuel 25:44](../../1sa/25/44.md). We recommend that you use these two different versions of his name in these places in your translation.

bsb_verse_text: Her husband followed her, weeping all the way to Bahurim. Then Abner said to him, “Go back.” So he returned home.
ult_verse_text: And her husband went with her, going and weeping after her, to Bahurim. Then Abner said to him, “Go, return.” So he returned.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:15](../03/15.md).

The phrase **going and weeping** expresses a single idea. The word **weeping** tells in what way Paltiel was **going**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [going tearfully]

Abner could be using the term **Go** to tell Paltiel: (1) that he must now **return**. **Bahurim** was near the border of Judah, and Abner did not want Paltiel to enter the territory that David was ruling. Alternate translation: [It is time for you to return]; (2) that Paltiel must leave that place, where Michal was, and return to his home without her. Alternate translation: [Leave here and return home]

bsb_verse_text: Now Abner conferred with the elders of Israel and said, “In the past you sought David as your king.
ult_verse_text: Now the word of Abner had been with the elders of Israel, saying, “Both yesterday and the third day you were seeking David as king over you.

notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture. Alternate translation: [Meanwhile, Abner had been speaking with the elders of Israel]

The author is using the term **word** to represent what Abner said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Now Abner had sent a message to the elders of Israel]

Abner is using **Both yesterday and the third day** as a common expression of his culture to mean the way things had been previously. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [In the past]

bsb_verse_text: Now take action, because the LORD has said to David, ‘Through My servant David I will save My people Israel from the hands of the Philistines and of all their enemies.’”
ult_verse_text: And now, do {it}, for Yahweh spoke about David, saying, ‘By the hand of David my servant, I will save my people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from the hand of all of their enemies.’”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

notes.orig_language_quote: עֲשׂ֑וּ כִּ֣י יְהוָ֗ה אָמַ֤ר אֶל־דָּוִד֙ לֵ⁠אמֹ֔ר בְּ⁠יַ֣ד ׀ דָּוִ֣ד עַבְדִּ֗⁠י הוֹשִׁ֜יעַ אֶת־עַמִּ֤⁠י יִשְׂרָאֵל֙ מִ⁠יַּ֣ד פְּלִשְׁתִּ֔ים וּ⁠מִ⁠יַּ֖ד כָּל־אֹיְבֵי⁠הֶֽם
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since Yahweh spoke about David, saying, ‘By the hand of David my servant, I will save my people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from the hand of all of their enemies,’ do it]

notes.orig_language_quote: לֵ⁠אמֹ֔ר בְּ⁠יַ֣ד ׀ דָּוִ֣ד עַבְדִּ֗⁠י הוֹשִׁ֜יעַ אֶת־עַמִּ֤⁠י יִשְׂרָאֵל֙ מִ⁠יַּ֣ד פְּלִשְׁתִּ֔ים וּ⁠מִ⁠יַּ֖ד כָּל־אֹיְבֵי⁠הֶֽם
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [saying that by the hand of David his servant he would save his people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from the hand of all of their enemies]

Here, **hand** represents the actions of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Through the actions of David my servant]

Here, **hand** represents the power or control of a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from the power of the Philistines and from the power of all of their enemies] or [from the control of the Philistines and from the control of all of their enemies]

bsb_verse_text: Abner also spoke to the Benjamites. Then he went to Hebron to tell David all that seemed good to Israel and to the whole house of Benjamin.
ult_verse_text: And Abner had also spoken in the ears of Benjamin. Then Abner went also to speak in the ears of David in Hebron all that {had been} good in the eyes of Israel and in the eyes of all of the house of Benjamin.

notes.note: The author is using the term **ears** to mean hearing. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [in the hearing of Benjamin … in the hearing of David] or [to Benjamin in person … to David in person]

notes.orig_language_quote: אֵ֤ת כָּל־אֲשֶׁר־טוֹב֙ בְּ⁠עֵינֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל וּ⁠בְ⁠עֵינֵ֖י כָּל־בֵּ֥ית בִּנְיָמִֽן
notes.note: See the discussion of the phrase **good in the eyes of** in the Introduction to this chapter. Alternate translation: [everything that Israel and the house of Benjamin had decided was the right thing to do]
Here, **Israel** represents the people of Israel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the Israelites]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [the whole tribe of Benjamin]

bsb_verse_text: When Abner and twenty of his men came to David at Hebron, David held a feast for them.
ult_verse_text: And Abner came to David {in} Hebron, and with him {were} 20 men. And David made a feast for Abner and for the men who {were} with him.

notes.note: Bringing a round and significant number of men with him was a symbolic action by which Abner showed respect for David. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [and he brought 20 men with him to show respect for David]

bsb_verse_text: Then Abner said to David, “Let me go at once, and I will gather all Israel to my lord the king, that they may make a covenant with you, and that you may rule over all that your heart desires.” So David dismissed Abner, and he went in peace.
ult_verse_text: Then Abner said to David, “Let me arise and go and gather to my lord the king all of Israel so they may cut a covenant with you so you may reign over all that your soul desires.” And David sent Abner away, and he went in peace.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [Let me take action]

Even though Abner is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [to you, my lord the king]

Abner says **all of Israel** as an generalization for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [leaders from throughout Israel]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [so they may make a covenant with you]

Abner is using David’s **soul** to represent all of him as a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you desire]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [peacefully]

bsb_verse_text: Just then David’s soldiers and Joab returned from a raid, bringing with them a great plunder. But Abner was not with David in Hebron, because David had sent him on his way in peace.
ult_verse_text: And behold, the servants of David and Joab came from a raid, and they brought much plunder with them. But Abner, he {was} not with David in Hebron, for he had sent him away and he had gone in peace.

notes.note: The author is using this possessive form to mean not people who served both David and Joab but people who served David, including Joab. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [Joab and other servants of David]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אַבְנֵ֗ר אֵינֶ֤⁠נּוּ עִם־דָּוִד֙ בְּ⁠חֶבְר֔וֹן כִּ֥י שִׁלְּח֖⁠וֹ וַ⁠יֵּ֥לֶךְ בְּ⁠שָׁלֽוֹם
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [But since David had sent Abner away and he had gone in peace, he was not with David in Hebron]

bsb_verse_text: When Joab and all his troops arrived, he was informed, “Abner son of Ner came to see the king, who sent him on his way in peace.”
ult_verse_text: And Joab and all of the army that {was} with him came, and they declared to Joab, saying, “Abner, the son of Ner, came to the king, and he sent him away, and he went in peace.”

notes.note: Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and Joab was told]

bsb_verse_text: So Joab went to the king and said, “What have you done? Look, Abner came to you. Why did you dismiss him? Now he is getting away!
ult_verse_text: And Joab came to the king, and he said, “What have you done? Behold, Abner came to you! Why {is} this, you have sent him away, and going, he has gone?

notes.note: Joab is using the question form to challenge David for letting Abner go. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You have done something that you should not have done!]

Joab is using the question form to express his strong disapproval of David letting Abner go. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [There was no good reason to send him away, so that going, he has gone!]

Joab is repeating forms of the verb “go” in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [and he has completely gone]

bsb_verse_text: Surely you realize that Abner son of Ner came to deceive you and to track your movements and all that you are doing.”
ult_verse_text: You know Abner, the son of Ner, that he came to deceive you and to know your going out and your coming in and to know all that you are doing!”

notes.note: Joab is speaking of the first and last actions of a military campaign, **going out** and **coming in**, in order to mean military activities as a whole. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the same expression in [1 Samuel 29:6](../../1sa/29/06.md). Alternate translation: [and to find out about how you conduct your military campaigns]

Joab speaks in the present tense to David of things **you are doing** in order to describe actions that David has not yet done but that Joab believes he is planning to do. Use the verb form in your language that is natural for referring to planned future actions. Alternate translation: [and to find out everything that you are planning to do]

bsb_verse_text: When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab pulled him aside into the gateway, as if to speak to him privately, and there Joab stabbed him in the stomach. So Abner died on account of the blood of Joab’s brother Asahel.
ult_verse_text: And Abner returned {to} Hebron, and Joab turned him aside to the middle of the gate to speak with him in quiet. And he struck him there {in} the stomach, and he died, for the blood of Asahel his brother.

notes.note: The author assumes that his readers will know that by **the middle of the gate**, he is referring to an area within the city wall between the openings that led out of the city and into the city. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. The UST models one way to do that.
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **quiet**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [quietly]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יַּכֵּ֤⁠הוּ שָׁם֙ הַ⁠חֹ֔מֶשׁ וַ⁠יָּ֕מָת בְּ⁠דַ֖ם עֲשָׂה־אֵ֥ל אָחִֽי⁠ו
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about why Joab killed Abner before the information about how he did it. Alternate translation: [And for the blood of Asahel his brother, he struck him there in the stomach, and he died]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יַּכֵּ֤⁠הוּ שָׁם֙ הַ⁠חֹ֔מֶשׁ וַ⁠יָּ֕מָת בְּ⁠דַ֖ם עֲשָׂה־אֵ֥ל אָחִֽי⁠ו
notes.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Joab, while the pronoun **him** refers to Abner. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And for the blood of Asahel his brother, Joab struck Abner there in the stomach, and Abner died]

Here, **blood** represents the killing of Asahel for which Joab wanted to take revenge. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [to avenge the death of Asahel his brother]

bsb_verse_text: Afterward, David heard about this and said, “I and my kingdom are forever guiltless before the LORD concerning the blood of Abner son of Ner.
ult_verse_text: And David heard after this, and he said, “I and my kingdom {are} innocent from with Yahweh forever from the blood of Abner, the son of Ner.

notes.note: The implication is that David is referring not just to his current reign but to the continuing rule of his descendants. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and my royal dynasty]

Here, **blood** represents the killing of Abner. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [regarding the death of Abner]

The word **blood** is plural here because it refers to blood shed by violence. Your language may use the plural form of its word for blood to mean the same thing. If not, you could express the meaning in another way. Alternate translation: [of the bloodshed against Abner]

bsb_verse_text: May it whirl over the head of Joab and over the entire house of his father, and may the house of Joab never be without one having a discharge or skin disease, or one who leans on a staff or falls by the sword or lacks food.”
ult_verse_text: May it writhe on the head of Joab and to all of the house of his father, and may not be cut off from the house of Joab one discharging or one stricken with leprosy or one holding onto a staff or one falling by the sword or a destitute of bread.”

notes.orig_language_quote: יָחֻ֨לוּ֙ עַל־רֹ֣אשׁ יוֹאָ֔ב וְ⁠אֶ֖ל כָּל־בֵּ֣ית אָבִ֑י⁠ו
notes.note: The word **it** refers back to “the blood of Abner” in the previous verse. If you translated “blood” with a plural form there, it may be natural for you to use a plural pronoun here. You could also state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [May Abner’s blood writhe on the head of Joab and to all of the house of his father]

notes.orig_language_quote: יָחֻ֨לוּ֙ עַל־רֹ֣אשׁ יוֹאָ֔ב וְ⁠אֶ֖ל כָּל־בֵּ֣ית אָבִ֑י⁠ו
notes.note: David is using the same common expression here that he used in [1:16](../01/16.md), about blood being on someone’s **head**, to mean that a person was morally and legally responsible for something and would be punished for it. Here he uses a more vivid form of the expression and wishes that the blood of Abner would **writhe** on Joab’s head. This represents the sufferings of Joab and his extended family that David describes in the rest of the verse. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [May Joab and all of the house of his father painfully bear the responsibility for it]

The expression **the house of his father** refers to Joab’s extended family and descendants. Your language may have its own term or expression for such a group of related people. Alternate translation: [his extended family]

The expression **be cut off** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and may not be missing from the house of Joab] or [may there always be in the house of Joab]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [among the descendants of Joab]

The expression **stricken with leprosy** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [or a leper]

This expression could describe: (1) a person who, because of injury or illness, needs to use a staff to support himself when standing or walking. Alternate translation: [or a lame person]; (2) a man who, because of injury or weakness, cannot do strenuous work or fight in battles and so must do domestic work such as using a distaff (spindle) to wind wool into thread. Alternate translation: [or a weak man]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [or one dying in battle]

David is using the adjective **destitute** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [or someone who lacks bread]

David is using **bread** to represent all food or basic necessities. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [or someone who lacks food] or [someone who is desperately poor]

bsb_verse_text: (Joab and his brother Abishai murdered Abner because he had killed their brother Asahel in the battle at Gibeon.)
ult_verse_text: Now Joab and Abishai his brother had murdered Abner because he had killed Asahel their brother at Gibeon in the battle.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠יוֹאָב֙ וַ⁠אֲבִישַׁ֣י אָחִ֔י⁠ו הָרְג֖וּ לְ⁠אַבְנֵ֑ר עַל֩ אֲשֶׁ֨ר הֵמִ֜ית אֶת־עֲשָׂהאֵ֧ל אֲחִי⁠הֶ֛ם בְּ⁠גִבְע֖וֹן בַּ⁠מִּלְחָמָֽה
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand why David so greatly disapproved of what Joab had done. The author is contrasting the way Abner **killed** Asahel in battle (as he described in [2:23](../02/23.md)) with the way Joab and Abishai **murdered** Abner treacherously under peaceful conditions. If your language has different words for killing and murdering, it would be appropriate to use them here in your translation to show this contrast.

bsb_verse_text: Then David ordered Joab and all the people with him, “Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourn before Abner.” And King David himself walked behind the funeral bier.
ult_verse_text: And David said to Joab and to all of the people who {were} with him, “Tear your clothes and put on sackcloth and mourn to the face of Abner.” And King David was walking behind the bier.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [the soldiers]

Tearing one’s **clothes** and wearing **sackcloth** were symbolic actions that showed intense grief and mourning in ancient Israelite culture. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of these actions in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [show your grief by tearing your clothes and wearing rough cloth]

Here David speaks of **Abner** to mean Abner’s body. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and walk in procession as mourners ahead of Abner’s body]

Here, **walking behind the bier** was a symbolic action by which David showed public respect for Abner and demonstrated that he had not been responsible for Abner’s death. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [King David himself followed the funeral procession to show his respect]

A **bier** is a kind of platform or frame used to carry a dead body to burial. If your readers would not be familiar with what a bier is, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [the stretcher carrying Abner’s body]

bsb_verse_text: When they buried Abner in Hebron, the king wept aloud at Abner’s tomb, and all the people wept.
ult_verse_text: And they buried Abner in Hebron. And the king lifted up his voice and wept at the grave of Abner, and all of the people wept.

notes.note: Here, the author is speaking as if **voice** were an object that could be lifted up. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And the king raised the volume of his voice and wept]

The phrase **lifted up his voice and wept** expresses a single idea. The words **lifted up his voice** describe in what way David **wept**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [And the king wept loudly]

bsb_verse_text: And the king sang this lament for Abner: “Should Abner die the death of a fool?
ult_verse_text: And the king lamented for Abner, and he said, “Should Abner have died like the death of a fool?

notes.note: David is using the question form to emphasize how wrong it was for Abner to have died the way he did. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Abner should not have died like the death of a fool!]

The implication is that Abner died in an unjust and dishonorable way, as if he were a criminal deserving death, when in fact he was not. You could indicate this if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [Abner should not have been executed as if he had been a wicked person!]

bsb_verse_text: Your hands were not bound, your feet were not fettered. As a man falls before the wicked, so also you fell.” And all the people wept over him even more.
ult_verse_text: Your hands were not bound, and your feet were not put in shackles. As falling to the face of sons of wickedness, you have fallen.”

notes.orig_language_quote: יָדֶ֣⁠ךָ לֹֽא־אֲסֻר֗וֹת וְ⁠רַגְלֶ֨י⁠ךָ֙ לֹא־לִ⁠נְחֻשְׁתַּ֣יִם הֻגָּ֔שׁוּ כִּ⁠נְפ֛וֹל לִ⁠פְנֵ֥י בְנֵֽי־עַוְלָ֖ה נָפָ֑לְתָּ
notes.note: David is speaking to Abner, who is dead and cannot hear him. He is doing this to communicate to the people listening to him that he feels very strongly about how Abner was treacherously murdered. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate these words as if he were speaking directly to the people about Abner. Alternate translation: [His hands were not bound, and his feet were not put in shackles. He died like someone murdered by wicked men]

Here, bound **hands** and shackled **feet** represent being held as a prisoner. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [You were not being held as a prisoner because you had been convicted of a crime]
See how you translated the expression similar to **falling** and **fallen** in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [As dying to the face of sons of wickedness, you have died]

See how you translated the expression similar to **to the face of** in [2:17](../02/17.md). Alternate translation: [As dying at the hands of sons of wickedness, you have died] or [You died because sons of wickedness killed you]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:7](../02/07.md). Alternate translation: [wicked men]
This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: [wept for him even more]; (2) Alternate translation: [wept for him again]

bsb_verse_text: Then all the people came and urged David to eat something while it was still day, but David took an oath, saying, “May God punish me, and ever so severely, if I taste bread or anything else before the sun sets!”
ult_verse_text: Then all of the people came to make David eat bread while {it was} still day, but David swore, saying, “Thus may God do to me, and thus may he add, that if to the face of the coming in of the sun I taste bread or any of a thing.”

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יָּבֹ֣א כָל־הָ⁠עָ֗ם לְ⁠הַבְר֧וֹת אֶת־דָּוִ֛ד לֶ֖חֶם בְּ⁠ע֣וֹד הַ⁠יּ֑וֹם
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about when this happened before the information about the people coming to David. Alternate translation: [Then, while it was still day, all of the people came to make David eat bread]

The author says **all of the people** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [Then the others in attendance came with concern]

The author is using **bread** to represent food in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [food] or [a meal]

notes.orig_language_quote: כֹּ֣ה יַעֲשֶׂה־לִּ֤⁠י אֱלֹהִים֙ וְ⁠כֹ֣ה יֹסִ֔יף כִּ֣י אִם־לִ⁠פְנֵ֧י בֽוֹא־הַ⁠שֶּׁ֛מֶשׁ אֶטְעַם־לֶ֖חֶם א֥וֹ כָל־מְאֽוּמָה
notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:9](../03/09.md). Alternate translation: [If I taste bread or any of a thing to the face of the coming in of the sun, then may God do thus to me, and thus may he add]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:9](../03/09.md). Alternate translation: [Thus may God do to me, and may he do even worse]

The word **Thus**: (1) could refer to the way Abner died a violent death. Alternate translation: [May God make me suffer a violent death, as Abner did, and even worse]; (2) could be a general expression introducing the entire statement as a reference to severe punishment. Alternate translation: [May God punish me very severely]

David not eating bread or anything else until sunset, not even a small taste, was a symbolic action that showed deep mourning and grief in ancient Israelite culture. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [if I fail to show proper morning by even tasting any food before sunset]
Here, **face** represents “before.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [before the coming in of the sun]

David is using **the coming in of the sun** as a common expression of his culture to mean “sunset.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [before the sun goes down] or [before sunset]

bsb_verse_text: All the people took note and were pleased. In fact, everything the king did pleased them.
ult_verse_text: And all of the people noticed, and it was good in their eyes, as everything that the king did was good in the eyes of all of the people.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:35](../03/35.md). Alternate translation: [And the others in attendance noticed]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [and they felt that he had done the right thing]

notes.orig_language_quote: כְּ⁠כֹל֙ אֲשֶׁ֣ר עָשָׂ֣ה הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ בְּ⁠עֵינֵ֥י כָל־הָ⁠עָ֖ם טֽוֹב
notes.note: The author says **everything that the king did was good in the eyes of all of the people** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [just as the people of Judah generally felt that David, their king, was doing the right things]

bsb_verse_text: Then the king said to his servants, “Do you not realize that a great prince has fallen today in Israel?
ult_verse_text: And the king said to his servants, “Do you not know that a commander and great has fallen this day in Israel?

notes.orig_language_quote: הֲ⁠ל֣וֹא תֵדְע֔וּ כִּי־שַׂ֣ר וְ⁠גָד֗וֹל נָפַ֛ל הַ⁠יּ֥וֹם הַ⁠זֶּ֖ה בְּ⁠יִשְׂרָאֵֽל
notes.note: David is using the question form for emphasis when he makes a strong statement that his people should recognize Abner’s importance. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You must appreciate that a commander and great has fallen this day in Israel!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:1](../03/01.md). Alternate translation: [a great commander]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [has died]
David is using the term **this day** to refer to a specific time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [at this time]

bsb_verse_text: And I am weak this day, though anointed as king, and these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too fierce for me. May the LORD repay the evildoer according to his evil!”
ult_verse_text: And I {am} weak today, though anointed king. For these men, the sons of Zeruiah, {are} more harsh than I. May Yahweh repay the one doing evil according to his evil.”

notes.note: The expression **anointed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [even though Yahweh has anointed me to be the king]

bsb_verse_text: Now when Ish-bosheth son of Saul heard that Abner had died in Hebron, he lost courage, and all Israel was dismayed.
ult_verse_text: And the son of Saul heard that Abner had died in Hebron, and his hands dropped, and all of Israel was terrified.

notes.note: The author is reporting that Ishbosheth’s **hands dropped** in order to indicate that he lost his strength and courage. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and he became weak with fear]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:28](../02/28.md). Alternate translation: [and all the people of Israel]

The expression **was terrified** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [became very afraid]

bsb_verse_text: Saul’s son had two men who were leaders of raiding parties. One was named Baanah and the other Rechab; they were sons of Rimmon the Beerothite of the tribe of Benjamin—Beeroth is considered part of Benjamin,
ult_verse_text: Now two men, commanders of troops, were {to} the son of Saul. The name of the one {was} Baanah, and the name of the second {was} Rechab, sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, from the sons of Benjamin, for Beeroth is also reckoned to Benjamin.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠שְׁנֵ֣י אֲנָשִׁ֣ים שָׂרֵֽי־גְדוּדִ֣ים הָי֪וּ בֶן־שָׁא֟וּל שֵׁם֩ הָ⁠אֶחָ֨ד בַּֽעֲנָ֜ה וְ⁠שֵׁ֧ם הַ⁠שֵּׁנִ֣י רֵכָ֗ב בְּנֵ֛י רִמּ֥וֹן הַ⁠בְּאֶֽרֹתִ֖י מִ⁠בְּנֵ֣י בִנְיָמִ֑ן
notes.note: Here the author is introducing **Baanah and Rechab** as new participants in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Among Ishbosheth’s officers were two men named Baanah and Rechab. They were sons of Rimmon from the town of Beeroth in the territory of Benjamin]

notes.orig_language_quote: בְּנֵ֛י רִמּ֥וֹן הַ⁠בְּאֶֽרֹתִ֖י מִ⁠בְּנֵ֣י בִנְיָמִ֑ן כִּ֚י גַּם־בְּאֵר֔וֹת תֵּחָשֵׁ֖ב עַל־בִּנְיָמִֽן
notes.note: See the discussion of this statement in the Introduction to this chapter. Alternate translation: [While they were the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, since the city of Beeroth is within the territory of the tribe of Benjamin, they were considered to be members of the tribe of Benjamin]

The expression **is reckoned** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [for people also reckon Beeroth to Benjamin]

bsb_verse_text: because the Beerothites fled to Gittaim and have lived there as foreigners to this day.
ult_verse_text: (But the Beerothites had fled to Gittaim, and they have been sojourning there to this day.)

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּבְרְח֥וּ הַ⁠בְּאֵרֹתִ֖ים גִּתָּ֑יְמָ⁠ה וַֽ⁠יִּהְיוּ־שָׁ֣ם גָּרִ֔ים עַ֖ד הַ⁠יּ֥וֹם הַ⁠זֶּֽה
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture. See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of why the author may provide this information.

See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. The author is using this phrase to refer to the time when he was writing. In your translation, make clear that the phrase refers to a time that is already past. Avoid giving the impression the phrase means “to the present day.” Alternate translation: [right up to the time of this writing]

bsb_verse_text: And Jonathan son of Saul had a son who was lame in his feet. He was five years old when the report about Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel. His nurse picked him up and fled, but as she was hurrying to escape, he fell and became lame. His name was Mephibosheth.
ult_verse_text: Now to Jonathan, the son of Saul, {was} a son, lame of feet. He was a son of five years when the report of Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel. And his nurse picked him up and fled. And it happened, when she hurried to flee, that he fell and became lame. And his name {was} Mephibosheth.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:10](../02/10.md). Alternate translation: [He was five years of age]

The author is speaking of **the report** as if it were a living thing that could have come from a place. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [when people came from Jezreel and reported about Saul and Jonathan]

bsb_verse_text: Now Rechab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, set out and arrived at the house of Ish-bosheth in the heat of the day, while the king was taking his midday nap.
ult_verse_text: And the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, Rechab and Baanah, went, and they came about the heat of the day to the house of Ishbosheth, and he was lying {on} the bed of noon.

notes.note: The phrase **bed of noon** describes a special bed or couch on which someone would rest or sleep during the midday rest period that was common in this region where the middle of the day would be very hot. If your readers would not be familiar with this custom, you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [was resting during the heat of midday] or [was taking his midday nap]

bsb_verse_text: They entered the interior of the house as if to get some wheat, and they stabbed him in the stomach. Then Rechab and his brother Baanah slipped away.
ult_verse_text: And behold, they came to the midst of the house, takers of wheat, and they struck him in the stomach. And Rechab and Baanah his brother escaped.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ֠⁠הֵנָּה בָּ֜אוּ עַד־תּ֤וֹךְ הַ⁠בַּ֨יִת֙ לֹקְחֵ֣י חִטִּ֔ים וַ⁠יַּכֻּ֖⁠הוּ אֶל־הַ⁠חֹ֑מֶשׁ וְ⁠רֵכָ֛ב וּ⁠בַעֲנָ֥ה אָחִ֖י⁠ו נִמְלָֽטוּ
notes.note: Following the conventions of Hebrew storytelling, the author gives a general summary of these events in this verse and then describes them in more specific detail in the next verse. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could create a verse bridge for [verses 6–7](../04/06.md) and relate these events only once. The UST models one way to do that.
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [Then suddenly]

bsb_verse_text: They brought the head of Ish-bosheth to David at Hebron and said to the king, “Here is the head of Ish-bosheth son of Saul, your enemy who sought your life. Today the LORD has granted vengeance to my lord the king against Saul and his offspring.”
ult_verse_text: And they brought the head of Ishbosheth to David {at} Hebron, and they said to the king, “Behold, the head of Ishbosheth, the son of Saul, your enemy who sought your life. Now Yahweh has given to my lord the king vengeance this day against Saul and against his seed.”

notes.note: Rechab and Baanah are using this phrase to describe Saul, not Ishbosheth. You may be able to use punctuation or some other convention of your language to make this clear.

By saying that Saul sought David’s **life**, Rechab and Baanah mean that Saul sought to take his life, that is, to kill him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [to murder you]

One of the sons of Rimmon is addressing David, so he calls him **my** lord, but since he is speaking on behalf of both of them, it may be more natural in your language to use a plural pronoun. Alternate translation: [to our lord the king]

Even though the sons of Rimmon are addressing David directly, one of them is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [to you, my lord the king] or [to you, our lord the king]

The speaker is speaking here of descendants as if they were **seed**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and against his descendants]

bsb_verse_text: But David answered Rechab and his brother Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, “As surely as the LORD lives, who has redeemed my life from all distress,
ult_verse_text: But David answered Rechab and Baanah his brother, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, and he said to them, “The life of Yahweh, who rescued my life from every distress,

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יַּ֨עַן דָּוִ֜ד אֶת־רֵכָ֣ב ׀ וְ⁠אֶת־בַּעֲנָ֣ה אָחִ֗י⁠ו בְּנֵ֛י רִמּ֥וֹן הַ⁠בְּאֵֽרֹתִ֖י וַ⁠יֹּ֣אמֶר לָ⁠הֶ֑ם
notes.note: The expression **and he said to them** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly. Alternate translation: [But David responded to Rechab and Baanah his brother, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite]

Following the custom of his culture, David is swearing an oath by guaranteeing it by something he holds sacred. David is using this oath to swear that what he says in the next verse is true. Use a natural way in your language to express an oath.

bsb_verse_text: when someone told me, ‘Look, Saul is dead,’ and thought he was a bearer of good news, I seized him and put him to death at Ziklag. That was his reward for his news!
ult_verse_text: that the one declaring to me, saying, ‘Behold, Saul is dead,’ and in his eyes he was like a bringer of {good} news, that I seized him, and I killed him at Ziklag, which {was} me giving him a reward for good news.

notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [the one who declared to me that Saul was dead]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [and he thought that he was bringing good news]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:15](../01/15.md). Alternate translation: [that I had one of my soldiers seize him and kill him]

In this figure of speech, David actually means to communicate the opposite of the literal meaning of his words. (By saying that he gave him **a reward for good news**, he means that he killed the messenger for bringing what the messenger wrongly thought was good news.) If a speaker of your language would not say the opposite of what he meant, you could translate the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [which was how I punished him for telling me that he had killed Saul as if that had been good news]

bsb_verse_text: How much more, when wicked men kill a righteous man in his own house and on his own bed, shall I not now require his blood from your hands and remove you from the earth!”
ult_verse_text: How much more, when men of wickedness have murdered a man of righteousness in his house on his bed! And now, shall I not seek his blood from your hand and consume you from the earth?”

notes.note: David is using this expression to convey a strong feeling, his conviction that the crime of Rechab and Baanah is much greater than the crime of the person who told him that Saul was dead. There may be an equivalent word or phrase in your language that you can use in your translation to convey this feeling.

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [How much more would I punish rather than reward]

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **wickedness** and **righteousness**, you could express the same ideas in other ways. Alternate translation: [wicked men … a righteous man]

**And now** was an expression that speakers in this culture commonly used to introduce their main topic. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

notes.orig_language_quote: הֲ⁠ל֨וֹא אֲבַקֵּ֤שׁ אֶת־דָּמ⁠וֹ֙ מִ⁠יֶּדְ⁠כֶ֔ם וּ⁠בִעַרְתִּ֥י אֶתְ⁠כֶ֖ם מִן־הָ⁠אָֽרֶץ
notes.note: David is using the question form to emphasize that he will certainly punish Rechab and Baanah for killing Ishbosheth. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I should certainly seek his blood from your hand and consume you from the earth!]

David is using **seek his blood from your hand** as a common expression of his culture to mean “punish you for killing him.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [should I not punish you for killing him]

Here, David is speaking as if he would **consume** the murderers as fire consumes something completely. This image emphasizes total destruction. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and completely destroy you]

bsb_verse_text: So David commanded his young men, and they killed Rechab and Baanah. They cut off their hands and feet and hung their bodies by the pool in Hebron, but they took the head of Ish-bosheth and buried it in Abner’s tomb in Hebron.
ult_verse_text: And David commanded the young men, and they killed them, and they cut off their hands and their feet, and they hung {them} beside the pool in Hebron. But the head of Ishbosheth, they took and buried in the grave of Abner in Hebron.

notes.note: This could mean: (1) that David’s soldiers hung up the **hands** and **feet** of Rechab and Baanah beside the pool. This would have been a symbolic action, exposing to disgrace in a public location the hands that these men had used to murder Ishbosheth and the feet that they had used to flee with his head. By this action, David would have been repudiating their deed and warning others against doing anything similar. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [and they hung their murderous hands and fugitive feet in disgrace beside the pool in Hebron]; (2) that David’s soldiers hung the bodies of Rechab and Baanah beside the pool. This too would have disgraced them as murderers, repudiated their deed, and warned others. However, it would have been a violation of [Deuteronomy 21:23](../../deu/21/23.md), which required the Israelites to bury the body of an executed person on the same day on which he was executed. So this is less likely. Alternate translation: [and they hung their bodies in disgrace beside the pool in Hebron]

bsb_verse_text: Then all the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron and said, “Here we are, your own flesh and blood.
ult_verse_text: And all of the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron. And they spoke, saying, “Behold us, we {are} your bone and your flesh.

notes.note: The author is speaking of a whole, **all of the tribes of Israel**, to mean a part of that whole, representatives of the tribes who came to David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [representatives of all of the tribes of Israel]

The tribal representatives are using the courteous expression that people in this culture would use to tell a superior that they were ready and willing to obey his orders. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:7](../01/07.md).

Here, **we are your bone and your flesh** was a common expression that the tribal representatives were using to affirm to David that they were related by descent from a common ancestor. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [we are your blood relatives]

bsb_verse_text: Even in times past, while Saul was king over us, you were the one who led Israel out and brought them back. And to you the LORD said, ‘You will shepherd My people Israel, and you will be ruler over them.’”
ult_verse_text: Both yesterday and the third day, when Saul was king over us, you, you were the one bringing out and bringing in Israel. And Yahweh said to you, ‘You, you will shepherd my people Israel, and you, you will become the ruler over Israel.’”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:7](../03/07.md). Alternate translation: [In the past]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:25](../03/25.md). Alternate translation: [the one leading Israel on military campaigns]

Here the term **Israel** represents the Israelite soldiers whom David commanded. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the Israelite soldiers]

notes.orig_language_quote: אַתָּ֗ה הָיִ֛יתָ & אַתָּ֨ה תִרְעֶ֤ה & וְ⁠אַתָּ֛ה תִּהְיֶ֥ה
notes.note: The Israelite leaders are stating the pronoun **you** separately, even though the verb translated as **you were** already includes this meaning. They are doing that to emphasize David’s personal role in leading the Israelite army. When Yahweh spoke to David as they describe, he was stating the pronoun **you** separately in both of these instances, even though the verbs translated as **you will shepherd** and **you will become** already included this meaning, to emphasize that he was making promises to David. If speakers of your language would use explicit pronouns for these same purposes, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing the meanings here.  Alternate translation: [you personally were … I promise that you will shepherd … and I promise that you will become]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֹּ֨אמֶר יְהוָ֜ה לְ⁠ךָ֗ אַתָּ֨ה תִרְעֶ֤ה אֶת־עַמִּ⁠י֙ אֶת־יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל וְ⁠אַתָּ֛ה תִּהְיֶ֥ה לְ⁠נָגִ֖יד עַל־יִשְׂרָאֵֽל
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [And they reminded David that Yahweh had told him that he would shepherd the people of Israel and become their ruler]

notes.orig_language_quote: אַתָּ֨ה תִרְעֶ֤ה אֶת־עַמִּ⁠י֙ אֶת־יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל וְ⁠אַתָּ֛ה תִּהְיֶ֥ה לְ⁠נָגִ֖יד עַל־יִשְׂרָאֵֽל
notes.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. Hebrew poetry was based on this kind of repetition, and it would be good to show this to your readers by including both phrases in your translation rather than combining them. It may be clearer in your language to connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [You yourself will shepherd my people Israel, indeed, you yourself will become the ruler over Israel]

Yahweh is speaking here as if David would actually **shepherd** the people of Israel as though they were sheep. This image compares the way a shepherd cares for and guides his sheep to the way a king should care for and lead his people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [You yourself will care for and guide my people Israel]

bsb_verse_text: So all the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron, where King David made with them a covenant before the LORD. And they anointed him king over Israel.
ult_verse_text: Then all of the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron, and King David cut for them a covenant in Hebron to the face of Yahweh. And they anointed David as king over Israel.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [and King David made a covenant with them]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:13](../03/13.md). Alternate translation: [in the presence of Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: David was thirty years old when he became king, and he reigned forty years.
ult_verse_text: David {was} a son of 30 years when he became king. He reigned 40 years.

notes.orig_language_quote: בֶּן־שְׁלֹשִׁ֥ים שָׁנָ֛ה דָּוִ֖ד בְּ⁠מָלְכ֑⁠וֹ אַרְבָּעִ֥ים שָׁנָ֖ה מָלָֽךְ
notes.note: Here the author is reintroducing **David** as a participant in the story in his new role as king over all Israel. Your language may have its own way of reintroducing participants in new roles that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Now David was 30 years old when he began to reign as king, and he ruled for 40 years]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:10](../02/10.md). Alternate translation: [David was 30 years old]

bsb_verse_text: Now the king and his men marched to Jerusalem against the Jebusites who inhabited the land. The Jebusites said to David: “You will never get in here. Even the blind and lame can repel you.” For they thought, “David cannot get in here.”
ult_verse_text: And the king and his men went {to} Jerusalem, to the Jebusite, the dweller of the land. And he spoke to David, saying, “You will not come here, but surely the blind and the lame will turn you away,” saying, “David will not come here.”

notes.note: The author is not referring to a specific **Jebusites**. He means the Jebusites who lived in this fortified area in Jerusalem. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use expressions that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [to the Jebusites, the inhabitants of that area. And they spoke to David]

The Jebusites say **the blind and the lame will turn you away** as an extreme statement for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [our least capable soldiers will be able to keep you from capturing our city]

The Jebusites are using the adjectives **blind** and **lame** as nouns to mean people who cannot see and people who cannot walk well. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate these adjectives with equivalent phrases. Alternate translation: [people who are blind and people who cannot walk well]

In this instance, the author is using the term **saying** to introduce what the Jebusites were thinking or saying to themselves. They did not say this out loud to David. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing what people said to themselves or thought. Alternate translation: [thinking to themselves]

bsb_verse_text: Nevertheless, David captured the fortress of Zion (that is, the City of David).
ult_verse_text: But David captured the stronghold of Zion. (It {is} the City of David.)

notes.note: The author is providing background information to explain to readers that the fortified area that he calls **Zion** is the same area that they know as **the City of David**. In your translation, present this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

bsb_verse_text: On that day he said, “Whoever attacks the Jebusites must use the water shaft to reach the lame and blind who are despised by David.” That is why it is said, “The blind and the lame will never enter the palace.”
ult_verse_text: And David said on that day, “Anyone striking the Jebusite, then let him approach through the water shaft the lame and the blind, hated by the soul of David.” (Therefore they say, “The blind and the lame shall not come into the house.”)

notes.note: David is not referring to a specific **Jebusite**. He means all of the Jebusites who are living in this fortified area of Jerusalem and fighting to keep him out of it. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [these Jebusites]

David is using the adjectives **lame** and **blind** as nouns to mean people who cannot walk well and people who cannot see. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate these adjectives with equivalent phrases. Alternate translation: [people who cannot walk well and people who cannot see]

The expression **hated by the soul of David** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [whom David’s soul hates]

David is using **the soul of David** to represent David himself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [whom David hates]

In giving an official command to his soldiers, David is speaking about himself formally in the third person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in the first person. Alternate translation: [whom I hate]

notes.orig_language_quote: עַל־כֵּן֙ יֹֽאמְר֔וּ עִוֵּ֣ר וּ⁠פִסֵּ֔חַ לֹ֥א יָב֖וֹא אֶל־הַ⁠בָּֽיִת
notes.note: The author is providing the background information that David’s statement that he hated the lame and the blind was the origin of the popular saying that he quotes. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

The people using this popular saying are not referring to a specific **blind** or **lame** person. They mean blind and lame people in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [A blind person or a lame person]

Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [it came to be said] or [it became a saying]
In this saying, **the house** means the palace where the king lived. You could clarify this if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the palace]

bsb_verse_text: So David took up residence in the fortress and called it the City of David. He built it up all the way around, from the supporting terraces inward.
ult_verse_text: And David dwelled in the stronghold, and he called it the City of David. And David built around {it}, from the Millo and toward the house.

notes.note: The word **Millo** is the name of a place. (It was likely a raised platform or landfill that formed part of Jerusalem’s fortifications.)

bsb_verse_text: And David became greater and greater, for the LORD God of Hosts was with him.
ult_verse_text: And David went, going and becoming great, for Yahweh, the God of Armies, {was} with him.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֵּ֥לֶךְ דָּוִ֖ד הָל֣וֹךְ וְ⁠גָד֑וֹל וַ⁠יהוָ֛ה אֱלֹהֵ֥י צְבָא֖וֹת עִמּֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [And since Yahweh, the God of Armies, was with him, David went, going and becoming great]

The author is using **went, going and becoming great** as a common expression of his culture to mean “kept becoming greater and greater.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And David kept becoming greater and greater]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [was helping him]

bsb_verse_text: Now Hiram king of Tyre sent envoys to David, along with cedar logs, carpenters, and stonemasons, and they built a palace for David.
ult_verse_text: And Hiram, the king of Tyre, sent messengers to David, and trees of cedar and craftsmen of wood and craftsmen of stone of wall. And they built a house for David.

notes.note: The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and he also sent trees of cedar]
The pronoun **they** refers to the woodworkers and stonemasons whom Hiram sent. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And Hiram’s craftsmen built]

bsb_verse_text: And David realized that the LORD had established him as king over Israel and had exalted his kingdom for the sake of His people Israel.
ult_verse_text: Then David knew that Yahweh had established him as king over Israel and that he had lifted up his kingdom for the sake of his people Israel.

notes.note: Here the author is speaking of David’s **kingdom** as if it had been an object that could have been lifted up physically. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [he had made his kingdom prosperous and strong]

bsb_verse_text: After he had arrived from Hebron, David took more concubines and wives from Jerusalem, and more sons and daughters were born to him.
ult_verse_text: And David again took concubines and wives at Jerusalem after his coming from Hebron. And again sons and daughters were born to David.

notes.note: The expression **were born** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And they bore more sons and daughters to David]

bsb_verse_text: These are the names of the children born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
ult_verse_text: And these {are} the names of the ones born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua and Shobab and Nathan and Solomon

notes.note: The expression **born** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the sons he had]

bsb_verse_text: When the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over Israel, they all went in search of him; but David learned of this and went down to the stronghold.
ult_verse_text: And the Philistines heard that they had anointed David as king over Israel, and all of the Philistines went up to seek David. And David heard, and he went down to the stronghold.

notes.note: Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [David had been anointed] or [the leaders of the Israelites had anointed David]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:1](../02/01.md). Alternate translation: [and all of the Philistines went … and he went]

bsb_verse_text: So David inquired of the LORD, “Should I go up against the Philistines? Will You deliver them into my hand?” “Go up,” replied the LORD, “for I will surely deliver the Philistines into your hand.”
ult_verse_text: And David inquired of Yahweh, saying, “Shall I go up to the Philistines? Will you give them into my hand?”

notes.note: In keeping with what is usual in this language and culture, David and Yahweh are marking travel for change in elevation. If these expressions contain extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten them. Alternate translation: [Shall I attack the Philistines … Attack them]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:8](../03/08.md). Alternate translation: [into my power … into your power]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since giving, I will give the Philistines into your hand, go up]

Yahweh is repeating forms of the verb **give** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [I will certainly give]

bsb_verse_text: So David went to Baal-perazim, where he defeated the Philistines and said, “Like a bursting flood, the LORD has burst out against my enemies before me.” So he called that place Baal-perazim.
ult_verse_text: So David came {to} Baal Perazim, and David struck them there. And he said, “Yahweh has broken through my enemies to my face like the breach of waters.” Therefore he called the name of that place Baal Perazim.

notes.note: See the discussion of the term “struck” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. The meaning of that term here and in [verses 24](../05/24.md) and [25](../05/25.md) is “defeated.” Alternate translation: [and David defeated them]

Here, **face** represents opposing or being in front. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [who were in front of me] or [who were opposing me]

The point of this comparison is that just as a ** breach of waters** is powerful and overwhelming, so was Yahweh’s defeat of David’s enemies. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [as powerfully as a rushing flood]

It might seem that the expression **called the name of** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [he called that place]
The name **Baal Perazim** means “the Lord of Breakthroughs.” If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain this in the text of your translation or in a footnote.

bsb_verse_text: There the Philistines abandoned their idols, and David and his men carried them away.
ult_verse_text: And they abandoned their idols there, and David and his men took them away.
