notes.note: The pronoun **they** refers to the Philistines who were fleeing from David’s army. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And the Philistines abandoned]

Taking away the Philistines’ idols was a symbolic action that illustrated the character of David’s victory over the Philistines and their gods. The Philistines had brought these idols into battle with them in the hopes that the gods they represented would help them defeat David and the Israelites. Instead, the gods themselves were shown to be helpless. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and David and his men carried off their idols to show how weak and helpless the Philistine gods were compared to Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: Once again the Philistines came up and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
ult_verse_text: And the Philistines resumed again to go up, and they spread themselves out in the Valley of the Raphaites.

notes.note: In keeping with what is usual for his language and culture, the author is marking travel for change in elevation. He is also saying **resumed again**. If these expressions contain extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten them. Alternate translation: [And the Philistines invaded again]

bsb_verse_text: So David inquired of the LORD, who answered, “Do not march straight up, but circle around behind them and attack them in front of the balsam trees.
ult_verse_text: And David inquired of Yahweh, and he said, “You shall not go up. Go around to behind them, and you shall come to them from opposite the balsam trees.

notes.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Yahweh. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [and Yahweh said]

While David would have had to move to a higher elevation in order to engage the Philistines, in this context, by telling him not to **go up**, Yahweh means that he should not make a direct, frontal attack. If this phrase would not have that meaning in your language in this context, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Do not make a frontal attack]

bsb_verse_text: As soon as you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, move quickly, because this will mean that the LORD has gone out before you to strike the camp of the Philistines.”
ult_verse_text: And it will be, when you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, then you shall act determinedly, for then Yahweh will go out to your face to strike the camp of the Philistines.”

notes.note: Here, **face** represents what is ahead of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in advance of you]

Here, **camp** represents the army that has camped in a place. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the army of the Philistines]

bsb_verse_text: So David did as the LORD had commanded him, and he struck down the Philistines all the way from Gibeon to Gezer.
ult_verse_text: And David did thus, just as Yahweh commanded him. And he struck the Philistines from Geba to your coming {to} Gezer.

notes.note: The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible) and the parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 14:16](../../1ch/14/16.md) read “Gibeon” instead of **Geba**. That may have been the original reading, particularly since the location of Gibeon suits the account of this battle better than the location of Geba. At one point in the process of transmission, scribes may have left out the additional letters that would have spelled “Gibeon” rather than “Geba,” either accidentally or as a way of abbreviating. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

bsb_verse_text: David again assembled the chosen men of Israel, thirty thousand in all.
ult_verse_text: And David again gathered all of the chosen in Israel, 30, 000.

notes.note: The author is using the adjective **chosen** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the select warriors] or [the elite troops]

bsb_verse_text: And he and all his troops set out for Baale of Judah to bring up from there the ark of God, which is called by the Name—the name of the LORD of Hosts, who is enthroned between the cherubim that are on it.
ult_verse_text: And David arose and went, and all of the people who {were} with him, from Baalah of Judah to bring up from there the Box of God, whose name is called {by} the name of Yahweh of Armies, dweller of the cherubim upon it.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [And David took action]

The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 13:6](../../1ch/13/06.md) explains that **Baalah** was another name for Kiriath Jearim. That was where the Box had remained since the Philistines returned it after capturing it, according to [1 Samuel 7:2](../../1sa/07/02.md). If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain this in the text of your translation or in a footnote.

In keeping with what is usual for his language and culture, the author is marking travel for change in elevation. If this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [to bring]

The expression **whose name is called** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [which people call]

bsb_verse_text: They set the ark of God on a new cart and brought it from the house of Abinadab, which was on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, were guiding the new cart,
ult_verse_text: And they mounted the Box of God on a new cart, and they bore it from the house of Abinadab, which {was} on the hill. And Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, were guiding the new cart.

notes.note: The author assumes that his readers will know that by **on the hill**, he means a certain hill within the city of Baalah, that is, Kiriath Jearim. Since modern readers would not recognize the identity of this hill, it may be more natural to speak of it in general terms. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 7:1](../../1sa/07/01.md). Alternate translation: [which was on a hill]

The author is speaking of the **new cart** to mean the oxen that were pulling the cart. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the oxen that were pulling the new cart]

bsb_verse_text: bringing with it the ark of God. And Ahio was walking in front of the ark.
ult_verse_text: And they bore it from the house of Abinadab, which {was} on the hill, with the Box of God, and Ahio was walking to the face of the Box.

notes.note: The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible) and the parallel passage in 1 Chronicles do not have this sentence, which seems to have been repeated accidentally from the previous verse. Without it, the text of [verses 3–4](../06/03.md) would sensibly read, “And Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, were leading the new cart with the Box of God” (that is, the new cart that had the Box of God on it). Many versions of the Bible do not include this sentence. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to omit the sentence if it does.

The author assumes that his readers will know that Ahio and Uzzah were following the custom of this culture for steadying a load on a cart that animals were pulling. One person would walk ahead of the cart, leading and guiding the animals, while another person would walk next to the cart to make sure that the load did not fall off. By saying that **Ahio was walking to the face of the Box**, he also means that Uzzah was walking alongside the cart that was carrying it, as the story itself indicates in [6:6](../06/06.md). You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. The UST models one way to do that.
Here, **to the face of** represents “in front of.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of]

Here, **the Box** represents the oxen that were pulling the cart that was carrying the Box. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the oxen that were pulling the cart that was carrying the Box]

bsb_verse_text: David and all the house of Israel were celebrating before the LORD with all kinds of wood instruments, harps, stringed instruments, tambourines, sistrums, and cymbals.
ult_verse_text: And David and all of the house of Israel were celebrating to the face of Yahweh with all woods of cypress and with lyres and with harps and with tambourines and with sistrums and with cymbals.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [and all of the people of Israel]

The author says **and all of the house of Israel** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [and people from throughout Israel]

Here, **face** represents “presence.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:13](../03/13.md). Alternate translation: [in the presence of Yahweh]

The expression **all woods of cypress** means various musical instruments made from cypress wood.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [with various musical instruments made from cypress wood]

A **tambourine** is a kind of hand-held drum with metal discs around its frame that jingle when people shake or strike the drum. If your readers would not be familiar with what a tambourine is, you could use the name of a similar instrument that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [and with hand drums] or [and with jingling drums]

A **sistrum** is a kind of musical instrument consisting of a handle and a U-shaped metal frame with loose metal crossbars that jingle when people shake the frame. If your readers would not be familiar with what a sistrum is, you could use the name of a similar instrument that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [and with rattles] or [and with shaking instruments]

A **cymbal** is a kind of musical instrument made of two metal discs that people strike together to make a loud, ringing sound. If your readers would not be familiar with what a cymbal is, you could use the name of a similar instrument that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [and with clashing metal discs] or [and with metal percussion instruments]

bsb_verse_text: When they came to the threshing floor of Nacon, Uzzah reached out and took hold of the ark of God, because the oxen had stumbled.
ult_verse_text: And they came to the threshing floor of Nacon, and Uzzah reached out to the Box of God and held it, for the oxen stumbled.

notes.note: The word **Nacon** is the name of the place where this threshing floor was located.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּשְׁלַ֨ח עֻזָּ֜א אֶל־אֲר֤וֹן הָֽ⁠אֱלֹהִים֙ וַ⁠יֹּ֣אחֶז בּ֔⁠וֹ כִּ֥י שָׁמְט֖וּ הַ⁠בָּקָֽר
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [and because the oxen stumbled, Uzzah reached out to the Box of God and held it]

bsb_verse_text: And the anger of the LORD burned against Uzzah, and God struck him down on the spot for his irreverence, and he died there beside the ark of God.
ult_verse_text: And the nose of Yahweh burned against Uzzah, and God struck him there for the fault. And he died there by the Box of God.

notes.note: The author is describing Yahweh becoming extremely angry by alluding to the way a person’s **nose** may become hot and red when he is angry. Your culture may also associate anger with heat or with a particular part of the body, and if so, you could use its characteristic expression in your translation. You could also use plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:8](../03/08.md). Alternate translation: [And Yahweh blazed with fury] or [And Yahweh became extremely angry]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:1](../01/01.md). Alternate translation: [and God killed him]

bsb_verse_text: Then David became angry because the LORD had burst forth against Uzzah. So he named that place Perez-uzzah, as it is called to this day.
ult_verse_text: And it burned to David because Yahweh had broken out an outbreak against Uzzah. And he called that place Perez Uzzah, to this day.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּ֣חַר לְ⁠דָוִ֔ד עַל֩ אֲשֶׁ֨ר פָּרַ֧ץ יְהוָ֛ה פֶּ֖רֶץ בְּ⁠עֻזָּ֑ה
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [And because Yahweh had broken out an outbreak against Uzzah, it burned to David]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:8](../03/08.md). Alternate translation: [And David became angry]

It might seem that the expression **Yahweh had broken out an outbreak** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [Yahweh had broken out]
The name **Perez Uzzah** means “Outbreak against Uzzah.” If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain this in the text of your translation or in a footnote.

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and that is still its name to this day]
See how you translated the similar expression in [4:3](../04/03.md). Alternate translation: [as of the time of this writing]

bsb_verse_text: That day David feared the LORD and asked, “How can the ark of the LORD ever come to me?”
ult_verse_text: And David feared Yahweh on that day, and he said, “How shall the Box of Yahweh come to me?”

notes.note: David is using the question form to express his concern about trying bring the Box of Yahweh to where he lives. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I should not dare to try to bring the Box of Yahweh to me!]

bsb_verse_text: So he was unwilling to move the ark of the LORD to the City of David; instead, he took it aside to the house of Obed-edom the Gittite.
ult_verse_text: And David was not willing to bring to himself the Box of Yahweh to the City of David. So David turned it aside {to} the house of Obed Edom the Gittite.

notes.note: Here the author is introducing **Obed Edom** as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [a certain man named Obed Edom who came from Gath]

bsb_verse_text: Thus the ark of the LORD remained in the house of Obed-edom the Gittite for three months, and the LORD blessed him and all his household.
ult_verse_text: And the Box of Yahweh remained {in} the house of Obed Edom the Gittite three months. And Yahweh blessed Obed Edom and all of his house.

notes.note: The author is using the term **house** by association to mean the people who lived in the same house with a man. He means the people in that man’s household. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:3](../02/03.md). Alternate translation: [and his entire household]

bsb_verse_text: Now it was reported to King David, “The LORD has blessed the house of Obed-edom and all that belongs to him, because of the ark of God.” So David went and had the ark of God brought up from the house of Obed-edom into the City of David with rejoicing.
ult_verse_text: And it was declared to King David, saying, “Yahweh has blessed the house of Obed Edom and all who {are} to him for the sake of the Box of God.” So David went, and he brought up the Box of God from the house of Obed Edom {to} the City of David with joy.

notes.note: The expression **it was declared** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And someone declared]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:1](../02/01.md). Alternate translation: [and he brought]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **joy**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [joyfully]

bsb_verse_text: When those carrying the ark of the LORD had advanced six paces, he sacrificed an ox and a fattened calf.
ult_verse_text: And it happened, when the carriers of the Box of Yahweh had stepped six steps, that he sacrificed an ox and a fatling.

notes.orig_language_quote: כִּ֧י צָעֲד֛וּ נֹשְׂאֵ֥י אֲרוֹן־יְהוָ֖ה שִׁשָּׁ֣ה צְעָדִ֑ים וַ⁠יִּזְבַּ֥ח שׁ֖וֹר וּ⁠מְרִֽיא
notes.note: See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of how having the **lifters of the Box** pause after taking **six steps** could have been a symbolic action.

It might seem that the expression **stepped six steps** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [had taken six steps]

bsb_verse_text: And David, wearing a linen ephod, danced with all his might before the LORD,
ult_verse_text: And David danced to the face of Yahweh with all of {his} strength. And David was girded {with} an ephod of linen.

notes.note: Here, **face** represents “presence.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the presence of Yahweh]

The expression **was girded** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And David was wearing an ephod of linen]

Wearing **an ephod of linen** was a symbolic action by which David showed he was humbling himself before Yahweh. He was dressing like an ordinary worshiper rather than wearing his royal robes. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And David had humbly dressed himself in a simple linen garment]

bsb_verse_text: while he and all the house of Israel brought up the ark of the LORD with shouting and the sounding of the ram’s horn.
ult_verse_text: And David and all of the house of Israel were bringing up the Box of Yahweh with shouting and with the sound of the shofar,

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [and all of the people of Israel]
See how you translated the similar expression in [6:5](../06/05.md). Alternate translation: [and people from throughout Israel]

When the author says **bringing up**, the implication is that David and the Israelites were bringing the Box of Yahweh up the mountain into Jerusalem. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [were bringing the Box of Yahweh up the mountain into Jerusalem]

The author is not referring to a specific **shofar**. He means shofars in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [shofars]

bsb_verse_text: As the ark of the LORD was entering the City of David, Saul’s daughter Michal looked down from a window and saw King David leaping and dancing before the LORD, and she despised him in her heart.
ult_verse_text: and the Box of Yahweh was entering the City of David. But Michal, the daughter of Saul, looked down through a window, and she saw King David leaping and dancing to the face of Yahweh, and she despised him in her heart.

notes.note: Here the author is reintroducing Michal into the story as **the daughter of Saul** to remind readers of who she was and to hint at why she might disapprove of David’s actions. If your language has its own way of reintroducing participants with characterizing information, you could use it here in your translation. Alternate translation: [But David’s wife Michal, who was Saul’s daughter]
Here the **heart** represents the feelings. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and she felt great disdain toward him]

bsb_verse_text: When David had finished sacrificing the burnt offerings and peace offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the LORD of Hosts.
ult_verse_text: And David finished offering the burnt offering and the peace offerings, and he blessed the people in the name of Yahweh of Armies.

notes.note: The author is not referring to a specific **burnt offering**. He means burnt offerings in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the burnt offerings]

To bless people **in the name of Yahweh** was to name Yahweh as the one whom one hoped and believed would bless those people. (The poetic parallel in [Psalm 129:8](../../psa/129/008.md) indicates this. It says, “May the blessing of Yahweh be on you; we bless you in the name of Yahweh.”) Alternate translation: [and he called upon Yahweh of Armies to bless the people]

bsb_verse_text: Then he distributed to every man and woman among the multitude of Israel a loaf of bread, a date cake, and a raisin cake. And all the people departed, each to his own home.
ult_verse_text: And he distributed to all of the people, to all of the multitude of Israel, to man and to woman, to a man one cake of bread and one date cake and one raisin cake. And all of the people went, a man to his house.

notes.note: The expressions **all of the people** and **all of the multitude of Israel** mean similar things. The author is using the two expressions together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [to all of the Israelites who had gathered there]

In these cases, the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [to each one … each one back to his or her home]

bsb_verse_text: When David returned home to bless his own household, Saul’s daughter Michal came out to meet him. “How the king of Israel has distinguished himself today!” she said. “He has uncovered himself today in the sight of the maidservants of his subjects, like a vulgar person would do.”
ult_verse_text: Then David returned to bless his house. And Michal, the daughter of Saul, came out to meet David, and she said, “How the king of Israel honored himself today, who uncovered himself today to the eyes of the female servants of his servants, as uncovering himself, one of the worthless uncovers himself!”

notes.note: The author is using the term **house** to mean the people who lived in the same house with a man. He means the people in that man’s household. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:3](../02/03.md). Alternate translation: [his household]

notes.orig_language_quote: מַה־נִּכְבַּ֨ד הַ⁠יּ֜וֹם מֶ֣לֶךְ יִשְׂרָאֵ֗ל אֲשֶׁ֨ר נִגְלָ֤ה הַ⁠יּוֹם֙ לְ⁠עֵינֵ֨י אַמְה֣וֹת עֲבָדָ֔י⁠ו כְּ⁠הִגָּל֥וֹת נִגְל֖וֹת אַחַ֥ד הָ⁠רֵקִֽים
notes.note: Even though Michal is addressing David directly, she is speaking of him in the third person mockingly as **the king of Israel**, as if she were showing respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person, even though that would still represent mockery on the part of Michal. Alternate translation: [How you, the king of Israel, honored yourself today by uncovering yourself today to the eyes of the female servants of your servants]

In this figure of speech, Michal actually means to communicate the opposite of the literal meaning of her words. If a speaker of your language would not do that, you could translate the meaning plainly Alternate translation: [How the king of Israel disgraced himself today]
Here, **eyes** represent seeing. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the sight of]

Michal is repeating forms of the verb “uncover” in order to intensify her expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. Alternate translation: [as one of the worthless shamelessly uncovers himself]

Michal is using the adjective **worthless** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [a worthless person]

bsb_verse_text: But David said to Michal, “I was dancing before the LORD, who chose me over your father and all his house when He appointed me ruler over the LORD’s people Israel. I will celebrate before the LORD,
ult_verse_text: But David said to Michal, “To the face of Yahweh, who chose me instead of your father and instead of all of his house to appoint me leader over the people of Yahweh, over Israel, yes, I celebrated to the face of Yahweh!

notes.note: Here, **face** represents “presence.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [In the presence of Yahweh … in the presence of Yahweh]

The author is using the term **house** to mean all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. Alternate translation: [his descendants]

The terms **over the people of Yahweh** and **over Israel** mean similar things. David is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [over his people Israel]

bsb_verse_text: and I will humiliate and humble myself even more than this. Yet I will be honored by the maidservants of whom you have spoken.”
ult_verse_text: And I will humble myself more than this, and I will be lowly in my eyes. But with the female servants {about} whom you spoke, with them, I will be honored.”

notes.note: David is using the expression **in the eyes of** to mean “in the judgment of” or “in the opinion of.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [in my own regard]

The expression **I will be honored** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [But the female servants about whom you spoke will honor me]

bsb_verse_text: After the king had settled into his palace and the LORD had given him rest from all his enemies around him,
ult_verse_text: And it happened, when the king dwelled in his house and Yahweh gave rest to him from all around, from all of his enemies,

notes.note: The author is using the words **And it happened** to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event.

The author is using a common expression of his culture when he says that Yahweh **gave rest** to David. He means that Yahweh made it so none of the enemy nations around him were at war with him. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and Yahweh had made it so that he was not at war with any of the enemy nations around him]

bsb_verse_text: he said to Nathan the prophet, “Here I am, living in a house of cedar, while the ark of God remains in a tent.”
ult_verse_text: that the king said to Nathan the prophet, “See, please, I am dwelling in a house of cedars, but the Box of God is dwelling in the midst of a curtain.”

notes.note: David is using the term **See** to focus Nathan’s attention on what he is about to say. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Listen]
Here, **cedars** represent cedar wood. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in a house built of cedar wood]

Israelites characteristically referred to the individual pieces of cloth that they sewed together to make tents as “curtains,” and they referred to an entire tent made from such pieces as a **curtain**. It may be more natural in your language to use a plural form here. Alternate translation: [in the midst of tent-curtains] or [in a tent]

The implication is that David wanted to build a splendid temple for Yahweh and put the Box in it. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [but the Box of God is dwelling in the midst of a curtain. I want to build a splendid temple for Yahweh and put the Box in it]

bsb_verse_text: And Nathan replied to the king, “Go and do all that is in your heart, for the LORD is with you.”
ult_verse_text: And Nathan said to the king, “All that {is} in your heart, go, do, for Yahweh {is} with you.”

notes.orig_language_quote: כֹּ֛ל אֲשֶׁ֥ר בִּֽ⁠לְבָבְ⁠ךָ֖ לֵ֣ךְ עֲשֵׂ֑ה כִּ֥י יְהוָ֖ה עִמָּֽ⁠ךְ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since Yahweh is with you, go, do all that is in your heart]
Here, the **heart** represents a person’s desires. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [All that you desire to do]

Nathan is not telling David to **go** somewhere. He is saying **go** to mean that David should take action. (The meaning is similar to that of the term “arise” in [3:21](../03/21.md).) Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [go ahead and do] or [take action and do]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [Yahweh will help you]

bsb_verse_text: But that night the word of the LORD came to Nathan, saying,
ult_verse_text: But it happened, during that night, that the word of Yahweh was to Nathan, saying,

notes.note: The author is using the words **But it happened** to introduce a new development in this episode. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

When the author says that **the word of Yahweh was to Nathan**, he is using a common expression to mean that Yahweh spoke a message to Nathan. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [that Yahweh spoke a message to Nathan]

bsb_verse_text: “Go and tell My servant David that this is what the LORD says: Are you the one to build for Me a house to dwell in?
ult_verse_text: “Go, and you shall say to my servant, to David, ‘Thus says Yahweh, “You, will you build for me a house for my dwelling?

notes.orig_language_quote: לֵ֤ךְ וְ⁠אָֽמַרְתָּ֙ אֶל־עַבְדִּ֣⁠י אֶל־דָּוִ֔ד כֹּ֖ה אָמַ֣ר יְהוָ֑ה הַ⁠אַתָּ֛ה תִּבְנֶה־לִּ֥⁠י בַ֖יִת לְ⁠שִׁבְתִּֽ⁠י
notes.note: See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of how you might use punctuation or some other convention of your language to indicate the second-level, third-level, and fourth-level quotations in Yahweh’s message to Nathan in [verses 5–16](../07/05.md). That discussion also suggests that, alternatively, you could translate these verses in such a way that there are not quotations within quotations. The UST models one way to do that.

Yahweh is using the question form for emphasis, to tell David that he will not build a house for him to dwell in. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You shall not build for me a house for my dwelling.]

Yahweh is stating the pronoun **you** separately, even though the verb translated as **will you build** already includes this meaning. He is doing that to emphasize that David is wanting to do something that he has never asked the Israelites to do for him. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing the meaning here. Alternate translation: [No, you shall not build a house for my dwelling]

Yahweh is speaking here as if David wants to build him a physical **house** as his **dwelling**. He is actually speaking of a temple where he would be present with his people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a temple where I will be present]

bsb_verse_text: For I have not dwelt in a house from the day I brought the Israelites up out of Egypt until this day, but I have moved about with a tent as My dwelling.
ult_verse_text: For I have not lived in a house from the day of my bringing up the sons of Israel from Egypt and to this day, but I have been going about in a tent and in a dwelling.

notes.note: Here the word **For** provides not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [After all]

Here, Yahweh is speaking as if a temple were actually a physical **house** in which he might live. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a temple]
Yahweh is using the term **day** to refer to a specific time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [since the time when I brought up]

In keeping with what is usual for this language and culture, Yahweh is marking travel for change in elevation. If this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [my bringing]

Here, **sons** means all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. So **the sons of Israel** figuratively means all the people descended from the patriarch Jacob, who was also known as Israel. Alternate translation: [the people of Israel]
See how you translated the similar expression in [4:3](../04/03.md). Alternate translation: [up to this time]

The phrase **in a tent and in a dwelling** expresses a single idea. The word **dwelling** describes the purpose of the **tent**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [in a tent for my dwelling]

bsb_verse_text: In all My journeys with all the Israelites, have I ever asked any of the leaders I appointed to shepherd My people Israel, ‘Why haven’t you built Me a house of cedar?’
ult_verse_text: In any {place} where I went about with all of the sons of Israel, did I speak a word with one of the scepters of Israel whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, saying, ‘Why have you not built for me a house of cedars’?”’

notes.orig_language_quote: הֲ⁠דָבָ֣ר דִּבַּ֗רְתִּי אֶת־אַחַד֙ שִׁבְטֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל אֲשֶׁ֣ר צִוִּ֗יתִי לִ⁠רְע֛וֹת אֶת־עַמִּ֥⁠י אֶת־יִשְׂרָאֵ֖ל לֵ⁠אמֹ֑ר לָ֛⁠מָּה לֹֽא־בְנִיתֶ֥ם לִ֖⁠י בֵּ֥ית אֲרָזִֽים
notes.note: Yahweh is using the question form to emphasize that he never asked any of Israel’s leaders to build him a house. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I did not speak a word with one of the scepters of Israel whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, saying, ‘Why have you not built for me a house of cedars’!]

Yahweh is using the term **word** to represent what he might have said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [did I give a command to]

Here, **scepters** represents “leaders,” since leaders held scepters as an emblem of their office. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [any of the leaders of Israel]

Here, Yahweh is speaking as if each of these leaders was a **shepherd** and as if his **people Israel** were sheep. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to guide]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:2](../07/02.md). Alternate translation: [a temple built from cedar wood]

bsb_verse_text: Now then, you are to tell My servant David that this is what the LORD of Hosts says: I took you from the pasture, from following the flock, to be the ruler over My people Israel.
ult_verse_text: And now, thus shall you say to my servant, to David, ‘Thus says Yahweh of Armies, “I, I took you from the pasture, from after the flock, to become a ruler over my people, over Israel.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you were” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: [I personally took you]

Yahweh is referring to the way a shepherd works in a **pasture** and walks behind a **flock** to represent the work of a shepherd generally. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [from being a shepherd]

The terms **over my people** and **over Israel** mean similar things. Yahweh is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [over my people Israel]

bsb_verse_text: I have been with you wherever you have gone, and I have cut off all your enemies from before you. Now I will make for you a name like that of the greatest in the land.
ult_verse_text: And I have been with you in every {place} where you have gone, and I have cut off all of your enemies from your face. And I will make for you a great name, like the name of the great who {have been} on the earth.

notes.note: Yahweh is using **I have been with you** as a common expression of this culture to mean “I have helped you.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And I have helped you]

Yahweh is speaking as if he had physically **cut off** David’s enemies, as if they had been a branch he wanted to remove from a tree. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I have destroyed]

Here, **from your face** means “in front of you,” with the implication that these enemies were confronting David and opposing him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [before you] or [who opposed you]

Here, a person’s **name** represents his reputation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [a great reputation, like the reputation of]

Yahweh is using the adjective **great** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the great leaders]

bsb_verse_text: And I will provide a place for My people Israel and will plant them so that they may dwell in a place of their own and be disturbed no more. No longer will the sons of wickedness oppress them as they did at the beginning
ult_verse_text: And I have established a place for my people, for Israel, and I will plant him that he may dwell under him, and he will not tremble anymore, and the sons of wickedness will not continue to afflict him as at first,

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠נְטַעְתִּי⁠ו֙ וְ⁠שָׁכַ֣ן תַּחְתָּ֔י⁠ו וְ⁠לֹ֥א יִרְגַּ֖ז & לְ⁠עַנּוֹת֔⁠וֹ
notes.note: In this verse, the words **him** and **he** are singular in form, but they refer to all the Israelites as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural forms of these words. Alternate translation: [and I will plant them that they may dwell in their place, and they will not tremble … to afflict them]

Yahweh is speaking here as if he would physically **plant** the Israelites, as if they were a tree or some other plant. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I will make them secure]

Yahweh is using a common expression of this culture that means “that the Israelites may live on the ground that is under them.” Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 14:9](../../1sa/14/09.md). Alternate translation: [that the Israelites may live in that place]

Here, **tremble** represents being afraid. It refers to trembling with fear. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and he will not be afraid]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:34](../03/34.md). Alternate translation: [wicked people]

The phrase **at first** refers to an earlier time. If your language would not represent a number in a form such as **first**, you could represent this number in a form that your language would use or in some other way that would be clear in your language. Alternate translation: [as formerly]

The expression **at first** refers to the time when Israel was oppressed in Egypt. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [as at the time when you were slaves in Egypt]

bsb_verse_text: and have done since the day I appointed judges over My people Israel. I will give you rest from all your enemies. The LORD declares to you that He Himself will establish a house for you.
ult_verse_text: and from the day when I commanded judges over my people Israel.

notes.note: Yahweh is using the term **day** to refer to a specific time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and during the time when]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:1](../07/01.md). Alternate translation: [And I will make it so that you are not at war with any of your enemies]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הִגִּ֤יד לְ⁠ךָ֙ יְהוָ֔ה כִּי & יַעֲשֶׂה & יְהוָֽה
notes.note: In making an official declaration, Yahweh is speaking about himself formally in the third person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in the first person. Alternate translation: [And I, Yahweh, declare to you that I will make]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:1](../03/01.md). Alternate translation: [a royal dynasty]

bsb_verse_text: And when your days are fulfilled and you rest with your fathers, I will raise up your descendant after you, who will come from your own body, and I will establish his kingdom.
ult_verse_text: When your days are full and you lie down with your fathers, then I will raise up after you your seed who will come forth from your belly, and I will establish his kingdom.

notes.note: **When your days are full** is a common expression of his culture to mean “when you have lived out your life.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [When you have lived out your life]

Yahweh is referring to death in a polite way by using the phrase **lie down**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language, or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [and you pass away as your fathers have] or [and you join your fathers in death]
Yahweh is using the term **fathers** to mean “ancestors.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [your ancestors]

Yahweh is speaking as if he will physically **raise up** one of David’s descendants to a high location. He means that he will make him become the next king. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [then I will make reign as king after you]

Yahweh is speaking of David’s descendant as if he were a **seed** and as if David were a plant that had produced it. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [one of your offspring]

The implication is that David will be the actual father of this son (that is, he will not be an adopted or foster son), and that this will happen in the future. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [whom you will father in the future]

bsb_verse_text: He will build a house for My Name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.
ult_verse_text: He, he will build a house for my name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom to forever!

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression “you, you will shepherd” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: [I promise that he will build]

Yahweh is speaking as if this descendant of David would build him a physical **house**. He means that he will build him a temple, a special building for worshiping him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a temple]

Here, **throne** represents the authority to rule as king. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [his reign as king]

bsb_verse_text: I will be his Father, and he will be My son. When he does wrong, I will discipline him with the rod of men and with the blows of the sons of men.
ult_verse_text: I myself will be a father to him, and he himself will be a son to me, that when he sins, then I will correct him with the rod of men and with the blows of the sons of man.

notes.orig_language_quote: אֲנִי֙ אֶהְיֶה־לּ֣⁠וֹ לְ⁠אָ֔ב וְ⁠ה֖וּא יִהְיֶה־לִּ֣⁠י לְ⁠בֵ֑ן
notes.note: Yahweh is speaking here as if he and David’s descendant would actually be **father** and **son**. He means that he will treat David’s descendant the way a father treats a son. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will treat him the way a father treats his son]

The terms **rod of men** and **blows of the sons of man** mean similar things. Yahweh is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [with human punishments]

Here, **rod** and **blows** represent punishment or discipline. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [with human discipline]

This could mean: (1) that Yahweh will discipline David’s son with measures of the same type and purpose that humans use to correct their children, not with divine judgments that would destroy him and his descendants. Alternate translation: [with measures such as humans use to correct their children]; (2) that Yahweh will use human beings as his agents to punish David’s son. Alternate translation: [I will use people to punish him]

Here the masculine term **sons of man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [human beings]

bsb_verse_text: But My loving devotion will never be removed from him as I removed it from Saul, whom I removed from before you.
ult_verse_text: But my covenant faithfulness will not turn away from you as I turned it away from with Saul, whom I turned away from your face.

notes.note: Yahweh is speaking of **covenant faithfulness** as if it were a living thing that could **turn away** from someone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But I will not stop treating you with covenant faithfulness]

The word **you** is plural here because Yahweh is using it to mean both David and his descendants. So use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction. Other languages may have other ways of making the meaning clear. Alternate translation: [from you and your descendants]

Here, Yahweh is speaking as if he had physically **turned it away** his covenant faithfulness away from Saul. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [as I stopped treating Saul with it]

Here, **face** represents the area in front of someone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [I turned away from in front of you]

Yahweh is speaking as if Saul had been in front of David, that is, in his way, as David moved toward becoming king. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I removed so that you could be king]

bsb_verse_text: Your house and kingdom will endure forever before Me, and your throne will be established forever.”
ult_verse_text: And your house and your kingdom will be confirmed to forever to your face. Your throne will be established to forever.”’”

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠נֶאְמַ֨ן בֵּיתְ⁠ךָ֧ וּ⁠מַֽמְלַכְתְּ⁠ךָ֛ עַד־עוֹלָ֖ם לְ⁠פָנֶ֑י⁠ךָ כִּֽסְאֲ⁠ךָ֔ יִהְיֶ֥ה נָכ֖וֹן עַד־עוֹלָֽם
notes.note: The two phrases **your house and your kingdom will be confirmed to forever to your face** and **your throne will be established to forever** mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. Hebrew poetry was based on this kind of repetition, and it would be good to show this to your readers by including both phrases in your translation rather than combining them. It may be clearer in your language to connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [And your house and your kingdom will be confirmed to forever to your face, yes, your throne will be established to forever]

The expression **will be confirmed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [And I will confirm your house and your kingdom]

The terms **house** and **kingdom** mean similar things. Yahweh is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [your royal dynasty]

Here, **face** represents what is in front of someone, but in time rather than in space. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [beyond you into the future]

The expression **will be established** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [I will establish your throne]

Here, **throne** represents royal authority or rule. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [The reign of your descendants]

This is the end of Yahweh’s message to Nathan. Review your translation of [verses 5–16](../07/05.md) to ensure that you have consistently used punctuation or some other convention of your language to indicate the second-level, third-level, and fourth-level quotations in this message. Alternatively, you may have decided to translate the entire message in such a way that there are not quotations within quotations. If so, ensure that you have done that consistently.

bsb_verse_text: So Nathan relayed to David all the words of this entire revelation.
ult_verse_text: According to all of these words and according to all of this vision, thus Nathan spoke to David.

notes.orig_language_quote: כְּ⁠כֹל֙ הַ⁠דְּבָרִ֣ים הָ⁠אֵ֔לֶּה וּ⁠כְ⁠כֹ֖ל הַ⁠חִזָּי֣וֹן הַ⁠זֶּ֑ה
notes.note: Together, the terms **words** and **vision** express a single idea. The term **vision** tells how Yahweh conveyed these **words** to David. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [According to all of these words that Yahweh had spoken to him in a vision]

notes.orig_language_quote: כְּ⁠כֹל֙ הַ⁠דְּבָרִ֣ים הָ⁠אֵ֔לֶּה וּ⁠כְ⁠כֹ֖ל הַ⁠חִזָּי֣וֹן הַ⁠זֶּ֑ה
notes.note: Here, **words** represents what Yahweh said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [According to all of these things that Yahweh had said to him in a vision]

bsb_verse_text: Then King David went in, sat before the LORD, and said, “Who am I, O Lord GOD, and what is my house, that You have brought me this far?
ult_verse_text: And King David went,

notes.note: Here, **face** represents “presence.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the presence of Yahweh]

notes.orig_language_quote: מִ֣י אָנֹכִ֞י אֲדֹנָ֤⁠י יְהוִה֙ וּ⁠מִ֣י בֵיתִ֔⁠י כִּ֥י הֲבִיאֹתַ֖⁠נִי עַד־הֲלֹֽם
notes.note: David is using the question form to express his humility and amazement at what God has done for him. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [I am not so significant, my Lord Yahweh, and neither is my house, that you should have brought me to here!]
By **my house**, David probably means his “father’s house,” that is, the extended family from which he comes. Alternate translation: [my family]

The implication is that **here** means being the king of Israel. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [that you have made me the king of Israel]

bsb_verse_text: And as if this was a small thing in Your eyes, O Lord GOD, You have also spoken about the future of the house of Your servant. Is this Your custom with man, O Lord GOD?
ult_verse_text: And this was yet small in your eyes, my Lord Yahweh, for you have spoken even about the house of your servant to afar. And this {is} the law of man, my Lord Yahweh!

notes.note: David is using **this was small in your eyes** as a common expression of his culture to mean “you considered this to be insignificant.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you considered even this a small thing]

David is speaking of himself in the third person as **your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person, here and in the rest of this chapter. Alternate translation: [my house]

Here, **house** means all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. So **the house of your servant** figuratively means all the people who would descend from David. Alternate translation: [my descendants]

This could mean: (1) that David is marveling that Yahweh has established the perpetual reign of his descendants as a **law** that people must obey. Alternate translation: [And you, my Lord Yahweh, have made the perpetual reign of my descendants a law that people must obey!]; (2) that David is marveling that Yahweh has said that if his descendants do wrong, he will correct them with human-style discipline, not destroy them with divine judgments ([verse 14](../07/14.md)). Alternate translation: [And you, my Lord Yahweh, have said that you will not destroy my descendants if they do wrong but correct them as humans discipline their children!]

Here the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [human beings]

bsb_verse_text: What more can David say to You? For You know Your servant, O Lord GOD.
ult_verse_text: And what more shall David continue to say to you? But you, you know your servant, my Lord Yahweh.

notes.note: David is using the question form to express that he is too overwhelmed to say anything more. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I find that I am now at a loss for words!]

David is stating the pronoun **you** separately, even though the verb translated as **you know** already includes this meaning. He is doing that in order to contrast Yahweh’s knowledge of what he is thinking and feeling with his own inability to say anything further. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing the meaning here. Alternate translation: [But for your part, you know your servant]

Here, **your servant** represents what David wants to say. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [But you certainly know what I, your servant, want to say]

bsb_verse_text: For the sake of Your word and according to Your own heart, You have accomplished this great thing and revealed it to Your servant.
ult_verse_text: For the sake of your word and according to your heart, you have done all this greatness, to make your servant know {this}.

notes.note: David is using the term **word** to represent what Yahweh said on some previous occasion by using words. In context, he seems to be referring to how Yahweh instructed Samuel in [1 Samuel 16:12](../../1sa/16/12.md) to anoint him as king. This constituted a commitment on Yahweh’s part to make David the king. The idea here seems to be that in order to keep this promise in the fullest sense, Yahweh is going to make David the head of a royal dynasty. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [In order to keep your promise in the fullest sense]

Here, the **heart** represents a person’s desires. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [according to your desire] or [because you wanted to]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **greatness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [all these great things]

In this context, the verb form **to make … know** does not describe the purpose of the preceding action **you have done all this greatness**. Instead, it describes an accompanying action. Use an appropriate verbal form in your language to convey this meaning. Alternate translation: [and you have made me, your servant, know this]

bsb_verse_text: How great You are, O Lord GOD! For there is none like You, and there is no God but You, according to everything we have heard with our own ears.
ult_verse_text: Therefore, you are great, my Lord Yahweh, for {there is} none like you and {there is} no God except you, in all that we have heard with our ears.

notes.note: David is not saying that the reason why Yahweh is **great** is that he has done the great things for him that he describes in the previous verse. David means that he is able to declare confidently to Yahweh **you are great** because he has personally experienced his greatness and goodness in these ways. If this would not be clear, you may want to use a different connecting word or phrase to show how this statement relates to what comes before it. It may be possible to make the relationship clear without using any connecting word or phrase. The UST models one way to do that. Alternate translation: [As a result, I can confidently declare]
Here the word **for** provides not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [and after all]

These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. Hebrew poetry was based on this kind of repetition, and it would be good to show this to your readers by including both phrases in your translation rather than combining them. It may be clearer in your language to connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [no god is like you, indeed, you are the only God]

It might seem that in this context, the expression **with our ears** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could leave it out. Alternate translation: [in all that we have heard]

bsb_verse_text: And who is like Your people Israel—the one nation on earth whom God went out to redeem as a people for Himself and to make a name for Himself? You performed great and awesome wonders by driving out nations and their gods from before Your people, whom You redeemed for Yourself from Egypt.
ult_verse_text: And who {is} like your people, like Israel, the one nation on earth whose God went to redeem for himself as a people and to make for himself a name and to do greatness for you and {things} being feared for your land, from the face of your people whom you redeemed for yourself from Egypt, nations and its gods?

notes.note: David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [And there is no other nation like your people … and its gods!]

The terms **like your people** and **like Israel** mean similar things. David is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [is like your people Israel]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:3](../07/03.md). Alternate translation: [took action]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:9](../07/09.md). Alternate translation: [a reputation]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **greatness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [great things]

The word **you** is plural here because it refers to the Israelites, so use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction. Alternate translation: [for you, O Israel] or [for them]

David has been addressing Yahweh in his prayer, but now he briefly addresses the nation of Israel (as **you**), even though he knows that the people of this nation cannot hear him. (David has gone to the sacred tent to speak with Yahweh alone, as [verse 18](../07/18.md) indicates.) He does this in order to express more powerfully his feelings about the **greatness** (great things) that Yahweh has done for Israel. You may be able to use punctuation or some other convention of your language to show that the addressee changes briefly here. You might also use a first-person plural pronoun to show that by **you** (plural), David is referring to the people group to which he belongs, not to Yahweh, to whom the singular forms of “you” refer in the rest of the verse. Alternate translation: [for us]

The expression **being feared** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and fearsome things]
The word **your** is singular here because it refers to Yahweh. So use the singular form in your translation if your language marks that distinction. Alternate translation: [for your land, O Yahweh]

Here, **from the face of** means “in front of,” with the implication that Yahweh did these fearsome things to defeat the enemies who were confronting the Israelites and opposing them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of] or [against the nations that opposed]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and from other enemy nations and the gods of each one]

bsb_verse_text: And now, O LORD God, confirm forever the word You have spoken concerning Your servant and his house. Do as You have promised,
ult_verse_text: And now, Yahweh God, the word that you have spoken concerning your servant and concerning his house, raise up to forever, and do just as you have spoken.

notes.note: **And now** was an expression that speakers in this culture commonly used to introduce their main topic. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

David is using the term **word** to represent what God said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the things that you have said]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:1](../03/01.md). Alternate translation: [my royal dynasty]

The phrases **raise up to forever** and **do just as you have spoken** mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. Hebrew poetry was based on this kind of repetition, and it would be good to show this to your readers by including both phrases in your translation rather than combining them. It may be clearer in your language to connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [raise up to forever, indeed, fulfill what you have promised]

David is speaking as if Yahweh’s **word** were an object that Yahweh could physically **raise up** or lift into a high position. He means that he wants Yahweh to fulfill the promise that he has made. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expressions in [1 Samuel 1:23](../../1sa/01/23.md), [1 Samuel 3:12](../../1sa/03/12.md), and [1 Samuel 15:11](../../1sa/15/11.md). Alternate translation: [perform] or [fulfill]

bsb_verse_text: so that Your name will be magnified forever when it is said, ‘The LORD of Hosts is God over Israel.’ And the house of Your servant David will be established before You.
ult_verse_text: And may your name be great to forever, saying, ‘Yahweh of Armies {is} God over Israel,’ and the house of your servant David will be established to your face.

notes.note: Here, **name** represents “reputation.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [your reputation]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [as people say that you, Yahweh of Armies, are God over Israel]

The term **saying** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. (In some languages, it may not be necessary to represent this term explicitly.) Alternate translation: [so that people will say]

The expression **will be established** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and you will establish the house of your servant David]
See how you translated the similar expression in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [and the dynasty of]

This could mean: (1) that David is using one part of Yahweh, his **face**, to mean all of him in the act of maintaining the rule of David and his descendants. The idea is that Yahweh would be watching them and protecting them. Alternate translation: [as you maintain it]; (2) that David is using Yahweh’s **face** to represent his presence. Alternate translation: [in your presence]

bsb_verse_text: For You, O LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel, have revealed this to Your servant when You said, ‘I will build a house for you.’ Therefore Your servant has found the courage to offer this prayer to You.
ult_verse_text: For you, Yahweh of Armies, {are} the God of Israel. You have uncovered the ear of your servant, saying, ‘I will build a house for you.’ Therefore, your servant has found his heart to pray this prayer to you.

notes.note: Here the word **For** provides not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [After all]

David is using a common expression, **You have uncovered the ear**, that described one person telling something to another person. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [You have told this to your servant] or [You have told this to me]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [saying that you will build a house for me]

David is using **found his heart** as a common expression of his culture to mean “found courage” or “became brave enough.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [your servant has found the courage] or [I have found the courage]

bsb_verse_text: And now, O Lord GOD, You are God! Your words are true, and You have promised this goodness to Your servant.
ult_verse_text: And now, my Lord Yahweh, you {are} he, the God, so your words are true. And you have spoken concerning this good your servant.

notes.note: It might seem that the expression **you {are} he, the God** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [you are God]
The implication is that Yahweh is the only true God. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [you are the only true God]

David is using the term **words** to represent what Yahweh says by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and what you say is true]

David is using the adjective **good** as a noun to mean a certain kind of thing. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [this good thing]

bsb_verse_text: Now therefore, may it please You to bless the house of Your servant, that it may continue forever before You. For You, O Lord GOD, have spoken, and with Your blessing the house of Your servant will be blessed forever.”
ult_verse_text: And now, take pleasure and bless the house of your servant to be to your face forever. For you, my Lord Yahweh, you have spoken and from your blessing the house of your servant will be blessed forever.”

notes.note: The phrase **take pleasure and bless** expresses a single idea. The word **take pleasure** tells with what attitude David hopes Yahweh will **bless** him and his descendants. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [gladly bless] or [may it please you to bless]

David is speaking here as if the dynasty Yahweh has promised him would actually be a **house**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the dynasty of your servant] or [my dynasty]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:26](../07/26.md). Alternate translation: [maintained by you] or [in your presence]
Here the word **For** provides not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [After all]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you were” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: [For you, my Lord Yahweh, have told me this personally]

The expression **will be blessed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and you will bless the house of your servant forever with your blessing]

bsb_verse_text: Some time later, David defeated the Philistines, subdued them, and took Metheg-ammah from the hand of the Philistines.
ult_verse_text: And it happened after this, that David struck the Philistines, and he subdued them. And David took Metheg Ammah from the hand of the Philistines.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:17](../02/17.md). Alternate translation: [that David defeated the Philistines]

Here and frequently in this chapter, the author uses **David**, one person who was involved in these actions, to represent everyone who was involved. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:1](../03/01.md), where “David” means “David and his supporters.” Alternate translation: [David and his army]

The expression **Metheg Ammah** seems to be a description rather than the name of a place. No place is known by that name. The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 18:1](../../1ch/18/01.md) says that David captured the city of Gath and its surrounding towns. **Metheg Ammah** means “the bridle of the mother city.” Gath was the capital city of the Philistine confederation, and the author may speak of it here as a “bridle” to mean that conquering it gave David the means to control the entire Philistine confederation. (The word “bridle” could also indicate that previously the Philistines had exercised control over the Israelites from their capital city of Gath.) In your translation, you may wish to represent the expression “Metheg Ammah” and spell it the way it sounds in your language. Alternatively, you could express the probable meaning and translate the expression as a reference to Gath. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to take the approach that it takes. Alternate translation: [Gath, their capital city]

Here, **hand** represents possession or control. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from the possession of the Philistines]

bsb_verse_text: David also defeated the Moabites, made them lie down on the ground, and measured them off with a cord. He measured off with two lengths those to be put to death, and with one length those to be spared. So the Moabites became subject to David and brought him tribute.
ult_verse_text: And he struck Moab, and he measured them with a rope, making them lie on the ground. And he measured two ropes to kill and the fullness of the rope to let live. And Moab became servants to David, lifters of tribute.

notes.note: The author is describing one event, David measuring these enemy soldiers **with a rope**, before describing another event that preceded it, David **making them lie on the ground**. If it would be helpful your language, you may wish to relate these events in the order in which they happened, as in the UST. Alternate translation: [and he made them lie on the ground and measured them with a rope]
The pronoun **them** refers to the Moabite soldiers. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [the Moabite soldiers]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יְמַדֵּ֤ד שְׁנֵֽי־חֲבָלִים֙ לְ⁠הָמִ֔ית וּ⁠מְלֹ֥א הַ⁠חֶ֖בֶל לְ⁠הַחֲי֑וֹת
notes.note: The implication is that David used a rope divided into three equal parts to measure groups of Moabite soldiers. He killed those who were lying under the first two parts but let those under the third part live. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [He used a rope divided into three equal parts. He stretched it out and killed the soldiers lying under the first two parts, but he let the soldiers lying under the rest of the rope live]
