In this verse, the word **Moab** is singular in form, but it refers to all the Moabite people as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could refer to these people by using a plural form. Alternate translation: [the Moabites]

The author is using the first thing that subject peoples would do to deliver tribute, lift it onto the backs of animals that would transport it, to represent the entire action of paying tribute. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [bringers of tribute] or [vassals]

bsb_verse_text: David also defeated Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah, who had marched out to restore his dominion along the Euphrates River.
ult_verse_text: And David struck Hadadezer, the son of Rehob, the king of Zobah, when he went to restore his hand at the River.

notes.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Hadadezer. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [when Hadadezer went]
See the Introduction to this chapter for a discussion of this phrase and for suggestions of how you might represent it in your translation.

The author is referring to the Euphrates River, which was the most important river in this region and so was sometimes simply called **the River**. You could use your language’s name for this river if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [at the Euphrates River]

bsb_verse_text: David captured from him a thousand chariots, seven thousand charioteers, and twenty thousand foot soldiers, and he hamstrung all the horses except a hundred he kept for the chariots.
ult_verse_text: And David took from him 1, 700 horsemen and 20, 000 men on foot. And David hamstrung all of the chariots, but he left from them 100 chariots.

notes.note: The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible) and the parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 18:4](../../1ch/18/04.md) read “1,000 chariots and 7,000 horsemen.” That may have been the original reading. At one point in the process of transmission, scribes may have accidentally left out the word “chariots,” and the letters or points that indicated numbers may also have been unintentionally altered. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יְעַקֵּ֤ר דָּוִד֙ אֶת־כָּל־הָ⁠רֶ֔כֶב וַ⁠יּוֹתֵ֥ר מִמֶּ֖⁠נּוּ מֵ֥אָה רָֽכֶב
notes.note: Here the term **chariots** represents the horses that pulled these chariots. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And David hamstrung all of the chariot horses, but he left from them 100 horses]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יְעַקֵּ֤ר דָּוִד֙ אֶת־כָּל־הָ⁠רֶ֔כֶב וַ⁠יּוֹתֵ֥ר מִמֶּ֖⁠נּוּ מֵ֥אָה רָֽכֶב
notes.note: If, in your language, it would appear that the author was making a statement here and then contradicting it, you could reverse the order of the clauses so that the exception is stated first and then the larger group is named second. Alternate translation: [And after choosing 100 horses from the chariots, David had his soldiers hamstring the rest]

When the author says that David **hamstrung** these horses, he meant that he had his soldiers use a method of disabling them by cutting tendons in their legs. This would be done carefully so that horses would still be able to walk and carry loads, but they would no longer be able to run. As a result, they could no longer be used in warfare. If your readers would not be familiar with what hamstringing is, you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [And David had his soldiers disable all of the chariot horses by cutting their leg tendons]

bsb_verse_text: When the Arameans of Damascus came to help King Hadadezer of Zobah, David struck down twenty-two thousand of their men.
ult_verse_text: And Aram of Damascus came to help Hadadezer, the king of Zobah. And David struck 22, 000 men among Aram.

notes.note: Here, **Aram of Damascus** represents the army of the Aramean kingdom whose capital was Damascus. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the army of the Aramean kingdom whose capital was Damascus]

bsb_verse_text: Then he placed garrisons in Aram of Damascus, and the Arameans became subject to David and brought him tribute. So the LORD made David victorious wherever he went.
ult_verse_text: And David put garrisons in Aram of Damascus, and Aram became servants to David, lifters of tribute. And Yahweh saved David in all that he went.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠תְּהִ֤י אֲרָם֙ לְ⁠דָוִ֔ד לַ⁠עֲבָדִ֖ים נוֹשְׂאֵ֣י מִנְחָ֑ה
notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [8:2](../08/02.md). Alternate translation: [and the Arameans became servants to David and brought him tribute]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֹּ֤שַׁע יְהוָה֙ אֶת־דָּוִ֔ד בְּ⁠כֹ֖ל אֲשֶׁ֥ר הָלָֽךְ
notes.note: The author is making a summary comment about everything he has described since introducing a new event in [8:1](../08/01.md). This signals the end of his account of these wars that David fought. Use the natural form in your language for indicating the conclusion of a story.

bsb_verse_text: And David took the gold shields that belonged to the officers of Hadadezer and brought them to Jerusalem.
ult_verse_text: And David took the shields of gold that were on the servants of Hadadezer, and he brought them {to} Jerusalem.

notes.orig_language_quote: אֵ֚ת שִׁלְטֵ֣י הַ⁠זָּהָ֔ב אֲשֶׁ֣ר הָי֔וּ אֶ֖ל עַבְדֵ֣י הֲדַדְעָ֑זֶר
notes.note: The meaning of the word translated as **shields** is uncertain. It could be a general term for military equipment whose meaning must be understood from the context. In some contexts, such as [Jeremiah 51:11](../../jer/51/11.md), it seems to mean “quivers” or arrow-cases, and some versions also translate it that way here. However, the context seems to support the meaning of **shields**. Some ancient rulers had their bodyguard carry shields that were plated with precious metals, and Hadadezer may have done that. Alternate translation: [the gold-plated shields that Hadadezer’s bodyguard had carried]

bsb_verse_text: And from Betah and Berothai, cities of Hadadezer, King David took a large amount of bronze.
ult_verse_text: And from Betah and from Berothai, the cities of Hadadezer, King David took bronze, making very much.

notes.note: The phrase **took bronze, making very much** expresses a single idea. The expression **making very much** tells in what way David **took bronze**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [greatly took bronze] or [took very much bronze]

bsb_verse_text: he sent his son Joram to greet King David and bless him for fighting and defeating Hadadezer, who had been at war with Toi. Joram brought with him articles of silver and gold and bronze,
ult_verse_text: And Toi sent Joram his son to King David to ask about him regarding peace and to bless him because he had fought with Hadadezer and had struck him. For Hadadezer had been a man of war of Toi. And in his hand were vessels of silver and vessels of gold and vessels of bronze.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Here the word **peace** indicates the idea of “welfare.” Alternate translation: [to ask about his welfare] or [to say that he hoped he was doing well]

The author is using **a man of war** as a common expression of his culture to mean “someone who fought wars against.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [For Hadadezer had been fighting wars against Toi]

Here the author is providing background information to help readers understand what is happening in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture. Alternate translation: [Hadadezer had been fighting wars against him]

The author does not mean that Joram somehow held all of these **vessels** in his **hand**. He is using the term **hand** to indicate that Joram was the agent who conveyed the vessels to David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And he brought]
The pronoun **his** refers to Joram. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And in Joram’s hand were] or [And Joram brought]

bsb_verse_text: from Edom and Moab, from the Ammonites and Philistines and Amalekites, and from the spoil of Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
ult_verse_text: from Aram and from Moab and from the sons of Ammon and from the Philistines and from Amalek and from the plunder of Hadadezer, the son of Rehob, the king of Zobah.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [7:6](../07/06.md). Alternate translation: [and from the Ammonites]

bsb_verse_text: And David made a name for himself when he returned from striking down eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
ult_verse_text: And David made a name when he returned from his striking Aram in the Valley of Salt, 18, 000.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [7:9](../07/09.md). Alternate translation: [a reputation]

The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible) and the parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 18:12](../../1ch/18/12.md) read “Edom.” That may have been the original reading, particularly since the **the Valley of Salt** (the Arabah south of the Dead Sea) was close to Edom, not to Aram. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [killing 18,000 Edomites]

bsb_verse_text: He placed garrisons throughout Edom, and all the Edomites were subject to David. So the LORD made David victorious wherever he went.
ult_verse_text: And he put garrisons in Edom. In all of Edom, garrisons there. And it happened, all of Edom {became} servants to David. And Yahweh saved David in all that he went.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יָּ֨שֶׂם בֶּ⁠אֱד֜וֹם נְצִבִ֗ים בְּ⁠כָל־אֱדוֹם֙ שָׂ֣ם נְצִבִ֔ים
notes.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine them and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [And he stationed military garrisons throughout all of Edom]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [there were garrisons throughout all of Edom] or [he placed garrisons throughout all of Edom]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יּ֤וֹשַׁע יְהוָה֙ אֶת־דָּוִ֔ד בְּ⁠כֹ֖ל אֲשֶׁ֥ר הָלָֽךְ
notes.note: After providing some further details about the plunder David captured, the gifts he received, and how he defeated Edom, the author is once again making a summary comment about everything he has described since introducing a new event in [8:1](../08/01.md). See how you translated the similar expression in [8:6](../08/06.md).

bsb_verse_text: Thus David reigned over all Israel and administered justice and righteousness for all his people:
ult_verse_text: And David was king over all of Israel. And it happened, David did justice and righteousness for all of his people.

notes.note: The phrase **justice and righteousness** expresses a single idea. The word **righteousness** describes what kind of **justice** David carried out. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [David did righteous judgment]

bsb_verse_text: Joab son of Zeruiah was over the army; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the recorder;
ult_verse_text: And Joab, the son of Zeruiah, {was} over the army, and Jehoshapat, the son of Ahilud, {was} the recorder.

notes.note: A **recorder** was a kind of royal official who kept records of important events and handled official documents. If your readers would not be familiar with what a recorder is, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [was the royal secretary] or [was in charge of the official records]

bsb_verse_text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and Pelethites; and David’s sons were priestly leaders.
ult_verse_text: And Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, both the Cherethites and the Pelethites, and the sons of David were priests.

notes.note: The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [was over both the Cherethites and the Pelethites] or [commanded both the Cherethites and the Pelethites]

The **Cherethites and the Pelethites** were special groups of soldiers who served as David’s personal bodyguards and elite fighting force. If your readers would not be familiar with what these groups were, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [the royal guard and special soldiers] or [the elite bodyguards and special military units]

David’s sons were from the tribe of Judah, not Levi, and so they could not serve as priests who offered sacrifices on the altar at the sacred tent. In this context, the author is probably using the term **priests** to mean high-ranking royal officials. The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 18:17](../../1ch/18/17.md) says that they were “chief officials,” suggesting that that is the meaning here. Alternate translation: [and the sons of David were chief officials]

bsb_verse_text: Then David asked, “Is there anyone left from the house of Saul to whom I can show kindness for the sake of Jonathan?”
ult_verse_text: And David said, “{Is it} that there is still {one} who remains to the house of Saul, that I may do covenant faithfulness with him for the sake of Jonathan?”

notes.note: The author is using the term **house** by association to mean all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. So **the house of Saul** figuratively means all the people descended from King Saul. (This is slightly different from the uses of this phrase in [chapter 3](../03/01.md) to mean “the supporters of Saul” or “the successors of Saul.”) Alternate translation: [among the descendants of Saul]

bsb_verse_text: And there was a servant of the house of Saul named Ziba. They summoned him to David, and the king inquired, “Are you Ziba?” “I am your servant,” he replied.
ult_verse_text: Now to the house of Saul {was} a servant, and his name {was} Ziba. And they called him to David. And the king said to him, “{Are} you Ziba?”

notes.note: Here the author is introducing **Ziba** as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Now there was a certain servant named Ziba in Saul’s household]

Ziba is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [Yes, your servant is Ziba]

Ziba is speaking of himself in the third person as **Your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. Alternate translation: [Yes, I am Ziba]

Ziba is responding to David with the courteous expression that a person in this culture would use to tell a superior that he had heard a summons and was ready and willing to obey. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Yes, I am Ziba, and I am ready to obey you]

bsb_verse_text: So the king asked, “Is there anyone left of the house of Saul to whom I can show the kindness of God?” Ziba answered, “There is still Jonathan’s son, who is lame in both feet.”
ult_verse_text: And the king said, “{Is there} no longer a man to the house of Saul, that I may do with him the covenant faithfulness of God?”

notes.note: Here the masculine term **a man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [a person] or [anyone]

David is using the possessive form **the covenant faithfulness of God** to mean the covenant faithfulness that he will show to such a person because of the oath he swore to God. He does not mean God’s own covenant faithfulness. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [the covenant faithfulness that I swore to God I would do]

bsb_verse_text: “Where is he?” replied the king. And Ziba said, “Indeed, he is in Lo-debar at the house of Machir son of Ammiel.”
ult_verse_text: And the king said to him, “Where {is} he?”

notes.note: Ziba is using the term **behold** to focus his listeners’ attention on what he is about to say. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [I will tell you]

bsb_verse_text: And when Mephibosheth son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, came to David, he fell facedown in reverence. Then David said, “Mephibosheth!” “I am your servant,” he replied.
ult_verse_text: And Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, came to David, and he fell on his face, and he prostrated himself.

notes.note: Be sure that it is clear in your translation that Mephibosheth did not fall down accidentally. He knelt down in front of David, pressing his face to the ground and stretching himself out completely, as a gesture to honor David. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [and he knelt down and pressed his face to the ground in front of David, stretching himself out completely, to show David great honor]

Mephibosheth is speaking of himself in the third person as **your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. Alternate translation: [Behold me]

Mephibosheth is responding to David with the courteous expression that a person in this culture would use to tell a superior that he had heard a summons and was ready and willing to obey. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. The meaning here is the same as for the expression “Behold me” in [1:7](../01/07.md). See how you translated that expression there.

bsb_verse_text: “Do not be afraid,” said David, “for surely I will show you kindness for the sake of your father Jonathan. I will restore to you all the land of your grandfather Saul, and you will always eat at my table.”
ult_verse_text: And David said to him, “Do not fear, for doing, I will do covenant faithfulness with you for the sake of Jonathan your father. And I will restore to you all of the field of Saul your father, and you yourself will eat bread at my table continually.”

notes.orig_language_quote: אַל־תִּירָ֗א כִּ֣י עָשֹׂה֩ אֶעֱשֶׂ֨ה עִמְּ⁠ךָ֥ חֶ֨סֶד֙ בַּֽ⁠עֲבוּר֙ יְהוֹנָתָ֣ן אָבִ֔י⁠ךָ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Doing, I will do covenant faithfulness with you for the sake of Jonathan your father, so do not fear]

David is repeating forms of the verb **do** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [I will certainly do]

In this verse, the word **field** is singular in form, but it refers to all of Saul’s agricultural lands. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “field.” Alternate translation: [the fields of] or [the lands of]
Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship. Saul was actually the father of the father of Mephibosheth. Alternate translation: [Saul your grandfather]

David is using **bread** to represent food in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [food] or [meals]

David is using the term **table** to represent eating meals as part of his household. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [with the rest of my household]

bsb_verse_text: Mephibosheth bowed down and said, “What is your servant, that you should show regard for a dead dog like me?”
ult_verse_text: And he prostrated himself, and he said, “What {is} your servant, that you should turn to a dead dog that {is} like me?”

notes.orig_language_quote: מֶ֣ה עַבְדֶּ֑⁠ךָ כִּ֣י פָנִ֔יתָ אֶל־הַ⁠כֶּ֥לֶב הַ⁠מֵּ֖ת אֲשֶׁ֥ר כָּמֽוֹ⁠נִי
notes.note: Mephibosheth is using the question form to express humility and to emphasize that he does not deserve such kindness. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Your servant is not anyone important, that you should turn to a dead dog that is like me!]

Mephibosheth is speaking as if David would physically **turn** toward him. In this context, **turn to** represents “show regard for” or “show kindness to.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [that you should show any regard for]

Mephibosheth is speaking as if he were actually a **dead dog**. In this culture, dogs were wild, and they were considered dirty and regarded with contempt. Moreover, a **dead dog** would be powerless. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 24:14](../../1sa/24/14.md). Alternate translation: [someone like me who is powerless and whom people regard with contempt]

bsb_verse_text: Then the king summoned Saul’s servant Ziba and said to him, “I have given to your master’s grandson all that belonged to Saul and to all his house.
ult_verse_text: And the king called to Ziba, the young man of Saul, and he said to him, “All that was to Saul and to all of his house, I have given to the son of your master.

notes.note: While the author refers to Ziba as a **young man** who belonged to Saul, in this context he is using that term to mean “servant,” which is what he calls Ziba in the rest of this chapter. Since Ziba had many grown sons, he was not physically a “young man.” If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use the term “servant” here. Alternate translation: [the servant of Saul]
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:1](../09/01.md). Alternate translation: [his family]

Mephibosheth was actually the son of the son of Ziba’s master. Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship that would be appropriate to use here and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [to the grandson of]

bsb_verse_text: You and your sons and servants are to work the ground for him and bring in the harvest, so that your master’s grandson may have food to eat. But Mephibosheth, your master’s grandson, is always to eat at my table.” Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.
ult_verse_text: And you shall work the land for him, you and your sons and your servants, and you shall bring, that {there} will be bread for the son of your master, that he may eat it. And Mephibosheth, the son of your master, shall eat bread continually at my table.” (Now to Ziba {were} 15 sons and 20 servants.)

notes.note: The word **you** is singular here because David is addressing Ziba directly. However, the context makes clear that David is commanding Ziba’s sons and servants to be involved in these actions as well. It may be more appropriate to use a plural form of “you” in your translation if your language marks that distinction.
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:7](../09/07.md). Alternate translation: [food … meals]
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:7](../09/07.md).

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠לְ⁠צִיבָ֗א חֲמִשָּׁ֥ה עָשָׂ֛ר בָּנִ֖ים וְ⁠עֶשְׂרִ֥ים עֲבָדִֽים
notes.note: Here, the author is providing background information to help readers understand something that happens later in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

bsb_verse_text: And Ziba said to the king, “Your servant will do all that my lord the king has commanded.” So Mephibosheth ate at David’s table like one of the king’s own sons.
ult_verse_text: And Ziba said to the king, “According to all that my lord the king commands his servant, thus shall your servant do.” And Mephibosheth was eating “at my table” like one from the sons of the king.

notes.orig_language_quote: יְצַוֶּ֜ה אֲדֹנִ֤⁠י הַ⁠מֶּ֨לֶךְ֙ אֶת־עַבְדּ֔⁠וֹ כֵּ֖ן יַעֲשֶׂ֣ה עַבְדֶּ֑⁠ךָ
notes.note: Ziba is speaking about David respectfully and about himself humbly in the third person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate his reference to David in the second person and his reference to himself in the first person. Alternate translation: [you, my lord the king, command me, your servant, thus shall I do]

Ziba is using a verb form that describes action in the present. The implication is that he will do not just what David has commanded him on this occasion but also anything further that David might command him in the future regarding Mephibosheth. Use an appropriate verb form in your language to convey this sense.

The author is quoting David’s words directly, perhaps to show that his command was carried out. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: [at his table]

bsb_verse_text: And Mephibosheth had a young son named Mica, and all who dwelt in the house of Ziba were servants of Mephibosheth.
ult_verse_text: Now to Mephibosheth {was} a young son, and his name {was} Mica. And all of the dwelling of the house of Ziba {were} servants to Mephibosheth.

notes.note: Here, **the dwelling of the house** means the people who lived in Ziba’s house, that is, the members of his household. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the members of the household of]

bsb_verse_text: So Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, because he always ate at the king’s table, and he was lame in both feet.
ult_verse_text: But Mephibosheth dwelled in Jerusalem, for he was continually eating at the table of the king. And he {was} lame, the two of his feet.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠מְפִיבֹ֗שֶׁת יֹשֵׁב֙ בִּ⁠יר֣וּשָׁלִַ֔ם כִּ֣י עַל־שֻׁלְחַ֥ן הַ⁠מֶּ֛לֶךְ תָּמִ֖יד ה֣וּא אֹכֵ֑ל
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [But since Mephibosheth was continually eating at the table of the king, he dwelled in Jerusalem]

Here, the author is providing background information to help readers understand something that happens later in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

bsb_verse_text: Some time later, the king of the Ammonites died and was succeeded by his son Hanun.
ult_verse_text: And it happened after this that the king of the sons of Ammon died, and Hanun his son reigned in place of him.

notes.note: The author is using the phrase **And it happened** to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event.
See how you translated the similar expression in [8:12](../08/12.md). Alternate translation: [the Ammonites]

bsb_verse_text: And David said, “I will show kindness to Hanun son of Nahash, just as his father showed kindness to me.” So David sent some of his servants to console Hanun concerning his father. But when they arrived in the land of the Ammonites,
ult_verse_text: And David said, “I will do kindness with Hanun the son of Nahash, just as his father did kindness with me.” And David sent by the hand of his servants to console him concerning his father.

notes.note: In this instance, the author is using the term **said** to introduce what David was thinking or saying to himself. David did not necessarily say this out loud to anyone. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing what people say to themselves or think. Alternate translation: [And David thought]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֹּ֨אמֶר דָּוִ֜ד אֶעֱשֶׂה־חֶ֣סֶד ׀ עִם־חָנ֣וּן בֶּן־נָחָ֗שׁ כַּ⁠אֲשֶׁר֩ עָשָׂ֨ה אָבִ֤י⁠ו עִמָּדִ⁠י֙ חֶ֔סֶד
notes.note: The author presents David’s thoughts as a direct quotation. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: [And David decided that he should do kindness with Hanun the son of Nahash, just as his father had done kindness with him]

Here, the **hand** of David’s servants represents their agency in acting with David’s authority as his representatives. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And David sent some of his servants as his representatives]

bsb_verse_text: the princes of the Ammonites said to Hanun their lord, “Just because David has sent you comforters, do you really believe he is showing respect for your father? Has not David instead sent his servants to explore the city, spy it out, and overthrow it?”
ult_verse_text: And the commanders of the sons of Ammon said to Hanun their master, “In your eyes, is David honoring your father, since he has sent consolers to you? {Is it} not in order to explore the city and to spy on it and to overthrow it {that} David has sent his servants to you?”

notes.orig_language_quote: הַֽ⁠מְכַבֵּ֨ד דָּוִ֤ד אֶת־אָבִ֨י⁠ךָ֙ בְּ⁠עֵינֶ֔י⁠ךָ כִּֽי־שָׁלַ֥ח לְ⁠ךָ֖ מְנַֽחֲמִ֑ים
notes.note: The advisors are using the question form to deny emphatically that David was honoring Hanun’s father. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You should not believe that David is honoring your father by sending consolers to you!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [In your opinion]

notes.orig_language_quote: הַֽ⁠מְכַבֵּ֨ד דָּוִ֤ד אֶת־אָבִ֨י⁠ךָ֙ בְּ⁠עֵינֶ֔י⁠ךָ כִּֽי־שָׁלַ֥ח לְ⁠ךָ֖ מְנַֽחֲמִ֑ים
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since David has sent consolers to you, is he honoring your father]

notes.orig_language_quote: הֲ֠⁠לוֹא בַּ⁠עֲב֞וּר חֲק֤וֹר אֶת־הָ⁠עִיר֙ וּ⁠לְ⁠רַגְּלָ֣⁠הּ וּ⁠לְ⁠הָפְכָ֔⁠הּ שָׁלַ֥ח דָּוִ֛ד אֶת־עֲבָדָ֖י⁠ו אֵלֶֽי⁠ךָ
notes.note: The advisors are using the question form to strongly assert that David sent his servants for a different reason, to explore, spy on, and overthrow the city. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [No, David has sent his servants to you in order to explore the city and to spy on it and to overthrow it!]

The terms **explore the city** and **spy on it** mean similar things. The commanders are using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [to investigate the city thoroughly]

The advisors are using one group of people who would be involved in the **overthrow** of their city, the messengers whom they believe to be spies, to represent everyone who would be involved. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [so that he can lead the Israelite army to overthrow it]

bsb_verse_text: So Hanun took David’s servants, shaved off half of each man’s beard, cut off their garments at the hips, and sent them away.
ult_verse_text: So Hanun took the servants of David, and he shaved half of their beard, and he cut their garments in the middle, to their buttocks, and he sent them away.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יְגַלַּח֙ אֶת־חֲצִ֣י זְקָנָ֔⁠ם וַ⁠יִּכְרֹ֧ת אֶת־מַדְוֵי⁠הֶ֛ם בַּ⁠חֵ֖צִי עַ֣ד שְׁתֽוֹתֵי⁠הֶ֑ם
notes.note: Shaving half of the beards of these men and cutting their garments in the middle was a symbolic action by which the Ammonite king sought to humiliate David’s messengers. (See the further discussion in the Introduction to this chapter.) If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and he humiliated them by shaving half of their beard and cutting their garments in the middle, to their buttocks]

In this verse, the word **beard** is singular in form, but it refers to all of the beards of David’s servants. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “beard.” Alternate translation: [their beards]

bsb_verse_text: When this was reported to David, he sent messengers to meet the men, since they had been thoroughly humiliated. The king told them, “Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back, and then return.”
ult_verse_text: And they declared to David, and he sent to meet them, for the men were greatly humiliated. And the king said, “Stay in Jericho until your beard has grown, then you shall return.”

notes.note: Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Someone declared to David] or [David was told]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּשְׁלַ֣ח לִ⁠קְרָאתָ֔⁠ם כִּֽי־הָי֥וּ הָ⁠אֲנָשִׁ֖ים נִכְלָמִ֣ים מְאֹ֑ד
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [and since the men were greatly humiliated, he sent to meet them]

The expression **were greatly humiliated** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [this had greatly humiliated the men]

The author is saying **the king** to mean his messengers, who were speaking on his behalf. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And the king’s messengers told them]

bsb_verse_text: When the Ammonites realized that they had become a stench to David, they hired twenty thousand Aramean foot soldiers from Beth-rehob and Zoba, as well as a thousand men from the king of Maacah and twelve thousand men from Tob.
ult_verse_text: And the sons of Ammon saw that they had made themselves stink to David. So the sons of Ammon sent and hired Aram of Beth Rehob and Aram of Zoba, 20, 000 footsoldiers, and the king of Maacah, 1, 000 men, and a man of Tob, 12, 000 men.

notes.note: The author is speaking as if the Ammonites had made themselves smell so bad that they were offensive to David. He is using this image to mean that the Ammonites had provoked David. Your language may have a comparable image that you could use in your translation. You could also use plain language. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 13:4](../../1sa/13/04.md). Alternate translation: [they had incensed David] or [they had provoked David]

notes.orig_language_quote: אֶת־אֲרַ֨ם בֵּית־רְח֜וֹב וְ⁠אֶת־אֲרַ֣ם צוֹבָ֗א עֶשְׂרִ֥ים אֶ֨לֶף֙ רַגְלִ֔י וְ⁠אֶת־מֶ֤לֶךְ מַֽעֲכָה֙ אֶ֣לֶף אִ֔ישׁ וְ⁠אִ֣ישׁ ט֔וֹב שְׁנֵים־עָשָׂ֥ר אֶ֖לֶף אִֽישׁ
notes.note: The author is using the names of each of these kingdoms to represent soldiers from those kingdoms. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [20,000 footsoldiers from Aram of Beth-Rehob and Aram of Zoba, 1,000 men of the king of Maacah, and 12,000 men of Tob]

The author is not referring to a specific **man of Tob**. He means men from Tob in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and men from Tob]

bsb_verse_text: On hearing this, David sent Joab and the entire army of mighty men.
ult_verse_text: And David heard, and he sent Joab and all of the army, the mighty.

notes.note: The expressions **all of the army** and **the mighty** mean similar things. The author is using the two expressions together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [all of the valiant warriors]

The author is using the adjective **mighty** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. In context, he seems to mean regular army soldiers who were experienced in warfare, as opposed to other men capable of fighting who would be summoned when large armies were needed. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the elite soldiers]

bsb_verse_text: The Ammonites marched out and arrayed themselves for battle at the entrance of the city gate, while the Arameans of Zobah and Rehob and the men of Tob and Maacah were by themselves in the open country.
ult_verse_text: And the sons of Ammon came out and arrayed {for} battle {at} the entrance of the gate. And Aram of Zobah and Rehob and a man of Tob and Maacah {were} by themselves in the field.

notes.note: The author is using one central location in the city wall, **the entrance of the gate**, to represent the entire wall, which served as a defensive support for the Ammonite battle line. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of the city wall]
See how you translated the similar expression in [10:6](../10/06.md). Alternate translation: [and the men from Tob]

bsb_verse_text: When Joab saw the battle lines before him and behind him, he selected some of the best men of Israel and arrayed them against the Arameans.
ult_verse_text: And Joab saw that the faces of the battle were against him from before and from behind, and he chose from all of the chosen of Israel, and he arrayed {them} to meet Aram.

notes.orig_language_quote: הָיְתָ֤ה אֵלָי⁠ו֙ פְּנֵ֣י הַ⁠מִּלְחָמָ֔ה מִ⁠פָּנִ֖ים וּ⁠מֵֽ⁠אָח֑וֹר
notes.note: Here, **the faces of the battle** represents the battle lines that the enemy armies had drawn up in order to fight the Israelites. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [there were battle fronts ahead of him and behind him]

The author is using the adjective **chosen** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the chosen troops]

The expression **chosen** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the select troops] or [the elite troops]

bsb_verse_text: And he placed the rest of the troops under the command of his brother Abishai, who arrayed them against the Ammonites.
ult_verse_text: And the rest of the people he put in the hand of Abishai his brother, and he arrayed {them} to meet the sons of Ammon.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [the army]

Here, **hand** represents control. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [under the control of] or [under the command of]
The pronoun **he** refers to Abishai. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [and Abishai arrayed {them}]

bsb_verse_text: “If the Arameans are too strong for me,” said Joab, “then you will come to my rescue. And if the Ammonites are too strong for you, then I will come to your rescue.
ult_verse_text: And he said, “If Aram is stronger than me, then you shall be to me for salvation, but if the sons of Ammon are stronger than you, then I will come to save you.

notes.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Joab. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And Joab said]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **salvation**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [then you shall come and save me]

bsb_verse_text: Be strong and let us fight bravely for our people and for the cities of our God. May the LORD do what is good in His sight.”
ult_verse_text: Be strong, and let us use our strength for the sake of our people and for the sake of the cities of our God. And may Yahweh do the good in his eyes.”

notes.note: Here, **the cities of our God** represents the cities of Israel, where the true God was worshiped. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [our Israelite cities]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [as he sees fit] or [what he considers to be right]

bsb_verse_text: So Joab and his troops advanced to fight the Arameans, who fled before him.
ult_verse_text: Then Joab and the people who {were} with him approached for battle against Aram, and they fled from his face.

notes.note: The author is using one part of Joab, his **face**, to represent all of him in the act of leading an attack against the Arameans. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from him as he led the attack]

bsb_verse_text: When the Ammonites saw that the Arameans had fled, they too fled before Abishai, and they entered the city. So Joab returned from fighting against the Ammonites and came to Jerusalem.
ult_verse_text: And the sons of Ammon saw that Aram had fled, and they fled from the face of Abishai, and they entered the city. Then Joab returned from against the sons of Ammon, and he came {to} Jerusalem.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [from Abishai as he led the attack]

bsb_verse_text: When the Arameans saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they regrouped.
ult_verse_text: And Aram saw that it had been struck to the face of Israel, and they gathered themselves together.

notes.note: The author is using the name of this people group, **Aram**, to represent the soldiers of its army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And the Arameans saw that they had been struck]

Here, **struck** represents “defeated.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. See the discussion of the term “struck” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [it had been defeated] or [they had been defeated]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:17](../02/17.md). Alternate translation: [as it opposed Israel] or [as they opposed Israel]

The expression **it had been struck** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the Israelites had defeated them in battle]

bsb_verse_text: Hadadezer sent messengers to bring more Arameans from beyond the Euphrates, and they came to Helam with Shobach the commander of Hadadezer’s army leading them.
ult_verse_text: And Hadadezer sent, and he brought out Aram that {was} from beyond the River, and they came {to} Helam. And Shobach, the commander of the army of Hadadezer, {was} to their faces.

notes.note: The author is referring to the Euphrates River, which was the most important river in this region and so was sometimes simply called **the River**. You could use your language’s name for this river if that would be helpful to your readers. See how you translated the similar expression in [8:3](../08/03.md). Alternate translation: [the Euphrates River]

This expression depicts Shobach as being in front of this combined army, and the author is using that position to represent his leadership of the army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [was leading them] or [was commanding them]

bsb_verse_text: When this was reported to David, he gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan, and went to Helam. Then the Arameans arrayed themselves against David and fought against him.
ult_verse_text: And it was declared to David, and he gathered all of Israel, and he crossed the Jordan, and he came toward Helam. And Aram arrayed themselves to meet David, and they fought with him.

notes.note: The expression **it was declared to David** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Someone declared to David]

The author is using the name **Israel** to represent the soldiers of the Israelite army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the whole Israelite army]

bsb_verse_text: But the Arameans fled before Israel, and David killed seven hundred charioteers and forty thousand foot soldiers. He also struck down Shobach the commander of their army, who died there.
ult_verse_text: And Aram fled from the face of Israel, and David killed from Aram 700 charioteers and 40, 000 horsemen. And he struck Shobach, the commander of his army, and he died there.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [10:14](../10/14.md). Alternate translation: [from the Israelites as they attacked]

The author is using one person who was involved in this action of the Israelite army, **David**, to represent the entire army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and David’s army killed] or [and David’s forces defeated]

The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 19:18](../../1ch/19/18.md) reads “footsoldiers” instead of **horsemen**. So does the Septuagint, an ancient Greek translation. (It is possible that here in 2 Samuel and in that passage in 1 Chronicles the biblical author is mentioning one kind of soldier in order to mean soldiers in general. The UST models one way to express that meaning, which would be the same in both cases.) If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אֵ֨ת שׁוֹבַ֧ךְ שַׂר־צְבָא֛⁠וֹ הִכָּ֖ה וַ⁠יָּ֥מָת שָֽׁם
notes.note: The pronoun **he** refers to David and his soldiers in the first instance, and it refers to Shobach in the second instance. The pronoun **his** refers to Hadadezer. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And David and his soldiers struck Shobach, the commander of Hadadezer’s army, and Shobach died there]

bsb_verse_text: When all the kings who were subject to Hadadezer saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they made peace with Israel and became subject to them. So the Arameans were afraid to help the Ammonites anymore.
ult_verse_text: And all of the kings, servants of Hadadezer, saw that they had been struck to the face of Israel, and they made peace with Israel, and they served them.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [10:15](../10/15.md). Alternate translation: [the Israelites had defeated them in battle]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [and they asked to have peaceful relations with Israel]

bsb_verse_text: In the spring, at the time when kings march out to war, David sent out Joab and his servants with the whole army of Israel. They destroyed the Ammonites and besieged Rabbah, but David remained in Jerusalem.
ult_verse_text: And it happened, at the return of the year, at the time of the going out of kings, that David sent Joab and his servants with him and all of Israel, and they destroyed the sons of Ammon, and they besieged against Rabbah. But David stayed in Jerusalem.

notes.note: The author is using the phrase **And it happened** to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event.

Here, **at the return of the year** was a common expression that referred to the beginning of a new year. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [at the start of the next year]

The people in this culture considered that a new year began in the spring, when they could once again start the cycle of planting and harvesting crops. You could indicate this in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [in the spring]

The author says **going out** as a common expression that meant “going to war.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:25](../03/25.md). Alternate translation: [in the season when kings go to war]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:6](../07/06.md). Alternate translation: [the Ammonites]

bsb_verse_text: One evening David got up from his bed and strolled around on the roof of the palace. And from the roof he saw a woman bathing—a very beautiful woman.
ult_verse_text: And it happened, at the time of the evening, that David arose from his bed and walked about on the roof of the house of the king. And from the roof he saw a woman bathing. And the woman {was} very good of appearance.

notes.note: The author is using the phrase **And it happened** to introduce a new development in this episode. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

This culture considered the **evening** to begin once the day had become cooler. Some cultures would describe that time as “late afternoon” rather than evening. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could describe what the author means here. Alternate translation: [after the hottest part of the day]
Since David is the subject of this sentence, it may be more natural in your language to refer to his **house** or palace with a pronoun. Alternate translation: [his house] or [his palace]

bsb_verse_text: So David sent and inquired about the woman, and he was told, “This is Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam and the wife of Uriah the Hittite.”
ult_verse_text: And David sent and inquired about the woman. And one said, “Is this not Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?”

notes.note: The phrase **sent and inquired** expresses a single idea. The word **inquired** tells for what purpose David **sent** someone. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [And David sent to inquire]
Here the author is using **one** in a general sense, not to refer to a specific person. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And he was told]

notes.orig_language_quote: הֲ⁠לוֹא־זֹאת֙ בַּת־שֶׁ֣בַע בַּת־אֱלִיעָ֔ם אֵ֖שֶׁת אוּרִיָּ֥ה הַ⁠חִתִּֽי
notes.note: The messenger is using the question form to give information to David. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [The woman is Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite.]

bsb_verse_text: Then David sent messengers to get her, and when she came to him, he slept with her. (Now she had just purified herself from her uncleanness.) Then she returned home.
ult_verse_text: And David sent messengers, and he took her. And she came to him, and he lay with her. (Now she had been sanctifying herself from her uncleanness.) And she returned to her house.

notes.note: The author is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **lay with her**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [and he slept with her]

The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. He is explaining that Bathsheba had been washing herself in order to restore ceremonial cleanness at the end of the seven-day period of uncleanness that followed her monthly period. This meant that she was at the time in her monthly cycle when she could conceive a child when David had sexual relations with her. In your translation, introduce this background information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

bsb_verse_text: And the woman conceived and sent word to David, saying, “I am pregnant.”
ult_verse_text: Αnd the woman became pregnant, and she sent and declared to David, and she said, “I {am} pregnant.”

notes.note: The author is using Bathsheba (referring to her with the pronoun **she**) to represent the person she **sent** to give this message to David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and the person she sent said on her behalf]

bsb_verse_text: At this, David sent orders to Joab: “Send me Uriah the Hittite.” So Joab sent him to David.
ult_verse_text: And David sent to Joab, “Send Uriah the Hittite to me.” So Joab sent Uriah to David.

notes.note: It may be natural in your language to use a term such as “saying” to introduce the direct quotation that follows this phrase.

bsb_verse_text: When Uriah came to him, David asked how Joab and the troops were doing and how the war was going.
ult_verse_text: And Uriah came to him, and David asked about the welfare of Joab and about the welfare of the people and about the welfare of the war.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [the army]

The author is speaking of **the war** as if it were a living thing that could experience **welfare** or well-being. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and about whether the Israelites were winning the war]

bsb_verse_text: Then he said to Uriah, “Go down to your house and wash your feet.” So Uriah left the palace, and a gift from the king followed him.
ult_verse_text: And David said to Uriah, “Go down to your house, and wash your feet.” And Uriah went out from the house of the king, and a gift {from} the king went out after him.

notes.note: In keeping with what is usual for his language and culture, David is marking travel for change in elevation. His palace was on the highest mountain in Jerusalem, so Uriah would have to go **down** from there to get to his **house**. If this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [Go]

In this culture, people wore sandals or went barefoot, and so their feet became dirty during work and travel. They would wash their feet when they returned home for the day and intended to do no further work or traveling. When David tells Uriah **wash your feet**, the implication is that he should consider himself to be finished with his military mission of bringing news from the battlefield. You could indicate this in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and consider yourself to be off duty]

The author is speaking of **a gift** as if it were a living thing that could have gone out from the palace on its own. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and the king sent messengers with a gift]

The implication is that this **gift** was special food that David had told someone to prepare. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and a choice portion of food]

bsb_verse_text: But Uriah slept at the door of the palace with all his master’s servants; he did not go down to his house.
ult_verse_text: But Uriah lay down {at} the entrance of the house of the king with all of the servants of his master, and he did not go down to his house.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּשְׁכַּ֣ב אוּרִיָּ֗ה פֶּ֚תַח בֵּ֣ית הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ אֵ֖ת כָּל־עַבְדֵ֣י אֲדֹנָ֑י⁠ו וְ⁠לֹ֥א יָרַ֖ד אֶל־בֵּיתֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information that Uriah did not go to his house as David told him to do before the new information about what he did instead. Alternate translation: [But Uriah did not go down to his house. Instead, lay down at the entrance of the house of the king with all of the servants of his master]

bsb_verse_text: And David was told, “Uriah did not go home.” “Haven’t you just arrived from a journey?” David asked Uriah. “Why didn’t you go home?”
ult_verse_text: And they declared to David, saying, “Uriah did not go down to his house.” And David said to Uriah, “Are you not coming from a journey? Why did you not go down to your house?”

notes.note: Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And someone declared to David] or [And David was told]

notes.orig_language_quote: הֲ⁠ל֤וֹא מִ⁠דֶּ֨רֶךְ֙ אַתָּ֣ה בָ֔א מַדּ֖וּעַ לֹֽא־יָרַ֥דְתָּ אֶל־בֵּיתֶֽ⁠ךָ
notes.note: David is using the question form for emphasis, to express his disapproval of Uriah not going to his house. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [You are coming from a journey! You should have gone down to your house!]

bsb_verse_text: Uriah answered, “The ark and Israel and Judah are dwelling in tents, and my master Joab and his soldiers are camped in the open field. How can I go to my house to eat and drink and sleep with my wife? As surely as you live, and as your soul lives, I will not do such a thing!”
ult_verse_text: And Uriah said to David, “The Box and Israel and Judah are dwelling in tents, and my master Joab and the servants of my master {are} camping on the face of the field. And I, shall I go to my house to eat and to drink and to lie with my wife? Your life, and the life of your soul, I will not do this thing!”

notes.note: Uriah is using **the face of the field** as a common expression of his culture to mean “the surface of the field.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [on the bare earth] or [on the surface of the ground]

Uriah is not referring to a specific **field**. He means open ground in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the ground]

Uriah is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **to lie with my wife**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [and to sleep with my wife]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠אֲנִ֞י אָב֧וֹא אֶל־בֵּיתִ֛⁠י לֶ⁠אֱכֹ֥ל וְ⁠לִ⁠שְׁתּ֖וֹת וְ⁠לִ⁠שְׁכַּ֣ב עִם־אִשְׁתִּ֑⁠י
notes.note: Uriah is using the question form for emphasis, to express his strong conviction that he should not go to his house. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [So I myself should not go to my house to eat and to drink and to lie with my wife!]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [And shall I, for my part, go]

Following the custom of his culture, Uriah is swearing an oath and guaranteeing it by something that he holds sacred. In your translation, express this in such a way that your readers will recognize it as an oath. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [I swear by your life, the life of your soul] or [As you live and breathe]

The terms **life** and **life of your soul** mean similar things. Uriah is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [I swear by your very life]

bsb_verse_text: Then David invited Uriah to eat and drink with him, and he got Uriah drunk. And in the evening Uriah went out to lie down on his cot with his master’s servants, but he did not go home.
ult_verse_text: And David called to him, and he ate to his face, and he drank, and he got him drunk. But he went out in the evening to lie down in his bed with the servants of his master, and he did not go down to his house.

notes.note: The pronouns **he** refer to Uriah in the first two instances and to David in the third instance. The pronoun **his** refers to David. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [and Uriah ate to David’s face, and Uriah drank, and David got him drunk]

The author is speaking of David’s **face** to represent his presence. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in his presence] or [as his guest]

bsb_verse_text: The next morning David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it with Uriah.
ult_verse_text: And it happened in the morning that David wrote a letter to Joab, and he sent {it} by the hand of Uriah.

notes.note: The author is using the phrase **And it happened** to introduce a new development in this episode. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

The author is using the term **hand** to indicate that Uriah was the agent who delivered the letter to Joab. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [8:10](../08/10.md). Alternate translation: [and he had Uriah deliver it]

bsb_verse_text: In the letter he wrote: “Put Uriah at the front of the fiercest battle; then withdraw from him, so that he may be struck down and killed.”
ult_verse_text: And he wrote in the letter, saying, “Put Uriah in the front of the face of the strongest battle, and turn them back from behind him so he will be struck and die.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [10:9](../10/09.md). Alternate translation: [the deadliest battle front]
The pronoun **them** refers to the other soldiers who were fighting with Uriah. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [and turn the other soldiers back]

The expression **will be struck** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [so that the Ammonites will strike him and he will die]

bsb_verse_text: So as Joab besieged the city, he assigned Uriah to a place where he knew the strongest enemy soldiers were.
ult_verse_text: And it happened, when Joab looked at the city, that he put Uriah in the place where he knew that men of valor {were} there.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:7](../02/07.md). Alternate translation: [valiant warriors]

bsb_verse_text: And when the men of the city came out and fought against Joab, some of David’s servants fell, and Uriah the Hittite also died.
ult_verse_text: And the men of the city came out, and they fought with Joab, and some of the people from the servants of David fell. And Uriah the Hittite also died.

notes.note: The author is using **Joab** to represent his entire army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [against Joab’s army]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:7](../02/07.md). Alternate translation: [and some of the people from the servants of David died]

By **the people**, the author means the Israelite army. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [the soldiers in David’s army]

bsb_verse_text: Joab sent to David a full account of the battle
ult_verse_text: And Joab sent, and he declared to David all of the things of the battle.

notes.note: The author is speaking as if Joab himself **declared** this to David. The author means that Joab sent a messenger to speak to David on his behalf. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And Joab sent a messenger, and that messenger declared]

bsb_verse_text: and instructed the messenger, “When you have finished giving the king a full account of the battle,
ult_verse_text: And he commanded the messenger, saying, “When you have finished to speak to the king all of the things of the battle,

notes.note: Joab is saying **all of the things of the battle** as a generalization. Since Joab expects that the messenger will not initially tell David that Uriah has been killed, the word **all** might not be appropriate in your language. If it would be clearer in your language, you could indicate that **all** is a generalization. Alternate translation: [a general report about the battle]

bsb_verse_text: if the king’s anger flares, he may ask you, ‘Why did you get so close to the city to fight? Did you not realize they would shoot from atop the wall?
ult_verse_text: it will be, if the heat of the king rises and he says to you, ‘Why did you draw near to the city to fight? Did you not know that they would shoot from the wall?

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [6:7](../06/07.md). Alternate translation: [the king becomes angry]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אָמַ֣ר לְ⁠ךָ֔ מַדּ֛וּעַ נִגַּשְׁתֶּ֥ם אֶל־הָ⁠עִ֖יר לְ⁠הִלָּחֵ֑ם הֲ⁠ל֣וֹא יְדַעְתֶּ֔ם אֵ֥ת אֲשֶׁר־יֹר֖וּ מֵ⁠עַ֥ל הַ⁠חוֹמָֽה
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [he may ask you why we drew near to the city to fight. He may say that we should have known that they would shoot from the wall.]

notes.orig_language_quote: מַדּ֛וּעַ נִגַּשְׁתֶּ֥ם אֶל־הָ⁠עִ֖יר לְ⁠הִלָּחֵ֑ם הֲ⁠ל֣וֹא יְדַעְתֶּ֔ם אֵ֥ת אֲשֶׁר־יֹר֖וּ מֵ⁠עַ֥ל הַ⁠חוֹמָֽה
notes.note: Joab anticipates that David may use the question form to rebuke the army for fighting so close to the city wall. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [You should not have drawn near to the city to fight! You should have known that they would shoot from the wall!]

The word **you** is plural here because David would be addressing all of the Israelite soldiers. So use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction. Alternate translation: [did you soldiers draw near … Did you soldiers not know]

bsb_verse_text: Who struck Abimelech son of Jerubbesheth? Was it not a woman who dropped an upper millstone on him from the wall, so that he died in Thebez? Why did you get so close to the wall?’ If he asks you this, then you are to say, ‘Your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead as well.’”
ult_verse_text: Who struck Abimelech, the son of Jerubbesheth? Did not a woman throw a piece of a millstone onto him from the wall, and he died in Thebez? Why did you draw near to the wall?’ then you shall say, ‘Your servant Uriah the Hittite is also dead.’”

notes.orig_language_quote: מִֽי־הִכָּ֞ה אֶת־אֲבִימֶ֣לֶךְ בֶּן־יְרֻבֶּ֗שֶׁת הֲ⁠לֽוֹא־אִשָּׁ֡ה הִשְׁלִ֣יכָה עָלָי⁠ו֩ פֶּ֨לַח רֶ֜כֶב מֵ⁠עַ֤ל הַֽ⁠חוֹמָה֙ וַ⁠יָּ֣מָת בְּ⁠תֵבֵ֔ץ לָ֥⁠מָּה נִגַּשְׁתֶּ֖ם אֶל־הַֽ⁠חוֹמָ֑ה
notes.note: If, in the previous verse, you translated the first two questions that Joab suggests David might ask so that there was not a quotation within a quotation, you can continue doing that here. Alternate translation: [He may ask you who struck Abimelech the son of Jerubbesheth. He may ask whether it was not a woman who threw a piece of a millstone onto him from the wall so that he died in Thebez. He may ask you why we drew near to the wall]

notes.orig_language_quote: מִֽי־הִכָּ֞ה אֶת־אֲבִימֶ֣לֶךְ בֶּן־יְרֻבֶּ֗שֶׁת הֲ⁠לֽוֹא־אִשָּׁ֡ה הִשְׁלִ֣יכָה עָלָי⁠ו֩ פֶּ֨לַח רֶ֜כֶב מֵ⁠עַ֤ל הַֽ⁠חוֹמָה֙ וַ⁠יָּ֣מָת בְּ⁠תֵבֵ֔ץ לָ֥⁠מָּה נִגַּשְׁתֶּ֖ם אֶל־הַֽ⁠חוֹמָ֑ה
notes.note: Joab continues to anticipate that David may use the question form to rebuke the army. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [Remember who struck Abimelech the son of Jerubbesheth! It was a woman who threw a piece of a millstone onto him from the wall, so that he died in Thebez! You should not have drawn near to the wall!]

**Jerubbesheth** is another name for the person who is called Jerubbaal in the book of Judges. (That was a second name that people gave to Gideon.) Here in this book, either the original author or later scribes did not want to reproduce the name “Baal,” since that was the name of a foreign god whom the Israelites detested. So the author or scribes replaced “baal” with “besheth,” a Hebrew word that means “shame.” We recommend that you use the name **Jerubbesheth** in your translation to reflect this. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain in a footnote that this is the same person known as Jerubbaal or Gideon in Judges.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אָ֣מַרְתָּ֔ גַּ֗ם עַבְדְּ⁠ךָ֛ אוּרִיָּ֥ה הַ⁠חִתִּ֖י מֵֽת
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [then you shall tell him that his servant Uriah the Hittite is also dead]

bsb_verse_text: The messenger said to David, “The men overpowered us and came out against us in the field, but we drove them back to the entrance of the gate.
ult_verse_text: And the messenger said to David that “the men became strong against us and they came out against us {to} the field, but we were against them to the entrance of the gate.

notes.note: The author is using the term **that** to introduce a direct quotation from the messenger. This is a shorter version of the usual introductory phrase. More typically he would write, “And the messenger spoke to David, saying.” This shorter form suggests the haste with which the messenger gave this report, fearing that David would become angry. Your language may have a way of introducing quotations that would similarly suggest this. Some languages may not need to use any introductory term. Alternate translation: [And the messenger told David, “The men]

The messenger is using **the men became strong against us** as a common expression of his culture to mean that the Ammonites organized a force to attack the Israelites. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the men organized a force against us]

The messenger is using **we were against them** as a common expression of his culture to mean that the Israelite soldiers repulsed this attack. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [but we drove them back]
See how you translated the similar expression in [10:8](../10/08.md). Alternate translation: [to in front of the city wall]

bsb_verse_text: Then the archers shot at your servants from the wall, and some of the king’s servants were killed. And your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead as well.”
ult_verse_text: And the shooters shot at your servants from the wall, and some of the servants of the king died, and also your servant Uriah the Hittite died.”

notes.note: Even though the messenger is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [some of your servants]

bsb_verse_text: Then David told the messenger, “Say this to Joab: ‘Do not let this matter upset you, for the sword devours one as well as another. Strengthen your attack against the city and demolish it.’ Encourage him with these words.”
ult_verse_text: And David said to the messenger, “Thus you shall say to Joab, ‘May this matter not be bad in your eyes, for like this and like this the sword devours. Strengthen your battle against the city and destroy it.’ So strengthen him.”

notes.orig_language_quote: כֹּֽה־תֹאמַ֤ר אֶל־יוֹאָב֙ אַל־יֵרַ֤ע בְּ⁠עֵינֶ֨י⁠ךָ֙ אֶת־הַ⁠דָּבָ֣ר הַ⁠זֶּ֔ה כִּֽי־כָ⁠זֹ֥ה וְ⁠כָ⁠זֶ֖ה תֹּאכַ֣ל הֶ⁠חָ֑רֶב הַחֲזֵ֨ק מִלְחַמְתְּ⁠ךָ֧ אֶל־הָ⁠עִ֛יר וְ⁠הָרְסָ֖⁠הּ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [Tell Joab not to let this matter be bad in his eyes, for like this and like this the sword devours. Tell him to strengthen his battle against the city and destroy it]

notes.orig_language_quote: אַל־יֵרַ֤ע בְּ⁠עֵינֶ֨י⁠ךָ֙ אֶת־הַ⁠דָּבָ֣ר הַ⁠זֶּ֔ה כִּֽי־כָ⁠זֹ֥ה וְ⁠כָ⁠זֶ֖ה תֹּאכַ֣ל הֶ⁠חָ֑רֶב
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since like this and like this the sword devours, may this matter not be bad in your eyes]

David is using **May this matter not be bad in your eyes** as a common expression of his culture to mean “Do not think that this matter is wrong” or “Do not be troubled about this matter.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Do not believe that you have done the wrong thing in this matter]

Here, **like this and like this** was a common expression that described things as uncertain and unpredictable. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the sword devours people here and there]

Here, David is speaking as if a **sword** were a living thing, such as a wild animal, that **devours** people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [soldiers die in battle here and there]

bsb_verse_text: When Uriah’s wife heard that her husband was dead, she mourned for him.
ult_verse_text: And the wife of Uriah heard that Uriah her man had died. And she lamented for her husband.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠תִּשְׁמַע֙ אֵ֣שֶׁת אֽוּרִיָּ֔ה כִּי־מֵ֖ת אוּרִיָּ֣ה אִישָׁ֑⁠הּ וַ⁠תִּסְפֹּ֖ד עַל־בַּעְלָֽ⁠הּ
notes.note: Here the author describes Uriah as Bathsheba’s husband in two different ways. First he calls him her **man**, perhaps referring more to the personal relationship that they had. Then he calls him her **husband**, using a word that can also mean “lord,” perhaps referring more to their social status in the context of Bathsheba’s public mourning for him. If your language has different terms for this relationship with these shades of meaning, it would be appropriate to use them in your translation.

bsb_verse_text: And when the time of mourning was over, David had her brought to his house, and she became his wife and bore him a son. But the thing that David had done was evil in the sight of the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And the mourning passed, and David sent and gathered her to his house, and she became a wife to him, and she bore a son to him. But the thing that David had done was bad in the eyes of Yahweh.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֵּ֧רַע הַ⁠דָּבָ֛ר אֲשֶׁר־עָשָׂ֥ה דָוִ֖ד בְּ⁠עֵינֵ֥י יְהוָֽה
