notes.note: The author is using the expression **in the eyes of** to mean “in the judgment of” or “in the opinion of.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But the thing that David had done was bad in the judgment of Yahweh] or [But Yahweh considered that David had done an evil thing]

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD sent Nathan to David, and when he arrived, he said, “There were two men in a certain city, one rich and the other poor.
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh sent Nathan to David. And he came to him, and he said to him, “Two men were in one city, one rich and one poor.

notes.note: To help David understand what Yahweh has sent him to say, Nathan tells David a story as if it were true. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could state that explicitly. Alternate translation: [and to help him understand what Yahweh had sent him to say, he told him a story as if it were true. He said to him]

Nathan is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [One man was rich, and the other one was poor]

bsb_verse_text: The rich man had a great number of sheep and cattle,
ult_verse_text: To the rich {one} was flock and herd very greatly.

notes.note: The author is using the adjective **rich** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. The ULT indicates this by adding the word **one**. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [To the rich man]

bsb_verse_text: but the poor man had nothing except one small ewe lamb that he had bought. He raised it, and it grew up with him and his children. It shared his food and drank from his cup; it slept in his arms and was like a daughter to him.
ult_verse_text: But to the poor {man} {was} not anything except one little ewe that he had bought. And he nourished it, and it grew up together with him and with his sons. It would eat from his morsel, and it would drink from his cup, and it would lie down in his lap. And it was like a daughter to him.

notes.note: A **ewe** is a female sheep. If your readers would not be familiar with what a ewe is, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [a young female sheep]

The author is not referring to a specific **morsel**. He means portions of food in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [scraps of food that he gave it]

bsb_verse_text: Now a traveler came to the rich man, who refrained from taking one of his own sheep or cattle to prepare for the traveler who had come to him. Instead, he took the poor man’s lamb and prepared it for his guest.”
ult_verse_text: Now a traveler came to the rich man, and he spared to take from his flock or from his herd to prepare for the wayfarer having come to him, but he took the ewe of the poor man, and he prepared it for the man having come to him.”

notes.note: Nathan uses two different terms to describe the rich man’s guest. The first term, **traveler**, simply refers to someone who is on a journey. The second term, **wayfarer**, refers in this context to a traveler whom someone has taken into his home as a guest. If your language has separate words or phrases that express these ideas, it would be appropriate to use them in your translation. Alternate translation: [a man who was on a journey … his guest]

bsb_verse_text: David burned with anger against the man and said to Nathan: “As surely as the LORD lives, the man who did this deserves to die!
ult_verse_text: And the nose of David burned greatly against the man, and he said to Nathan, “The life of Yahweh, that the man having done this {is} a son of death!

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [6:7](../06/07.md). Alternate translation: [And David became very angry with the man]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:27](../02/27.md). Alternate translation: [I swear by Yahweh]

In certain contexts, biblical authors and characters use the expression **son of** to indicate that a person has the characteristic of something. In this case, David is saying that the rich man has the characteristic of **death**, in the sense that David feels he deserves to die for what he did. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 26:16](../../1sa/26/16.md). Alternate translation: [deserves to die]

bsb_verse_text: Because he has done this thing and has shown no pity, he must pay for the lamb four times over.”
ult_verse_text: Now he shall restore the ewe fourfold because he did this thing and because he did not spare.”

notes.orig_language_quote: עֵ֗קֶב אֲשֶׁ֤ר עָשָׂה֙ אֶת־הַ⁠דָּבָ֣ר הַ⁠זֶּ֔ה וְ⁠עַ֖ל אֲשֶׁ֥ר לֹֽא־חָמָֽל
notes.note: The author is describing one event, **he did this thing**, before describing another event that preceded it, **he did not spare**. If it would be helpful your language, you may wish to relate these events in the order in which they happened, as in the UST. Alternate translation: [because he did not spare but instead did this thing]

David is using the same term, **spare**, that Nathan used in his story. Nathan said that the rich man spared all of the animals in his flock and herd from being butchered, while David means that the rich man did not spare the poor man, that is, he had no pity on him but cruelly took his lamb and butchered it. Your language may have a term that you can use meaningfully in both places in your translation. If not, be sure that the meaning of **spare** in this verse is clear. Alternate translation: [he had no pity on the poor man]

bsb_verse_text: Then Nathan said to David, “You are that man! This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: ‘I anointed you king over Israel, and I delivered you from the hand of Saul.
ult_verse_text: And Nathan said to David, “You {are} the man. Thus says Yahweh, the God of Israel: ‘I, I anointed you as king over Israel, and I, I delivered you from the hand of Saul.

notes.note: Nathan is speaking as if David actually were **the man** in his story. He means that David has done something just like what the man in the story did. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state this as a comparison. Alternate translation: [You are just like that man] or [You have done something just like what that man did]

notes.orig_language_quote: כֹּה־אָמַ֨ר יְהוָ֜ה אֱלֹהֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֗ל אָנֹכִ֞י מְשַׁחְתִּ֤י⁠ךָֽ לְ⁠מֶ֨לֶךְ֙ עַל־יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל וְ⁠אָנֹכִ֥י הִצַּלְתִּ֖י⁠ךָ מִ⁠יַּ֥ד שָׁאֽוּל
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [Yahweh, the God of Israel, says that he himself anointed you as king over Israel and that he himself delivered you from the hand of Saul]

See how you translated the similar expression “you, you were” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: [I personally ensured that the Israelites would anoint you … and I personally delivered you]

Here, **hand** represents the actions of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:18](../03/18.md). Alternate translation: [from Saul when he was trying to kill you]

bsb_verse_text: I gave your master’s house to you and your master’s wives into your arms. I gave you the house of Israel and Judah, and if that was not enough, I would have given you even more.
ult_verse_text: And I gave to you the house of your master, and the wives of your master into your lap, and I gave to you the house of Israel and Judah. And if {this had been} little, then I would have added to you like them and like them.

notes.note: Nathan is continuing to speak a message from Yahweh to David. If, in the previous verse, you started translating this so that there was not a quotation within a quotation, you can continue doing that here and through [verse 12](../12/12.md). Alternate translation: [He says that he gave … and he gave … then he would have added]

The author is using the term **house** by association to mean all the people and property associated with a person. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the property and possessions of]

Yahweh is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and I gave the wives of your master into your lap]

Yahweh is referring to sexual intimacy in a polite way by using the phrase **into your lap**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language, or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [and I allowed you to have your master’s harem as your own harem]

Here, **house** means all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. So **the house of Israel and Judah** figuratively means all the people descended from the patriarch Jacob, who was also known as Israel, including specifically those descended from his son Judah. Alternate translation: [and I made you the king of the people of Israel and Judah]

Here, **like them and like them** was a common expression that described unspecified things similar to ones just mentioned. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [then I would have given to you even more of such things]

bsb_verse_text: Why then have you despised the command of the LORD by doing evil in His sight? You put Uriah the Hittite to the sword and took his wife as your own. You have slain him with the sword of the Ammonites.
ult_verse_text: Why have you despised the word of Yahweh to do evil in my eyes? You struck Uriah the Hittite with the sword, and you took his wife for yourself as a wife, and you murdered him with the sword of the sons of Ammon.

notes.orig_language_quote: מַדּ֜וּעַ בָּזִ֣יתָ ׀ אֶת־דְּבַ֣ר יְהוָ֗ה לַ⁠עֲשׂ֣וֹת הָ⁠רַע֮ בְּעֵינַי֒
notes.note: Yahweh is using the question form to rebuke David. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You should not have despised the word of Yahweh to do evil in my eyes!]

Because he is officially rebuking David, Yahweh is speaking about himself formally in the third person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in the first person. Alternate translation: [my word]

Here, **word** represents the commandments that Yahweh gave by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [my commandments]

Yahweh is using **in my eyes** as a common expression of this culture to mean “in my judgment.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what I regard as evil]

notes.orig_language_quote: אֵ֣ת אוּרִיָּ֤ה הַֽ⁠חִתִּי֙ הִכִּ֣יתָ בַ⁠חֶ֔רֶב וְ⁠אֶ֨ת־אִשְׁתּ֔⁠וֹ לָקַ֥חְתָּ לְּ⁠ךָ֖ לְ⁠אִשָּׁ֑ה וְ⁠אֹת֣⁠וֹ הָרַ֔גְתָּ בְּ⁠חֶ֖רֶב בְּנֵ֥י עַמּֽוֹן
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about Uriah’s murder with the information about striking him with the sword, before the information about David taking his wife. Alternate translation: [You struck Uriah the Hittite with the sword, murdering him with the sword of the sons of Ammon, and then you took his wife for yourself as a wife]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:1](../01/01.md). Alternate translation: [you killed]

Here, **sword** represents warfare, since in this culture people used swords as a primary weapon of war. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [using warfare]

Here, Yahweh is using the **sword**, one kind of weapon, to represent weapons in general. (What the messenger tells David in [11:24](../11/24.md) suggests that the Ammonites actually killed Uriah primarily with arrows.) If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [with the weapons of]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:6](../07/06.md). Alternate translation: [the Ammonites]

bsb_verse_text: Now, therefore, the sword will never depart from your house, because you have despised Me and have taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your own.’
ult_verse_text: And now, the sword will not turn away from your house to forever, because you despised me and took the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be a wife for you.’

notes.orig_language_quote: לֹא־תָס֥וּר חֶ֛רֶב מִ⁠בֵּיתְ⁠ךָ֖ עַד־עוֹלָ֑ם עֵ֚קֶב כִּ֣י בְזִתָ֔⁠נִי וַ⁠תִּקַּ֗ח אֶת־אֵ֨שֶׁת֙ אוּרִיָּ֣ה הַ⁠חִתִּ֔י לִ⁠הְי֥וֹת לְ⁠ךָ֖ לְ⁠אִשָּֽׁה
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [because you despised me and took the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be a wife for you, the sword will not turn away from your house to forever]
Speakers in this culture used the expression **And now** to introduce their main point. See how you translated this expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

The author is speaking of **the sword** as if it were a living thing that could **turn away** and leave David and his family. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [there will always be deadly fighting within your house]

Here, **house** means all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. So **the house** figuratively means all the people descended from David, here and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [from your household] or [from your family]

bsb_verse_text: This is what the LORD says: ‘I will raise up adversity against you from your own house. Before your very eyes I will take your wives and give them to another, and he will lie with them in broad daylight.
ult_verse_text: Thus says Yahweh, ‘Behold me, raising up harm against you from your house. And I will take your wives to your eyes, and I will give {them} to your neighbor. And he will lie with your wives to the eyes of this sun.

notes.note: Here, **Behold me ** was a common expression that speakers used to mean that they were about to do something. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I am about to raise up]

Here, God is speaking as if harm were an object that he could be **raising up** or lifting into a higher position. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [causing harm to happen to you]

Here, the **eyes** represent being aware or conscious of something happening. Yahweh does not necessarily mean that David will see this, but he will know about it. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [with your full awareness]

Yahweh is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **lie with**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [And he will sleep with your wives]

God is speaking of the **sun** as if it were a living thing that had **eyes** and could see. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [out in the open]

bsb_verse_text: You have acted in secret, but I will do this thing in broad daylight before all Israel.’”
ult_verse_text: For you, you did {this} in secret, but I, I will do this thing before all of Israel and before the sun.’”

notes.note: Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but further consideration. Alternate translation: [Indeed]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [For you, for your part, did this in secret, but I, for my part, will do]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **secret**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [secretly]
See how you translated the similar expression about the sun in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [out in the open where any Israelite can see it]

bsb_verse_text: Then David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against the LORD.” “The LORD has taken away your sin,” Nathan replied. “You will not die.
ult_verse_text: And David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against Yahweh.”

notes.note: In this context, the word translated as **also** indicates a correspondence between what David has said, **I have sinned against Yahweh**, and what Yahweh has done, **taken away** his sin. Use a connecting word in your language that shows how Nathan’s statement relates to the statement that David made before it. Alternate translation: [consequently]

bsb_verse_text: Nevertheless, because by this deed you have shown utter contempt for the word of the LORD, the son born to you will surely die.”
ult_verse_text: Nevertheless, because spurning, you have spurned the enemies of Yahweh with this thing, also the son born to you dying, will die.”

notes.note: Nathan is repeating forms of the verb **spurn** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [you have utterly spurned]
See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to this chapter.
The word translated as **also** here has the same meaning as in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [consequently]

Nathan is repeating forms of the verb **die** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [will certainly die]

bsb_verse_text: After Nathan had gone home, the LORD struck the child that Uriah’s wife had borne to David, and he became ill.
ult_verse_text: Then Nathan went to his home.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּגֹּ֣ף יְהוָ֗ה אֶת־הַ⁠יֶּ֜לֶד אֲשֶׁ֨ר יָלְדָ֧ה אֵֽשֶׁת־אוּרִיָּ֛ה לְ⁠דָוִ֖ד וַ⁠יֵּאָנַֽשׁ
notes.note: Here, the author is speaking as Yahweh had physically **struck** a blow against this **child**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And Yahweh caused the child whom the wife of Uriah had borne to David to become sick]
Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship, since Uriah was now dead and Bathsheba was no longer his legal **wife**. Alternate translation: [the widow of Uriah]

bsb_verse_text: David pleaded with God for the boy. He fasted and went into his house and spent the night lying in sackcloth on the ground.
ult_verse_text: And David sought God on behalf of the boy. And David fasted a fast, and he went in and lodged and lay on the ground.

notes.note: Here, the author is speaking as if David had actually **sought** or looked for God somewhere. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And David entreated God]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יָּ֤צָם דָּוִד֙ צ֔וֹם וּ⁠בָ֥א וְ⁠לָ֖ן וְ⁠שָׁכַ֥ב אָֽרְצָ⁠ה
notes.note: Abstaining from food and lying on the ground were symbolic actions by which David expressed deep mourning and humility before God. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of these actions in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [David showed his deep sorrow by refusing to eat and by going inside and spending the night lying on the ground]

It might seem that the expression **fasted a fast** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [And David fasted] or [ And David kept a fast]

The phrase **lodged and lay on the ground** expresses a single idea. The phrase **lay on the ground** tells how David **lodged**, that is, how he slept at night. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [and lodged by lying on the ground] or [and slept on the floor at night]

bsb_verse_text: The elders of his household stood beside him to help him up from the ground, but he was unwilling and would not eat anything with them.
ult_verse_text: And the elders of his house arose upon him to make him arise from the ground, but he was not willing, and he would not eat bread with them.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:3](../02/03.md). Alternate translation: [his household]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [took action regarding]

The author is using **bread** to represent food in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [food]

bsb_verse_text: On the seventh day the child died. But David’s servants were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, for they said, “Look, while the child was alive, we spoke to him, and he would not listen to us. So how can we tell him the child is dead? He may even harm himself.”
ult_verse_text: And it happened on the seventh day that the child died, and the servants of David were afraid to declare to him that the child had died, for they said, “Behold, while the child was living, we spoke to him, but he did not listen to our voice. So how shall we say to him, ‘The child has died’? For he will do harm.”

notes.note: The author is using this phrase to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:2](../01/02.md).

In this verse, the word **voice** is singular in form, but the servants are using it to refer to all of their voices. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “voice.” Alternate translation: [but he did not listen to our voices]

The servants are speaking of their **voice** to represent what they said to David by using their voices. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [but he did not listen to what we said]
See the discussion in the Introduction to 2 Samuel of this use of the term “listen.” Alternate translation: [but he did not agree to do what we said]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [So how can we tell him that the child has died?]

The servants are using the question form to emphasize that they think it would be risky to tell David that his child has died. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [So we cannot safely say to him, ‘The child has died’!]

bsb_verse_text: Then David got up from the ground, washed and anointed himself, changed his clothes, and went into the house of the LORD and worshiped. Then he went to his own house, and at his request they set food before him, and he ate.
ult_verse_text: Then David arose from the ground, and he washed, and he anointed {himself}, and he changed his clothes, and he entered the house of Yahweh, and he prostrated himself. Then he went to his house, and he asked, and they set out bread for him, and he ate.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יָּקָם֩ דָּוִ֨ד מֵ⁠הָ⁠אָ֜רֶץ וַ⁠יִּרְחַ֣ץ וַ⁠יָּ֗סֶךְ וַ⁠יְחַלֵּף֙ שִׂמְלֹתָ֔יו
notes.note: Getting up from the ground, washing, anointing himself, and changing his clothes were symbolic actions by which David showed that he was accepting God’s decision about his child. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [Then David showed that he accepted God’s will regarding the child by getting up from the ground, washing himself, putting olive oil on his hair and body, and changing into clean clothes]

The author is using **bread** to represent food in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [food] or [a meal]

bsb_verse_text: David answered, “While the child was alive, I fasted and wept, for I said, ‘Who knows? The LORD may be gracious to me and let him live.’
ult_verse_text: And he said, “When yet the child {was} alive, I fasted and wept, for I said, ‘Who knows? Yahweh may be gracious to me, and the child may live.’

notes.orig_language_quote: אָמַ֨רְתִּי֙ מִ֣י יוֹדֵ֔עַ יחנ⁠ני יְהוָ֖ה וְ⁠חַ֥י הַ⁠יָּֽלֶד
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [I said that for all anyone knew, Yahweh might be gracious to me and the child might live]
See how you translated the similar expression in [10:2](../10/02.md). Alternate translation: [I thought]

David is using the question form to express uncertainty about what might happen. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [For all anyone knows, Yahweh may be gracious to me]

bsb_verse_text: But now that he is dead, why should I fast? Can I bring him back again? I will go to him, but he will not return to me.”
ult_verse_text: But now, he is dead. Why {is} this, {that} I should fast? Am I able to bring him back again? I am going to him, but he, he will not return to me.”

notes.orig_language_quote: לָ֤⁠מָּה זֶּה֙ אֲנִ֣י צָ֔ם הַ⁠אוּכַ֥ל לַ⁠הֲשִׁיב֖⁠וֹ ע֑וֹד
notes.note: David is using the question form to emphasize that there is no reason to continue fasting since he cannot bring his son back to life. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [I have no reason to fast any longer. I am not able to bring him back again.]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [but he, for his part, will not return]

bsb_verse_text: Then David comforted his wife Bathsheba, and he went to her and lay with her. So she gave birth to a son, and they named him Solomon. Now the LORD loved the child
ult_verse_text: And David consoled Bathsheba his wife, and he came to her and lay with her. And she bore a son, and he called his name Solomon. And Yahweh loved him.

notes.note: The author is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **lay with her**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [and slept with her]

It might seem that the expression **called his name** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [and he called him Solomon]

bsb_verse_text: and sent word through Nathan the prophet to name him Jedidiah because the LORD loved him.
ult_verse_text: And he sent by the hand of Nathan the prophet, and he called his name Jedidiah because of Yahweh.

notes.note: The author is using one part of Nathan, his **hand**, to mean all of him in the act of bringing a message from Yahweh, as if he had carried that message in his hand. Alternate translation: [And Yahweh sent Nathan the prophet to bring a message from him]

The name **Jedidiah** means “beloved of Yahweh.” The pronoun **he** could mean: (1) that Yahweh named the child Jedidiah. Alternate translation: [and Yahweh gave him the name Jedidiah because he loved him]; (2) that Nathan named the child Jedidiah. Alternate translation: [and Nathan called his name Jedidiah, since Yahweh loved him]; (3) that David named the child Jedidiah. Alternate translation: [and David called his name Jedidiah, since Yahweh loved him]
See how you translated the similar expression in [12:24](../12/24.md). Alternate translation: [and he called him]

bsb_verse_text: Meanwhile, Joab fought against Rabbah of the Ammonites and captured the royal fortress.
ult_verse_text: And Joab fought with Rabbah of the sons of Ammon, and he captured the city of the kingdom.

notes.note: The word that the ULT translates as **And** indicates that Joab fought against Rabbah at the same time as when the events described in the previous part of this chapter took place in Jerusalem. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could describe the time relationship more explicitly. Alternate translation: [At the same time, Joab was fighting]

bsb_verse_text: Then Joab sent messengers to David to say, “I have fought against Rabbah and have captured the water supply of the city.
ult_verse_text: And Joab sent messengers to David, and he said, “I have fought against Rabbah. Also, I have captured the city of waters.

notes.note: The author is speaking as if Joab himself **said** this to David. The author means that the messengers Joab sent said this to David on his behalf. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And Joab sent messengers to David, and those messengers said on Joab’s behalf]
See how you translated the similar expression in [12:13](../12/13.md). Alternate translation: [Consequently]

Joab is using the possessive form to describe the part of this **city** that was characterized by **waters**. If your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the part of the city near the water]

bsb_verse_text: Now, therefore, assemble the rest of the troops, lay siege to the city, and capture it. Otherwise I will capture the city, and it will be named after me.”
ult_verse_text: And now, gather the rest of the people and encamp against the city and capture it, lest I myself capture the city and my name be called to it.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [the rest of the army]

The implication is that this was the main fortified part of the city. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the citadel] or [the fortress]

notes.orig_language_quote: פֶּן־אֶלְכֹּ֤ד אֲנִי֙ אֶת־הָ⁠עִ֔יר וְ⁠נִקְרָ֥א שְׁמִ֖⁠י עָלֶֽי⁠הָ
notes.note: Joab is using the word translated as **lest** to introduce an outcome that he does not want to happen. Because he does not want this outcome to happen, he first encourages David to do something so that this will not happen. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that avoiding this outcome is the purpose of the encouragement. Alternate translation: [otherwise, I myself will capture the city and my name will be called to it]

Joab is using **my name be called to it** as a common expression of his culture to mean “people give me credit for capturing it.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and it be named after me]

bsb_verse_text: Then he took the crown from the head of their king. It weighed a talent of gold and was set with precious stones, and it was placed on David’s head. And David took a great amount of plunder from the city.
ult_verse_text: And he took the crown of their king from his head, and its weight {was} a talent of gold, and a precious stone, and it became on the head of David. And he brought out the plunder of the city, very much.

notes.note: A **talent** of gold weighed about 34 kilograms or 75 pounds. In your translation, you could use the ancient measurement and spell the word “talent” the way it sounds in your language. You could also use the metric measurement given in the UST or use the measurement that your language and culture customarily use. Alternatively, you could use the ancient measurement and put a modern measurement in parentheses in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and its weight was 34 kilograms of gold] or [and its weight was 75 pounds of gold]

It is possible that this expression describes the value of the crown rather than its weight, since a crown weighing 34 kilograms or 75 pounds would have been too heavy to wear. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and it was worth a talent of gold]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. He seems to be noting one particular **precious stone** of exceptional value that was in the crown. (One Jewish historian says that it was a very large sardonyx.) This does not mean that there were not other precious stones in the crown as well. Alternate translation: [and one of the stones it contained was especially precious]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [There was very much of it]

bsb_verse_text: After some time, David’s son Amnon fell in love with Tamar, the beautiful sister of David’s son Absalom.
ult_verse_text: And it happened after this that to Absalom, the son of David, {was} a beautiful sister, and her name {was} Tamar, and Amnon, the son of David, loved her.

notes.note: The author is using the word translated **And it happened** to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠לְ⁠אַבְשָׁל֧וֹם בֶּן & אָח֥וֹת יָפָ֖ה וּ⁠שְׁמָ֣⁠הּ תָּמָ֑ר & דָּוִֽד
notes.note: Here the author is introducing **Tamar** as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [that there was a beautiful young woman named Tamar who was the sister of Absalom, David’s son]

The rest of the story makes clear that Amnon felt sexual desire for Tamar but that he did not care about her as a person, and he was not unselfishly devoted to her. If your language has different words for love, in your translation, use the word that indicates sexual desire.

bsb_verse_text: Amnon was sick with frustration over his sister Tamar, for she was a virgin, and it seemed implausible for him to do anything to her.
ult_verse_text: And it narrowed to Amnon, so that he made himself sick over Tamar his sister. For she {was} a virgin, so it was difficult in the eyes of Amnon to do anything to her.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֵּ֨צֶר לְ⁠אַמְנ֜וֹן לְ⁠הִתְחַלּ֗וֹת בַּֽ⁠עֲבוּר֙ תָּמָ֣ר אֲחֹת֔⁠וֹ כִּ֥י בְתוּלָ֖ה הִ֑יא וַ⁠יִּפָּלֵא֙ בְּ⁠עֵינֵ֣י אַמְנ֔וֹן לַ⁠עֲשׂ֥וֹת לָ֖⁠הּ מְאֽוּמָה
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [She {was} a virgin, so it was difficult in the eyes of Amnon to do anything to her. As a result, it narrowed to Amnon, so that he made himself sick over Tamar his sister]

The author is using the expression **it narrowed to Amnon** as a common expression of his culture to mean that Amnon became very distressed. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And Amnon felt so thwarted that he became sick] or [And Amnon felt so distressed that he became sick]

Here and throughout the chapter, the author and characters refer to Tamar as Amnon’s **sister**. Since they had the same father but different mothers, your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship that you can use in your translation.

The author is using the expression **in the eyes of** to mean “in the judgment of” or “in the opinion of.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [so Amnon considered it difficult]

bsb_verse_text: Now Amnon had a friend named Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimeah. Jonadab was a very shrewd man,
ult_verse_text: Now to Amnon {was} a friend, and his name {was} Jonadab, the son of Shimeah the brother of David. And Jonadab {was} a very cunning man.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠לְ⁠אַמְנ֣וֹן רֵ֗עַ וּ⁠שְׁמ⁠וֹ֙ יֽוֹנָדָ֔ב בֶּן־שִׁמְעָ֖ה אֲחִ֣י דָוִ֑ד וְ⁠י֣וֹנָדָ֔ב אִ֥ישׁ חָכָ֖ם מְאֹֽד
notes.note: Here the author is introducing **Jonadab** as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Now there was a man named Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimeah, who was a very cunning man and who was a friend of Amnon]

bsb_verse_text: and he asked Amnon, “Why are you, the son of the king, so depressed morning after morning? Won’t you tell me?” Amnon replied, “I am in love with Tamar, my brother Absalom’s sister.”
ult_verse_text: And he said to him, “Why {are} you so weak, son of the king, by morning, by morning? Will you not declare to me?”

notes.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Jonadab, while the pronoun **him** refers to Amnon. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And Jonadab said to Amnon]

Jonadab is referring to Amnon by the respectful title **son of the king**. Use a comparable title or expression for addressing someone in such a position respectfully in your language. Alternate translation: [Your Highness] or [Prince Amnon]

The author is using **by morning, by morning** as a common expression of his culture to mean “every morning.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [every morning]

Jonadab is using the question form as a polite way of urging Amnon to tell him what is wrong. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Please declare to me]

Here and throughout the chapter, the author and characters refer to Absalom and Amnon as each other’s **brother**. Since they had the same father but different mothers, your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship that you can use in your translation.

bsb_verse_text: Jonadab told him, “Lie down on your bed and pretend you are ill. When your father comes to see you, say to him, ‘Please let my sister Tamar come and give me something to eat. Let her prepare it in my sight so I may watch her and eat it from her hand.’”
ult_verse_text: And Jonadab said to him, “Lie down on your bed and pretend to be sick. And your father will come to see you, and you shall say to him, ‘Please let Tamar my sister come and let her serve me bread, and let her make the food to my eyes so that I may see, and I will eat from her hand.’”

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אָמַרְתָּ֣ אֵלָ֡י⁠ו תָּ֣בֹא נָא֩ תָמָ֨ר אֲחוֹתִ֜⁠י וְ⁠תַבְרֵ֣⁠נִי לֶ֗חֶם וְ⁠עָשְׂתָ֤ה לְ⁠עֵינַ⁠י֙ אֶת־הַ⁠בִּרְיָ֔ה לְמַ֨עַן֙ אֲשֶׁ֣ר אֶרְאֶ֔ה וְ⁠אָכַלְתִּ֖י מִ⁠יָּדָֽ⁠הּ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and you shall ask him please to let Tamar your sister come and let her serve you bread, and let her make the food to your eyes so that you may see, and you will eat from her hand]

Jonadab is using **bread** to represent a meal or food in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a meal]

Here, **to my eyes** represents “where I can see.” If it would be helpful in your language, in your translation you could use an equivalent expression or plain language, here and in [verses 6](../13/06.md) and [8](../13/08.md). Alternate translation: [in my sight]

Here, **hand** represents the service and care of Tamar bringing food to Amnon. If it would be helpful in your language, in your translation you could use an equivalent expression or plain language here and in [verses 6](../13/06.md) and [10](../13/10.md). Alternate translation: [if she serves it to me]

bsb_verse_text: So Amnon lay down and feigned illness. When the king came to see him, Amnon said, “Please let my sister Tamar come and make a couple of cakes in my sight, so that I may eat from her hand.”
ult_verse_text: So Amnon lay down, and he pretended to be sick. And the king came to see him, and Amnon said to the king, “Please let Tamar my sister come, and let her make to my eyes a couple of pancakes, and I will eat from her hand.”

notes.note: A **pancake** is a kind of flat bread cooked in a pan. If your readers would not be familiar with what a pancake is, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [flat bread] or [breadcakes]

bsb_verse_text: Then David sent word to Tamar at the palace: “Please go to the house of Amnon your brother and prepare a meal for him.”
ult_verse_text: So David sent to Tamar at the house, saying, “Please go {to} the house of Amnon your brother and make food for him.”

notes.note: The implication is that Tamar lived in the women’s quarters of David’s palace. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [in the women’s apartments in his palace]

bsb_verse_text: Then she brought the pan and set it down before him, but he refused to eat. “Send everyone away!” said Amnon. And everyone went out.
ult_verse_text: And she took the pan, and she poured {them} out to his face, but he refused to eat.

notes.note: Here, **to his face** represents “in front of him.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of him]

Here the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [Make every person go out from me]

While this is a plural imperative that Amnon appears to be using to tell two or more people to **Make** everyone in the room leave, he is actually addressing everyone in the room except Tamar and telling them to leave. Translate this with the appropriate verbal form in your language. Alternate translation: [All of you people, go out from me]

bsb_verse_text: And when she had brought them to him to eat, he took hold of her and said, “Come lie with me, my sister!”
ult_verse_text: And she brought {them} near to him to eat, and he seized her, and he said to her, “Come, lie with me, my sister.”

notes.note: Amnon is not telling Tamar to **Come** somewhere. She is already in his room. He is saying **Come** to mean that he wants her to take action. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [Come on, lie with me]

Amnon is referring to having sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **lie with me**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [sleep with me]

In this context, Amnon may be using the word **sister** not to describe a kinship relationship but as a term of endearment, as in [Song of Songs 4:9](../../sng/04/09.md) and several other places in that book. Your language may have a comparable term that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [my darling]

bsb_verse_text: “No, my brother!” she cried. “Do not violate me, for such a thing should never be done in Israel. Do not do this disgraceful thing!
ult_verse_text: And she said to him, “No, my brother, do not humble me, for it is not done thus in Israel. Do not do this wickedness!

notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [it is not done thus in Israel, so do not humble me]

The expression **it is not done** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [people in Israel do not do thus]

Here the expression **humble me** has the sense of forcibly violating and raping a woman. You could translate the expression that way if that would be clearer for your readers. Alternate translation: [do not rape me]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **wickedness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [this wicked thing]

bsb_verse_text: Where could I ever take my shame? And you would be like one of the fools in Israel! Please speak to the king, for he will not withhold me from you.”
ult_verse_text: And I, where would I bring my shame? And you, you would be like one of the wicked {ones} in Israel. And now, please, speak to the king, for he would not withhold me from you.”

notes.note: Tamar is stating the pronouns **I** and **you** separately, even though the verbs translated as **would I bring** and **you would be** already include their meanings. She is doing that because she is comparing the situations that she and Amnon would each be in. If a speaker of your language would use explicit pronouns for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that Tamar is comparing these situations. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronouns explicitly. Alternate translation: [For my part … And for your part]

Tamar is using the question form to emphasize that she would be permanently disgraced if Amnon raped her. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I would not be able to bring my shame anywhere!]

Here, Tamar is speaking as if **shame** were actually something that could be carried to a different place. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I could never get rid of my shame]

**And now** was an expression that speakers in this culture commonly used to introduce their main topic. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

notes.orig_language_quote: דַּבֶּר־נָ֣א אֶל־הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ כִּ֛י לֹ֥א יִמְנָעֵ֖⁠נִי מִמֶּֽ⁠ךָּ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since the king would not withhold me from you, please speak to him]

This is a double negative, consisting of the negative particle **not** and the negative word **withhold**. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use a positive expression to translate this. Alternate translation: [he would give me to you]

bsb_verse_text: But Amnon refused to listen to her, and being stronger, he violated her and lay with her.
ult_verse_text: But he was not willing to listen to her voice. And he was stronger than she, and he humbled her, and he lay with her.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [12:18](../12/18.md). Alternate translation: [to do what she said]
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:12](../13/12.md). Alternate translation: [and he raped her]

bsb_verse_text: Then Amnon hated Tamar with such intensity that his hatred was greater than the love he previously had. “Get up!” he said to her. “Be gone!”
ult_verse_text: Then Amnon hated her {with} very great hatred, so that the hatred {with} which he hated her {was} greater than the love {with} which he had loved her. And Amnon said to her, “Arise, go.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [13:1](../13/01.md). Alternate translation: [the sexual attraction that he had felt toward her]

While Tamar would have to **Arise** from the bed in order to **go**, Amnon seems to be saying **Arise** brusquely to tell Tamar to take action. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [Go on, get out of here]

bsb_verse_text: “No,” she replied, “sending me away is worse than this great wrong you have already done to me!” But he refused to listen to her.
ult_verse_text: But she said to him, “No, because this great evil, to send me away, than the other that you did to me.”

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **evil**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [this very evil action]

Tamar is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [is worse than the other]

Tamar is using the adjective **other** as a noun to mean a certain kind of action. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the other very evil action]
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:14](../13/14.md). Alternate translation: [But he was not willing to do what she said]

bsb_verse_text: Instead, he called to his attendant and said, “Throw this woman out and bolt the door behind her!”
ult_verse_text: And he called his young man, the one attending him, and he said, “Now send this {one} away from me outside, and lock the door behind her.”

notes.note: Amnon is using the adjective **this** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Amnon is being hostile and dismissive toward the woman he previously admired but whom he now detests because of his own guilt. Use an expression in your translation that reflects this. The UST models one way to do that.

bsb_verse_text: So Amnon’s attendant threw her out and bolted the door behind her. Now Tamar was wearing a robe of many colors, because this is what the king’s virgin daughters wore.
ult_verse_text: Now a long robe {was} on her, for thus the virgin daughters of the king dressed {in} garments. And the one attending him brought her outside, and he locked the door behind her.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠עָלֶ֨י⁠הָ֙ כְּתֹ֣נֶת פַּסִּ֔ים כִּי֩ כֵ֨ן תִּלְבַּ֧שְׁןָ בְנוֹת־הַ⁠מֶּ֛לֶךְ הַ⁠בְּתוּלֹ֖ת מְעִילִ֑ים וַ⁠יֹּצֵ֨א אוֹתָ֤⁠הּ מְשָֽׁרְת⁠וֹ֙ הַ⁠ח֔וּץ וְ⁠נָעַ֥ל הַ⁠דֶּ֖לֶת אַחֲרֶֽי⁠הָ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about the servant forcing Tamar outside and locking the door first in the verse to connect it with Amnon’s instruction in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [So the one attending him brought her outside, and he locked the door behind her. Now a long robe was on her, for thus the virgin daughters of the king dressed in garments]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠עָלֶ֨י⁠הָ֙ כְּתֹ֣נֶת פַּסִּ֔ים כִּי֩ כֵ֨ן תִּלְבַּ֧שְׁןָ בְנוֹת־הַ⁠מֶּ֛לֶךְ הַ⁠בְּתוּלֹ֖ת
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

It might seem that the expression **dressed in garments** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [dressed]
The pronoun **him** refers to Amnon. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And the one attending Amnon]

bsb_verse_text: And Tamar put ashes on her head and tore her robe. And putting her hand on her head, she went away crying aloud.
ult_verse_text: And Tamar put ashes on her head, and she tore the long robe that {was} on her, and she put her hand on her head, and she went, going and she cried out.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠תִּקַּ֨ח תָּמָ֥ר אֵ֨פֶר֙ עַל־רֹאשָׁ֔⁠הּ וּ⁠כְתֹ֧נֶת הַ⁠פַּסִּ֛ים אֲשֶׁ֥ר עָלֶ֖י⁠הָ קָרָ֑עָה וַ⁠תָּ֤שֶׂם יָדָ⁠הּ֙ עַל־רֹאשָׁ֔⁠הּ
notes.note: Putting ashes on her head, tearing her robe, and putting her hand on her head were symbolic actions by which Tamar showed extreme grief and distress. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And Tamar showed her deep grief by putting ashes on her head, tearing her long robe, and putting her hand on her head]

The phrase **going and she cried out** expresses a single idea. The word **going** describes what she did as she **cried out**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [crying out as she went]

bsb_verse_text: Her brother Absalom said to her, “Has your brother Amnon been with you? Be quiet for now, my sister. He is your brother. Do not take this thing to heart.” So Tamar lived as a desolate woman in the house of her brother Absalom.
ult_verse_text: And Absalom her brother said to her, “Has Amnon your brother been with you? And now, my sister, keep silent, he {is} your brother. Do not set your heart to this matter.” And Tamar dwelled and was desolate {in} the house of Absalom her brother.

notes.note: Absalom is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **been with you**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [Has Amnon your brother slept with you?]

Absalom is using a common expression of his culture to mean that Tamar should not continue to think about what happened and be upset about it. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Do not take this matter to heart] or [Do not dwell on this matter]

The meaning of the term **desolate** in this context is that Tamar remained unmarried because of her defilement. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and never married]

bsb_verse_text: When King David heard all this, he was furious.
ult_verse_text: And King David heard all of these things, and it burned to him greatly.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:8](../03/08.md). Alternate translation: [And he became very angry]

bsb_verse_text: And Absalom never said a word to Amnon, either good or bad, because he hated Amnon for violating his sister Tamar.
ult_verse_text: But Absalom did not speak with Amnon to evil or to good, for Absalom hated Amnon for the reason that he had humbled Tamar his sister.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠לֹֽא־דִבֶּ֧ר אַבְשָׁל֛וֹם עִם־אַמְנ֖וֹן לְ⁠מֵ⁠רָ֣ע וְ⁠עַד־ט֑וֹב כִּֽי־שָׂנֵ֤א אַבְשָׁלוֹם֙ אֶת־אַמְנ֔וֹן עַל־דְּבַר֙ אֲשֶׁ֣ר עִנָּ֔ה אֵ֖ת תָּמָ֥ר אֲחֹתֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [But since Absalom hated Amnon for the reason that he had humiliated Tamar his sister, Absalom did not speak with Amnon to evil or to good]

The author is referring to all of Absalom’s speech by naming two extremes, **evil** and **good**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [But Absalom did not say anything at all to Amnon about this]
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:12](../13/12.md). Alternate translation: [he had raped]

bsb_verse_text: Two years later, when Absalom’s sheepshearers were at Baal-hazor near Ephraim, he invited all the sons of the king.
ult_verse_text: And it happened after two years of days that shearers were to Absalom in Baal Hazor, which {is} near Ephraim. And Absalom called to all of the sons of the king.

notes.note: The author is using the words translated **And it happened** to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.
Here, **days** represents “time.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [after two years’ time]

bsb_verse_text: And he went to the king and said, “Your servant has just hired shearers. Will the king and his servants please come with me?”
ult_verse_text: And Absalom went to the king, and he said, “Behold, please, shearers {are} to your servant. May the king and his servants please go with your servant.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:2](../01/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

Absalom is speaking of himself in the third person as **your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. Alternate translation: [I have hired shearers … with me]
In a context such as this, your language might say “come” instead of **go**, here and in the next verse Alternate translation: [May the king and his servants please come]

Even though Absalom is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [you, O king, and your servants]

bsb_verse_text: “No, my son,” the king replied, “we should not all go, or we would be a burden to you.” Although Absalom urged him, he was not willing to go, but gave him his blessing.
ult_verse_text: And the king said to Absalom, “No, my son, please let not all of us go, and let us not be heavy to you.” Then he urged him, but he was not willing to go, but he blessed him.

notes.note: The king is using the word translated as **and** to introduce an outcome that he does not want to happen. Because of this, he first gives Absalom an instruction to follow so that this will not happen. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that avoiding this outcome is the purpose of the instruction. Alternate translation: [otherwise, we would be heavy to you]

Here, the king is speaking as if he and his sons were **heavy** objects that would weigh Absalom down. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language, as the UST does. Alternate translation: [so that we will not be a burden to you]

The pronoun **he** refers to Absalom in the first instance and to David in the next two instances. The pronoun **him** refers to David in the first instance and to Absalom in the second instance. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [Then Absalom urged David, but David was not willing to go, but David blessed Absalom]

bsb_verse_text: “If not,” said Absalom, “please let my brother Amnon go with us.” “Why should he go with you?” the king asked.
ult_verse_text: And Absalom said, “If not, may Amnon my brother please go with us.”

notes.note: The king is using the question form to emphasize that Amnon does not need to go with Absalom. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [There is no need for him to go with you.]

bsb_verse_text: Now Absalom had ordered his young men, “Watch Amnon until his heart is merry with wine, and when I order you to strike Amnon down, you are to kill him. Do not be afraid. Have I not commanded you? Be courageous and valiant!”
ult_verse_text: And Absalom commanded his young men, saying, “See, now, when Amnon {is} good of heart with wine, and I say to you, ‘Strike Amnon!’ then you shall kill him. Do not fear. {Is it} not that I, I have commanded you? Be courageous and be sons of valor.”

notes.note: Here, Absalom is speaking as if to pay attention meant to **See**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Listen]

Absalom is using **good of heart with wine** as a common expression of his culture to describe Amnon beginning to become drunk from the wine he would serve. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [is tipsy from the wine] or [has begun to become drunk from the wine]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and I call out to you to strike Amnon,]

Absalom is using the question form to emphasize that he himself has given this command. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [It is I myself who have commanded you.]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you were” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation [I have commanded you personally]

In certain contexts, biblical authors and characters use the expression **sons of** to indicate that a person has a certain characteristic. In this case, Absalom means that he wants his servants to have the characteristic of **valor**. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Be courageous and be brave men]

The expressions **Be courageous** and **be sons of valor** mean similar things. Absalom is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [Be very courageous]

bsb_verse_text: While they were on the way, a report reached David: “Absalom has struck down all the sons of the king; not one of them is left!”
ult_verse_text: And it happened, they {were} on the road, and the report came to David, saying, “Absalom has struck all of the sons of the king, and not one of them is left.”

notes.note: The author is speaking of **the report** as if it were a living thing that could have come to David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and someone brought a report to David, saying]

notes.orig_language_quote: הִכָּ֤ה אַבְשָׁלוֹם֙ אֶת־כָּל־בְּנֵ֣י הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ וְ⁠לֹֽא־נוֹתַ֥ר מֵ⁠הֶ֖ם אֶחָֽד
notes.note: These two phrases **Absalom has struck all of the sons of the king** and **not one of them is left** mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine them and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [Absalom has killed every single one of the king’s sons]
See how you translated the similar expression in [12:9](../12/09.md). Alternate translation: [has murdered]

The expression **is left** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [remains alive]

bsb_verse_text: Then the king stood up, tore his clothes, and lay down on the ground. And all his servants stood by with their clothes torn.
ult_verse_text: And the king arose, and he tore his clothes, and he lay on the ground, and all of his servants were standing, torn of clothes.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּקְרַ֥ע אֶת־בְּגָדָ֖י⁠ו וַ⁠יִּשְׁכַּ֣ב אָ֑רְצָ⁠ה וְ⁠כָל־עֲבָדָ֥י⁠ו נִצָּבִ֖ים קְרֻעֵ֥י בְגָדִֽים
notes.note: Tearing his clothes and lying on the ground were symbolic actions by which David showed extreme grief and distress. David’s servants similarly tore their clothes to show their grief. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of these actions in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and he showed his deep anguish by tearing his clothes and lying on the ground, and all his servants stood there, having also torn their clothes in grief]

The expression **torn of clothes** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [having torn their clothes]

bsb_verse_text: But Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimeah, spoke up: “My lord must not think they have killed all the sons of the king, for only Amnon is dead. In fact, Absalom has planned this since the day Amnon violated his sister Tamar.
ult_verse_text: But Jonadab, the son of Shimeah the brother of David, answered and said, “May my lord not say, ‘All of the young men, the sons of the king, have been killed,’ for Amnon alone has died. For it was placed on the mouth of Absalom from the day of his humbling Tamar his sister.

notes.note: The expression **and said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly. Alternate translation: [But Jonadab, the son of Shimeah the brother of David, responded]

notes.orig_language_quote: אַל־יֹאמַ֤ר אֲדֹנִ⁠י֙ אֵ֣ת כָּל־הַ⁠נְּעָרִ֤ים בְּנֵֽי־הַ⁠מֶּ֨לֶךְ֙ הֵמִ֔יתוּ כִּֽי־אַמְנ֥וֹן לְ⁠בַדּ֖⁠וֹ מֵ֑ת
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since Amnon alone has died, may my lord not say, ‘All of the young men, the sons of the king, have been killed.’]

notes.orig_language_quote: אַל־יֹאמַ֤ר אֲדֹנִ⁠י֙ אֵ֣ת כָּל־הַ⁠נְּעָרִ֤ים בְּנֵֽי־הַ⁠מֶּ֨לֶךְ֙ הֵמִ֔יתוּ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [May my lord not say that all of the young men, the sons of the king, have been killed]

Even though Jonadab is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [Please do not say, my lord]

The expression **have been killed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Absalom has killed all of the young men, the sons of the king] or [All of the young men, the sons of the king, are dead]
Here the word **For** provides not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [You see]

By saying **it was placed on the mouth of Absalom**, Jonadab is using a common expression of his culture to mean that Absalom had been talking about this. (The context suggests that he had been talking about it only to himself or perhaps a few close confidants over the previous two years, not talking about it publicly.) If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Absalom has been telling himself that he would do this]

The pronoun **his** refers to Amnon in the first instance and to Absalom in the second instance. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state these names explicitly. Alternate translation: [from the day when Amnon humbled Absalom’s sister Tamar]

bsb_verse_text: So now, my lord the king, do not take to heart the report that all the sons of the king are dead. Only Amnon is dead.”
ult_verse_text: And now, may my lord the king not put the matter to his heart, saying, ‘All of the sons of the king have died,’ for only Amnon has died.”

notes.orig_language_quote: אַל־יָשֵׂם֩ אֲדֹנִ֨⁠י הַ⁠מֶּ֤לֶךְ אֶל־לִבּ⁠וֹ֙ דָּבָ֣ר לֵ⁠אמֹ֔ר כָּל־בְּנֵ֥י הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ מֵ֑תוּ כִּֽי־אִם־אַמְנ֥וֹן לְ⁠בַדּ֖⁠וֹ מֵֽת
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since only Amnon has died, may my lord the king not put the matter to his heart, saying, ‘All of the sons of the king have died.’]
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:20](../13/20.md). Alternate translation: [may my lord the king not be distressed about the matter]

Even though Jonadab is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [may you, my lord the king, not put]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [saying that all of the sons of the king have died]

bsb_verse_text: Meanwhile, Absalom had fled. When the young man standing watch looked up, he saw many people coming down the road west of him, along the side of the hill. And the watchman went and reported to the king, “I see men coming from the direction of Horonaim, along the side of the hill.”
ult_verse_text: (Now Absalom had fled.) And the young man watching lifted his eyes, and he saw, and behold, many people were coming from the road behind him, from the side of the mountain.

notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture. Alternate translation: [By this time, Absalom had already escaped] or [Meanwhile, Absalom had run away]

The author is using **lifted his eyes** as a common expression of his culture to mean that this young man looked off into the distance. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 6:13](../../1sa/06/13.md). Alternate translation: [looked off into the distance]

Here and in the next two verses, the term **behold** calls attention to the information that follows. Your language may have its own way of calling attention to information that you can use in your translation.

The author is indicating a direction in the way that was customary in his culture, in which people spoke as if someone were facing in the direction of the sunrise. So **behind him** would mean in the direction of the sunset, or to the west. Your culture may have its own way of indicating directions that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [from the west]

bsb_verse_text: So Jonadab said to the king, “Look, the sons of the king have arrived! It is just as your servant said.”
ult_verse_text: And Jonadab said to the king, “Behold, the sons of the king are coming. As your servant spoke, thus it is.”

notes.note: Jonadab is speaking in the third person respectfully about David as **the king** and about himself humbly as **your servant**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in the second person and the first person. Alternate translation: [your sons … I, your servant]

bsb_verse_text: And as he finished speaking, the sons of the king came in, wailing loudly. Then the king and all his servants also wept very bitterly.
ult_verse_text: And it happened, as he finished speaking, that behold, the sons of the king came, and they lifted up their voice and wept. And the king and all of his servants also wept a very great weeping.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:32](../03/32.md). Alternate translation: [and they wept very loudly]

In this verse, the word **voice** is singular in form, but the author is using it to refer to the voices of all of David’s sons. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “voice.” Alternate translation: [their voices]

It might seem that the expression **wept a very great weeping** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [wept very greatly]

bsb_verse_text: Now Absalom fled and went to Talmai son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur. But David mourned for his son every day.
ult_verse_text: But Absalom fled, and he went to Talmai, the son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur. And David mourned for his son all of the days.

notes.note: The phrase **for his son** refers to Amnon, who had been killed. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [for his son Amnon]

The author is using **all of the days** as a common expression of his culture to mean “every day” or “continually.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [day after day]

bsb_verse_text: And King David longed to go to Absalom, for he had been consoled over Amnon’s death.
ult_verse_text: And it ceased, David the king to go out against Absalom, for he was comforted concerning Amnon, that he had died.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠תְּכַל֙ דָּוִ֣ד הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ לָ⁠צֵ֖את אֶל־אַבְשָׁל֑וֹם כִּֽי־נִחַ֥ם עַל־אַמְנ֖וֹן כִּֽי־מֵֽת
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Then, since he was comforted concerning Amnon, that he had died, it ceased, David the king to go out against Absalom]

This could mean: (1) that David had planned to **go out against** Absalom (that is, to attack him so that he could capture and punish him), but he **ceased** to plan that. Alternate translation: [Then David the king would no longer go out against Absalom]; (2) that David longed (another possible meaning of the term translated as **ceased**) to **go out** to see Absalom. Alternate translation: [Then David the king longed to see Absalom]

The expression **he was comforted** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [he felt consolation]

bsb_verse_text: Now Joab son of Zeruiah perceived that the king’s heart longed for Absalom.
ult_verse_text: Now Joab the son of Zeruiah knew that the heart of the king {was} against Absalom.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֵּ֖דַע יוֹאָ֣ב בֶּן־צְרֻיָ֑ה כִּֽי־לֵ֥ב הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ עַל־אַבְשָׁלֽוֹם
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

Here, the **heart** represents a person’s feelings. This could mean: (1) that David felt hostile toward Absalom. That is the meaning in [Daniel 11:28](../../dan/11/28.md), the only other instance of this expression in the Bible. The rest of this chapter shows that David had to be persuaded through an elaborate ruse to allow Absalom to return to Jerusalem, and even then he would not allow him to come into his presence. Alternate translation: [that King David felt hostile toward Absalom]; (2) that David was longing to see Absalom. Many versions follow this interpretation, and you may wish to follow it if a translation of the Bible exists in your region and follows it. Alternate translation: [that King David longed to see Absalom]

bsb_verse_text: So Joab sent to Tekoa to bring a wise woman from there. He told her, “Please pretend to be a mourner; put on clothes for mourning and do not anoint yourself with oil. Act like a woman who has mourned for the dead a long time.
ult_verse_text: And Joab sent {to} Tekoa, and he brought a wise woman from there. And he said to her, “Please mourn, and please put on clothes of mourning. And you shall not anoint {yourself} {with} oil, but you shall be like this woman mourning many days for one having died.”

notes.note: Putting on **clothes of mourning** and not anointing oneself **with oil** were symbolic actions that in ancient Israel showed grief and sorrow over someone who had died.
