If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of these actions in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and act as if you are grieving by wearing dark clothes and not applying any oil to yourself]

Joab is not referring to a specific **woman**. He means any woman who had been **mourning many days**. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [like a woman]

bsb_verse_text: Then go to the king and speak these words to him.” And Joab put the words in her mouth.
ult_verse_text: And you shall come to the king, and you shall speak to him according to this word.” And Joab put the words in her mouth.

notes.note: In a context such as this, your language might say “go” instead of **come**. Alternate translation: [And you shall go]

Joab is using the term **word** to represent what he is going to say by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and tell him the following]

Here, the author is speaking as if **words** were actually objects that Joab could have placed in the woman’s **mouth**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Then Joab specified what she ought to say]

bsb_verse_text: When the woman from Tekoa went to the king, she fell facedown in homage and said, “Help me, O king!”
ult_verse_text: So the Tekoite woman spoke to the king. And she fell on her nose to the ground, and she prostrated herself, and she said, “Save, O king!”

notes.note: The author is using a summary statement to introduce a new part of this story, which takes place in [verses 4–20](../14/04.md). Your language may have its own way of offering an introductory summary at the beginning of a new part of a story. Alternate translation: [So the Tekoite woman went to speak to the king]

Be sure that it is clear in your translation that the woman did not fall down accidentally. She knelt down in front of David, pressing her face **to the ground** as a gesture to honor him. She then **prostrated herself** or stretched out flat on the ground to show David great honor. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and she knelt on the ground in front of David, stretching herself out flat, to honor him greatly]

The woman is referring to King David by a respectful title, and she is using the customary expression of this culture to ask him to use his royal power to help her. Use a comparable title and expression from your language. Alternate translation: [Help me, Your Majesty]

bsb_verse_text: “What troubles you?” the king asked her. “Indeed,” she said, “I am a widow, for my husband is dead.
ult_verse_text: And the king said to her, “What {is} to you?”

notes.note: The king is using **What {is} to you** as a common expression of his culture to ask the woman why she needs help. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [What is the matter]

To try to convince David that he should allow Absalom to return, the woman, as instructed by Joab, tells David a story as if it were true. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could state that explicitly. Alternate translation: [And to try to convince David to allow Absalom, she told him a story as if it were true. She said to him]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. The woman is clarifying that she is not without the support of a male relative for some other reason, for example, she has not separated from a husband who is still living. Alternate translation: [Since my husband has died, I am truly a widow]

The woman is using **a woman, a widow** as a common expression of her culture to mean “a woman who is a widow.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a woman who is a widow] or [a widow]

bsb_verse_text: And your maidservant had two sons who were fighting in the field with no one to separate them, and one struck the other and killed him.
ult_verse_text: And to your maidservant {were} two sons. But the two of them fought in the field, and {there was} no deliverer between them. And the one struck him, the one, and he killed him.

notes.note: The woman is speaking of herself in the third person as **your maidservant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. You could translate similar expressions in the same way throughout the chapter. Alternate translation: [And to me, your maidservant]

It might seem that the expression **And the one struck him, the one** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [And one of them struck the other]

bsb_verse_text: Now the whole clan has risen up against your maidservant and said, ‘Hand over the one who struck down his brother, that we may put him to death for the life of the brother whom he killed. Then we will cut off the heir as well!’ So they would extinguish my one remaining ember by not preserving my husband’s name or posterity on the earth.”
ult_verse_text: And behold, all of the clan has arisen against your maidservant, and they have said, ‘Give the one having struck his brother, and we will kill him for the life of his brother whom he slew, and let us destroy the heir also.’ And they would quench my coal that remains, without leaving to my husband a name or remnant on the face of the ground.”

notes.note: The woman is using the term **behold** to call attention to what she is about to say. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the term “behold” in [1:2](../01/02.md).

The woman is using **has arisen** as a common expression of her culture to mean “has taken action.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [has taken action]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֹּֽאמְרוּ֙ תְּנִ֣י ׀ אֶת־מַכֵּ֣ה אָחִ֗י⁠ו וּ⁠נְמִתֵ֨⁠הוּ֙ בְּ⁠נֶ֤פֶשׁ אָחִי⁠ו֙ אֲשֶׁ֣ר הָרָ֔ג וְ⁠נַשְׁמִ֖ידָה גַּ֣ם אֶת־הַ⁠יּוֹרֵ֑שׁ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and they have told me to give them the one having struck his brother so that they can kill him for the life of his brother whom he slew, and they want to destroy the heir also]
Here, **life** represents “death.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [to avenge the death of his brother]

The other members of the clan would not have spoken these words directly to the woman. Since they say **let us**, in her depiction of them, they are pausing to speak confidentially to one another. They are speaking in this way because they are betraying their real motive, which is to get the late husband’s property by killing his sole remaining **heir**. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could indicate this explicitly in your translation, ending the second-level direct quotation after **he slew** and beginning a new sentence. Alternate translation: [But their real motive is to destroy the heir also]

Here, the woman is speaking as if her son were actually a **coal** that could be extinguished. She uses this image to describe her son as her family’s last remaining source of life, hope, and continuation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And they would destroy my only remaining son]

The terms **name** and **remnant** mean similar things. The woman is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [any survivors]

Here, **a name** represents “someone to carry on the family line.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [anyone to carry on his name]

The woman is using one part of the earth, **the face of the ground**, to represent the entire earth. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [alive on earth]
See how you translated the similar expression in [11:11](../11/11.md). Alternate translation: [on the surface of the ground]

bsb_verse_text: “Go home,” the king said to the woman, “and I will give orders on your behalf.”
ult_verse_text: And the king said to the woman, “Go to your house, and I, I will command concerning you.”

notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about the king’s command with the information about the woman going home. Alternate translation: [Since I myself will command concerning you, you may go to your house]

The implication is that the king will take some action that will ensure that the woman and her son are protected. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and I myself will take care of this matter for you]

David is stating the pronoun **I** separately, even though the verb translated as **I will command** already includes this meaning. He is doing that because he is making a promise to the woman. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for this same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that David is making a promise. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [and I promise that I will command]

bsb_verse_text: But the woman of Tekoa said to the king, “My lord the king, may any blame be on me and on my father’s house, and may the king and his throne be guiltless.”
ult_verse_text: And the Tekoite woman said to the king, “On me, my lord the king, {be} the iniquity, and on the house of my father, and {may} the king and his throne {be} innocent.”

notes.orig_language_quote: עָלַ֞⁠י אֲדֹנִ֥⁠י הַ⁠מֶּ֛לֶךְ הֶ⁠עָוֺ֖ן וְ⁠עַל־בֵּ֣ית אָבִ֑⁠י
notes.note: The woman is actually describing a possible condition. She is saying that if there is any wrong in this situation, she and her family, not David, will be guilty and bear the responsibility. Express this possible condition in a way that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [If there is any iniquity, my lord the king, then let it be on me and on the house of my father]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:29](../03/29.md). Alternate translation: [my extended family]

Even though the woman is addressing the king directly, she is speaking of him in the third person as **the king and his throne** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person, here and in similar instances throughout the chapter. Alternate translation: [and may you, O king, and your throne]
Here, **throne** represents “kingdom.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and his kingdom]

bsb_verse_text: “If anyone speaks to you,” said the king, “bring him to me, and he will not trouble you again!”
ult_verse_text: And the king said, “The one speaking to you, then bring him to me, and he will not continue to touch you further.”

notes.note: The king is actually describing a possible condition. He is telling the woman that if anyone speaks to her about this matter, then she should bring that person to him. Express this possible condition in a way that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [If anyone speaks to you about this again, then bring him to me]

It might seem that the expression **he will not continue to touch you further** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [and he will not continue to touch you] or [and he will not touch you further]

The king is using **he will not continue to touch you further** as a common expression of his culture to mean “he will not do any further harm to you.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and he will not do any further harm to you]

bsb_verse_text: “Please,” she replied, “may the king invoke the LORD your God to prevent the avenger of blood from increasing the devastation, so that my son may not be destroyed!” “As surely as the LORD lives,” he vowed, “not a hair of your son’s head will fall to the ground.”
ult_verse_text: And she said, “May the king please remember Yahweh your God, from the increasing of the avenger of blood to destroy. Then they will not destroy my son.”

notes.note: The woman is using **remember Yahweh your God** as a common expression of her culture to mean “swear an oath by Yahweh your God.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [May you, the king, please swear an oath by Yahweh your God]

The implication is that the woman wants the king to protect her son from the avenger of blood who is trying to kill him, since that would increase the number of people who had died. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [so that the avenger of blood will not cause any further destruction of life]

Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Then no one will destroy my son] or [Then my son will not be destroyed]

Following the custom of his culture, David is swearing an oath and guaranteeing it by something that he holds sacred. He is then stating the first part of a condition (“if”) but not the second part (“then”). If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explicitly state the second part of this condition. Alternate translation: [I swear by Yahweh that not a single hair from your son will fall to the ground. If he suffers any harm, then may Yahweh punish me severely]

David is using one small part of the woman’s son, implicitly a single strand from his **hair**, to emphasize that he will not allow any harm to come to him at all. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the same expression in [1 Samuel 14:45](../../1sa/14/45.md). Alternate translation: [I swear that no one shall harm your son in the slightest way]

bsb_verse_text: Then the woman said, “Please, may your servant speak a word to my lord the king?” “Speak,” he replied.
ult_verse_text: And the woman said, “May your maidservant please speak a word to my lord the king.”

notes.note: The woman is using the term **word** to represent what she wants to say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [say something further]
This is an imperative, but it communicates permission rather than a command. Use a form in your language that communicates permission. Alternate translation: [You may speak]

bsb_verse_text: The woman asked, “Why have you devised a thing like this against the people of God? When the king says this, does he not convict himself, since he has not brought back his own banished son?
ult_verse_text: And the woman said, “Then why have you devised like this against the people of God? For from speaking this word, the king {is} like the guilty, in that the king has not brought back his banished one.

notes.note: The woman is using the question form to rebuke the king mildly and indirectly. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Then you should not have devised like this against the people of God.]

Here, **the people of God** represents the Israelite people, who worshiped the one true **God**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the Israelite people]

Here, **word** represents the judgment that David pronounced by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [For as a result of giving this judgment]

The woman is not referring to a specific **guilty** person. She means guilty people in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [is like a guilty person]

The expression **his banished one** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the one he has banished]

bsb_verse_text: For we will surely die and be like water poured out on the ground, which cannot be recovered. Yet God does not take away a life, but He devises ways that the banished one may not be cast out from Him.
ult_verse_text: For dying, we will die, and like water spilled on the ground that is not gathered. But God does not take away life, but he devises devices so that the banished will not be banished from him.

notes.note: The woman is repeating forms of the verb **die** in order to intensify her expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [For we will certainly die]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠כַ⁠מַּ֨יִם֙ הַ⁠נִּגָּרִ֣ים אַ֔רְצָ⁠ה אֲשֶׁ֖ר לֹ֣א יֵאָסֵ֑פוּ
notes.note: The woman is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and we will die like water spilled on the ground that is not gathered]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠כַ⁠מַּ֨יִם֙ הַ⁠נִּגָּרִ֣ים אַ֔רְצָ⁠ה אֲשֶׁ֖ר לֹ֣א יֵאָסֵ֑פוּ
notes.note: The expressions **water spilled** and **is not gathered** are passive verbal forms. If your language would not use those forms, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and we will die like water that someone has spilled on the ground that no one can gather up]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠כַ⁠מַּ֨יִם֙ הַ⁠נִּגָּרִ֣ים אַ֔רְצָ⁠ה אֲשֶׁ֖ר לֹ֣א יֵאָסֵ֑פוּ
notes.note: The point of this comparison is that just as **water spilled on the ground** cannot be **gathered** up again, so a person who dies cannot be brought back to life. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [and after that we cannot be brought back to life]

The woman is using a construction in which a verb and its object come from the same root. You may be able to use the same construction in your language to express the meaning here. Alternatively, your language may have another way of saying this. Alternate translation: [but he makes merciful arrangements]

The expressions **the banished** and **will not be banished** are passive verbal forms. If your language would not use those forms, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [so that people whom he has banished will not remain in banishment]

Here, the woman is speaking as if God had actually **banished** some people. She is referring to the way God works to restore people who have alienated themselves from him through sin and rebellion. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [to bring people back who have gone away from him]

bsb_verse_text: Now therefore, I have come to present this matter to my lord the king because the people have made me afraid. Your servant thought, ‘I will speak to the king. Perhaps he will grant the request of his maidservant.
ult_verse_text: “And now that I have come to speak this word to my lord the king, {it is} because the people have frightened me. And your maidservant said, ‘Let me now speak to the king. Perhaps the king will do the word of his female servant.

notes.note: The woman is using the term **word** to the case she presented by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to present my case]

The implication is that **the people** are specifically the members of the woman’s own clan. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the members of my clan]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠תֹּ֤אמֶר שִׁפְחָֽתְ⁠ךָ֙ אֲדַבְּרָה־נָּ֣א אֶל־הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ אוּלַ֛י יַעֲשֶׂ֥ה הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ אֶת־דְּבַ֥ר אֲמָתֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [And I told myself that I should come and speak to you, since you might do what I requested]
See how you translated the similar expression in [10:2](../10/02.md). Alternate translation: [And your maidservant said to herself] or [And your maidservant thought]

The woman is using the term **word** to represent what she planned to say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what his female servant asks] or [what I ask]

Here and in the next verse, the woman describes herself as a **female servant**, using a different term than the one she had been using, which the ULT translates as “maidservant.” This term refers to a higher-ranking member of the household whose master might feel some sense of obligation toward her. If your language and culture have different terms for female servants of different rank, use the term for a female servant of higher rank here and in the next verse.

bsb_verse_text: For the king will hear and deliver his maidservant from the hand of the man who would cut off both me and my son from God’s inheritance.’
ult_verse_text: For the king will listen to deliver his female servant from the palm of the man {who is} to destroy me and my son together from the inheritance of God.’

notes.orig_language_quote: כִּ֚י יִשְׁמַ֣ע הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ לְ⁠הַצִּ֥יל אֶת־אֲמָת֖⁠וֹ מִ⁠כַּ֣ף הָ⁠אִ֑ישׁ לְ⁠הַשְׁמִ֨יד אֹתִ֤⁠י וְ⁠אֶת־בְּנִ⁠י֙ יַ֔חַד מִֽ⁠נַּחֲלַ֖ת אֱלֹהִֽים
notes.note: If you decided in the previous verse to translate what the woman claims she said to herself so that there would not be a quotation within a quotation, you can continue to do that here.
See how you translated the similar expression in [12:18](../12/18.md). Alternate translation: [will agree]

Here, **palm**, equivalent to “hand” in other contexts, represents the power and capability of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from the power of the man]

The woman is speaking of the people of Israel as if they were something that Yahweh had inherited as a lasting possession. She is referring to the Israelites as the people who belong to Yahweh perpetually. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 10:1](../../1sa/10/01.md). Alternate translation: [from living among the people of Israel]

bsb_verse_text: And now your servant says, ‘May the word of my lord the king bring me rest, for my lord the king is able to discern good and evil, just like the angel of God. May the LORD your God be with you.’”
ult_verse_text: Then your maidservant said, ‘Now the word of my lord the king will be for rest, because like an angel of God, so {is} my lord the king, to understand good and evil.’ And may Yahweh your God be with you!’”

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠תֹּ֨אמֶר֙ שִׁפְחָ֣תְ⁠ךָ֔ יִֽהְיֶה־נָּ֛א דְּבַר־אֲדֹנִ֥⁠י הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ לִ⁠מְנוּחָ֑ה כִּ֣י ׀ כְּ⁠מַלְאַ֣ךְ הָ⁠אֱלֹהִ֗ים כֵּ֣ן אֲדֹנִ֤⁠י הַ⁠מֶּ֨לֶךְ֙ לִ⁠שְׁמֹ֨עַ֙ הַ⁠טּ֣וֹב וְ⁠הָ⁠רָ֔ע
notes.note: Some versions end the second-level quotation after **rest**. Alternate translation: [Then your maidservant said, ‘Now the word of my lord the king will be for rest.’ For like an angel of God, so {is} my lord the king, to understand good and evil]

notes.orig_language_quote: יִֽהְיֶה־נָּ֛א דְּבַר־אֲדֹנִ֥⁠י הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ לִ⁠מְנוּחָ֑ה כִּ֣י ׀ כְּ⁠מַלְאַ֣ךְ הָ⁠אֱלֹהִ֗ים כֵּ֣ן אֲדֹנִ֤⁠י הַ⁠מֶּ֨לֶךְ֙ לִ⁠שְׁמֹ֨עַ֙ הַ⁠טּ֣וֹב וְ⁠הָ⁠רָ֔ע
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since my lord the king is like an angel of God, to understand good and evil, now the word of my lord the king will be for rest]

The woman is using the term **word** to represent what the king would say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what my lord the king tells me will be for rest]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **rest**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [will restore me to a restful situation]

Since the woman has already referred to David as **my lord the king** once in this sentence, it may be more natural in your language to use a pronoun in this second instance. Alternate translation: [so is he]

The woman is asking God to bless King David. In your translation, use a form that people would recognize as a blessing in your language. You could express this as a prayer if that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [I pray that Yahweh your God will continue to guide and support you]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [And may Yahweh your God help you]

bsb_verse_text: Then the king said to the woman, “I am going to ask you something; do not conceal it from me!” “Let my lord the king speak,” she replied.
ult_verse_text: And the king answered and said to the woman, “Now do not hide from me a thing that I am asking you.”

notes.note: The expression **and said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly. Alternate translation: [And the king replied]

The woman is responding to David with a courteous expression that implies that she will answer truthfully. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Ask whatever you want, and I will tell you the truth]

bsb_verse_text: So the king asked, “Is the hand of Joab behind all this?” The woman answered, “As surely as you live, my lord the king, no one can turn to the right or to the left from anything that my lord the king says. Yes, your servant Joab is the one who gave me orders; he told your maidservant exactly what to say.
ult_verse_text: And the king said, “{Is} the hand of Joab with you in all of this?”

notes.note: The king is using **the hand of Joab** to represent Joab himself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Is Joab with you in all this]
See how you translated the similar expression in [14:18](../14/18.md). Alternate translation: [And the woman responded]

notes.orig_language_quote: חֵֽי־נַפְשְׁ⁠ךָ֩ אֲדֹנִ֨⁠י הַ⁠מֶּ֜לֶךְ אִם־אִ֣שׁ ׀ לְ⁠הֵמִ֣ין וּ⁠לְ⁠הַשְׂמִ֗יל מִ⁠כֹּ֤ל אֲשֶׁר־דִּבֶּר֙ אֲדֹנִ֣⁠י הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ
notes.note: Following the custom of her culture, the woman is swearing an oath and guaranteeing it by something that he holds sacred. She is then stating the first part of a condition (“if”) but not the second part (“then”). Use a natural way in your language to express an oath. In a context such as this, it may be natural to express just the first part of the condition as a negative statement. Alternate translation: [I swear by the life of your soul, my lord the king, that there is no turning to the right or turning to the left from all that my lord the king has spoken]

The woman is using **your soul** to represent David himself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Your life]

The woman is using **turning** in two basic directions, **the right** and **the left**, to represent all directions. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [any turning away at all from anything]

Here, the woman is speaking of agreeing completely with the king’s words as if that were staying on a straight path and not **turning to the right or turning to the left**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [contradicting anything]
Here the word **For** provides not a reason but a further explanation. Alternate translation: [In fact,]

The woman is stating the pronoun **he** separately in both of these instances, even though the verbs translated as **he commanded** and **he put** already include this meaning. She is doing that to confirm Joab’s personal role in these actions. If a speaker of your language would use explicit pronouns for this same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that the woman is confirming Joab’s personal role. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronouns explicitly. Alternate translation: [he was the one who commanded me, and he was the one who put]

notes.orig_language_quote: שָׂ֚ם בְּ⁠פִ֣י שִׁפְחָֽתְ⁠ךָ֔ אֵ֥ת כָּל־הַ⁠דְּבָרִ֖ים הָ⁠אֵֽלֶּה
notes.note: Here, the woman is speaking as if words were actually objects that could be **put** in the **mouth** of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [told your maidservant everything she should say] or [told me everything I should say]

bsb_verse_text: Joab your servant has done this to bring about this change of affairs, but my lord has wisdom like the wisdom of the angel of God, to know everything that happens in the land.”
ult_verse_text: In order to turn the face of the matter, your servant Joab did this thing. But my master {is} wise like the wisdom of an angel of God, to know everything that {is} in the land.”

notes.orig_language_quote: לְ⁠בַ⁠עֲב֤וּר סַבֵּב֙ אֶת־פְּנֵ֣י הַ⁠דָּבָ֔ר עָשָׂ֛ה עַבְדְּ⁠ךָ֥ יוֹאָ֖ב אֶת־הַ⁠דָּבָ֣ר הַ⁠זֶּ֑ה
notes.note: The woman is speaking as if the **matter** of Absalom’s banishment were a living thing that had a **face** that Joab could **turn**, in other words, as if Joab could get it to head in a different direction. This could mean: (1) that Joab wanted to change the situation so that Absalom could come home. Alternate translation: [In order to help Absalom come home from banishment, your servant Joab sent me to speak with you]; (2) that Joab told the woman to pretend to be a widow in order to make her appeal to David for Absalom appear to be an appeal for a son of her own. Alternate translation: [So that you would not realize I was talking about Absalom, your servant Joab told me to pretend I was talking about my own situation]

The woman is making an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. She could be saying: (1) that David knows what is happening in **the land**, that is, in the kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: [since you clearly know what is happening in the land]; (2) that David knows everything that is happening on earth. Alternate translation: [as if you knew everything that was happening on earth]

bsb_verse_text: Then the king said to Joab, “I hereby grant this request. Go, bring back the young man Absalom.”
ult_verse_text: And the king said to Joab, “Behold, I will now do this thing. So go, bring back the young man Absalom.”

notes.note: Joab was clearly not present when the woman was speaking with David, since David had to ask her whether Joab had sent her to him. David must first have summoned Joab and then spoken to him as this verse describes. It may be appropriate in your language to reintroduce Joab as a participant in the story here. Alternate translation: [And the king summoned Joab and said to him]

bsb_verse_text: Joab fell facedown in homage and blessed the king. “Today,” said Joab, “your servant knows that he has found favor in your eyes, my lord the king, because the king has granted his request.”
ult_verse_text: And Joab fell on his face to the ground, and he prostrated himself, and he blessed the king. And Joab said, “Today your servant knows that I have found favor in your eyes, my lord the king, that the king does the word of his servant.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [14:4](../14/04.md). Alternate translation: [And Joab bowed down all the way to the ground as a sign of deep respect]

The author does not mean that Joab gave David his blessing, since an inferior does not bless a superior. He means that Joab wished that Yahweh would bless David for agreeing that Absalom could return. In your translation, you may wish to represent what Joab may have said as a direct quotation. Alternate translation: [and he said, “May Yahweh bless you, O king!”]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [you regard me with favor]

Here, **the word** represents what Joab said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what his servant has requested] or [what I, your servant, have requested]

bsb_verse_text: So Joab got up, went to Geshur, and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.
ult_verse_text: And Joab arose and went to Geshur, and he brought Absalom {to} Jerusalem.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [And Joab took action]

bsb_verse_text: But the king added, “He may return to his house, but he must not see my face.” So Absalom returned to his own house, but he did not see the face of the king.
ult_verse_text: Now the king had said, “He may return to his house, but my face he shall not see.” So Absalom returned to his house, but the face of the king he did not see.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֹּ֤אמֶר הַ⁠מֶּ֨לֶךְ֙ יִסֹּ֣ב אֶל־בֵּית֔⁠וֹ וּ⁠פָנַ֖⁠י לֹ֣א יִרְאֶ֑ה
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠פָנַ֖⁠י לֹ֣א יִרְאֶ֑ה & וּ⁠פְנֵ֥י הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ לֹ֥א רָאָֽה
notes.note: Here, **face** represents the presence of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [but he shall not come into my presence … but he did not come into the presence of the king]

bsb_verse_text: Now there was not a man in all Israel as handsome and highly praised as Absalom. From the sole of his foot to the top of his head, he did not have a single flaw.
ult_verse_text: Now {there} was not a handsome man like Absalom in all of Israel to praise greatly. From the sole of his foot and to his pate, no blemish was on him.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠כְ⁠אַבְשָׁל֗וֹם לֹא־הָיָ֧ה אִישׁ־יָפֶ֛ה בְּ⁠כָל־יִשְׂרָאֵ֖ל לְ⁠הַלֵּ֣ל מְאֹ֑ד
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. This verse describes Absalom’s outstanding physical appearance, which helps explain his popularity among the people and sets up his ability to gain followers later in the narrative. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠כְ⁠אַבְשָׁל֗וֹם לֹא־הָיָ֧ה אִישׁ־יָפֶ֛ה בְּ⁠כָל־יִשְׂרָאֵ֖ל לְ⁠הַלֵּ֣ל מְאֹ֑ד
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about Absalom being a handsome man with the information about people praising him. Alternate translation: [Now there was not another man in all of Israel whom people praised as greatly as they praised Absalom for being a handsome man]

notes.orig_language_quote: מִ⁠כַּ֤ף רַגְל⁠וֹ֙ וְ⁠עַ֣ד קָדְקֳד֔⁠וֹ לֹא־הָ֥יָה ב֖⁠וֹ מֽוּם
notes.note: The author is referring to all of Absalom’s body by naming two extremes, **the sole of his foot** and **his pate**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [He did not have a single blemish anywhere on his body]

notes.orig_language_quote: מִ⁠כַּ֤ף רַגְל⁠וֹ֙ וְ⁠עַ֣ד קָדְקֳד֔⁠וֹ לֹא־הָ֥יָה ב֖⁠וֹ מֽוּם
notes.note: The author is making an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [People felt that he was attractive in every part of his body]

bsb_verse_text: And when he cut the hair of his head—he shaved it every year because his hair got so heavy—he would weigh it out to be two hundred shekels, according to the royal standard.
ult_verse_text: And when he shaved his head (and it was at the end of years to years that he would shave, because {it was} heavy on him, so he would shave it) and he weighed the hair of his head, 200 shekels by the stone of the king.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּֽ⁠בְ⁠גַלְּח⁠וֹ֮ אֶת־רֹאשׁ⁠וֹ֒ וְֽ֠⁠הָיָה מִ⁠קֵּ֨ץ יָמִ֤ים ׀ לַ⁠יָּמִים֙ אֲשֶׁ֣ר יְגַלֵּ֔חַ כִּֽי־כָבֵ֥ד עָלָ֖י⁠ו וְ⁠גִלְּח֑⁠וֹ וְ⁠שָׁקַל֙ אֶת־שְׂעַ֣ר רֹאשׁ֔⁠וֹ מָאתַ֥יִם שְׁקָלִ֖ים בְּ⁠אֶ֥בֶן הַ⁠מֶּֽלֶךְ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the initial statement about Absalom shaving his hair with the information about him weighing his hair. Alternate translation: [At the end of years to years he would shave, because it was heavy on him, so he would shave it. And when he shaved his head and weighed the hair of his head, it weighed 200 shekels by the stone of the king]

The author is using **at the end of years to years** as a common expression of his culture to mean “at the end of each year.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [at the end of each year]

The pronoun **it** refers in the first instance to Absalom’s hair and in the second instance to his head. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [because his hair heavy on him, so he would shave his head]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [he found that it weighed 200 shekels by the stone of the king]
See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to this chapter for an explanation of what it might mean and for suggestions as to how you might represent it in your translation.

bsb_verse_text: Three sons were born to Absalom, and a daughter named Tamar, who was a beautiful woman.
ult_verse_text: And to Absalom were born three sons and one daughter, and her name {was} Tamar. She was a woman beautiful of appearance.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּֽוָּלְד֤וּ לְ⁠אַבְשָׁלוֹם֙ שְׁלוֹשָׁ֣ה בָנִ֔ים וּ⁠בַ֥ת אַחַ֖ת
notes.note: The expression **were born** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And Absalom’s wife bore him three sons and one daughter]

bsb_verse_text: Now Absalom lived in Jerusalem two years without seeing the face of the king.
ult_verse_text: And Absalom lived in Jerusalem two years, days, but the face of the king he did not see.

notes.note: The author is using **two years, days** as a common expression of his culture to mean “two full years.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [two full years]
See how you translated the similar expression in [14:24](../14/24.md). Alternate translation: [but he did not come into the presence of the king]

bsb_verse_text: Then he sent for Joab to send him to the king, but Joab refused to come to him. So Absalom sent a second time, but Joab still would not come.
ult_verse_text: So Absalom sent to Joab to send him to the king, but he was not willing to come to him. So Absalom sent again a second time, but he was not willing to come.

notes.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Joab, while the pronoun **him** refers to Absalom. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [but Joab was not willing to come to Absalom]

It might seem that the expression **Absalom sent again a second time** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [So Absalom sent for him again] or [So Absalom sent for him a second time]

bsb_verse_text: Then Absalom said to his servants, “Look, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley there. Go and set it on fire!” And Absalom’s servants set the field on fire.
ult_verse_text: So he said to his servants, “See, the property of Joab {is} to my hand, and barley {is} to him there. Go and burn it with fire.” So the servants of Absalom burned the property with fire.

notes.note: Absalom is using the term **See** to focus his servants’ attention on what he is about to say. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the similar expression in [7:2](../07/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

Absalom is using **to my hand** as a common expression of his culture to mean “next to mine.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [is next to mine]

It might seem that the expression **burn it with fire** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it, here, in the next sentence, and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [Go and burn it] or [Go and set it on fire]

Here, the author is saying **the property** to represent the barley that was growing on the property. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the barley]

bsb_verse_text: Then Joab came to Absalom’s house and demanded, “Why did your servants set my field on fire?”
ult_verse_text: And Joab arose, and he came to Absalom, to the house, and he said to him, “Why did your servants burn with fire the property that {is} to me?”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [And Joab took action]

Joab is using this expression to represent the barley on his **property**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the barley on my property]

bsb_verse_text: “Look,” said Absalom, “I sent for you and said, ‘Come here. I want to send you to the king to ask: Why have I come back from Geshur? It would be better for me if I were still there.’ So now, let me see the king’s face, and if there is iniquity in me, let him kill me.”
ult_verse_text: And Absalom said to Joab, “Behold, I sent to you, saying, ‘Come here, that I may send you to the king, saying, “Why have I come from Geshur? {It would be} better for me {if} I {were} still there.”’ And now, let me see the face of the king, but if iniquity is in me, then let him kill me.”

notes.orig_language_quote: הִנֵּ֣ה שָׁלַ֣חְתִּי אֵלֶ֣י⁠ךָ ׀ לֵ⁠אמֹ֡ר בֹּ֣א הֵ֠נָּה וְ⁠אֶשְׁלְחָה֩ אֹתְ⁠ךָ֨ אֶל־הַ⁠מֶּ֜לֶךְ לֵ⁠אמֹ֗ר לָ֤⁠מָּה בָּ֨אתִי֙ מִ⁠גְּשׁ֔וּר ט֥וֹב לִ֖⁠י עֹ֣ד אֲנִי־שָׁ֑ם
notes.note: There are three levels of quotation here. The author is quoting what Absalom said (level 1). Absalom is quoting what he sent his messengers to tell Joab on his behalf (level 2). And as he quotes their message, Absalom quotes what the messengers told Joab to say to King David on his behalf (level 3). Use the appropriate punctuation in your language to mark these levels of quotation. Alternatively, you could translate this so that there is not a second-level or third-level quotation (see the Quotes within Quotes note).

notes.orig_language_quote: הִנֵּ֣ה שָׁלַ֣חְתִּי אֵלֶ֣י⁠ךָ ׀ לֵ⁠אמֹ֡ר בֹּ֣א הֵ֠נָּה וְ⁠אֶשְׁלְחָה֩ אֹתְ⁠ךָ֨ אֶל־הַ⁠מֶּ֜לֶךְ לֵ⁠אמֹ֗ר לָ֤⁠מָּה בָּ֨אתִי֙ מִ⁠גְּשׁ֔וּר ט֥וֹב לִ֖⁠י עֹ֣ד אֲנִי־שָׁ֑ם
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [Behold, I sent to you and told you to come here so that I could send you to the king and ask him on my behalf why I had come from Geshur, since it seemed as if it would be better for me if I were still there]

Absalom is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I should not have come from Geshur!]

**And now** was an expression that speakers in this culture commonly used to introduce their main topic. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. See how you translated the same expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

Here, **the face of the king** represents “the presence of the king.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [arrange for me to come into the presence of the king]

Absalom is speaking as if iniquity were an object that was actually **in him**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [but if I am guilty of a serious crime]

bsb_verse_text: So Joab went and told the king, and David summoned Absalom, who came to him and bowed facedown before him. Then the king kissed Absalom.
ult_verse_text: So Joab came to the king, and he declared to him. And he called to Absalom, and he came to the king, and he prostrated himself to him on his nose to the ground to the face of the king. And the king kissed Absalom.

notes.note: The pronoun **he** refers to King David. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And King David called to Absalom]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּשְׁתַּ֨חוּ ל֧⁠וֹ עַל־אַפָּ֛י⁠ו אַ֖רְצָ⁠ה לִ⁠פְנֵ֣י הַ⁠מֶּ֑לֶךְ
notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [14:4](../14/04.md). Alternate translation: [and he bowed down with his face to the ground before the king]

Kissing Absalom was a symbolic action by which David expressed reconciliation and acceptance. After years of estrangement, this gesture demonstrated that David was officially forgiving his son and restoring him to his position in the royal family. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And the king kissed Absalom, signifying that he was restoring him to his position in the royal family]

bsb_verse_text: Some time later, Absalom provided for himself a chariot with horses and fifty men to run ahead of him.
ult_verse_text: And it happened after this that Absalom made for himself a chariot and horses and 50 men running to his face.

notes.note: The author is using this expression to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

Having **50 men** run ahead of his **chariot** to clear the way and announce his coming was a symbolic action by which Absalom asserted his importance. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [and he had 50 men run ahead of his chariot to show how important he was]
Here, **to his face** represents “ahead of him.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [ahead of him]

bsb_verse_text: He would get up early and stand beside the road leading to the city gate. Whenever anyone had a grievance to bring before the king for a decision, Absalom would call out and ask, “What city are you from?” And if he replied, “Your servant is from one of the tribes of Israel,”
ult_verse_text: And Absalom would arise early, and he would stand at the hand of the way of the gate. And it happened, {when} any man to whom was a dispute came to the king for judgment, then Absalom would call to him, and he would say, “Where from this city {are} you?” And he would say, “Your servant {is} from one of the tribes of Israel.”

notes.note: The author is using **at the hand of the way of the gate** as a common expression of his culture to mean “by the side of the road leading to the city gate.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [by the side of the road leading to the city gate]

Here the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women, here and in [verses 5](../15/05.md) and [6](../15/06.md). Alternate translation: [person]

Absalom was using a common expression of his culture to ask what city a person was from. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 30:13](../../1sa/30/13.md). Alternate translation: [What city are you from]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this as an indirect quotation, since these are not the exact words that a person would have spoken. Alternate translation: [And he would tell Absalom what tribe of Israel he came from]

The man is speaking of himself in the third person as **Your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this and similar expressions in a humble form in the first person, here and throughout the chapter. Alternate translation: [I am from one of the tribes of Israel]

bsb_verse_text: Absalom would say, “Look, your claims are good and right, but the king has no deputy to hear you.”
ult_verse_text: Then Absalom would say to him, “See, your matter {is} good and right, but there is not a hearer for you from with the king.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [7:2](../07/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

Here Absalom is using plural forms of **good** and **right** where he could have used singular forms. This suggests that he is using plural forms to emphasize the validity of the person’s case. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the singular and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [your case is very good and very right]

The terms **good** and **right** mean similar things. Absalom is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [your claims are completely justified]

bsb_verse_text: And he would add, “If only someone would appoint me judge in the land, then everyone with a grievance or dispute could come to me, and I would give him justice.”
ult_verse_text: And Absalom would say, “Who will appoint me a judge in the land, that every person to whom was a dispute and a judgment would come to me, and I would do him justice?”

notes.orig_language_quote: מִי־יְשִׂמֵ֥⁠נִי שֹׁפֵ֖ט בָּ⁠אָ֑רֶץ וְ⁠עָלַ֗⁠י יָב֥וֹא כָּל־אִ֛ישׁ אֲשֶֽׁר־יִהְיֶה־לּ⁠וֹ־רִ֥יב וּ⁠מִשְׁפָּ֖ט וְ⁠הִצְדַּקְתִּֽי⁠ו
notes.note: Absalom is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Someone should appoint me a judge in the land, that every person to whom was a dispute and a judgment would come to me, and I would do him justice!]

Here, **the land** represents “the people of the land.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [for the people of the land]

The phrase **a dispute and a judgment** expresses a single idea. The word **judgment** tells what kind of **dispute** this is. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [a dispute calling for a judgment] or [a judicial dispute]

bsb_verse_text: Also, when anyone approached to bow down to him, Absalom would reach out his hand, take hold of him, and kiss him.
ult_verse_text: And it happened, when a man approached to prostrate himself to him, that he would stretch out his hand and take hold of him and kiss him.

notes.orig_language_quote: בִּ⁠קְרָב־אִ֔ישׁ לְ⁠הִשְׁתַּחֲוֺ֖ת ל֑⁠וֹ וְ⁠שָׁלַ֧ח אֶת־יָד֛⁠וֹ וְ⁠הֶחֱזִ֥יק ל֖⁠וֹ וְ⁠נָ֥שַׁק לֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: A person would start to **prostrate himself** as a symbolic action that showed submission and honor to Absalom as a royal figure. By stopping the person from bowing down and instead embracing him and kissing him, Absalom was treating him as a friend and equal. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of these actions in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [when a man approached him to bow down before him in respect, Absalom would stop him and instead embrace him and kiss him as a friend and equal]

bsb_verse_text: Absalom did this to all the Israelites who came to the king for justice. In this way he stole the hearts of the men of Israel.
ult_verse_text: And Absalom acted according to this matter for all of Israel who came to the king for judgment. And Absalom stole the heart of the men of Israel.

notes.note: Here, **Israel** represents “the Israelites.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [for all the Israelites]

Here, the **heart** represents the feelings of the Israelite people. The author is speaking as if Absalom actually **stole** these feelings. He mean that Absalom used these manipulative means to get the Israelites to feel positively toward him. You may have a comparable expression in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And Absalom manipulatively won the affections]

bsb_verse_text: After four years had passed, Absalom said to the king, “Please let me go to Hebron to fulfill a vow I have made to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And it happened at the end of 40 years that Absalom said to the king, “Please may I go, and may I fulfill in Hebron my vow that I vowed to Yahweh.

notes.note: The author is using the word translated **And it happened** to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to this chapter. Many versions read “four years,” following the reading of some ancient manuscripts. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

It might seem that the expression **my vow that I vowed to Yahweh** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it here and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [the vow that I made to Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: For your servant made a vow while dwelling in Geshur of Aram, saying: ‘If indeed the LORD brings me back to Jerusalem, I will worship the LORD in Hebron.’”
ult_verse_text: For your servant vowed a vow when I was living in Geshur in Aram, saying, ‘If bringing back, Yahweh brings me back {to} Jerusalem, then I will serve Yahweh.”

notes.note: Absalom is repeating forms of the verb **brings** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [If Yahweh indeed brings me back]

bsb_verse_text: “Go in peace,” said the king. So Absalom got up and went to Hebron.
ult_verse_text: And the king said to him, “Go in peace.” So he arose and went to Hebron.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [Go with my blessing] or [Go undisturbed]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [So he took action]

bsb_verse_text: Then Absalom sent spies throughout the tribes of Israel with this message: “When you hear the sound of the horn, you are to say, ‘Absalom reigns in Hebron!’”
ult_verse_text: Then Absalom sent spies among all of the tribes of Israel, saying, “When you hear the sound of the shofar, then you shall say, ‘Absalom reigns in Hebron!’”

notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [then you shall shout out that Absalom reigns in Hebron]

bsb_verse_text: Two hundred men from Jerusalem accompanied Absalom. They had been invited as guests and they went along innocently, for they knew nothing about the matter.
ult_verse_text: Now 200 men from Jerusalem had gone with Absalom, called and walking in their innocence, and they did not know any of the matter.

notes.note: The author is speaking of how these men lived as if they were **walking** along a path. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and proceeding innocently] or [and acting without knowing Absalom’s plans]

bsb_verse_text: While Absalom was offering the sacrifices, he sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David’s counselor, to come from his hometown of Giloh. So the conspiracy gained strength, and Absalom’s following kept increasing.
ult_verse_text: And Absalom sent {for} Ahithophel the Gilonite, the counselor of David, from his city, from Giloh, while he sacrificed the sacrifices. And it happened, the conspiracy {became} strong, and the people were going and many with Absalom.

notes.note: It might seem that the expression **while he sacrificed the sacrifices** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [while he offered the sacrifices]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:1](../03/01.md). Alternate translation: [and more and more people joined Absalom]

bsb_verse_text: Then a messenger came to David and reported, “The hearts of the men of Israel are with Absalom.”
ult_verse_text: And a declarer came to David, saying, “The heart of a man of Israel {is} behind Absalom.”

notes.note: Here, **a man of Israel** represents the people of Israel in general, not a specific person. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [The heart of the people of Israel is behind Absalom]

In this verse, the word **heart** is singular in form, but it refers to all the people of Israel as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “heart.” Alternate translation: [The hearts of the people of Israel are behind Absalom]

Here, the **heart** represents people’s commitments and intentions. You may have a comparable expression in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [The people of Israel are now supporting Absalom]

bsb_verse_text: And David said to all the servants with him in Jerusalem, “Arise and let us flee, or we will not escape from Absalom! We must leave quickly, or he will soon overtake us, heap disaster on us, and put the city to the sword.”
ult_verse_text: And David said to all of his servants who {were} with him in Jerusalem, “Arise, and let us flee, for there will not be for us an escape from the face of Absalom. Hurry to go, lest he hurry and overtake us and bring harm upon us and strike the city to the mouth of the sword.”

notes.orig_language_quote: ק֣וּמוּ וְ⁠נִבְרָ֔חָה כִּ֛י לֹא־תִֽהְיֶה־לָּ֥⁠נוּ פְלֵיטָ֖ה מִ⁠פְּנֵ֣י אַבְשָׁל֑וֹם
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since there will not be for us an escape from the face of Absalom otherwise, arise, and let us flee]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [Let us take action to flee]

David is using Absalom’s **face** to represent the murderous intent with which he regards him and his supporters. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [from Absalom, who would kill us]

David is using the word translated as **lest** to introduce an outcome that he does not want to happen. Because of this, he first gives his servants an instruction to follow so that this will not happen. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that avoiding this outcome is the purpose of the instruction. Alternate translation: [Hurry to go! Otherwise, he will hurry and overtake us]

David is using a common expression of his culture to mean that Absalom would kill everyone in the city of Jerusalem if David and his supporters tried to resist him there. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the same expression in [1 Samuel 15:8](../../1sa/15/08.md). Alternate translation: [and kill everyone in this city]

bsb_verse_text: The king’s servants replied, “Whatever our lord the king decides, we are your servants.”
ult_verse_text: And the servants of the king said to the king, “According to all that my lord the king chooses, behold your servants.”

notes.note: Since there are multiple speakers among **the servants of the king**, you could use the plural form of “my” if that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [our lord]

David’s servants are responding to him with the courteous expression that a person in this culture would use to tell a superior that he had heard a summons and was ready and willing to obey. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:7](../01/07.md). Alternate translation: [we are at your disposal]

bsb_verse_text: Then the king set out, and his entire household followed him. But he left behind ten concubines to take care of the palace.
ult_verse_text: And the king went out, and all of his house {was} at his feet. And the king left ten women, concubines, to keep the house.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [12:10](../12/10.md). Alternate translation: [and all of his household]

Here, **at his feet** means that the people of David’s household were following him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [followed him]

It might seem that the expression **women, concubines** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [ten of his concubines]

bsb_verse_text: So the king set out with all the people following him. He stopped at the last house,
ult_verse_text: And the king went out, and all of the people {were} at his feet. And they stopped {at} the farthest house.

notes.note: This could be the name of a place, Beth Merhak. Some interpreters suggest that it may have been the location of a pavilion on the edge of the Kidron Valley where travelers could rest before going down into and across the valley. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region and represents this as a place name, you may wish to do the same in your translation.

bsb_verse_text: and all his servants marched past him—all the Cherethites and Pelethites, and six hundred Gittites who had followed him from Gath.
ult_verse_text: And all of his servants were passing by at his hand. And all of the Cherethites and all of the Pelethites and all of the Gittites, the 600 men who had come at his foot from Gath, were passing by to the face of the king.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [15:2](../15/02.md). Alternate translation: [beside him]
See how you translated these names in [8:18](../08/18.md).

The author is using this phrase to describe the relationship to David of the **600 men** who gathered around him while he was fleeing from Saul. He calls them **Gittites**, meaning people from the city of Gath, because these men went with David to the city of Gath, as [1 Samuel 27:2](../../1sa/27/02.md) describes, and then returned with him to Hebron, as the author states in [2:3](../02/03.md). Alternate translation: [under his leadership]
Here, **face** represents “front.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of the king]

bsb_verse_text: Then the king said to Ittai the Gittite, “Why should you also go with us? Go back and stay with the new king, since you are both a foreigner and an exile from your homeland.
ult_verse_text: But the king said to Ittai the Gittite, “Why are you also going with us? Return and dwell with the king, for you {are} a foreigner and you {are} also an exile to your place.

notes.note: The author does not formally introduce **Ittai the Gittite** as a participant in the story, even though he later has an important role in it. The next verse provides some further information about him, but if it would be helpful to your readers, you could introduce him in more detail here. The UST models one way to do that.

David is using the question form to tell Ittai the Gittite not to go with him. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You should not be going with us!]
In a context such as this, your language might say “coming” instead of **going**. Alternate translation: [are you also coming]

notes.orig_language_quote: שׁ֣וּב וְ⁠שֵׁ֤ב עִם־הַ⁠מֶּ֨לֶךְ֙ כִּֽי־נָכְרִ֣י אַ֔תָּה וְ⁠גַם־גֹּלֶ֥ה אַתָּ֖ה לִ⁠מְקוֹמֶֽ⁠ךָ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since you are a foreigner and you are also an exile to your place, return and dwell with the king]

bsb_verse_text: In fact, you arrived only yesterday; should I make you wander around with us today while I do not know where I am going? Go back and take your brothers with you. May the LORD show you loving devotion and faithfulness.”
ult_verse_text: Yesterday {was} your coming, and today shall I make you wander with us to go, when I am going upon where I am going? Return, and make your brothers return. {May} kindness and faithfulness {be} with you.”

notes.orig_language_quote: תְּמ֣וֹל ׀ בּוֹאֶ֗⁠ךָ וְ⁠הַ⁠יּ֞וֹם אֲנִֽיעֲךָ֤ עִמָּ֨⁠נוּ֙ לָ⁠לֶ֔כֶת וַ⁠אֲנִ֣י הוֹלֵ֔ךְ עַ֥ל אֲשֶׁר־אֲנִ֖י הוֹלֵ֑ךְ
notes.note: David is using the question form to express that he should not make Ittai the Gittite wander with him. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Since yesterday was your coming, today I should not make you wander with us to go, when I am going upon where I am going.]

David is using **Yesterday** as a common expression of his culture to mean “only recently” or “a little while ago.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Only recently]

The phrase **wander with us to go** expresses a single idea. The word **wander** tells in what way Itta would have to **go** with David if he accompanied him. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [shall I make you go wandering with us]

David is using **when I am going upon where I am going** as a common expression of his culture to mean “when I do not know where I am going.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [when I am going I know not where] or [when I will have to go wherever I can]
David is speaking as if Ittai’s soldiers were actually his **brothers**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [your soldiers]

David is asking God to bless Ittai. In your translation, use a form that people would recognize as a blessing in your language. You might express this as a prayer, if that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [I pray that Yahweh will make kindness and faithfulness be with you]

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **kindness** and **faithfulness**, you could express the same ideas in other ways. Alternate translation: [I pray that Yahweh will make people kind and loyal to you]

From the vow that Ittai makes in [verse 21](../15/21.md), it is clear that he has been kind and loyal to David, and David is wishing the same for him. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [I pray that Yahweh will make people kind and loyal to you, just as you have been to me]

bsb_verse_text: But Ittai answered the king, “As surely as the LORD lives, and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be, whether it means life or death, there will your servant be!”
ult_verse_text: But Ittai answered the king and said, “The life of Yahweh and the life of my lord the king, surely in the place where my lord the king will be there, whether to death, whether to life, that there your servant shall be.”

notes.note: The expression **and said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly. Alternate translation: [But Ittai responded to the king]

Following the custom of this culture, Ittai is swearing an oath and guaranteeing it by something that he holds sacred. Use a natural way in your language to express such an oath. Alternate translation: [I swear by Yahweh and by the life of my lord the king]

It might seem that the expression **where my lord the king will be there** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [where my lord the king will be]

Ittai is using **whether to death, whether to life** as a common expression of his culture to mean “whether I live or die.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [even if it costs me my life]

bsb_verse_text: “March on then,” said David to Ittai. So Ittai the Gittite marched past with all his men and all the little ones who were with him.
ult_verse_text: And David said to Ittai, “Go and pass by.” So Ittai the Gittite passed by, and all of his men and all of the little {ones} who {were} with him.

notes.note: David is not telling Ittai to **go** somewhere. He is saying **go** to mean that Ittai should take action. See how you translated the similar expression in [7:23](../07/23.md). Alternate translation: [Go ahead and pass by]

The author is using the adjective **little** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. The ULT indicates this by adding the word **ones**. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the children]

bsb_verse_text: Everyone in the countryside was weeping loudly as all the people passed by. And as the king crossed the Kidron Valley, all the people also passed toward the way of the wilderness.
ult_verse_text: And all of the land was weeping {with} a great voice, and all of the people were crossing, and the king was crossing, over the Valley of Kidron, and all of the people were crossing to the face of the way of the wilderness.

notes.note: Here, **the land** represents the people of the land. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And all the people of the land were weeping]

The author says **all** as an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [And people throughout the land were weeping]
Here, **face** represents “direction.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the direction of]

bsb_verse_text: Zadok was also there, and all the Levites with him were carrying the ark of the covenant of God. And they set down the ark of God, and Abiathar offered sacrifices until all the people had passed out of the city.
ult_verse_text: And behold, Zadok and all of the Levites with him were also carrying the Box of the Covenant of God. And they set down the Box of God, but Abiathar went up until all of the people had finished passing from the city.

notes.note: The author is using the term **behold** to focus his listeners’ attention on what he is abo ut to say. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:2](../01/02.md).

The implication is that Abiathar went up onto the Mount of Olives, which was across the valley. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [but Abiathar went up onto the Mount of Olives across the valley]

bsb_verse_text: Then the king said to Zadok, “Return the ark of God to the city. If I find favor in the eyes of the LORD, He will bring me back and let me see both it and His dwelling place again.
ult_verse_text: And the king said to Zadok, “Bring back the Box of God {to} the city. If I find favor in the eyes of Yahweh, then he will bring me back, and he will make me see it and his habitation.

notes.note: David is using the expression ** in the eyes of** to mean “in the judgment of” or “in the perspective of.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [If Yahweh favors me]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **habitation**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the place that he inhabits]

Here, David is speaking of the sanctuary he prepared for the ark of the covenant ([6:17](../06/17.md)) as if it were actually Yahweh’s **habitation** or the place where he lived. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [his sanctuary]

bsb_verse_text: But if He should say, ‘I do not delight in you,’ then here I am; let Him do to me whatever seems good to Him.”
ult_verse_text: But if he says thus, ‘I do not delight in you,’ behold me, may he do to me just as {is} good in his eyes.”

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אִם֙ כֹּ֣ה יֹאמַ֔ר לֹ֥א חָפַ֖צְתִּי בָּ֑⁠ךְ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [But if he says that he does not delight in me]
See how you translated the similar expression in [15:15](../15/15.md) and [1:7](../01/07.md). Alternate translation: [I am at his disposal]

David is using the expression **as {is} good in his eyes** to mean “in the judgment of” or “in the opinion of.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [as he sees fit]

bsb_verse_text: The king also said to Zadok the priest, “Are you not a seer? Return to the city in peace—you with your son Ahimaaz, and Abiathar with his son Jonathan.
ult_verse_text: And the king said to Zadok the priest, “Are you seeing? Return {to} the city in peace, and Ahimaaz your son and Jonathan the son of Abiathar, your two sons, with you.
