notes.note: David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. This could mean: (1) that David is using sight to represent attention, as in the expression “behold.” Alternate translation: [Pay attention to what I am about to say!]; (2) that David is questioning whether Zadok is a “seer” or prophet. By asking “Are you a seer?” he would mean “You are not a seer.” Alternate translation: [You have no more idea than I do of what is going to happen]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [without openly taking my side]
The pronouns **your** and **you** are plural here. David now addressing both Zadok and Abiathar. So use plural forms in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [should go with you]

bsb_verse_text: See, I will wait at the fords of the wilderness until word comes from you to inform me.”
ult_verse_text: See, I will be waiting at the fords of the wilderness until word comes from you to declare to me.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [7:2](../07/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

David is identifying the Jordan River by its location in the **wilderness** east of Jerusalem. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [at the fords of the Jordan River]

David is speaking of a **word** as if it were a living thing that could come to him on its own from someone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you send me word]

David is using the term **word** to represent what Zadok would say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you send me a message]

bsb_verse_text: But David continued up the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went up. His head was covered, and he was walking barefoot. And all the people with him covered their heads and went up, weeping as they went.
ult_verse_text: And David was going up onto the Mount of Olives, going up and weeping, and his head was covered, and he was walking barefoot. And all of the people who {were} with him covered, a man his head, and they went up, going up and weeping.

notes.note: The phrase **going up and weeping** expresses a single idea. The word **weeping** tells in what way David was **going up**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way, here and at the end of the verse. Alternate translation: [going up weepingly] or [weeping as he went]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠רֹ֥אשׁ ל⁠וֹ֙ חָפ֔וּי וְ⁠ה֖וּא הֹלֵ֣ךְ יָחֵ֑ף
notes.note: Covering his head and walking barefoot were symbolic actions by which David expressed mourning, humiliation, and distress. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and he had covered his head and removed his sandals as signs of his deep sorrow]

The expression **his head was covered** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and he had covered his head]

The author is using **covered, a man his head** as a common expression of his culture to mean “each person covered his own head.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [covered their own heads]

bsb_verse_text: When David came to the summit, where he used to worship God, Hushai the Archite was there to meet him with his robe torn and dust on his head.
ult_verse_text: And it happened, David came to the top, where one would prostrate himself to God there, and behold, meeting him {was} Hushai the Archite. His robe was torn, and dirt {was} on his head.

notes.note: The author is using the word translated **And it happened** to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

The author is using the term **behold** to focus his listeners’ attention on an unexpected development in the story. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use for this purpose in your translation. Alternate translation: [and whom do you think he should meet but Hushai the Archite]

Tearing his robe and putting dirt on his head were symbolic actions by which Hushai was expressing deep mourning, grief, and distress. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [He had torn his robe and put dirt on his head to show his great distress]

The expression **His robe was torn** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [He had torn his robe]

bsb_verse_text: David said to him, “If you go on with me, you will be a burden to me.
ult_verse_text: And David said to him, “If you pass along with me, you will become a burden to me.

notes.note: David is speaking as if Hushai were actually a **burden** that would weigh him down. He means that Hushai would slow him down or make his situation more difficult. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you will only make things more difficult for me] or [you will not be able to help me, and you might slow me down]

bsb_verse_text: But you can thwart the counsel of Ahithophel for me if you return to the city and say to Absalom: ‘I will be your servant, my king; in the past I was your father’s servant, but now I will be your servant.’
ult_verse_text: But if you return {to} the city and say to Absalom, ‘I {am} your servant, O king. I was the servant of your father, and {as} I {was} previously, and now, so I {will be} your servant,’ then you will break up the counsel of Ahithophel for me.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אָמַרְתָּ֤ לְ⁠אַבְשָׁלוֹם֙ עַבְדְּ⁠ךָ֨ אֲנִ֤י הַ⁠מֶּ֨לֶךְ֙ אֶֽהְיֶ֔ה עֶ֣בֶד אָבִ֤י⁠ךָ וַֽ⁠אֲנִי֙ מֵ⁠אָ֔ז וְ⁠עַתָּ֖ה וַ⁠אֲנִ֣י עַבְדֶּ֑⁠ךָ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and address Absalom as king and tell him that you are his servant. Say that just as previously you were the servant of his father, so now you will be his servant]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

David is speaking as if Ahithophel’s advice were actually a physical object that Hushai could **break up**. He means that Hushai could prevent Absalom from accepting or following Ahithophel’s advice. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [then you will be able to help me by preventing Absalom from following Ahithophel’s advice] or [then you will be able to counter Ahithophel’s advice for my benefit]

bsb_verse_text: Will not Zadok and Abiathar the priests be there with you? Report to them everything you hear from the king’s palace.
ult_verse_text: {Will} not Zadok and Abiathar the priests {be} with you there? And may it be, every word that you hear from the house of the king, declare to Zadok and to Abiathar the priests.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠הֲ⁠ל֤וֹא עִמְּ⁠ךָ֙ שָׁ֔ם צָד֥וֹק וְ⁠אֶבְיָתָ֖ר הַ⁠כֹּהֲנִ֑ים
notes.note: David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Zadok and Abiathar the priests will be with you there.]

David is using the term **word** to represent what Absalom or others might say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [any information that you get]
David is using the term **house** to mean an entire household living together. In this context, it would apply to Absalom’s family and officials. Alternate translation: [in the royal court]

bsb_verse_text: Indeed, their two sons, Ahimaaz son of Zadok and Jonathan son of Abiathar, are there with them. Send them to me with everything you hear.”
ult_verse_text: Behold, with them there {are} the two of their sons, Ahimaaz to Zadok and Jonathan to Abiathar. And you shall send to me by their hand every word that you hear.”

notes.note: David is describing the father-son relationship between these men in the terms of his own culture. Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship. Alternate translation: [Zadok’s son Ahimaaz and Abiathar’s son Jonathan] or [Ahimaaz the son of Zadok and Jonathan the son of Abiathar]

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠שְׁלַחְתֶּ֤ם בְּ⁠יָדָ⁠ם֙ אֵלַ֔⁠י כָּל־דָּבָ֖ר אֲשֶׁ֥ר תִּשְׁמָֽעוּ
notes.note: The word **you** is plural in both instances. David seems to mean that Hushai, Zadok, and Abiathar should have Ahimaaz and Jonathan inform him of anything they hear. So use the plural form of “you” in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠שְׁלַחְתֶּ֤ם בְּ⁠יָדָ⁠ם֙ אֵלַ֔⁠י כָּל־דָּבָ֖ר אֲשֶׁ֥ר תִּשְׁמָֽעוּ
notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [11:14](../11/14.md). Alternate translation: [And you shall have them come and tell me any news that you hear]

bsb_verse_text: So David’s friend Hushai arrived in Jerusalem just as Absalom was entering the city.
ult_verse_text: So Hushai the friend of David came {to} the city. And Absalom came {to} Jerusalem.

notes.note: The word that the ULT translates as **And** indicates that Hushai **came** to Jerusalem around the same time as when Absalom **came** there himself. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could describe the time relationship more explicitly. Alternate translation: [returned to Jerusalem just as Absalom was arriving there himself]

bsb_verse_text: When David had gone a little beyond the summit, Ziba the servant of Mephibosheth was there to meet him. He had a pair of saddled donkeys loaded with two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred clusters of raisins, a hundred summer fruits, and a skin of wine.
ult_verse_text: And David passed over a little from the top, and behold, meeting him {was} Ziba, the young man of Mephibosheth, and a pair of saddled donkeys, and on them 200 {loaves of} bread and 100 clusters of raisins and 100 summer fruit and a skin of wine.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [15:32](../15/32.md).
See how you translated this expression in [9:9](../09/09.md), where it has a similar meaning. Alternate translation: [the servant of Mephibosheth]

The expression **saddled** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [donkeys that someone had saddled]
Here, **summer fruit** represents “figs.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and 100 bunches of figs]

bsb_verse_text: “Why do you have these?” asked the king. Ziba replied, “The donkeys are for the king’s household to ride, the bread and summer fruit are for the young men to eat, and the wine is to refresh those who become exhausted in the wilderness.”
ult_verse_text: And the king said to Ziba, “What {are} these to you?”

notes.note: David is using **What {are} these to you?** as a common expression of his culture to mean “Why have you brought these things?” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [What do you have here] or [Why have you brought these things]

Even though Ziba is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [for your house]
Ziba is using the term **house** to mean David’s household, that is, his family and servants. Alternate translation: [for the household of the king] or [for your household]

Ziba is using the adjective **faint** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [is for people who become faint in the wilderness]

bsb_verse_text: “Where is your master’s grandson?” asked the king. And Ziba answered, “Indeed, he is staying in Jerusalem, for he has said, ‘Today, the house of Israel will restore to me the kingdom of my grandfather.’”
ult_verse_text: And the king said, “And where {is} the son of your master?”

notes.orig_language_quote: יוֹשֵׁ֣ב בִּ⁠ירוּשָׁלִַ֔ם כִּ֣י אָמַ֔ר הַ⁠יּ֗וֹם יָשִׁ֤יבוּ לִ⁠י֙ בֵּ֣ית יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל אֵ֖ת מַמְלְכ֥וּת אָבִֽ⁠י
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since he said, ‘Today, the house of Israel will return the kingdom of my father to me,’ he is staying in Jerusalem]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [the people of Israel]
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:7](../09/07.md). Alternate translation: [my grandfather]

bsb_verse_text: So the king said to Ziba, “All that belongs to Mephibosheth is now yours!” “I humbly bow before you,” said Ziba. “May I find favor in your eyes, my lord the king!”
ult_verse_text: And the king said to Ziba, “Behold, to you {is} all that {was} to Mephibosheth.”

notes.note: Ziba did **prostrate** himself as he said this. This was a symbolic action that expressed submission, respect, and gratitude to the king. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [I prostrate myself to you in submission and gratitude]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [May you regard me with favor]

bsb_verse_text: As King David approached Bahurim, a man from the family of the house of Saul was just coming out. His name was Shimei son of Gera, and as he approached, he kept yelling out curses.
ult_verse_text: And King David came to Bahurim. And behold, a man from the clan of the house of Saul was coming out from there, and his name {was} Shimei, the son of Gera. {He} was coming out, coming out and cursing.

notes.orig_language_quote: מִ⁠שָּׁם֩ אִ֨ישׁ יוֹצֵ֜א מִ⁠מִּשְׁפַּ֣חַת בֵּית־שָׁא֗וּל וּ⁠שְׁמ⁠וֹ֙ שִׁמְעִ֣י בֶן־גֵּרָ֔א
notes.note: Here the author is introducing Shimei as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [a certain man named Shimei son of Gera, who belonged to the same clan as Saul’s family, was coming out from there]

The phrase **coming out and cursing** expresses a single idea. The word **cursing** tells in what way Shimei was **coming out**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [and he was cursing as he came out]

bsb_verse_text: He threw stones at David and at all the servants of the king, though the troops and all the mighty men were on David’s right and left.
ult_verse_text: And he stoned David with stones and all of the servants of King David, and all of the people and all of the mighty {were} on his right and on his left.

notes.note: It might seem that the expression **stoned David with stones** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [And he hurled stones at David]

Throwing stones at David was a symbolic action by which Shimei showed contempt and rebellion against David’s authority as king. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [he contemptuously threw stones at David]

The author is using this clause to describe something that was ongoing. This provides the background for the event that he describes in the first part of the verse. Connect this clause to that event in a way that makes it clear in your language that this clause is describing something that was ongoing at the same time. Alternate translation: [even though all of the people and all of the mighty had formed a protective shield on his right and on his left]

The author is using the adjective **mighty** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the mighty warriors]

The author is referring to the area all around David by naming two directions, **on his right** and **on his left**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [were surrounding him]

bsb_verse_text: And as he yelled curses, Shimei said, “Get out, get out, you worthless man of bloodshed!
ult_verse_text: And thus Shimei said in his cursing, “Get out, get out, man of blood, man of wickedness!

notes.note: Shimei is repeating the verb **get out** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [Get all the way out of here]

Shimei is saying **man of** here in the same way that biblical authors and characters often use the similar expression “son of” to indicate that a person has the characteristic of something. In this case, Shimei is saying that David has the characteristics of being deadly violent and wicked. The first phrase describes what David has done, and the second phrase describes what kind of person Shimei believes David to be. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. The UST models one way to do that.

The word **blood** is plural here because it refers to blood shed by violence. Your language may use the plural form of its word for blood to mean the same thing. If not, you could express the meaning in another way, here and in the next verse. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:28](../03/28.md). Alternate translation: [man of bloodshed]

bsb_verse_text: The LORD has paid you back for all the blood of the house of Saul, in whose place you have reigned, and the LORD has delivered the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. See, you have come to ruin because you are a man of bloodshed!”
ult_verse_text: Yahweh has brought back upon you all of the blood of the house of Saul, in whose place you are king, and Yahweh has given the kingdom into the hand of Absalom your son. And behold you in your evil, for you {are} a man of blood.”

notes.orig_language_quote: הֵשִׁיב֩ עָלֶ֨י⁠ךָ יְהוָ֜ה כֹּ֣ל ׀ דְּמֵ֣י בֵית־שָׁא֗וּל
notes.note: Shimei is using an expression similar to the one David used in [3:29](../03/29.md) when he spoke of the blood of Abner being on the head of Joab. By saying that Yahweh has brought the blood of the house of Saul **upon** David, Shimei means that Yahweh is holding David responsible for shedding this blood and punishing him for doing that. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Yahweh is holding you responsible for all of the blood of the house of Saul that you shed]

notes.orig_language_quote: הֵשִׁיב֩ עָלֶ֨י⁠ךָ יְהוָ֜ה כֹּ֣ל ׀ דְּמֵ֣י בֵית־שָׁא֗וּל
notes.note: Shimei is using **blood** to represent death, since people bleed when they are killed violently. He is referring to the many people whom David’s soldiers killed when, in order to make David the king, they fought against soldiers loyal to Saul’s descendants. Alternate translation: [Yahweh is holding you responsible for the deaths of all of the people loyal to Saul whom your soldiers killed]

Shimei is using the term **evil** to represent what he believes are the consequences of evil actions on David’s part. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And behold you suffering the consequences of your evil actions]

Shimei is using **behold you** as a common expression of his culture to mean that one can **behold** or look at David and see that what he is saying is true. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Now look at you, suffering the consequences of your evil actions] or [It is clear that you are suffering the consequences of your evil actions]

bsb_verse_text: Then Abishai son of Zeruiah said to the king, “Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and cut off his head!”
ult_verse_text: And Abishai the son of Zeruiah said to the king, “Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Please, let me go over and let me remove his head.”

notes.orig_language_quote: לָ֣⁠מָּה יְקַלֵּ֞ל הַ⁠כֶּ֤לֶב הַ⁠מֵּת֙ הַ⁠זֶּ֔ה אֶת־אֲדֹנִ֖⁠י הַ⁠מֶּ֑לֶךְ
notes.note: Abishai is using the question form for emphasis to express his outrage that Shimei would curse King David. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [This dead dog should not be cursing my lord the king!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:5](../09/05.md). Alternate translation: [contemptible person]

Even though Abishai is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [you, my lord the king]

bsb_verse_text: But the king replied, “What have I to do with you, O sons of Zeruiah? If he curses me because the LORD told him, ‘Curse David,’ who can ask, ‘Why did you do this?’”
ult_verse_text: And the king said, “What to me and to you, sons of Zeruiah? If he curses because Yahweh has said to him, ‘Curse David,’ then who shall say, ‘Why have you done thus’?”

notes.note: David is using **What to me and to you** as a common expression of his culture to say that he has nothing in common with these **sons of Zeruiah** in terms of what they want to do. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will have nothing to do with your suggestion, sons of Zeruiah!]

The word **you** is plural here because David is addressing both Abishai and Joab. Joab seems to have been nearby and supporting his brother Abishai’s suggestion. So use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

notes.orig_language_quote: כי יְקַלֵּ֗ל כִּ֤י יְהוָה֙ אָ֤מַר ל⁠וֹ֙ קַלֵּ֣ל אֶת־דָּוִ֔ד וּ⁠מִ֣י יֹאמַ֔ר מַדּ֖וּעַ עָשִׂ֥יתָה כֵּֽן
notes.note: David is using the question form for emphasis to express that no one should tell Shimei that he should not curse David. He is suggesting that someone might use the question form to tell Shimei that. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for those purposes, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [If he is cursing me because Yahweh has said to him, ‘Curse David,’ then no one should tell him, ‘You should not be doing thus’!]

notes.orig_language_quote: כִּ֤י יְהוָה֙ אָ֤מַר ל⁠וֹ֙ קַלֵּ֣ל אֶת־דָּוִ֔ד וּ⁠מִ֣י יֹאמַ֔ר מַדּ֖וּעַ עָשִׂ֥יתָה כֵּֽן
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [because Yahweh has told him to curse me, then no one should ask him why he is doing this] or [because Yahweh has told him to curse me, then no one should tell him that he should not be doing this]

David probably does not mean to suggest that Yahweh may have said this directly to Shimei. Instead, he probably means that Yahweh may have led Shimei to do this. So even if your language could put a quotation within a quotation, you may wish not to represent this as a direct quotation. Alternate translation: [Yahweh has led him to curse me]

bsb_verse_text: Then David said to Abishai and to all his servants, “Behold, my own son, my own flesh and blood, seeks my life. How much more, then, this Benjamite! Leave him alone and let him curse me, for the LORD has told him so.
ult_verse_text: And David said to Abishai and to all of his servants, “Behold, my son, who came out from my belly, is seeking my life. And how much more that now a Benjaminite! Leave him alone and let him curse, if Yahweh has spoken to him.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [7:12](../07/12.md). Alternate translation: [whose actual father I am]
See how you translated the similar expression in [4:8](../04/08.md). Alternate translation: [is seeking to kill me]
See how you translated the similar expression in [4:11](../04/11.md). Alternate translation: [And with how much greater reason]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [that now a Benjaminite should wish that I were dead]

bsb_verse_text: So David and his men proceeded along the road as Shimei went along the ridge of the hill opposite him. As Shimei went, he yelled curses, threw stones, and flung dust at David.
ult_verse_text: So David and his men walked on the road, and Shimei was walking on the side of the hill beside him, walking and he cursed, and he stoned with stones beside him, and he dusted with dust.

notes.note: The phrase **walking and he cursed** expresses a single idea. The word **cursed** tells in what way Shimei was **walking**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [walking cursingly] or [cursing as he walked]
See how you translated the similar expression in [16:6](../16/06.md). Alternate translation: [and he threw stones at him]

It might seem that the expression **dusted with dust** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [and he showered dirt on him]

Throwing dust on David was a symbolic action by which Shimei showed extreme disrespect and contempt for him. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and he threw dirt at him to show his contempt]

bsb_verse_text: Finally, the king and all the people with him arrived, exhausted. And there he refreshed himself.
ult_verse_text: And the king and all of the people who {were} with him came, weary. And he refreshed himself there.

notes.note: The implication is that David and his people arrived at the fords of the Jordan River. That was where David specified he would be going in [15:28](../15/28.md). You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [arrived at the fords of the Jordan]

bsb_verse_text: Then Absalom and all the men of Israel came to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.
ult_verse_text: And Absalom and all of the people, a man of Israel, came {to} Jerusalem, and Ahithophel {was} with him.

notes.note: The author is using **the people, a man of Israel** as a common expression of his culture to refer to Israelites from various tribes. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the Israelites from various tribes who had joined him]

bsb_verse_text: And David’s friend Hushai the Archite went to Absalom and said to him, “Long live the king! Long live the king!”
ult_verse_text: And it happened, when Hushai the Archite, the friend of David, came to Absalom, that Hushai said to Absalom, “May the king live! May the king live!”

notes.note: Hushai is repeating this phrase in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If speakers of your language repeat phrases for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [May the king live forever!]

Hushai is using a courteous and deferential expression that people in this culture would use to greet and acknowledge someone as their ruler. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Long live the king! Long live the king!] or [God save the king! God save the king!]

bsb_verse_text: “Is this the loyalty you show your friend?” Absalom replied. “Why did you not go with your friend?”
ult_verse_text: And Absalom said to Hushai, “{Is} this your loyalty to your friend? Why did you not go with your friend?”

notes.orig_language_quote: זֶ֥ה חַסְדְּ⁠ךָ֖ אֶת־רֵעֶ֑⁠ךָ לָ֥⁠מָּה לֹֽא־הָלַ֖כְתָּ אֶת־רֵעֶֽ⁠ךָ
notes.note: Absalom is using the question form to express disappointment with Hushai and to rebuke him for not being loyal to David. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [You are not showing loyalty to your friend! I would have expected you to go with him.]

bsb_verse_text: “Not at all,” Hushai answered. “For the one chosen by the LORD, by this people, and by all the men of Israel—his I will be, and with him I will remain.
ult_verse_text: And Hushai said to Absalom, “No, but whom Yahweh has chosen, and this people, and every man of Israel, to him I will be, and with him I will stay.

notes.note: Here the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [all the people of Israel]
See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to this chapter.

bsb_verse_text: Furthermore, whom should I serve if not his son? As I served in your father’s presence, so also I will serve in yours.”
ult_verse_text: And second, I, before whom shall I serve? {Is it} not to the face of his son? Just as I served to the face of your father, thus I will be to your face.”

notes.note: If your language would not represent a number in a form such as **second**, you could represent this number in a form that your language would use, or you could use a comparable expression. Alternate translation: [And point number two] or [Furthermore]

notes.orig_language_quote: לְ⁠מִי֙ אֲנִ֣י אֶֽעֱבֹ֔ד הֲ⁠ל֖וֹא לִ⁠פְנֵ֣י בְנ֑⁠וֹ
notes.note: Hushai is using the question form to emphasize that it is right and proper for him to serve Absalom, David’s son. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [it is appropriate for you, his son, to be the one before whose face I serve!]

After saying that Yahweh, the people present, and many other Israelites have chosen Absalom as king, Hushai is stating the pronoun **I**, even though its meaning is already included in the verb translated as **shall I serve**, to indicate that for his part, he will do the same thing. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that Hushai is saying that his own actions will be comparable to those of others. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [before whom shall I, for my part, serve]

notes.orig_language_quote: הֲ⁠ל֖וֹא לִ⁠פְנֵ֣י בְנ֑⁠וֹ כַּ⁠אֲשֶׁ֤ר עָבַ֨דְתִּי֙ לִ⁠פְנֵ֣י אָבִ֔י⁠ךָ כֵּ֖ן אֶהְיֶ֥ה לְ⁠פָנֶֽי⁠ךָ
notes.note: Here, **to the face of** represents being in the presence of someone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [Is it not in the presence of his son? Just as I served in the presence of your father, thus I will be in your presence]

bsb_verse_text: Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, “Give me counsel. What should we do?”
ult_verse_text: And Absalom said to Ahithophel, “Give counsel for yourselves. What shall we do?”

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֹּ֥אמֶר אַבְשָׁל֖וֹם אֶל־אֲחִיתֹ֑פֶל הָב֥וּ לָ⁠כֶ֛ם עֵצָ֖ה
notes.note: The implied “you” in the imperative **Give** is plural, as the plural pronoun **yourselves** indicates. While the author says that Absalom spoke these words to Ahithophel, Absalom was evidently addressing him as chief among a group of advisors. So use a plural form of the imperative in your translation if your language marks that distinction. You may also wish to indicate more fully whom Absalom was addressing. Alternate translation: [And Absalom said to Ahithophel and his other advisors, “Give counsel for yourselves]

Absalom is using the pronoun **yourselves** because his advisors are part of the group for whose benefit this **counsel** will be given. Since the speaker, Absalom, is also part of this group, it may be natural in your language to use a first-person plural pronoun. Alternate translation: [Give counsel for us]

bsb_verse_text: Ahithophel replied, “Sleep with your father’s concubines, whom he has left to take care of the palace. When all Israel hears that you have become a stench to your father, then the hands of all who are with you will be strengthened.”
ult_verse_text: And Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Go in to the concubines of your father whom he left to keep the house, and all of Israel will hear that you have made yourself stink with your father, and the hands of all who {are} with you will become strong.”

notes.note: The author is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **Go in to**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly, here and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [Sleep with]
See how you translated the similar expression in [10:6](../10/06.md). Alternate translation: [you have incensed your father] or [you have made yourself abhorrent to your father]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:7](../02/07.md). Alternate translation: [and all who are with you will become more determined]

bsb_verse_text: So they pitched a tent for Absalom on the roof, and he slept with his father’s concubines in the sight of all Israel.
ult_verse_text: So they spread a tent for Absalom on the roof, and Absalom went in to the concubines of his father to the eyes of all of Israel.

notes.note: Here, the word ** eyes** represents sight. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the sight of all of Israel]

The author says **all of Israel** as an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [for any Israelite to see]

bsb_verse_text: Now in those days the advice of Ahithophel was like the consultation of the word of God. Such was the regard that both David and Absalom had for Ahithophel’s advice.
ult_verse_text: Now the counsel of Ahithophel that he counseled in those days {was} just as if one inquired of the word of God. Thus {was} all of the counsel of Ahithophel, both to David and to Absalom.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠עֲצַ֣ת אֲחִיתֹ֗פֶל אֲשֶׁ֤ר יָעַץ֙ בַּ⁠יָּמִ֣ים הָ⁠הֵ֔ם כַּ⁠אֲשֶׁ֥ר יִשְׁאַל־בִּ⁠דְבַ֣ר הָ⁠אֱלֹהִ֑ים
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what has just happened in the story. He is accounting for why Absalom did such an outrageous thing without questioning it. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

It might seem that the expression **counsel of Ahithophel that he counseled** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [Now the counsel that Ahithophel gave]

The author is using the term **word** to represent what God would say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what God had to say]

bsb_verse_text: Furthermore, Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Let me choose twelve thousand men and set out tonight in pursuit of David.
ult_verse_text: And Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Please let me choose 12, 000 men, and let me arise and pursue after David tonight.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [let me take action]

bsb_verse_text: I will attack him while he is weak and weary; I will throw him into a panic, and all the people with him will flee; I will strike down only the king
ult_verse_text: And I will come upon him, and he {will be} weary and weak of hands, and I will make him tremble, and all of the people who {are} with him will flee. And I will strike the king alone.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [4:1](../04/01.md). Alternate translation: [and worn out]

Ahithophel assumes that Absalom will understand that he means he will **make** David **tremble** with fear. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 13:7](../../1sa/13/07.md). Alternate translation: [and I will make him tremble with fear] or [and I will terrify him]

See how you translated the similar expression in [1:1](../01/01.md). Also see the discussion of the term “strike” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [And I will kill the king alone]

bsb_verse_text: and bring all the people back to you as a bride returning to her husband. You seek the life of only one man; then all the people will be at peace.”
ult_verse_text: And I will make all of the people return to you. Like the returning of all {is} the man whom you are seeking. All of the people will be {at} peace.”

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. This could mean: (1) that all of the other people with David will be unharmed. The term “peace” would have the sense of “welfare” or “well-being.” Alternate translation: [All of the other people will be unharmed]; (2) that none of the people with David will continue fighting against Absalom once David is dead. The term “peace” would have the sense of “absence of war.” Alternate translation: [None of the other people will continue fighting against you]

bsb_verse_text: This proposal seemed good to Absalom and all the elders of Israel.
ult_verse_text: And the word was right in the eyes of Absalom and in the eyes of all of the elders of Israel.

notes.note: The author is using the term **word** to represent what Ahithophel said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And what Ahithophel had said]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּישַׁ֥ר & בְּ⁠עֵינֵ֣י אַבְשָׁלֹ֑ם וּ⁠בְ⁠עֵינֵ֖י כָּל־זִקְנֵ֥י יִשְׂרָאֵֽל
notes.note: The author is using the common expression of his culture **in the eyes of** to mean “in the judgment of” or “in the opinion of.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [seemed to Absalom and all of the elders of Israel to be the right thing to do]

bsb_verse_text: Then Absalom said, “Summon Hushai the Archite as well, and let us hear what he too has to say.”
ult_verse_text: But Absalom said, “Please also call to Hushai the Archite, and let us hear what {is} in his mouth, even he.”

notes.note: Absalom is probably speaking to a servant or official while using the pronoun **us** to refer to himself and the elders of Israel. Since the addressee is probably not included, use the exclusive form of “us” if your language marks that distinction.
Here, **in his mouth** represents “what he has to say.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [what he has to say]

Absalom adds this phrase to clarify his meaning. Without it, the word **his** might apply to Ahithophel, and Absalom might mean that he wants to hear what Ahithophel says about what Hushai recommends. He is clarifying that his meaning is simply that he wants to hear what Hushai has to say. You could indicate this in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [for his part]

bsb_verse_text: So Hushai came to Absalom, who told him, “Ahithophel has spoken this proposal. Should we carry it out? If not, what do you say?”
ult_verse_text: And Hushai came to Absalom, and Absalom spoke to him, saying, “According to this word, Ahithophel has spoken. Shall we do his word? If not, you speak.”

notes.orig_language_quote: לֵ⁠אמֹ֗ר כַּ⁠דָּבָ֤ר הַ⁠זֶּה֙ דִּבֶּ֣ר אֲחִיתֹ֔פֶל הֲ⁠נַעֲשֶׂ֖ה
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could express the first part of this as an indirect quotation, since Absalom did not actually say **According to this word**. Rather, he gave Hushai a summary of what Ahithophel had said. Alternate translation: [and told him what Ahithophel had said. Then he asked, “Shall we do]

Absalom is using the term **word** to represent what Ahithophel said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what he has recommended]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [tell us what you, for your part, would recommend]

bsb_verse_text: Hushai replied, “This time the advice of Ahithophel is not sound.”
ult_verse_text: And Hushai said to Absalom, “The counsel that Ahithophel has counseled on this occasion is not good.”

notes.note: It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. See how you translated the similar expression in [16:23](../16/23.md). Alternate translation: [The counsel that Ahithophel has given]

bsb_verse_text: He continued, “You know your father and his men. They are mighty men, and as fierce as a wild bear robbed of her cubs. Moreover, your father is a man of war who will not spend the night with the troops.
ult_verse_text: And Hushai said, “You, you know your father and his men, that they {are} warriors and they {are} bitter of soul, like a bear bereaved in the field. And your father {is} a man of war, so he will not lodge with the people.”

notes.orig_language_quote: אַתָּ֣ה יָ֠דַעְתָּ אֶת־אָבִ֨י⁠ךָ וְ⁠אֶת־אֲנָשָׁ֜י⁠ו כִּ֧י גִבֹּרִ֣ים הֵ֗מָּה
notes.note: Hushai is stating the pronoun **you** separately, even though the verb translated as **you know** already includes this meaning. He is doing that to emphasize that Absalom has knowledge that should make him realize that Ahithophel has not given good advice. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing the meaning here. Alternate translation: [You know quite well that your father and his men are warriors]

Hushai is speaking as if David and his men actually had souls that were **bitter**. He means that they were easily provoked to violence. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of Judges, see how you translated the similar expression in [Judges 18:25](../../jdg/18/25.md). Alternate translation: [and prone to violence]

The expression **bereaved** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [like a she-bear whose cubs someone has taken from her]

Hushai is using this comparison to make the point that just as a **bear bereaved in the field** is enraged and aggressive, so David and his men will be as well. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [as vicious as a bear in the wild whose cubs have been taken] or [as fierce as a bear in the wild that has lost her young]

Hushai is using this possessive form to describe a **man** who is characterized by having much experience in **war**. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form in that way, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [is an experienced warrior]

bsb_verse_text: Surely by now he is hiding in a cave or some other location. If some of your troops fall first, whoever hears of it will say, ‘There has been a slaughter among the troops who follow Absalom.’
ult_verse_text: Behold, he has now hidden himself in one of the pits or in one of the places. And it will be, when {some} among them fall in the beginning, the hearer will hear and say, ‘A slaughter has happened among the people who {are} behind Absalom.’

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:2](../01/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

The author is using **one of the places** as a common expression of his culture to mean “some other such place.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [or in some other such place]

The author is using the term **fall** by association to mean that they died, since people fall down when they die. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:16](../02/16.md). Alternate translation: [when some among them die] or [when some among them are killed]

The pronoun **them** refers to the soldiers whom Ahithophel wants to lead out against David. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [when some among the soldiers whom Ahithophel wants to lead out tonight fall]

It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you state this differently. Alternate translation: [people will hear and say]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אָמַ֔ר הָֽיְתָה֙ מַגֵּפָ֔ה בָּ⁠עָ֕ם אֲשֶׁ֖ר אַחֲרֵ֥י אַבְשָׁלֹֽם
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and say that a slaughter has happened among the people who are behind Absalom]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:25](../02/25.md). Alternate translation: [the soldiers who are fighting for Absalom]

bsb_verse_text: Then even the most valiant soldier with the heart of a lion will melt with fear, because all Israel knows that your father is a mighty man who has valiant men with him.
ult_verse_text: And even he, a son of valor whose heart {is} like the heart of a lion, melting, he will melt, because all of Israel knows that your father {is} a warrior and {they} who {are} with him {are} sons of valor.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:7](../02/07.md). Alternate translation: [a valiant warrior … are valiant warriors]

Here, the **heart** represents a person’s courage. You may have a comparable expression in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [whose courage is like the courage of a lion]

The point of this comparison is that just as **a lion** has great courage, so does King David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [whose courage is great, like the courage of a lion]

notes.orig_language_quote: הִמֵּ֣ס יִמָּ֑ס כִּֽי־יֹדֵ֤עַ כָּל־יִשְׂרָאֵל֙ כִּי־גִבּ֣וֹר אָבִ֔י⁠ךָ וּ⁠בְנֵי־חַ֖יִל אֲשֶׁ֥ר אִתּֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since all of Israel knows that your father is a warrior and they who are with him are sons of valor, melting, he will melt]

Hushai is repeating forms of the verb **melt** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [he will certainly melt]

Hushai is speaking as if even the bravest warrior in Absalom’s army would actually **melt** when he heard that David’s soldiers were killing the soldiers in his army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of Joshua, see how you translated the similar expressions in [Joshua 2:11](../../jos/02/11.md), [Joshua 5:1](../../jos/05/01.md), and [Joshua 7:5](../../jos/07/05.md). Alternate translation: [he will certainly become terrified]

bsb_verse_text: Instead, I advise that all Israel from Dan to Beersheba—a multitude like the sand on the seashore—be gathered to you, and that you yourself lead them into battle.
ult_verse_text: Therefore I counsel, being gathered, all of Israel shall be gathered to you, from Dan and to Beersheba, like the sand that {is} by the sea for multitude. And your face shall be going into the battle.

notes.note: The author is repeating forms of the verb **gathered** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [all of Israel shall certainly be gathered]

The expression **being gathered … shall be gathered** uses passive verbal forms. If your language would not use those forms, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you shall certainly gather all of Israel]

**Israel** represents “the soldiers of Israel.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language, here and in [verse 13](../17/13.md). Alternate translation: [you shall certainly gather all of the soldiers of Israel] or [you shall certainly gather the entire Israelite army]

Hushai is referring to all of Israel by naming cities at its northern and southern extremes, **Dan** and **Beersheba**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:10](../03/10.md). Alternate translation: [from throughout the country]

The point of this comparison is that just as **the sand that is by the sea** is uncountable, so would be the soldiers whom Absalom would gather. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [like the seemingly countless grains of sand that are by the sea for multitude]

By suggesting that Absalom will have too many troops to count, Hushai is making an overstatement for emphasis in order to convince Absalom to follow his advice. See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of how you might represent this overstatement and the ones in the next two verses in your translation.

Hushai is using one part of Absalom, his **face**, to represent Absalom himself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you personally shall go into the battle as the Israelite commander]

bsb_verse_text: Then we will attack David wherever we find him, and we will descend on him like dew on the ground. And of all the men with him, not even one will remain.
ult_verse_text: And we will come upon him in one of the places where he may be found there, and we {will be} upon him just as the dew falls upon the ground. And not even one will be left of him or of any of the men who {are} with him.

notes.note: It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you can shorten it. Alternate translation: [where he may be found]

The expression **will be found** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [where we may find him]

The point of this comparison is that just as the **dew** that **falls upon the ground** completely covers the ground, so Absalom’s army would completely overwhelm David and his soldiers. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [just as the dew falls everywhere upon the ground]
We recommend that you represent this overstatement in your translation, like the one in the previous verse.

The expression **will be left** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [will remain]

bsb_verse_text: If he retreats to a city, all Israel will bring ropes to that city, and we will drag it down to the valley until not even a pebble can be found there.”
ult_verse_text: And if he gathers himself into a city, then all of Israel will bring ropes to that city, and we will drag it to the wadi until that not even a pebble will be found there.”

notes.note: Here, David **himself** represents him and all of his forces. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [he gathers his forces]

Hushai is assuming that David would retreat into a fortified city that had been built on a hill above a valley or ravine through which water sometimes flowed. Since [16:2](../16/02.md) indicates that it was summer at this time, Hushai may not be expecting that water would be flowing. So you may wish to describe this feature without implying that there would be water in it. Alternate translation: [down into the ravine below]

Hushai is using the term **found** in a way characteristic of his language and culture to mean that such a **pebble** will not be able to **be found**, that is, it will not be there. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 9:8](../../1sa/09/08.md). Alternate translation: [not even a pebble will be there]
We recommend that you represent this overstatement in your translation, like the ones in the previous two verses.

bsb_verse_text: Then Absalom and all the men of Israel said, “The advice of Hushai the Archite is better than that of Ahithophel.” For the LORD had purposed to thwart the good counsel of Ahithophel in order to bring disaster on Absalom.
ult_verse_text: And Absalom and all of the men of Israel said, “The counsel of Hushai the Archite {is} better than the counsel of Ahithophel.” For Yahweh had appointed to break up the good counsel of Ahithophel for the sake of Yahweh bringing harm to Absalom.

notes.note: Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [This happened because]
See how you translated the similar expression in [15:34](../15/34.md). Alternate translation: [to counter]

The author does not mean that it was morally **good** for Ahithophel to have recommended launching a sudden attack in order to kill David. He means that Ahithophel’s counsel would have been “good” for Absalom in the sense that it would have been more effective in defeating David. You could translate the term that way if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the counsel of Ahithophel that would have been more effective]

Since the author has already mentioned Yahweh earlier in the sentence, it may be more natural in your language to refer to him with a pronoun here. Alternate translation: [so that he could bring harm to Absalom]

bsb_verse_text: So Hushai told Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, “This is what Ahithophel has advised Absalom and the elders of Israel, and this is what I have advised.
ult_verse_text: Then Hushai said to Zadok and to Abiathar, the priests, “Like this and like this Ahithophel counseled Absalom and the elders of Israel, but like this and like this I, I have counseled.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֹּ֣אמֶר חוּשַׁ֗י אֶל־צָד֤וֹק וְ⁠אֶל־אֶבְיָתָר֙ הַ⁠כֹּ֣הֲנִ֔ים כָּ⁠זֹ֣את וְ⁠כָ⁠זֹ֗את יָעַ֤ץ אֲחִיתֹ֨פֶל֙ אֶת־אַבְשָׁלֹ֔ם וְ⁠אֵ֖ת זִקְנֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֑ל וְ⁠כָ⁠זֹ֥את וְ⁠כָ⁠זֹ֖את יָעַ֥צְתִּי אָֽנִי
notes.note: Since Hushai did not actually say the words **like this and like this**, if it would be more natural in your language, you could express this as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: [Then Hushai told Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, what Ahithophel had counseled Absalom and the elders of Israel and what he himself had counseled instead]

The author is using **Like this and like this** as a common expression of his culture to mean that Hushai summarized what he and Ahithophel had said. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [In such and such a way … but in such and such a way]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [I, for my part, have counseled]

bsb_verse_text: Now send quickly and tell David, ‘Do not spend the night at the fords of the wilderness, but be sure to cross over. Otherwise the king and all the people with him will be swallowed up.’”
ult_verse_text: And now, send quickly and declare to David, saying, ‘Do not lodge tonight at the fords of the wilderness, but also crossing over, cross over, lest the king be swallowed and all of the people who {are} with him.’”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

notes.orig_language_quote: לֵ⁠אמֹ֗ר אַל־תָּ֤לֶן הַ⁠לַּ֨יְלָה֙ בְּ⁠עַֽרְב֣וֹת הַ⁠מִּדְבָּ֔ר וְ⁠גַ֖ם עָב֣וֹר תַּעֲב֑וֹר פֶּ֚ן יְבֻלַּ֣ע לַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ וּ⁠לְ⁠כָל־הָ⁠עָ֖ם אֲשֶׁ֥ר אִתּֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and tell him not to lodge tonight at the fords of the wilderness but instead, crossing over, to cross over, lest the king be swallowed and all of the people who are with him]
See how you translated the similar expression in [15:28](../15/28.md). Alternate translation: [at the fords of the Jordan River]

Hushai is repeating forms of the verb **cross over** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [but instead certainly cross over]

Hushai is using the word translated as **lest** to introduce an outcome that he does not want to happen. Because of this, he first gives David an instruction for him and his men to follow so that this will not happen. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that avoiding this outcome is the purpose of the instruction. Alternate translation: [Otherwise, the king will be swallowed]

Here, Hushai is speaking as if King David would actually be **swallowed**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [lest the king be destroyed]

The expression **be swallowed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [lest Absalom and his army swallow up the king] or [lest Absalom and his army destroy the king]

Even though the priests’ messengers would be addressing David directly, Hushai tells them to speak of him in the third person as **the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [you, the king]

bsb_verse_text: Now Jonathan and Ahimaaz were staying at En-rogel, where a servant girl would come and pass along information to them. They in turn would go and inform King David, for they dared not be seen entering the city.
ult_verse_text: Now Jonathan and Ahimaaz were staying at En Rogel, and a maidservant would go and declare to them, and they, they would go and declare to King David, for they were not able to be seen entering the city.

notes.orig_language_quote: וִ⁠יהוֹנָתָ֨ן וַ⁠אֲחִימַ֜עַץ עֹמְדִ֣ים בְּ⁠עֵין־רֹגֵ֗ל וְ⁠הָלְכָ֤ה הַ⁠שִּׁפְחָה֙ וְ⁠הִגִּ֣ידָה לָ⁠הֶ֔ם וְ⁠הֵם֙ יֵֽלְכ֔וּ וְ⁠הִגִּ֖ידוּ לַ⁠מֶּ֣לֶךְ דָּוִ֑ד כִּ֣י לֹ֥א יוּכְל֛וּ לְ⁠הֵרָא֖וֹת לָ⁠ב֥וֹא הָ⁠עִֽירָ⁠ה
notes.note: Here, the author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. This information explains how Jonathan and Ahimaaz were secretly communicating with David after he had fled from Jerusalem. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הָלְכָ֤ה הַ⁠שִּׁפְחָה֙ וְ⁠הִגִּ֣ידָה לָ⁠הֶ֔ם וְ⁠הֵם֙ יֵֽלְכ֔וּ וְ⁠הִגִּ֖ידוּ לַ⁠מֶּ֣לֶךְ דָּוִ֑ד כִּ֣י לֹ֥א יוּכְל֛וּ לְ⁠הֵרָא֖וֹת לָ⁠ב֥וֹא הָ⁠עִֽירָ⁠ה
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since they could not risk being seen in the city, a servant girl would bring them messages, which they would then deliver to King David]
In a context such as this, your language might say “come” instead of **go**. Alternate translation: [and a maidservant would come]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [and for their part, they would go]

The expression **be seen** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [they could not allow people to see them]

bsb_verse_text: But a young man did see them and told Absalom. So the two left quickly and came to the house of a man in Bahurim. He had a well in his courtyard, and they climbed down into it.
ult_verse_text: But a young man saw them, and he declared to Absalom. So the two of them went {in} haste, and they came to the house of a man in Bahurim, and to him {was} a well in his courtyard, and they went down there.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **haste**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [hastily]

bsb_verse_text: Then the man’s wife took a covering, spread it over the mouth of the well, and scattered grain over it so nobody would know a thing.
ult_verse_text: And the woman took and stretched out a covering over the face of the well, and she spread grain over it, so the matter was not known.

notes.note: The context indicates that this **woman** was married to the man whom the author describes in the previous verse. Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship. Alternate translation: [And his wife]

The author is using **the face of the well** as a common expression of his culture to mean “the top of the well” or “the opening of the well.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the mouth of the well]

The expression **was not known** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [so no one knew the matter]

bsb_verse_text: When Absalom’s servants came to the woman at the house, they asked, “Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?” “They have crossed over the brook,” she replied. The men searched but did not find them, so they returned to Jerusalem.
ult_verse_text: And the servants of Absalom came to the woman {at} the house, and they said, “Where {are} Ahimaaz and Jonathan?”

notes.note: It might seem that the expression **brook of waters** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [that brook]

bsb_verse_text: After the men had gone, Ahimaaz and Jonathan climbed up out of the well and went to inform King David, saying, “Get up and cross over the river at once, for Ahithophel has given this advice against you.”
ult_verse_text: And it happened after they went that they came up from the well, and they went and declared to King David. And they said to David, “Arise and cross over the waters in haste, for according to this Ahithophel has counseled against you.”

notes.note: The author is using the phrase **And it happened** to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

The first pronoun **they** refers to Absalom’s soldiers, while the second pronoun **they** refers to Jonathan and Ahimaaz. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [after the soldiers left that Jonathan and Ahimaaz came up]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֹּאמְר֣וּ אֶל־דָּוִ֗ד ק֣וּמוּ וְ⁠עִבְר֤וּ מְהֵרָה֙ אֶת־הַ⁠מַּ֔יִם כִּי־כָ֛כָה יָעַ֥ץ עֲלֵי⁠כֶ֖ם אֲחִיתֹֽפֶל
notes.note: Since Jonathan and Ahimaaz did not actually say **according to this**, but provided an actual summary, if it would be more natural in your language, you could express the first part of this as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: [And they told David what Ahithophel had counseled against him and then said, “Arise and cross over the waters in haste.”]

notes.orig_language_quote: ק֣וּמוּ וְ⁠עִבְר֤וּ מְהֵרָה֙ אֶת־הַ⁠מַּ֔יִם כִּי־כָ֛כָה יָעַ֥ץ עֲלֵי⁠כֶ֖ם אֲחִיתֹֽפֶל
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since according to this Ahithophel has counseled against you, arise and cross over the waters in haste]

The word **you** and the implied “you” in the imperatives **Arise** and **cross over** are plural because Jonathan and Ahimaaz mean David and all of the people who are with him. So use plural forms in your translation if your language marks that distinction.
The implication is that **the waters** refers to the Jordan River. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the Jordan River]

bsb_verse_text: So David and all the people with him got up and crossed the Jordan. By daybreak, there was no one left who had not crossed the Jordan.
ult_verse_text: So David and all of the people who {were} with him arose and crossed the Jordan until the light of dawn, until not one was missing who had not crossed the Jordan.

notes.orig_language_quote: אַחַד֙ לֹ֣א נֶעְדָּ֔ר אֲשֶׁ֥ר לֹא־עָבַ֖ר אֶת־הַ⁠יַּרְדֵּֽן
notes.note: This is a double negative, consisting of two instances of the negative word **not**. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use a positive expression to translate this. Alternate translation: [every one of them had crossed the Jordan]

The expression **was missing** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [they were not missing anyone]

bsb_verse_text: When Ahithophel saw that his advice had not been followed, he saddled his donkey and set out for his house in his hometown. He put his affairs in order and hanged himself. So he died and was buried in his father’s tomb.
ult_verse_text: And Ahithophel saw that his counsel was not done, and he saddled his donkey, and he arose and went to his house, to his city, and he commanded about his house, and he hanged himself, and he died. And he was buried in the grave of his father.

notes.note: The expression **was not done** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Absalom had not followed his counsel] or [Absalom had not done what he advised]

The author is using **commanded about his house** as a common expression of his culture to mean “put his affairs in order” or “arranged his household affairs.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and he put his house in order]

The expression **was buried** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And his family buried him]

bsb_verse_text: Then David went to Mahanaim, and Absalom crossed the Jordan with all the men of Israel.
ult_verse_text: And David came to Mahanaim. And Absalom crossed the Jordan, he and all of the men of Israel with him.

notes.note: The author is saying **all of the men of Israel** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [and all of the Israelite soldiers who were supporting him]

bsb_verse_text: Absalom had appointed Amasa over the army in place of Joab. Amasa was the son of a man named Ithra, the Ishmaelite who had married Abigail, the daughter of Nahash and sister of Zeruiah the mother of Joab.
ult_verse_text: And Absalom appointed Amasa over the army in place of Joab. Now Amasa {was} the son of a man and his name {was} Ithra the Israelite, who had gone in to Abigail, the daughter of Nahash, the sister of Zeruiah the mother of Joab.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠עֲמָשָׂ֣א בֶן־אִ֗ישׁ וּ⁠שְׁמ⁠וֹ֙ יִתְרָ֣א הַ⁠יִּשְׂרְאֵלִ֔י אֲשֶׁר־בָּא֙ אֶל־אֲבִיגַ֣ל בַּת־נָחָ֔שׁ אֲח֥וֹת צְרוּיָ֖ה אֵ֥ם יוֹאָֽב
notes.note: Here the author is introducing Amasa as new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation.

It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [a man named Ithra the Israelite]

The account of Amasa’s lineage in [1 Chronicles 2:17](../../1ch/02/17.md) identifies his father as “Jether the Ishmaelite.” The name Jether is simply a variant of the name Ithra, but “Ishmaelite” may have been the original reading here, since identifying Ithra as an **Israelite** would not provide information that would help readers distinguish him from other men by the same name. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

notes.orig_language_quote: אֲבִיגַ֣ל בַּת־נָחָ֔שׁ אֲח֥וֹת צְרוּיָ֖ה אֵ֥ם יוֹאָֽב
notes.note: Abigail was the sister of Zeruiah. Zeruiah was the mother of Joab. Be sure that these relationships are clear in your translation.

The author is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **had gone in to**. The implication, which the author is politely not stating directly, is that Ithra had not necessarily been married to Abigail. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language, or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [who had slept with Abigail, the daughter of Nahash]

bsb_verse_text: They brought beds, basins, and earthen vessels, as well as wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, lentils,
ult_verse_text: beds and basins and vessels of the potter and wheat and barley and flour and roasted grain and beans and lentils and roasted beans

notes.note: The main verb of this sentence, “brought,” occurs in the next verse. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine [17:28](../17/28.md) and [17:29](../17/29.md) into a verse bridge so that you can put the verb “brought” before the list of things that these men provided. You could also state the verb, which is implied in the context, in this verse and repeat it in the next verse. The UST models one way to do that.

Here, **vessels of the potter** represents “earthenware vessels” or “clay pots.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [earthenware vessels]

The term that the ULT translates as **roasted grain** is the same one that it translates as **roasted beans**, but the context suggests that the author is not listing the same item twice. Instead, this term describes the way in which the grain and beans were prepared.

The term **beans** describes edible seeds that typically grow in pods. A **lentil** is a kind of small, round, edible seed. If your readers would not be familiar with these foods, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [and peas and small beans]

bsb_verse_text: honey, curds, sheep, and cheese from the herd for David and his people to eat. For they said, “The people have become hungry, exhausted, and thirsty in the wilderness.”
ult_verse_text: and honey and curds and sheep and cheese of cattle, they brought to David and to the people who {were} with him to eat, for they said, “The people {will be} hungry and weary and thirsty in the wilderness.”

notes.note: The word **curds** describes a soft, thickened milk product similar to yogurt. If your readers would not be familiar with what curds are, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [and yogurt] or [and soured milk]
If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about thirst with the information about hunger. Alternate translation: [hungry and thirsty and weary]

bsb_verse_text: He sent out the troops, a third under Joab, a third under Joab’s brother Abishai son of Zeruiah, and a third under Ittai the Gittite. And the king said to the troops, “I will surely march out with you as well.”
ult_verse_text: And David sent out the people, a third in the hand of Joab and a third in the hand of Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, the brother of Joab, and a third in the hand of Ittai the Gittite. And the king said to the people, “Going out, I will go out, I too, with you.”

notes.note: A **third** means one part out of three equal parts. Represent this in the way your language and culture characteristically would.

Here, **hand** represents the control of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly, in this case and for the same expression as applied to Abishai and Ittai. Alternate translation: [under the command of Joab]
The author is identifying **Abishai**, not **Zeruiah**, as the **brother of Joab**. Be sure that this is clear in your translation.

David is repeating forms of the verb **go out** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [I will certainly go out, I too]

David is stating the pronoun **I** separately, even though the verb translated as **I will go out** already includes this meaning. He is doing that to indicate that his actions will be comparable to those of the Israelite soldiers and commanders. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that David is indicating that his actions will be comparable. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [And for my own part, going out, I will go out] or [And for my own part, I will certainly go out]

bsb_verse_text: But the people pleaded, “You must not go out! For if we have to flee, they will not care about us. Even if half of us die, they will not care. But you are worth ten thousand of us. It is better now if you support us from the city.”
