ult_verse_text: But the people said, “You shall not go out, for if fleeing, we flee, they will not set a heart to us. Even if half of us die, they will not set a heart to us. For now {there are} ten thousand like us. And now, {it is} better that you be help for us from the city.”

notes.note: The soldiers are repeating forms of the verb **flee** in order to intensify their expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [if in fact we flee]
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:20](../13/20.md). Alternate translation: [they will not be concerned about us]
A **half** means one part out of two equal parts. Represent this in the way your language and culture characteristically would.

The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation) reads “you” instead of **now**. This reflects a difference of only one letter in Hebrew, and it gives the meaning, “For you are worth ten thousand of us.” That may have been the original reading, since it does not require the reader to supply the rest of the thought (as the traditional Hebrew text requires, “but there is only one like you”). If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

bsb_verse_text: “I will do whatever seems best to you,” the king replied. So he stood beside the gate, while all the troops marched out by hundreds and by thousands.
ult_verse_text: And the king said to them, “What is good in your eyes, I will do.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [I will do as you see fit] or [I will do what you think is best]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יַּעֲמֹ֤ד הַ⁠מֶּ֨לֶךְ֙ אֶל־יַ֣ד הַ⁠שַּׁ֔עַר וְ⁠כָל־הָ⁠עָם֙ יָֽצְא֔וּ לְ⁠מֵא֖וֹת וְ⁠לַ⁠אֲלָפִֽים
notes.note: Standing beside the gate was a symbolic action by which the king showed his support for the troops and his authority in sending them to battle. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And the king took his place beside the gate to review the troops as they marched out in their military units]
See how you translated the similar expression in [15:2](../15/02.md). Alternate translation: [next to the gate]

bsb_verse_text: Now the king had commanded Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, “Treat the young man Absalom gently for my sake.” And all the people heard the king’s orders to each of the commanders regarding Absalom.
ult_verse_text: And the king commanded Joab and Abishai and Ittai, saying, “Gently for me with the young man, with Absalom.” And all of the people heard when the king commanded all of the commanders about the matter of Absalom.

notes.note: David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [Deal gently for my sake]

David could have referred to Absalom as “my son” rather than as **the young man**. However, by rebelling against his father, Absalom was acting in a way unworthy of a son, so David did not describe him in terms of their family relationship. So while the expression “young man” can have the sense of “son” in some contexts, it would not be appropriate to translate it that way here.

bsb_verse_text: So David’s army marched into the field to engage Israel, and the battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.
ult_verse_text: And the people went out {to} the field to meet Israel, and the battle was in the Forest of Ephraim.

notes.note: Here, **Israel** represents “the Israelite army.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the Israelite army]

This is a name, not a description of a forest within the territory of the tribe of Ephraim. That territory was west of the Jordan River, while the narrative makes clear that this battle was fought on the east side of the river. This forest is not mentioned elsewhere in the Bible, and it is not entirely clear how it got this name. But translate this as a name, not as a description.

bsb_verse_text: There the people of Israel were defeated by David’s servants, and the slaughter was great that day—twenty thousand men.
ult_verse_text: And the people of Israel were struck there to the face of the servants of David. And the striking there was great on that day, 20, 000.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּנָּ֤גְפוּ שָׁם֙ עַ֣ם יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל לִ⁠פְנֵ֖י עַבְדֵ֣י דָוִ֑ד
notes.note: Here, **to the face of** represents being in front of David’s servants, that is, opposing them in battle. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And the people of Israel were struck there in front of the servants of David] or [ And the people of Israel were struck there as they opposed the servants of David]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּנָּ֤גְפוּ שָׁם֙ עַ֣ם יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל לִ⁠פְנֵ֖י עַבְדֵ֣י דָוִ֑ד
notes.note: The expression **were struck** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And the servants of David struck the people of Israel there as they opposed them]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:17](../02/17.md). Alternate translation: [And the people of Israel were defeated]

While the word **struck** in the previous sentence describes defeat, the term **striking** in this sentence describes killing. You could indicate this in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. See the discussion of the term “struck” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [the slaughter]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [for 20,000 Israelite soldiers were killed]

bsb_verse_text: The battle spread over the whole countryside, and that day the forest devoured more people than the sword.
ult_verse_text: And the battle was scattered there over the face of all of the land. And the forest made more to consume among the people than what the sword consumed on that day.

notes.note: The expression **was scattered** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And the battle spread out]
See how you translated the similar expression in [11:11](../11/11.md). Alternate translation: [the surface of]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֶּ֤רֶב הַ⁠יַּ֨עַר֙ לֶ⁠אֱכֹ֣ל בָּ⁠עָ֔ם מֵ⁠אֲשֶׁ֥ר אָכְלָ֛ה הַ⁠חֶ֖רֶב בַּ⁠יּ֥וֹם הַ⁠הֽוּא
notes.note: The author is speaking of this **forest** and of a **sword** as if they were living things that could have **consumed** or eaten these soldiers. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: [And more of Absalom’s soldiers died from injuries they suffered trying to flee through the forest than died from injuries they suffered from the swords that David’s soldiers used against them]; (2) Alternate translation: [And more of Absalom’s soldiers died during the fighting in the forest, which slowed them down as they were trying to flee, than died from the fighting in the open field]

Together, the terms **made more** and **to consume** expresses a single idea. The term **made more** tells to what extent the forest consumed or killed soldiers, that is, to a greater extent than the weapons opposing soldiers were using. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [And the forest consumed more of the people] or [And the forest killed more of the people]

bsb_verse_text: Now Absalom was riding on his mule when he met the servants of David, and as the mule went under the thick branches of a large oak, Absalom’s head was caught fast in the tree. The mule under him kept going, so that he was suspended in midair.
ult_verse_text: And Absalom was met to the face of the servants of David. Now Absalom was riding on the mule, and the mule came under the branches of a great oak tree, and his head was caught in the oak tree, and he was put between the heavens and between the earth, and the mule that {was} under him passed on.

notes.note: Here, **to the face of** represents being in the presence of David’s servants. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And Absalom encountered some of the servants of David]

The author is using **was met** as a common expression of his culture to mean “happened to be.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And Absalom unexpectedly found himself in the presence of the servants of David] or [And Absalom happened to come into the presence of the servants of David]

Here, the author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

Riding on a mule was a symbolic action by which Absalom showed that he claimed to be king of Israel, since kings rode on mules. (For example, David has Solomon ride on his mule in [1 Kings 1:33](../../1ki/01/33.md) to show that he has chosen him to be the next king.) If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [Now Absalom was riding on the royal mule]
In a context such as this, your language might say “went” instead of **came**. Alternate translation: [and the mule went]
In this context, the term **heavens** refers to the sky, and the term **earth** refers to the ground. Alternate translation: [between the sky and the ground] or [up in the air]

bsb_verse_text: When one of the men saw this, he told Joab, “I just saw Absalom hanging in an oak tree!”
ult_verse_text: And one man saw, and he declared to Joab, and he said, “Behold, I saw Absalom hung on an oak tree.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:2](../01/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

The expression **hung** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [hanging from an oak tree]

bsb_verse_text: “You just saw him!” Joab exclaimed. “Why did you not strike him to the ground right there? I would have given you ten shekels of silver and a warrior’s belt!”
ult_verse_text: And Joab said to the man declaring to him, “And behold, you saw, so why did you not strike him there to the ground? For {it was} to me to give to you ten silver and one belt.”

notes.note: Joab is using the question form to rebuke the soldier for not killing Absalom. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [so you should have struck him there to the ground!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:1](../01/01.md). Alternate translation: [kill him]

Joab is using **to the ground** as a common expression of his culture to mean “right where he is.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [on the spot]

Joab is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [shekels of silver]

Joab is using **{it was} to me** as a common expression of his culture to mean “I had the capacity.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [For I could have given you]

In this culture, commanders would give a soldier a decorative and costly military **belt** in recognition of distinguished service in battle. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and a military belt for distinguished service] or [and a military decoration]

bsb_verse_text: The man replied, “Even if a thousand shekels of silver were weighed out into my hands, I would not raise my hand against the son of the king. For we heard the king command you and Abishai and Ittai, ‘Protect the young man Absalom for my sake.’
ult_verse_text: And the man said to Joab, “Even if I were weighing on my palm a thousand silver, I would not stretch out my hand against the son of the king. For in our ears the king commanded you and Abishai and Ittai, saying, ‘Guard who {is} upon the young man Absalom.’

notes.note: While this soldier might have hefted the silver in his **palm** or hand to be sure it was the entire weight Joab promised, the term **palm** in this context also represents possession. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [I had in my possession]

The soldier is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [a thousand shekels of silver]

These 1,000 **silver** shekels would have weighed nearly 12 kilograms or over 25 pounds. In your translation, you could use the ancient measurement and spell the word “shekel” the way it sounds in your language. You could also use the metric measurement given in the UST or use the measurement that your language and culture customarily use. Alternatively, you could use the ancient measurement and put a modern measurement in parentheses in the text or in a footnote.
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:14](../01/14.md). Alternate translation: [I would not use violence]
Here the word **For** provides not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [After all]
The soldier is using the term **ears** to mean hearing. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [in our hearing]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [to guard who was upon the young man Absalom]

In paraphrasing what David said, the soldier is using **Guard who is upon** as a common expression of his culture to mean “make sure that no one hurts.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Make sure that no one hurts]

bsb_verse_text: If I had jeopardized my own life—and nothing is hidden from the king—you would have abandoned me.”
ult_verse_text: Otherwise I would have done wrong against my life, for every matter is not hidden from the king, and you, you would have stationed yourself from before {me}.”

notes.orig_language_quote: עָשִׂ֤יתִי בְנַפְשִׁי֙ שֶׁ֔קֶר וְ⁠כָל־דָּבָ֖ר לֹא־יִכָּחֵ֣ד מִן־הַ⁠מֶּ֑לֶךְ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since every matter is not hidden from the king, I would have done wrong against my life]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **wrong**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [something wrong]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:8](../17/08.md). Alternate translation: [and you know quite well that you would have stationed yourself]

The soldier is using **stationed yourself from before me** as a common expression of his culture to mean “kept your distance” or “would not have defended me.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and you would have kept your distance from me] or [and you would not have defended me]

bsb_verse_text: But Joab declared, “I am not going to wait like this with you!” And he took three spears in his hand and thrust them through the heart of Absalom while he was still alive in the oak tree.
ult_verse_text: And Joab said, “I will not wait thus to your face.” And he took three spears in his palm, and he thrust them into the heart of Absalom, he still {being} alive in the heart of the oak tree.

notes.note: Here, **to your face** represents being in your presence. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in your presence] or [here with you]

Here, **in his palm** represents possession and conveyance. (These **spears** were likely too large to have all fit in Joab’s palm.) If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [with him]

Here the word **heart** probably refers to Absalom’s chest or torso, the central part of his body. (It has the same sense as in the phrase **the heart of the oak tree** in the next clause.) It is unlikely that Absalom would still have been alive afterwards if Joab had thrust three spears into his actual heart. You could indicate this meaning in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [into the chest of Absalom] or [into Absalom’s body]

The author is using **in the heart of the oak tree** as a common expression of his culture to mean “in the midst of the oak tree” or “among the branches of the oak tree.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [in the midst of the oak tree] or [among the branches of the oak tree]

bsb_verse_text: Then Joab blew the ram’s horn, and the troops broke off their pursuit of Israel because Joab had restrained them.
ult_verse_text: Then Joab blew on the shofar, and the people returned from pursuing after Israel, for Joab restrained the people.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יָּ֣שָׁב הָ⁠עָ֔ם מִ⁠רְדֹ֖ף אַחֲרֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֑ל כִּֽי־חָשַׂ֥ךְ יוֹאָ֖ב אֶת־הָ⁠עָֽם
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [and since Joab had restrained the people, the people returned from pursuing after Israel]

Here, **Israel** represents “the Israelite soldiers.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the Israelite soldiers]

bsb_verse_text: They took Absalom, cast him into a large pit in the forest, and piled a huge mound of stones over him. Meanwhile, all the Israelites fled, each to his home.
ult_verse_text: And they took Absalom, and they threw him into a great pit in the forest, and they set up a very great heap of stones over him. And all of Israel fled, a man to his tent.

notes.note: In this culture, piling a **heap of stones** over a grave was a way putting shame on the person who had died. The Israelites had done this, for example, to Achan in [Joshua 7:26](../../jos/07/26.md). Some interpreters believe that in this case, it was also symbolic of the stoning that the Law of Moses said was the penalty for a rebellious son ([Deuteronomy 21:18–21](../../deu/21/18.md). If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and to shame him, they set over him a very great heap of stones]

The author is using **a man to his tent** as a common expression of his culture to mean that the soldiers stopped their military campaign altogether and each of them went back to his home and family. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [abandoning the army and returning home]

bsb_verse_text: During his lifetime, Absalom had set up for himself a pillar in the King’s Valley, for he had said, “I have no son to preserve the memory of my name.” So he gave the pillar his name, and to this day it is called Absalom’s Monument.
ult_verse_text: Now while he was living, Absalom had taken and set up for himself a pillar, which {was} in the Valley of the King. For he said, “{There is} no son to me in order to make {people} remember my name.” And he called the pillar according to his name, and it is called the Hand of Absalom to this day.

notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers appreciate the irony of Absalom wanting to have a high monument that would make people remember him. His monument turned out to be the shameful pile of stones, not the one described here. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

The author says in [14:27](../14/27.md) that Absalom had three sons, so they had all apparently died by the time Absalom set up this pillar. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. The UST models one way to do that.

The expression **it is called** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and people call it]
See how you translated the similar expression in [4:3](../04/03.md). Alternate translation: [as of the time of this writing]

In this culture, people used the term **Hand** to mean a monument. They may have done this because ancient monuments may have had an image of a hand engraved or sculpted on them as a symbol of power and strength, or because monuments called attention to an achievement, as a gesturing hand would do. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 15:12](../../1sa/15/12.md). Alternate translation, as in the UST: [Absalom’s Monument]

bsb_verse_text: Then Ahimaaz son of Zadok said, “Please let me run and tell the king the good news that the LORD has avenged him of his enemies.”
ult_verse_text: And Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, said, “Please let me run and let me bring news {to} the king, for Yahweh has judged him out of the hand of his enemies.”

notes.orig_language_quote: אָר֣וּצָה נָּ֔א וַ⁠אֲבַשְּׂרָ֖ה אֶת־הַ⁠מֶּ֑לֶךְ כִּי־שְׁפָט֥⁠וֹ יְהוָ֖ה מִ⁠יַּ֥ד אֹיְבָֽי⁠ו
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since Yahweh has judged the king out of the hand of his enemies, please let me run and bring news to him]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [Yahweh has judged him favorably and has delivered him out of the hand of his enemies]

Here, **hand** represents the capability of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the power of his enemies]

bsb_verse_text: But Joab replied, “You are not the man to take good news today. You may do it another day, but you must not do so today, because the king’s son is dead.”
ult_verse_text: But Joab said to him, “You {are} not a man of news this day, but you will bring news another day. But this day you will not bring news, because the son of the king is dead.”

notes.note: Joab is saying **man of** here in the same way that biblical authors and characters often use the similar expression “son of” to indicate that a person has the characteristic of something. See how you translated the similar expression in [16:7](../16/07.md). Alternate translation: [a man who brings news] or [the one to bring the news]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הַ⁠יּ֤וֹם הַ⁠זֶּה֙ לֹ֣א תְבַשֵּׂ֔ר כִּֽי־על בֶּן־הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ מֵֽת
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [But since the son of the king is dead, this day you will not bring news]

bsb_verse_text: So Joab said to a Cushite, “Go, tell the king what you have seen.” The Cushite bowed to Joab and took off running.
ult_verse_text: Then Joab said to the Cushite, “Go, declare to the king what you have seen.” And the Cushite prostrated himself to Joab, then he ran.

notes.note: The author assumes that his readers will know that by **the Cushite**, he means a particular man from the region of Cush (modern Ethiopia) who was able to run far and fast and so served Joab as a messenger. You could say that explicitly if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the Cushite man who served him as a swift messenger]

Bowing down before Joab was a symbolic action by which the Cushite showed his respect and submission to Joab’s authority to indicate that he would obey Joab’s command. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And the Cushite expressed his obedience to Joab]

bsb_verse_text: Ahimaaz son of Zadok, however, persisted and said to Joab, “No matter what, please let me also run behind the Cushite!” “My son,” Joab replied, “why do you want to run, since you will not receive a reward?”
ult_verse_text: And again Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, resumed and said to Joab, “But whatever may be, please let me run, I too, after the Cushite.”

notes.note: It might seem that saying both **again** and **resumed** would be extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten this. Alternate translation: [And Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, resumed and said]

It might seem that saying both **again** and **resumed** would be to present extra information that would not be natural in your language. If so, you can just use one of these terms. Alternate translation: [And Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, said again]

Ahimaaz is stating the pronoun **I** separately, even though the verb translated as **let me run** already includes this meaning. He is doing that to indicate that his action would be comparable to that of the **Cushite**. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that Ahimaaz is indicating that his action would be comparable. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [please let me run, for my own part]

notes.orig_language_quote: לָֽ⁠מָּה־זֶּ֞ה אַתָּ֥ה רָץ֙ בְּנִ֔⁠י וּ⁠לְ⁠כָ֖ה אֵין־בְּשׂוֹרָ֥ה מֹצֵֽאת
notes.note: Joab is using the question form to rebuke Ahimaaz for wanting to run. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You should not be running, my son, when for you there is no news finding!]

Joab is using **Why {is} this, you running** as a common expression of his culture to mean “Why would you run?” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [For what reason would you run]

Joab is referring to Ahimaaz with an affectionate expression. Use a comparable title or expression from your language and culture for addressing someone affectionately. Alternate translation: [young man]

Joab is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [there is no news finding a reward]

Joab is speaking of **news** as if it were a living thing that could find something. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [there is no news for which King David would reward you]

bsb_verse_text: “No matter what, I want to run!” he replied. “Then run!” Joab told him. So Ahimaaz ran by way of the plain and outran the Cushite.
ult_verse_text: “But whatever may be, let me run.”

notes.note: The direct quotation can be marked to clearly show that these are Ahimaaz’s words. Use whatever punctuation or other ways of indicating quotations that are natural in your language. Alternate translation: [But Ahimaaz replied, “But whatever may be, let me run.”]
The pronoun **he** refers to Joab, while the pronoun **him** refers to Ahimaaz. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And Joab said to Ahimaaz]
This is an imperative, but it communicates permission rather than a command. Use a form in your language that communicates permission. Alternate translation: [You may run]

The implication is that Ahimaaz ran faster than the Cushite and got to King David before he did. The author indicates that Ahimaaz took a different route, so it was not the case that he **passed** the Cushite in the sense of running past him on the same road. Indicate this in your translation in a way that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and he outran the Cushite]

bsb_verse_text: Now David was sitting between the two gates when the watchman went up to the roof of the gateway by the wall, looked out, and saw a man running alone.
ult_verse_text: Now David was sitting between the two gates, and the watcher went to the roof of the gate, on the wall, and he lifted his eyes, and he saw, and behold, a man running by himself.

notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.
This phrase means the same thing as the phrase “in the middle of the gate” in [3:27](../03/27.md). See how you translated that phrase.
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:34](../13/34.md). Alternate translation: [and he looked off into the distance]

bsb_verse_text: So he called out and told the king. “If he is alone,” the king replied, “he bears good news.” As the first runner drew near,
ult_verse_text: And the watcher called and declared to the king. And the king said, “If {he is} by himself, news {is} in his mouth.” And he came, coming and near.

notes.note: David is using the term **mouth** to mean that the messenger would use his mouth to say or tell something. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [he has some news to tell]

Together, the words **coming** and **near** express a single idea. The word **near** indicates that the messenger got nearer and nearer as he was **coming**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this idea in a different way. Alternate translation: [And as he came, he kept coming nearer and nearer]

bsb_verse_text: the watchman saw another man running, and he called out to the gatekeeper, “Look! Another man is running alone!” “This one also brings good news,” said the king.
ult_verse_text: And the watcher saw another man running, and the watcher called to the gatekeeper and said, “Behold, a man running by himself.”

notes.note: The phrase translated as **to the gatekeeper** could also be translated “into the gate,” that is, down to where David was. That may be the correct translation, since David responds directly to what the watcher says, and there is no mention of a gatekeeper in the previous verse when the watcher similarly calls to David. Alternate translation: [into the gate]

bsb_verse_text: The watchman said, “The first man appears to me to be running like Ahimaaz son of Zadok.” “This is a good man,” said the king. “He comes with good news.”
ult_verse_text: And the watcher said, “I am seeing the running of the first like the running of Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok.”

notes.orig_language_quote: אֲנִ֤י רֹאֶה֙ אֶת־מְרוּצַ֣ת הָ⁠רִאשׁ֔וֹן כִּ⁠מְרֻצַ֖ת אֲחִימַ֣עַץ
notes.note: The watcher is using a participle form to describe an impression that is forming as he looks. Your language may have a verb form or comparable expression that would convey this meaning. Alternate translation: [The running of the first appears to me like the running of Ahimaaz]

bsb_verse_text: Then Ahimaaz called out to the king, “All is well!” And he bowed facedown before the king. He continued, “Blessed be the LORD your God! He has delivered up the men who raised their hands against my lord the king.”
ult_verse_text: And Ahimaaz called and said to the king, “Peace!” And he prostrated himself to the king with his nose to the ground. And he said, “Blessed be Yahweh your God, who has enclosed the men who lifted their hand against my lord the king.”

notes.note: The expression **and said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly.

The expression **Blessed be** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Bless Yahweh your God]

Ahimaaz is speaking as if Yahweh had actually **enclosed** Absalom’s soldiers in the hands of David’s soldiers, that is, as if Yahweh had enabled David’s soldiers to grasp Absalom’s soldiers completely in their hands. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 17:46](../../1sa/17/46.md). Alternate translation: [who has enabled your soldiers to overpower the men]

Ahimaaz is using **lifted their hand** as a common expression of his culture to mean “used violence.” (The meaning is the same as in the similar phrase “stretch out my hand” in [18:12](../18/12.md).) If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [who took up arms] or [who violently rebelled]

Even though Ahimaaz is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person, here and in [verses 31](../18/31.md) and [32](../18/32.md). Alternate translation: [you, my lord the king]

bsb_verse_text: The king asked, “Is the young man Absalom all right?” And Ahimaaz replied, “When Joab sent the king’s servant and your servant, I saw a great tumult, but I do not know what it was.”
ult_verse_text: And the king said, “{Is} peace to the young man, to Absalom?”

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [Is the young man Absalom well]

The implication is that this refers to the Cushite messenger who was sent after Ahimaaz. (He may be gesturing to him as he approaches.) You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the Cushite]

Ahimaaz is speaking of himself in the third person as **your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. Alternate translation: [and me, your servant]

Ahimaaz is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [but I do not know what was happening]

bsb_verse_text: Just then the Cushite came and said, “May my lord the king hear the good news: Today the LORD has avenged you of all who rose up against you!”
ult_verse_text: And behold, the Cushite came. And the Cushite said, “May my lord the king receive the good news that Yahweh has judged you today out of the hand of all of the ones having arisen against you.”

notes.orig_language_quote: שְׁפָטְ⁠ךָ֤ יְהוָה֙ הַ⁠יּ֔וֹם מִ⁠יַּ֖ד כָּל־הַ⁠קָּמִ֥ים עָלֶֽי⁠ךָ
notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [18:19](../18/19.md). Alternate translation: [Yahweh has judged you favorably today and has delivered you from the power of all of the ones having arisen against you]

In this verse, the word **hand** is singular in form, but it refers to all of the hands of David’s enemies as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “hand.” Alternate translation: [the hands of]

The phrase **the ones having arisen against you** was a common expression meaning those who rebel against authority or try to overthrow someone from power. Alternate translation: [the ones who tried to overthrow you]

bsb_verse_text: The king asked the Cushite, “Is the young man Absalom all right?” And the Cushite replied, “May the enemies of my lord the king and all who rise up against you to harm you be like that young man.”
ult_verse_text: And the king said to the Cushite, “{Is} peace to the young man, to Absalom?”

notes.orig_language_quote: יִהְי֤וּ כַ⁠נַּ֨עַר֙ אֹֽיְבֵי֙ אֲדֹנִ֣⁠י הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ וְ⁠כֹ֛ל אֲשֶׁר־קָ֥מוּ עָלֶ֖י⁠ךָ לְ⁠רָעָֽה
notes.note: The Cushite is courteously and gently not stating directly that Absalom has died. David nevertheless understands his meaning clearly and goes away to grieve. In your translation, it would be appropriate to represent this as an indirect statement, rather than suggest that the Cushite said directly that Absalom had died. You may be able to indicate this meaning another way. The UST models one way to do that.

bsb_verse_text: The king was shaken and went up to the chamber over the gate and wept. And as he walked, he cried out, “O my son Absalom! My son, my son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, O Absalom, my son, my son!”
ult_verse_text: And the king trembled, and he went up to the upper room of the gate, and he wept. And thus he said as he went: “My son Absalom! My son, my son, Absalom! Who will give my dying myself in place of you? Absalom, my son, my son!”

notes.note: David repeats the words **my son** to show how deeply distressed he is about his son’s death. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express his deep distress in another way. Alternate translation: [Oh, my son Absalom]

The phrase **Who will give my dying myself in place of you** was a common expression meaning “I wish that I had died instead of you.” It is a way of expressing deep grief and regret. Alternate translation: [If only I had been the one who had died, not you]

bsb_verse_text: Then it was reported to Joab, “The king is weeping and mourning over Absalom.”
ult_verse_text: And it was declared to Joab, “Behold, the king is weeping and mourning for Absalom.”

notes.note: The expression **it was declared** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And someone declared]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:2](../01/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

bsb_verse_text: And that day’s victory was turned into mourning for all the people, because on that day they were told, “The king is grieving over his son.”
ult_verse_text: And the victory on that day became mourning for all of the people, for the people heard on that day, saying, “The king is grieved because of his son.”

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠תְּהִ֨י הַ⁠תְּשֻׁעָ֜ה בַּ⁠יּ֥וֹם הַ⁠ה֛וּא לְ⁠אֵ֖בֶל לְ⁠כָל־הָ⁠עָ֑ם כִּֽי־שָׁמַ֣ע הָ⁠עָ֗ם בַּ⁠יּ֤וֹם הַ⁠הוּא֙ לֵ⁠אמֹ֔ר נֶעֱצַ֥ב הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ עַל־בְּנֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Because the people heard on that day, saying, “The king is grieved because of his son,” the victory on that day became mourning for all of the people]

notes.orig_language_quote: שָׁמַ֣ע הָ⁠עָ֗ם בַּ⁠יּ֤וֹם הַ⁠הוּא֙ לֵ⁠אמֹ֔ר נֶעֱצַ֥ב הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ עַל־בְּנֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: [the people heard on that day that the king was grieved because of his son]

The expression **is grieved** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [What has happened to his son has grieved the king]

bsb_verse_text: So they returned to the city quietly that day, as people steal away in humiliation after fleeing a battle.
ult_verse_text: And the people stole away on that day to enter the city, as ashamed people steal away when they flee in battle.

notes.note: The expression **ashamed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [people who feel shame]

bsb_verse_text: But the king covered his face and cried out at the top of his voice, “O my son Absalom! O Absalom, my son, my son!”
ult_verse_text: And the king covered his face, and the king cried out {with} a loud voice, “My son Absalom! Absalom, my son, my son!”

notes.note: Covering his face was a symbolic action by which David showed his deep grief and distress, as he had done when fleeing Jerusalem in [15:30](../15/30.md). If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And to express his deep sorrow, the king covered his face]
See how you translated the similar expression in [18:33](../18/33.md). Alternate translation: [Oh, Absalom, my son]

bsb_verse_text: Then Joab went into the house and said to the king, “Today you have disgraced all your servants who have saved your life and the lives of your sons and daughters, of your wives, and of your concubines.
ult_verse_text: And Joab came to the king, {to} the house, and he said, “Today you have shamed the faces of all of your servants, the ones having rescued your life today and the life of your sons and your daughters and the life of your wives and the life of your concubines,

notes.note: The author is using **the faces** to represent the people themselves. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [all of your servants]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אֵ֨ת נֶ֤פֶשׁ בָּנֶ֨י⁠ךָ֙ וּ⁠בְנֹתֶ֔י⁠ךָ וְ⁠נֶ֣פֶשׁ נָשֶׁ֔י⁠ךָ וְ⁠נֶ֖פֶשׁ פִּלַגְשֶֽׁי⁠ךָ
notes.note: In this verse, the word **life** is singular in form, but it refers to all the sons, daughters, wives, and concubines as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “life.” Alternate translation: [and the lives of your sons and your daughters and the lives of your wives and the lives of your concubines]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אֵ֨ת נֶ֤פֶשׁ בָּנֶ֨י⁠ךָ֙ וּ⁠בְנֹתֶ֔י⁠ךָ וְ⁠נֶ֣פֶשׁ נָשֶׁ֔י⁠ךָ וְ⁠נֶ֖פֶשׁ פִּלַגְשֶֽׁי⁠ךָ
notes.note: It might seem that repeating the term **life** three times would be extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could represent the term only once. Alternate translation: [and the lives of your sons and your daughters and your wives and your concubines]

bsb_verse_text: You love those who hate you and hate those who love you! For you have made it clear today that the commanders and soldiers mean nothing to you. I know today that if Absalom were alive and all of us were dead, it would have pleased you!
ult_verse_text: by loving the ones hating you and by hating the ones loving you. For you have declared today that the commanders and servants {are} nothing to you. For I know today that if Absalom {were} alive and all of us were dead today, that then {it would be} right in your eyes.

notes.note: Joab is saying that the implication is that David has shown by his actions, not necessarily by his words, how little he values his commanders and servants. You could indicate this in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [your actions have shown]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [you would consider that to be a good thing]

bsb_verse_text: Now therefore get up! Go out and speak comfort to your servants, for I swear by the LORD that if you do not go out, not a man will remain with you tonight. This will be worse for you than all the adversity that has befallen you from your youth until now!”
ult_verse_text: But now, arise, go out and speak to the heart of your servants, for I swear by Yahweh, if you are not going out, if a man will lodge with you tonight, and this {will be} more trouble for you than all of the trouble that has come on you from your youth until now.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [take action]

Joab is using **speak to the heart of** as a common expression of his culture to mean “speak kindly and encouragingly to.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [speak encouragingly to your servants]

Following the custom of his culture, Joab is swearing an oath and guaranteeing it by something that he holds sacred (**I swear by Yahweh**). He is then stating the first part of a condition (“if”) but not the second part (“then”). Use a natural way in your language to express an oath. In a context such as this, it may be natural to express the first part of the condition as a negative statement. See how you translated the similar expression in [14:19](../14/19.md). Alternate translation: [not a man will lodge with you tonight]

Joab is speaking of **trouble** as if it were a living thing that could have **come on** someone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [that you have experienced]

bsb_verse_text: So the king got up and sat in the gate, and all the people were told: “Behold, the king is sitting in the gate.” So they all came before the king. Meanwhile, the Israelites had fled, each man to his home.
ult_verse_text: So the king arose and sat in the gate.

notes.note: Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And it was declared]

Here, **to the face of** represents being in the presence of the king. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [came into the presence of the king]

The author is using this sentence to describe something that happened while the events he has been describing were taking place. He had already reported this in [18:17](../18/17.md), but he mentions it again here in order to provide the background for other events he will describe that happened afterwards. Translate this sentence the same way you did there, and connect it to the story in a way that makes it clear in your language that it is describing something that was ongoing in the background. The UST models one way to do that.

bsb_verse_text: And all the people throughout the tribes of Israel were arguing, “The king rescued us from the hand of our enemies and delivered us from the hand of the Philistines, but now he has fled the land because of Absalom.
ult_verse_text: And it happened, all of the people were contending in all of the tribes of Israel, saying, “The king delivered us from the palm of our enemies, and he, he rescued us from the palm of the Philistines. But now he has fled from the land, away from Absalom.

notes.note: The author is using the phrase **And it happened** to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event.

The author is saying **all of the people** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [people throughout the tribes of Israel were contending]

Here, **palm**, equivalent to “hand” in similar contexts, represents the power or control of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from the power of our enemies … from the power of the Philistines]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you were” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: [and he personally rescued us]

bsb_verse_text: But Absalom, the man we anointed over us, has died in battle. So why do you say nothing about restoring the king?”
ult_verse_text: But Absalom, whom we anointed over us, has died in the battle. And now, why are you being silent about bringing back the king?”

notes.note: See how you translated this expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

The people are using the question form to criticize those who are not taking action to bring back the king. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [you should not be silent about bringing back the king!]
The word **you** is plural here because groups of Israelites are addressing one another, so use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

Here, **being silent** represents not taking action. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [why are you doing nothing]

bsb_verse_text: Then King David sent this message to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests: “Say to the elders of Judah, ‘Why should you be the last to restore the king to his palace, since the talk of all Israel has reached the king at his quarters?
ult_verse_text: And King David sent to Zadok and to Abiathar, the priests, saying, “Speak to the elders of Judah, saying, ‘Why are you the last to bring back the king to his house? For the word of all of Israel has come to the king, to his house.

notes.orig_language_quote: לֵ⁠אמֹ֔ר לָ֤⁠מָּה תִֽהְיוּ֙ אַֽחֲרֹנִ֔ים לְ⁠הָשִׁ֥יב אֶת־הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ אֶל־בֵּית֑⁠וֹ וּ⁠דְבַר֙ כָּל־יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל בָּ֥א אֶל־הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ אֶל־בֵּיתֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and ask them why they are the last to bring back the king to his house. Tell them that the word of all of Israel has come to the king, to his house]

David is speaking through these messengers, as the next verse shows, so here he is speaking of himself regally in the third person as **the king**. Your language may have a regal form that it could use here. (For example, in some languages, kings and queens speak of themselves in the plural.) You could also use the first person. Alternate translation: [to bring me, the king, back to my house … to me, to my house]

notes.orig_language_quote: לָ֤⁠מָּה תִֽהְיוּ֙ אַֽחֲרֹנִ֔ים לְ⁠הָשִׁ֥יב אֶת־הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ אֶל־בֵּית֑⁠וֹ
notes.note: David is using the question form to rebuke those who have not yet acted to bring him back. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You should not be the last to bring back the king to his house!]

While this instance of the term **house** may initially mean David’s palace in Jerusalem, it seems also to represent David’s kingdom and authority. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [to restore the king to his throne] or [to make David king again]

David is speaking of this **word** as if it were a living thing that could have **come** to him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [For the king has heard the word of all of Israel]

David is using the term **word** to represent what Israel said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [For the king has learned what all of Israel has been saying]

David is saying **all of Israel** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [For the king has learned what people throughout Israel have been saying]

This could mean: (1) that David is suggesting that Zadok and Abiathar could leave out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [that they want to return him to his house] or [that they want him to rule them again]; (2) that the **word of all of Israel** has come to David in the **house** where he is staying in Mahanaim. Alternate translation: [at the place where he is staying]; (3) that scribes have accidentally repeated the phrase **to his house** from the end of the previous sentence. Some versions omit the phrase on that assumption.

bsb_verse_text: You are my brothers, my own flesh and blood. So why should you be the last to restore the king?’
ult_verse_text: You {are} my brothers. You {are} my bone and my flesh. So why are you last to bring back the king?’

notes.orig_language_quote: אַחַ֣⁠י אַתֶּ֔ם עַצְמִ֥⁠י וּ⁠בְשָׂרִ֖⁠י אַתֶּ֑ם וְ⁠לָ֧⁠מָּה תִהְי֛וּ אַחֲרֹנִ֖ים לְ⁠הָשִׁ֥יב אֶת־הַ⁠מֶּֽלֶךְ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [Tell them that I say that they are my brothers, my bone and my flesh, and ask them why they are the last to bring back the king]

David is using the term **brothers** to describe people who are descended from the same ancestor. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [You are my kinsmen]

David is using **my bone and my flesh** as a common expression of his culture to refer to close relations. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [You are my blood relations] or [We belong to the same tribe]

David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [So you should not be the last to bring back the king!]

bsb_verse_text: And say to Amasa, ‘Aren’t you my flesh and blood? May God punish me, and ever so severely, if from now on you are not the commander of my army in place of Joab!’”
ult_verse_text: And to Amasa you shall say, ‘{Are} you not my bone and my flesh? Thus may God do to me, and thus may he add, if you are not the commander of the army to my face all of the years in place of Joab.’”

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠לַֽ⁠עֲמָשָׂא֙ תֹּֽמְר֔וּ הֲ⁠ל֛וֹא עַצְמִ֥⁠י וּ⁠בְשָׂרִ֖⁠י אָ֑תָּה כֹּ֣ה יַֽעֲשֶׂה־לִּ֤⁠י אֱלֹהִים֙ וְ⁠כֹ֣ה יוֹסִ֔יף אִם־לֹ֠א שַׂר־צָבָ֞א תִּהְיֶ֧ה לְ⁠פָנַ֛⁠י כָּל־הַ⁠יָּמִ֖ים תַּ֥חַת יוֹאָֽב
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [And tell Amasa that I say he is indeed my bone and my flesh. Tell him I say that thus may God do to me, and thus may he add, if he is not the commander of the army to the face of all of the years in place of Joab]

David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You are indeed my bone and my flesh!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [19:12](../19/12.md). Alternate translation: [Are you not my blood relative?] or [You are indeed my blood relative!]

notes.orig_language_quote: כֹּ֣ה יַֽעֲשֶׂה־לִּ֤⁠י אֱלֹהִים֙ וְ⁠כֹ֣ה יוֹסִ֔יף אִם־לֹ֠א שַׂר־צָבָ֞א תִּהְיֶ֧ה לְ⁠פָנַ֛⁠י כָּל־הַ⁠יָּמִ֖ים תַּ֥חַת יוֹאָֽב
notes.note: Following the custom of his culture, David is using a conditional statement to swear an oath. What he states as a condition (“if”) is what he is swearing to do. Use a natural way in your language to express an oath. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could put the condition before the consequence. See how you translated the similar oath in [3:9](../03/09.md). Alternate translation: [I swear that you will be the commander of the army to my face all of the years in place of Joab, and if not, then may God do thus to me, and thus may he add]

When David says **thus may he add**, he is using a common expression of his culture. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Thus may God do to me, and may he do even worse]

The word **Thus**: (1) could refer to what David describes in the “if” statement of this oath. David could be saying that if he does not give Amasa the privileged position of being his **commander**, then he wants God not to restore him to his privileged position as king of Israel. The UST models one way to express that meaning. (2) could be a general expression introducing the entire statement as a reference to severe punishment. Alternate translation: [May God punish me very severely]

Here, **to my face** represents being in the presence of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in my presence]

David is using the term **years** to represent time, since time is made up of years. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [from this time forward] or [permanently]

bsb_verse_text: So he swayed the hearts of all the men of Judah as though they were one man, and they sent word to the king: “Return, you and all your servants.”
ult_verse_text: And he inclined the heart of every man of Judah as one man. And they sent to the king, “Return, you and all of your servants.”

notes.note: The pronoun **he** could refer to (1) David. The UST expresses that interpretation. (2) Amasa. Many versions do not replace the pronoun with a name but say “he” in order to allow for either interpretation.

Here the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [And he inclined the heart of every person in Judah]

Here, the **heart** represents where a person’s thoughts, feelings, and desires exist. You may have a comparable expression in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And he won the hearts of all the people of Judah] or [And he made everyone in Judah desire that he return as their king]

The author is using **as one man** as a common expression of his culture to mean “in complete agreement.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 11:7](../../1sa/11/07.md). Alternate translation: [in complete agreement] or [unitedly]

The phrase **And they sent** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. Alternate translation: [And they sent this message to the king, saying] or [ And they sent to the king, saying]

This is an imperative, but it communicates a polite request rather than a command. Use a form in your language that communicates a polite request. It may be helpful to add an expression such as “please” to make this clear. Alternate translation: [Please return]

bsb_verse_text: So the king returned, and when he arrived at the Jordan, the men of Judah came to Gilgal to meet him and escort him across the Jordan.
ult_verse_text: And the king returned, and he came to the Jordan.

notes.note: Here, **Judah** represents the elders or leaders of Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the elders of Judah]

Meeting the king and escorting him across the Jordan River was a symbolic action by which the leaders of Judah showed their renewed loyalty to David and their acceptance of his restored kingship. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [to welcome the king and demonstrate their loyalty by helping him cross the Jordan]
It may be more natural in your language to use a pronoun rather than the expression **the king** in it second instance. Alternate translation: [to meet the king to bring him across the Jordan]

bsb_verse_text: Then Shimei son of Gera, a Benjamite from Bahurim, hurried down with the men of Judah to meet King David,
ult_verse_text: And Shimei, the son of Gera, the Benjaminite, who {was} from Bahurim, hurried and came down with a man of Judah to meet King David,

notes.note: The author is not distinguishing this **Benjaminite**, Shimei, from another Benjaminite who was not **from Bahurim**. The detail is reminding readers about the identity of this character. Be sure that this is clear in your translation.

The phrase **hurried and came down** expresses a single idea. The word **hurried** tells in what way Shimei **came down**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [And … hurriedly came down]

In keeping with what is usual for his language and culture, the author is marking travel for change in elevation. If this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. You can do the same for the similar instances in [verses 20](../19/20.md) and [24](../19/24.md). Alternate translation: [and came]

The author is not referring to a specific **man of Judah**. He means the Judean leaders in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the men of Judah]

bsb_verse_text: along with a thousand men of Benjamin, as well as Ziba the steward of the house of Saul and his fifteen sons and twenty servants. They rushed down to the Jordan before the king
ult_verse_text: and 1, 000 men {were} with him from Benjamin. And Ziba, the young man of the house of Saul, and his 15 sons and his 20 servants {were} with him. And they rushed {into} the Jordan to the face of the king.

notes.note: Bringing 1,000 Benjaminite men was a symbolic action by which Shimei showed that there was now broad support for David’s kingship within his tribe, even though its members had previously supported Saul’s family. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and to show his tribe’s support, he brought 1,000 men from Benjamin with him]
Here, **Benjamin** represents the tribe of Benjamin. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [who were Benjaminites]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and Ziba, the young man of the house of Saul, also came]
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:1](../09/01.md). Alternate translation: [the servant of the descendants of Saul]

Here, **to the face of** represents being in the presence of the king. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [into the presence of the king]

bsb_verse_text: and crossed at the ford to carry over the king’s household and to do what was good in his sight. When Shimei son of Gera crossed the Jordan, he fell down before the king
ult_verse_text: And they crossed the ford to bring over the house of the king and to do the good in his eyes.

notes.note: The pronoun **they** refers to the elders of Judah. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And the elders of Judah crossed]
See how you translated the similar expression in [15:35](../15/35.md). Alternate translation: [the household of the king]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [and to do what he regarded as right]
Be sure that it is clear in your translation that Shimei did not fall down accidentally. He knelt down in front of David as a gesture to honor him. Alternate translation: [knelt down respectfully]
Here, **to the face of** represents being in front of the king. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of]
The pronoun **he** refers to Shimei. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [after Shimei had crossed in the Jordan]

When the author says **in**, the implication is that in order to get to David quickly, Shimei waded through the water of the Jordan River. (Some interpreters suggest that the elders of Judah would instead have crossed the river on rafts and brought David across the same way.) You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [after he had waded across the Jordan]

bsb_verse_text: and said, “My lord, do not hold me guilty, and do not remember your servant’s wrongdoing on the day my lord the king left Jerusalem. May the king not take it to heart.
ult_verse_text: And he said to the king, “May my lord not reckon iniquity to me, and may you not remember that your servant committed iniquity on the day that my lord the king went out from Jerusalem, for the king to set {it} to his heart.

notes.note: This is a double negative, consisting of the negative particle **not** and the verb **reckon**, which in this context would be negative. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use a positive expression to translate this. Alternate translation: [May my lord please forgive my iniquity]

Even though Shimei is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord**, **my lord the king**, and **the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of speakers using the third person either for themselves, to show humility (as Shimei does later in this verse), or for people whom they are addressing directly, to show respect. Use the appropriate forms in your language throughout the chapter. Alternate translation: [you, my lord … you, my lord the king … you]

Shimei is using **may you not remember** as a common expression of his culture to mean “may you not punish.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and may you not punish your servant for the iniquity that he committed]

Shimei is speaking of himself in the third person as **your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. Alternate translation: [me, your servant]
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:20](../13/20.md). Alternate translation: [Please do not take it to heart] or [Please do not hold it against me]

bsb_verse_text: For your servant knows that I have sinned, so here I am today as the first of all the house of Joseph to come down to meet my lord the king.”
ult_verse_text: For your servant knows that I, I have sinned, and behold, I have come today, the first of all of the house of Joseph to come down to meet my lord the king.”

notes.note: Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [After all]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you were” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: [I have personally sinned]

Here, **the house of Joseph** represents the other Israelite tribes. The two largest, Ephraim and Manasseh, consisted of the descendants of Joseph. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the other Israelite tribes]

bsb_verse_text: But Abishai son of Zeruiah said, “Shouldn’t Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the LORD’s anointed?”
ult_verse_text: And Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, answered and said, “In place of this, shall not Shimei be killed? For he cursed the anointed of Yahweh.”

notes.note: The expression **and said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly. (Shimei had addressed David rather than Abishai, so it was not Shimei personally whom Abishai **answered**. Rather, he was responding to the situation.) Alternate translation: [And Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, responded]

Abishai is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [In place of this, Shimei should be killed!]

The expression **shall not Shimei be killed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [In place of this, should you not kill Shimei?] or [In place of this, you should kill Shimei!]

Even though Abishai is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **the anointed of Yahweh** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [you, the anointed of Yahweh]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:14](../01/14.md). Alternate translation: [the anointed one of Yahweh] or [the one whom Yahweh anointed as king]

bsb_verse_text: And David replied, “Sons of Zeruiah, what have I to do with you, that you should be my adversaries today? Should any man be put to death in Israel today? Am I not indeed aware that today I am king over Israel?”
ult_verse_text: And David said, “What to me and to you, sons of Zeruiah, that you have become an adversary to me today? Shall a man be killed in Israel today? For do I not know that I {am} king over Israel today?”

notes.orig_language_quote: מַה־לִּ֤⁠י וְ⁠לָ⁠כֶם֙ בְּנֵ֣י צְרוּיָ֔ה כִּי־תִֽהְיוּ־לִ֥⁠י הַ⁠יּ֖וֹם לְ⁠שָׂטָ֑ן
notes.note: David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I have nothing in common with you, sons of Zeruiah, that I would agree to your suggestion when it is so contrary to my interests!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [16:10](../16/10.md). Alternate translation: [What do I have in common with you]

The word **you** is plural in both of these instances because David is addressing both Abishai and also Joab, who seems to have been nearby and supporting his brother’s suggestion. So use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

In this verse, the word **adversary** is singular in form, but it refers to the two sons of Zeruiah, Abishai and Joab. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “adversary.” Alternate translation: [adversaries]

David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [No man shall be killed in Israel today!]

The expression **Shall a man be killed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Shall anyone execute a man in Israel today?]

notes.orig_language_quote: כִּ֚י הֲ⁠ל֣וֹא יָדַ֔עְתִּי כִּ֥י הַ⁠יּ֖וֹם אֲנִי־מֶ֥לֶךְ עַל־יִשְׂרָאֵֽל
notes.note: David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [For I certainly know that I am king over Israel today!]

David is repeating the word **today** in order to emphasize that the glorious day of his restoration to the kingship should not be the occasion of an execution. It might seem that repeating this word three times would be extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you translate the word only once, expressing what it means in this context. For example, instead of saying “today” in each sentence, you could just say “on this day of celebration” in the second sentence.

bsb_verse_text: Then Mephibosheth, Saul’s grandson, went down to meet the king. He had not cared for his feet or trimmed his mustache or washed his clothes from the day the king had left until the day he returned safely.
ult_verse_text: And Mephibosheth, the son of Saul, came down to meet the king. And he had not done his feet, and he had not done his mustache, and he had not washed his clothes from the day the king went up to the day that he came in peace.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [9:9](../09/09.md). Alternate translation: [the grandson of Saul]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠לֹא־עָשָׂ֨ה רַגְלָ֜י⁠ו וְ⁠לֹא־עָשָׂ֣ה שְׂפָמ֗⁠וֹ וְ⁠אֶת־בְּגָדָי⁠ו֙ לֹ֣א כִבֵּ֔ס
notes.note: Not caring for his feet, mustache, or clothes was a symbolic action by which Mephibosheth showed his deep mourning over David’s departure. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And to show his grief, he had not done his feet, and he had not done his mustache, and he had not washed his clothes]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [peacefully] or [unharmed]

bsb_verse_text: And he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, who asked him, “Mephibosheth, why did you not go with me?”
ult_verse_text: And it happened that he came {from} Jerusalem to meet the king. And the king said to him, “Why did you not go with me, Mephibosheth?”

notes.note: In a context such as this, your language might say “come” instead of **go**. Alternate translation: [Why did you not come with me]

bsb_verse_text: “My lord the king,” he replied, “because I am lame, I said, ‘I will have my donkey saddled so that I may ride on it and go with the king.’ But my servant Ziba deceived me,
ult_verse_text: And he said, “My lord the king, my servant deceived me, for your servant said, ‘Let me saddle a donkey for myself, and let me ride on it, and let me go with the king.’ For your servant {is} lame.

notes.orig_language_quote: כִּֽי־אָמַ֨ר עַבְדְּ⁠ךָ֜ אֶחְבְּשָׁה־לִּ⁠י֩ הַ⁠חֲמ֨וֹר וְ⁠אֶרְכַּ֤ב עָלֶ֨י⁠הָ֙ וְ⁠אֵלֵ֣ךְ אֶת־הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [for your servant told him to saddle a donkey for me and let me ride on it so that I could go with you]

Mephibosheth was speaking of himself as the one who would actively **saddle** a **donkey** for himself, but this was a way of instructing Ziba to saddle a donkey for him. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use an imperative form. Alternate translation: [Saddle a donkey for me] or [Make it possible for me to have a saddled donkey for myself]
Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [After all]

bsb_verse_text: and he has slandered your servant to my lord the king. Yet my lord the king is like the angel of God, so do what is good in your eyes.
ult_verse_text: And he slandered your servant to my lord the king. But my lord the king {is} like an angel of God, so do the good in your eyes.
