notes.note: The point of this comparison is that just as **an angel of God** has comprehensive knowledge, so does David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. See how you translated the similar expression in [14:20](../14/20.md). Alternate translation: [is like an angel of God in that he knows what is really happening throughout his kingdom]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [as you see fit] or [what you think best]

bsb_verse_text: For all the house of my grandfather deserves death from my lord the king, yet you have set your servant among those who eat at your table. What further right, then, do I have to keep appealing to the king?”
ult_verse_text: For all of the house of my father was nothing except men of death to my lord the king, but you set your servant among the eaters at your table. So what right is there still for me to cry out more to the king?”

notes.orig_language_quote: לֹ֨א הָיָ֜ה כָּל־בֵּ֣ית אָבִ֗⁠י כִּ֤י אִם־אַנְשֵׁי־מָ֨וֶת֙
notes.note: If it would appear in your language that Mephibosheth was making a statement and then contradicting it, you could reword this as a positive statement. Alternate translation: [all of the house of my father were only men of death]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:29](../03/29.md). Alternate translation: [my extended family]
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:7](../09/07.md). Alternate translation: [my grandfather]
See how you translated the similar expressions “son of death” in [12:5](../12/05.md) and “man of blood” in [16:7](../16/07.md). Alternate translation: [men whom my lord the king could have executed]

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠מַה־יֶּשׁ־לִ֥⁠י עוֹד֙ צְדָקָ֔ה וְ⁠לִ⁠זְעֹ֥ק ע֖וֹד אֶל־הַ⁠מֶּֽלֶךְ
notes.note: Mephibosheth is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [So I have no further right to cry out more to the king.]

bsb_verse_text: The king replied, “Why say any more? I hereby declare that you and Ziba are to divide the land.”
ult_verse_text: And the king said to him, “Why do you still speak your words? I have said, ‘You and Ziba shall divide the field.’”

notes.note: This could mean: (1) that David is using the term **words** to represent what Mephibosheth has been saying by using words. Alternate translation: [Why are you still speaking like that]; (2) that the term **words** has the sense of “matters,” as in [18:13](../18/13.md). Alternate translation: [Why do you still speak of your affairs]

The king is using the question form to discourage Mephibosheth from speaking further. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You do not need to keep speaking like that] or [You do not need to speak any further of your affairs]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [I have said that you and Ziba shall divide the field]

David is using the past tense in order to pronounce his judgment in this case. If it would not be natural to do that in your language, you could use the present tense in your translation. Alternate translation: [My decision is]
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:7](../09/07.md). Alternate translation: [the fields] or [the lands]

bsb_verse_text: And Mephibosheth said to the king, “Instead, since my lord the king has safely come to his own house, let Ziba take it all!”
ult_verse_text: And Mephibosheth said to the king, “Let him even take the whole, after that my lord the king has come in peace to his house.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [19:24](../19/24.md). Alternate translation: [peacefully] or [unharmed]

bsb_verse_text: Now Barzillai the Gileadite had come down from Rogelim to cross the Jordan with the king and send him on his way from there.
ult_verse_text: And Barzillai the Gileadite came down from Rogelim. And he crossed the Jordan with the king to send him {across} the Jordan.

notes.note: In keeping with what is usual for his language and culture, the author is marking travel for change in elevation. If this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [came]

Crossing the Jordan with the king was a symbolic action by which Barzillai showed his loyalty to David and honored him. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And he traveled with the king to the Jordan River to honor him by escorting him across]

bsb_verse_text: Barzillai was quite old, eighty years of age, and since he was a very wealthy man, he had provided for the king while he stayed in Mahanaim.
ult_verse_text: Now Barzillai had aged greatly, a son of 80 years. And he, he had sustained the king in his stay in Mahanaim, for he {was} a very great man.

notes.note: Here, the author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [for he was a son of 80 years]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:10](../02/10.md). Alternate translation: [80 years old]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הֽוּא־כִלְכַּ֤ל אֶת־הַ⁠מֶּ֨לֶךְ֙ בְּ⁠שִׁיבָת֣⁠וֹ בְ⁠מַחֲנַ֔יִם כִּֽי־אִ֛ישׁ גָּד֥וֹל ה֖וּא מְאֹֽד
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [And since he was a very great man, he himself had sustained the king in his stay in Mahanaim]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you were” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: [And he had personally sustained]

In this context, the term **great** means having considerable wealth and possessions. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 25:2](../../1sa/25/02.md). Alternate translation: [he was a very wealthy man]

bsb_verse_text: The king said to Barzillai, “Cross over with me, and I will provide for you at my side in Jerusalem.”
ult_verse_text: And the king said to Barzillai, “You, cross over with me, and I will sustain you with me in Jerusalem.”

notes.note: This is an imperative, but it communicates a polite request rather than a command. Use a form in your language that communicates a polite request. It may be helpful to add an expression such as “please” to make this clear. Alternate translation: [Please cross over with me]

David is stating the pronoun **You** separately, even though the verb translated as **cross over** already includes this meaning. He is doing that because he is making a promise to Barzillai. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that David is making a promise to Barzillai. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [I promise that if you cross over with me, I will sustain you]

bsb_verse_text: But Barzillai replied, “How many years of my life remain, that I should go up to Jerusalem with the king?
ult_verse_text: But Barzillai said to the king, “How many {will be} the days of the years of my life, that I should go up with the king {to} Jerusalem?

notes.orig_language_quote: כַּ⁠מָּ֗ה יְמֵי֙ שְׁנֵ֣י חַיַּ֔⁠י כִּי־אֶעֱלֶ֥ה אֶת־הַ⁠מֶּ֖לֶךְ יְרוּשָׁלִָֽם
notes.note: Barzillai is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [The days of the years of my life will not be many more, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem!]

It might seem that the expression **the days of the years of my life** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [will be the days of my life] or [ will be the years of my life]
See how you translated the similar expression in [19:31](../19/31.md). Alternate translation: [I should go]

bsb_verse_text: I am now eighty years old. Can I discern what is good and what is not? Can your servant taste what he eats or drinks? Can I still hear the voice of singing men and women? Why should your servant be an added burden to my lord the king?
ult_verse_text: I {am} a son of 80 years today. Do I know between good to bad? Or does your servant taste what I eat or what I drink? Or do I still hear the voice of the {male} singers or the {female} singers? So why should your servant become a further burden to my lord the king?”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [19:32](../19/32.md). Alternate translation: [I am 80 years old]

notes.orig_language_quote: הַ⁠אֵדַ֣ע ׀ בֵּין־ט֣וֹב לְ⁠רָ֗ע אִם־יִטְעַ֤ם עַבְדְּ⁠ךָ֙ אֶת־אֲשֶׁ֤ר אֹכַל֙ וְ⁠אֶת־אֲשֶׁ֣ר אֶשְׁתֶּ֔ה אִם־אֶשְׁמַ֣ע ע֔וֹד בְּ⁠ק֖וֹל שָׁרִ֣ים וְ⁠שָׁר֑וֹת וְ⁠לָ⁠מָּה֩ יִֽהְיֶ֨ה עַבְדְּ⁠ךָ֥ עוֹד֙ לְ⁠מַשָּׂ֔א אֶל־אֲדֹנִ֖⁠י הַ⁠מֶּֽלֶךְ
notes.note: Barzillai is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [I no longer know between good to bad. And your servant does not taste what I eat or what I drink. And I no longer hear the voice of the male singers or the female singers. So your servant should not become a further burden to my lord the king.]

In this verse, the word **voice** is singular in form, but it refers to all the singers as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “voice.” Alternate translation: [the voices]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠לָ⁠מָּה֩ יִֽהְיֶ֨ה עַבְדְּ⁠ךָ֥ עוֹד֙ לְ⁠מַשָּׂ֔א אֶל־אֲדֹנִ֖⁠י הַ⁠מֶּֽלֶךְ
notes.note: Barzillai is speaking as if he would actually become a **burden** or weight that David needed to carry on his back. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [So why should your servant cause my lord the king to have additional responsibilities for his care?]

bsb_verse_text: Your servant will go with the king only a short distance past the Jordan; why should the king repay me with such a reward?
ult_verse_text: According to a little your servant will go across the Jordan with the king. But why will the king reward me this reward?

notes.note: Going across the Jordan with the king was a symbolic action by which Barzillai showed respect and honor to David, even though he would only go a short distance beyond the river. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [To show respect and honor, according to a little your servant will go across the Jordan with the king]

Barzillai is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [But the king does not need to reward me this reward]

Barzillai is using a construction in which a verb and its object come from the same root. You may be able to use the same construction in your language to express the meaning here. Alternatively, your language may have another way of saying this. Alternate translation: [reward me so generously]

bsb_verse_text: Please let your servant return, that I may die in my own city near the tomb of my father and mother. But here is your servant Chimham. Let him cross over with my lord the king, and do for him what is good in your sight.”
ult_verse_text: Please let your servant return, and let me die in my city by the grave of my father and my mother. But behold your servant Chimham. Let him cross over with my lord the king, and do for him what {is} good in your eyes.”

notes.note: While Barzillai may want David to look at Chimham (who has accompanied him, and who is likely his son, as [1 Kings 2:7](../../1ki/02/07.md) suggests), he seems to be saying **behold** as part of the courteous expression that people in this culture would use to tell a superior that someone was ready and willing to obey his orders. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:7](../01/07.md). Alternate translation: [But now here is your servant Chimham, at your disposal]

This is an imperative, but it communicates a polite request rather than a command. Use a form in your language that communicates a polite request. It may be helpful to add an expression such as “please” to make this clear. Alternate translation: [and please do for him]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [as you see fit] or [what you think is best]

bsb_verse_text: The king replied, “Chimham will cross over with me, and I will do for him what is good in your sight, and I will do for you whatever you desire of me.”
ult_verse_text: And the king said, “Chimham shall cross over with me, and I, I shall do for him the good in your eyes. And all that you choose upon me, I shall do for you.”

notes.note: David is stating the pronoun **I** separately, even though the verb translated as **I shall do** already includes this meaning. He is doing that because he is making a promise to Barzillai. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that David is making a promise to Barzillai. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [and I promise that I shall do for him]

The king is using the adjective **good** as a noun to mean a certain kind of thing. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [what is good]

The king is using **choose upon me** as a common expression of his culture to mean “require of me.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And all that you require of me]

bsb_verse_text: So all the people crossed the Jordan, and then the king crossed over. The king kissed Barzillai and blessed him, and Barzillai returned home.
ult_verse_text: And all of the people crossed the Jordan, and the king crossed. And the king kissed Barzillai, and he blessed him, and he returned to his place.

notes.note: The author seems to be suggesting that first the **people** (the tribal leaders) **crossed the Jordan**, and then **the king crossed**. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And all of the people crossed the Jordan to lead the way in an honor procession, and then the king crossed]

bsb_verse_text: Then the king crossed over to Gilgal, and Chimham crossed over with him. All the troops of Judah and half the troops of Israel escorted the king.
ult_verse_text: And the king passed on to Gilgal, and Chimham passed on with him. And all of the people of Judah brought the king over, and also half of the people of Israel.

notes.note: The implication here and in the next verse is that these were the leaders of Judah and the leaders of the other Israelite tribes rather than all the people. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the leaders of Judah … the leaders of the other Israelite tribes]
In this context, the word **half** does not indicate exactly one of two equal parts. Alternate translation: [only some of]

bsb_verse_text: Soon all the men of Israel came to the king and asked, “Why did our brothers, the men of Judah, take you away secretly and bring the king and his household across the Jordan, together with all of David’s men?”
ult_verse_text: And behold, all of the men of Israel were coming to the king, and they said to the king, “Why did our brothers, the men of Judah, steal you away and bring the king and his house across the Jordan and all of the men of David with him?”

notes.orig_language_quote: כָּל־אִ֥ישׁ יִשְׂרָאֵ֖ל בָּאִ֣ים אֶל־הַ⁠מֶּ֑לֶךְ וַ⁠יֹּאמְר֣וּ אֶל־הַ⁠מֶּ֡לֶךְ
notes.note: The author is saying **all of the men of Israel were coming to the king** to describe something that was ongoing. This provides the background for other events he will describe that began to happen during this time. Connect this clause to the story in a way that makes it clear in your language that this clause is describing something that was ongoing in the background. Alternate translation: [as the rest of the men of Israel continued to arrive where David was, they said to him]

The implication is that these were the leaders of the other Israelite tribes rather than all the men of Israel. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the rest of the leaders of the other Israelite tribes]

notes.orig_language_quote: מַדּוּעַ֩ גְּנָב֨וּ⁠ךָ אַחֵ֜י⁠נוּ אִ֣ישׁ יְהוּדָ֗ה וַ⁠יַּעֲבִ֨רוּ אֶת־הַ⁠מֶּ֤לֶךְ וְ⁠אֶת־בֵּית⁠וֹ֙ אֶת־הַ⁠יַּרְדֵּ֔ן וְ⁠כָל־אַנְשֵׁ֥י דָוִ֖ד עִמּֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: The men of Israel are using the question form to express their anger that the men of Judah had brought David back without including them. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [It was not right for our brothers, the men of Judah, to steal you away and bring the king and his house across the Jordan and all of the men of David with him!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [19:12](../19/12.md). Alternate translation: [our kinsmen]

Here, the men of Israel are speaking as if the king were an object that someone could **steal … away**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [take you away without considering us]

Even though the men of Israel are addressing David directly, they are speaking of him in the third person as **the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [you, the king]
See how you translated the similar expression in [19:18](../19/18.md). Alternate translation: [and his household] or [and your household]

Since these tribal leaders are addressing David directly, and since they call him **you** earlier in the sentence, it may be natural to use second-person pronouns here. Alternate translation: [your men with you]

bsb_verse_text: And all the men of Judah replied to the men of Israel, “We did this because the king is our relative. Why does this anger you? Have we ever eaten at the king’s expense or received anything for ourselves?”
ult_verse_text: And each man of Judah answered to a man of Israel, “Because the king {is} near to me. And why this, it burns to you about this matter? Eating, have we eaten from the king? Or being taken, has it been taken for us?”

notes.note: In this verse, the expressions **each man** and **a man** are singular in form, but they refer to all the men of Judah and Israel as groups. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “man.” Alternate translation: [And all of the men of Judah answered to the men of Israel]

In this verse, the word **me** is singular in form, but it refers to all the men of Judah as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a plural form. Alternate translation: [Because the king is near to us]

The men of Judah are leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [We brought the king across the Jordan River because he is near to us]

Here, the men of Judah are speaking as if being related to someone were actually being **near** to that person physically. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [is our close relative]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠לָ֤⁠מָּה זֶּה֙ חָרָ֣ה לְ⁠ךָ֔ עַל־הַ⁠דָּבָ֖ר הַ⁠זֶּ֑ה הֶ⁠אָכ֤וֹל אָכַ֨לְנוּ֙ מִן־הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ אִם־נִשֵּׂ֥את נִשָּׂ֖א לָֽ⁠נוּ
notes.note: The men of Judah are using the question form to emphasize that the men of Israel should not be angry and that they have not received any favors from the king. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [And it should not be that it burns to you about this matter. Eating, we have not eaten from the king, and being taken, it has not been taken for us!]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠לָ֤⁠מָּה זֶּה֙ חָרָ֣ה לְ⁠ךָ֔ עַל־הַ⁠דָּבָ֖ר הַ⁠זֶּ֑ה
notes.note: The Judean leaders are using **And why this** as a common expression of their culture to mean “There is no need for this.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 20:8](../../1sa/20/08.md). Alternate translation: [And there is no need for it to burn to you about this matter.] or [And it should not be that it burns to you about this matter.]

Here the phrase **it burns to you** is a common expression that means that the men of Israel have become angry. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you have become angry about this matter]

notes.orig_language_quote: הֶ⁠אָכ֤וֹל אָכַ֨לְנוּ֙ מִן־הַ⁠מֶּ֔לֶךְ אִם־נִשֵּׂ֥את נִשָּׂ֖א לָֽ⁠נוּ
notes.note: The men of Judah are repeating forms of the verbs **eaten** and **taken** in order to intensify their expression of the ideas that these verbs convey. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [Have we eaten at all from the king? Or has anything at all been taken for us?] or [We certainly have not eaten from the king! And certainly nothing has been taken for us!]

The men of Judah are using **eaten from the king** as a common expression of their culture to describe receiving food or other provisions from the king. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Has the king been providing any of our food?] or [The king has not been providing any of our food!]

The expression **being taken, has it been taken** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And the king has not taken anything and given it to us]

bsb_verse_text: “We have ten shares in the king,” answered the men of Israel, “so we have more claim to David than you. Why then do you despise us? Were we not the first to speak of restoring our king?” But the men of Judah spoke more fiercely than the men of Israel.
ult_verse_text: And a man of Israel answered a man of Judah, and he said, “Ten hands {are} to me in the king, and also in David, I more than you. So why have you despised me? Was not my word first, to bring back my king to me?”

notes.note: In this verse, the words **a man of Israel** and **a man of Judah** are singular in form, but they refer to all the men of Israel and all the men of Judah as groups. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “man.” Alternate translation: [And the men of Israel answered the men of Judah, and they said]

The phrase **and he said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this phrase explicitly. Alternate translation: [And the men of Israel responded to the men of Judah]

The men of Israel are using **Ten hands {are} to me in the king** as a common expression of their culture to mean “we have ten shares in the king.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [We have ten shares in the king]

The men of Israel are leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and we also have a greater share in David than you do]

The word **you** is singular here because the author is depicting individual conversations between Israelite and Judean leaders. If you depict this scene in the same way, use the singular form of “you” in your translation if your language marks that distinction. But if you decide to say “men” rather than **man**, use the plural form of “you.”

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠מַדּ֨וּעַ֙ הֱקִלֹּתַ֔⁠נִי וְ⁠לֹא־הָיָ֨ה דְבָרִ֥⁠י רִאשׁ֛וֹן לִ֖⁠י לְ⁠הָשִׁ֣יב אֶת־מַלְכִּ֑⁠י
notes.note: The men of Israel are using the question form to emphasize that the men of Judah should not have despised them and that they were the first to speak of bringing back the king. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [So you should not have despised me! It was my word that was first, to bring back my king to me!] or [ So you should not have despised us! It was our word that was first, to bring back my king to us!]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠לֹא־הָיָ֨ה דְבָרִ֥⁠י רִאשׁ֛וֹן לִ֖⁠י לְ⁠הָשִׁ֣יב אֶת־מַלְכִּ֑⁠י
notes.note: The men of Israel are using the term **word** to represent what they said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Were we not the first to say that we should bring our king back to us?]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּ֨קֶשׁ֙ דְּבַר־אִ֣ישׁ יְהוּדָ֔ה מִ⁠דְּבַ֖ר אִ֥ישׁ יִשְׂרָאֵֽל
notes.note: The author is using the term **word** to represent what the men of Judah and Israel said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But the leaders of Judah spoke more harshly than the leaders of Israel spoke]

bsb_verse_text: Now a worthless man named Sheba son of Bichri, a Benjamite, happened to be there, and he blew the ram’s horn and shouted: “We have no share in David, no inheritance in Jesse’s son. Every man to his tent, O Israel!”
ult_verse_text: And a man of wickedness was met there, and his name {was} Sheba, the son of Bichri, a man of Benjamin. And he blew on a shofar, and he said, “{There} is no portion to us in David, and no inheritance {is} to us in the son of Jesse. A man to his tents, Israel!”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [18:9](../18/09.md). Alternate translation: [And a man of wickedness happened to be there]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **wickedness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [a wicked man]

Here the author is introducing **Sheba, the son of Bichri, a man of Benjamin** as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation.

notes.orig_language_quote: אֵֽין־לָ֨⁠נוּ חֵ֜לֶק בְּ⁠דָוִ֗ד וְ⁠לֹ֤א נַֽחֲלָה־לָ֨⁠נוּ֙ בְּ⁠בֶן־יִשַׁ֔י
notes.note: If Sheba were speaking to the Judeans with whom he and his fellow Israelites have been disputing, the word **us** would not include them, so it would be appropriate to use the exclusive form of that word if your language marks that distinction. That is one interpretive possibility. However, since he directly addresses his fellow Israelites in the next sentence, he may well also be addressing them here, in which case it would be appropriate to use the inclusive form. Decide as a translation team which interpretation you wish to follow.

notes.orig_language_quote: אֵֽין־לָ֨⁠נוּ חֵ֜לֶק בְּ⁠דָוִ֗ד וְ⁠לֹ֤א נַֽחֲלָה־לָ֨⁠נוּ֙ בְּ⁠בֶן־יִשַׁ֔י
notes.note: These two phrases **There is no portion to us in David** and **no inheritance is to us in the son of Jesse** mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine them and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [We will have no part of David son of Jesse]

notes.orig_language_quote: אֵֽין־לָ֨⁠נוּ חֵ֜לֶק בְּ⁠דָוִ֗ד וְ⁠לֹ֤א נַֽחֲלָה־לָ֨⁠נוּ֙ בְּ⁠בֶן־יִשַׁ֔י
notes.note: Sheba is speaking as if David were actually land or property of which the Israelites could have a **portion** that they would receive as an **inheritance**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [We want nothing to do with David son of Jesse]

Sheba is using **a man to his tent** as a common expression of his culture that often described soldiers stopping a military campaign altogether and each one going back to his home and family. In this particular context, Sheba is using the expression to mean that the soldiers from the other tribes will not obey David as their military commander. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Abandon the army and go home, Israel!]

Here, **tents** represents homes or dwelling places. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [Each of you return to his own home, you Israelites]

bsb_verse_text: So all the men of Israel deserted David to follow Sheba son of Bichri. But the men of Judah stayed by their king all the way from the Jordan to Jerusalem.
ult_verse_text: And all of the men of Israel went up from after David {to} after Sheba, the son of Bichri. But the men of Judah clung to their king from the Jordan and to Jerusalem.

notes.note: In keeping with what is usual for his language and culture, the author is marking travel for change in elevation with **went up**. If this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [went] or [left there]

Here, the author is speaking as if people who followed either David or Sheba as their leader actually walked **after** or behind them. He means that the people stopped being loyal to David as their king and started being loyal to Sheba instead. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [with Sheba, the son of Bichri, as their leader rather than David]

The author is speaking as if the men of Judah had actually **clung** to David. He means that they remained loyal to him and supported his leadership. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [remained entirely loyal]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and they escorted him from the Jordan River area to Jerusalem]

bsb_verse_text: When David returned to his palace in Jerusalem, he took the ten concubines he had left to take care of the palace, and he placed them in a house under guard. He provided for them, but he no longer slept with them. They were confined until the day of their death, living as widows.
ult_verse_text: And David came to his house {in} Jerusalem, and the king took the ten concubine wives whom he had left to keep the house, and he put them {in} a house of keeping, and he sustained them, but he did not go in to them. And they were confined until the day of their death, a widowhood of life.

notes.note: The author is using the possessive form to describe a **house** or residence that was a place for **keeping** these women away from other people. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [in seclusion]

The author is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **go in to them**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language, or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [but he did not sleep with them]

The author is using as a common expression of his culture. This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: [and it was as if each was a widow, even though their husband had not died]; (2) Alternate translation: [and it was as if they were widows without a husband for the rest of their lives]

bsb_verse_text: Then the king said to Amasa, “Summon the men of Judah to come to me within three days, and be here yourself.”
ult_verse_text: And the king said to Amasa, “Call up the men of Judah to me, three days. And you, stand here.”

notes.note: David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [Have them here in three days]

In this culture, the current day was considered the first day, the next day was considered the second day, and the day after that was considered the third day. So David is using this phrase to refer to the day after the day he gives this command to Amasa. Express this in terms that your language and culture would naturally use. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:2](../01/02.md). Alternate translation: [Have them here within two days]

David is stating the pronoun **you** separately, even though the verb translated as **stand** already includes this meaning. See how you translated the similar expression “you, you were” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: [And lead them here personally]

David is not telling Amasa to **stand here** and not leave. He means that once Amasa has gone and summoned the Judean soldiers, he should **stand** or present himself to David along with them. The implication is that he is to present himself as their commander. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [And you, be present here as their commander] or [And it will be your responsibility to bring them here under your command]

bsb_verse_text: So Amasa went to summon Judah, but he took longer than the time allotted him.
ult_verse_text: And Amasa went to call up Judah, but he delayed beyond the appointment that he had appointed him.

notes.note: Here, **Judah** represents the soldiers or fighting men of Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the soldiers of Judah]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **appointment**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [appointed time]

bsb_verse_text: And David said to Abishai, “Now Sheba the son of Bichri will do us more harm than Absalom. Take your lord’s servants and pursue him, or he will find fortified cities and elude us.”
ult_verse_text: And David said to Abishai, “Now Sheba, the son of Bichri, will harm us more than Absalom. You, take the servants of your lord and pursue after him, lest he find fortified cities for himself and remove our eyes.”

notes.note: By **us**, David means to include both himself and Abishai, whom he is addressing, so use the inclusive form of that word if your language marks that distinction.
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [For your part, take]

Even though David is addressing Abishai directly, he is speaking of himself regally in the third person as **your lord**. Your language may have a regal form that it could use here. (For example, in some languages, kings and queens speak of themselves in the plural.) You could also use the first person. Alternate translation: [my servants]

By **the servants of your lord**, David means the standing army that is under his direct command. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [my standing troops]

notes.orig_language_quote: פֶּן־מָ֥צָא ל֛⁠וֹ עָרִ֥ים בְּצֻר֖וֹת וְ⁠הִצִּ֥יל עֵינֵֽ⁠נוּ
notes.note: David is using the word translated as **lest** to introduce an outcome that he does not want to happen. Because of this, he first gives Abishai the instruction to pursue Sheba, so that this will not happen. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that avoiding this outcome is the purpose of this instruction. Alternate translation: [Otherwise, he may find fortified cities for himself and remove our eyes]

notes.orig_language_quote: מָ֥צָא ל֛⁠וֹ עָרִ֥ים בְּצֻר֖וֹת וְ⁠הִצִּ֥יל עֵינֵֽ⁠נוּ
notes.note: David is describing one event, Sheba finding **fortified cities**, before describing another event that would precede it, Sheba figuratively removing the **eyes** of David and his servants. If it would be helpful your language, you may wish to relate these events in the order in which would happen. Alternate translation: [he remove our eyes and find fortified cities for himself]

David is speaking as if Sheba might actually **remove** his **eyes** and those of his soldiers so that they would not be able to see where he had gone. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [and we lose sight of where he has gone] or [and he go somewhere that we are not aware of]

bsb_verse_text: So Joab’s men, along with the Cherethites, the Pelethites, and all the mighty men, marched out of Jerusalem in pursuit of Sheba son of Bichri.
ult_verse_text: And the men of Joab and the Cherethites and the Pelethites and all of the warriors went out after him. And they went out from Jerusalem to pursue after Sheba, the son of Bichri.

notes.note: This expression probably refers to Joab’s armor bearers or personal guard, whom the author describes as the “carriers of the weapons of Joab” in [18:15](../18/15.md). Alternate translation: [Joab’s armor bearers]
See how you translated these names in [8:18](../08/18.md) and [15:18](../15/18.md).
These seem to be the same men whom the author describes as “the Gittites” in [15:18](../15/18.md). See what expression you used for them there.
The pronoun **him** refers to Abishai. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [after Abishai]

The author is speaking as if these soldiers were all physically traveling **after** or behind Abishai. He means that they were under his command as their leader. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [with Abishai as their commander]

bsb_verse_text: And while they were at the great stone in Gibeon, Amasa joined them. Now Joab was dressed in military attire, with a dagger strapped to his belt. And as he stepped forward, he slipped the dagger from its sheath.
ult_verse_text: They {were} near the great stone that {is} in Gibeon, and Amasa came to their faces. Now Joab was girded {with}his garment {as} his clothing, and on him {was} a belt of a sword strapped on his waist in its sheath. And he, he went out, and it fell.

notes.note: Here, **to their faces** represents being in the presence of David’s soldiers. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and Amasa met them] or [and Amasa came before them]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠יוֹאָ֞ב חָג֣וּר ׀ מִדּ֣⁠וֹ לְבֻשׁ֗⁠וּ ו⁠על⁠ו חֲג֥וֹר חֶ֨רֶב֙ מְצֻמֶּ֤דֶת עַל־מָתְנָי⁠ו֙ בְּ⁠תַעְרָ֔⁠הּ
notes.note: Here, the author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

It might seem that the expression **with his garment as his clothing** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [Now Joab was girded with his garment]

The expression **was girded** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Now Joab was wearing his garment]

The author assumes that his readers will know that by **garment**, he means an article of clothing that was designed for soldiers to wear under armor. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 17:38](../../1sa/17/38.md). Alternate translation: [with his military tunic]

notes.orig_language_quote: ו⁠על⁠ו חֲג֥וֹר חֶ֨רֶב֙ מְצֻמֶּ֤דֶת עַל־מָתְנָי⁠ו֙ בְּ⁠תַעְרָ֔⁠הּ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about **the sword** with the information about **its sheath**. Alternate translation: [and on him a belt was strapped around his waist holding a sword in its sheath]

Since Joab was able to hold this **sword** in his hand without Amasa knowing it was there, it was probably a short sword. Your language may have a term for such a weapon that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [a dagger]

The author is stating the pronoun **he** separately, even though the verb translated as **he went out** already includes this meaning. He is doing that to emphasize that these two actions occurred at the same time. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for this same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that the author is describing simultaneous actions. Alternate translation: [And as he went out, it fell] or [And he made it fall as he went out]

The author means that Joab **went out** from the group of soldiers he was in and approached Amasa and the group of soldiers that he was leading. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [And he stepped forward]

The author is speaking of this sword or dagger as if it had been a living thing that **fell** on its own. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and he let it fall]

This could mean: (1) that the sword **fell** secretly into Joab’s hand in a way that he contrived. Alternate translation: [and it fell secretly into his hand]; (2) that the sword **fell** to the ground without Amasa noticing and Joab picked it up secretly. Alternate translation: [and it fell unseen to the ground, where Joab secretly picked it up]

bsb_verse_text: “Are you well, my brother?” Joab asked Amasa. And with his right hand Joab grabbed Amasa by the beard to kiss him.
ult_verse_text: And Joab said to Amasa, “Peace {to} you, my brother?” And the right hand of Joab held onto the beard of Amasa to kiss him.

notes.note: Joab is addressing Amasa with a polite greeting of his culture. (The term **Peace** has the sense of “well-being” here.) Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [How are you]

This could mean: (1) that Joab is using the term **brother** to describe the close family relationship that he and Amasa have. The narrative indicates elsewhere that Joab’s mother and Amasa’s mother were sisters. Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship. Alternate translation: [my cousin]; (2) that Joab is using the term **brother** as a term of endearment. Alternate translation: [my friend]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠תֹּ֜חֶז יַד־יְמִ֥ין יוֹאָ֛ב בִּ⁠זְקַ֥ן עֲמָשָׂ֖א לִ⁠נְשָׁק־לֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: The author is speaking of **the right hand of Joab** as if it were a living thing that could hold onto Amasa’s beard. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And Joab held onto the beard of Amasa with his right hand so that he could kiss him]

Kissing Amasa was a symbolic action by which Joab pretended to show friendship and respect. He actually intended to get close to Amasa so he could kill him. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [to greet him with a kiss] or [to pretend friendship by giving him a kiss]

bsb_verse_text: Amasa was not on guard against the dagger in Joab’s hand, and Joab stabbed him in the stomach and spilled out his intestines on the ground. And Joab did not need to strike him again, for Amasa was dead. Then Joab and his brother Abishai pursued Sheba son of Bichri.
ult_verse_text: But Amasa did not guard himself against the sword that {was} in the hand of Joab. And he struck him with it in the stomach, and his intestines poured out to the ground, and he did not do again to him, and he died. And Joab and Abishai his brother pursued after Sheba, the son of Bichri.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יַּכֵּ⁠הוּ֩ בָ֨⁠הּ אֶל־הַ⁠חֹ֜מֶשׁ וַ⁠יִּשְׁפֹּ֨ךְ מֵעָ֥י⁠ו אַ֛רְצָ⁠ה וְ⁠לֹא־שָׁ֥נָה ל֖⁠וֹ וַ⁠יָּמֹ֑ת
notes.note: If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use names instead of pronouns in order to clarify who did what to whom here. Alternate translation: [And Joab struck Amasa with the sword in the stomach, and Amasa’s intestines poured out to the ground, and Joab did not do again to Amasa, and Amasa died.]

The author is using the phrase **he did not do again to him** as a common expression of his culture to mean that Joab did not repeat the action of stabbing Amasa. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and he did not stab him a second time]

bsb_verse_text: One of Joab’s young men stood near Amasa and said, “Whoever favors Joab, and whoever is for David, let him follow Joab!”
ult_verse_text: And a man from the young men of Joab stood beside him, and he said, “Whoever delights in Joab and whoever {is} to David, after Joab!”

notes.note: The pronoun **him** refers to Amasa. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [beside Amasa]

The man is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [go after Joab] or [follow Joab in pursuit of Sheba]

bsb_verse_text: But Amasa wallowed in his blood in the middle of the road, and when the man saw that all the troops were stopping there, he dragged the body off the road into a field and threw a garment over it.
ult_verse_text: Now Amasa was rolling himself in blood in the midst of the road. And the man saw that all of the people stood. So he removed Amasa from the road {to} a field, and he threw a garment over him, because he saw everyone coming to him, that he stood.

notes.note: The author assumes that his readers will know that by **the man**, he means the “man from the young man of Joab” whom he describes in the previous verse. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the man from the young men of Joab]

If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information that soldiers **stood** before the information that this happened as they were **coming** to where Amasa was. Alternate translation: [because he saw that everyone stopped when they came to him]

It might seem that this statement provides extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, since it basically repeats what the author says in the first part of the verse. If so, you could present this information only once. The UST models one way to do that.

bsb_verse_text: Sheba passed through all the tribes of Israel to Abel-beth-maacah and through the entire region of the Berites, who gathered together and followed him.
ult_verse_text: And he passed through all of the tribes of Israel to Abel and Beth Maacah. And all of the Berites, now they gathered themselves, and they also came after him.

notes.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Sheba. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And Sheba passed through]

The author says **all of the tribes of Israel** as an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [the territory of Israel all the way to its northern boundary]

The phrase **Abel and Beth Maacah** identifies a single place. The name **Beth Maacah** tells which specific city of **Abel** this was, since there were several cities by that name in Israel. The author uses the expression “Abel Beth Maacah” in the next verse, and you may wish to use that name here as well. You could also reflect how the author is identifying this city. Alternate translation: [to the city of Abel, that is, the one in Beth Maacah]

The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. Because Sheba had the support of these troops, Joab and his soldiers had to mount a protracted siege against the city he was in. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

The author says **all of the Berites** as a generalization. He is referring specifically to the fighting men among the Berites. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And all of the Berite soldiers]

This could be the name of: (1) the people who lived in and around the city of Beroth in the tribe of Benjamin. They may have supported and accompanied Sheba since he was from their tribe. Alternate translation: [the soldiers from the area of Beroth]; (2) some other people group in northern Israel that is otherwise unknown. Alternate translation: [the soldiers of the Berite people group]

The author is speaking as if the Berites actually **came after** their leader, Sheba, in the sense of physically following behind him. He means that they joined his cause and accepted his leadership. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and they were also following him as their leader]

bsb_verse_text: And Joab’s troops came and besieged Sheba in Abel-beth-maacah and built a siege ramp against the outer rampart of the city. As all the troops with Joab were battering the wall to topple it,
ult_verse_text: And they came, and they besieged against him in Abel Beth Maacah. And they poured out a mound against the city, and it stood against the rampart. And all of the people who {were} with Joab were destroying to make the wall fall.

notes.note: The pronoun **they** refers to Joab and his soldiers. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state this explicitly. Alternate translation: [And Joab and his soldiers came]

A **rampart** is a kind of defensive wall or fortification around a city, specifically in this context an outer wall of a city that also has an inner wall. If your readers would not be familiar with what a rampart is, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [against the outer wall]

bsb_verse_text: a wise woman called out from the city, “Listen! Listen! Please tell Joab to come here so that I may speak with him.”
ult_verse_text: But a wise woman called from the city, “Listen, listen! Please say to Joab, ‘Approach to here, and let me speak to you.’”

notes.note: The woman is repeating the verb **Listen** in order to intensify her expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [Do listen]

notes.orig_language_quote: אִמְרוּ־נָ֣א אֶל־יוֹאָ֔ב קְרַ֣ב עַד־הֵ֔נָּה וַ⁠אֲדַבְּרָ֖ה אֵלֶֽי⁠ךָ
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [Please ask Joab to come here so that I can speak to him]
If your language has a formal form of **you** that it uses to address a superior respectfully, it would be appropriate to use that form here.

bsb_verse_text: When he had come near to her, the woman asked, “Are you Joab?” “I am,” he replied. “Listen to the words of your servant,” she said. “I am listening,” he answered.
ult_verse_text: And he approached to her, and the woman said, “{Are you} Joab?”

notes.note: This is an imperative, but it communicates a polite request rather than a command. Use a form in your language that communicates a polite request. It may be helpful to add an expression such as “please” to make this clear. Alternate translation: [Please hear]

The woman is using the term **words** to represent what she wants to say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what your female servant has to say]

The woman is speaking of herself in the third person as **your female servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. Alternate translation: [what I, your female servant, have to say]

Joab is using the present tense **I am listening** to describe something that is going to happen in the near future in order to show that it will indeed happen. In other words, he is agreeing to the woman’s request that he **Hear** what she has to say. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use the future tense or express the meaning in plain language. Alternate translation: [I will be listening] or [I agree to listen]

bsb_verse_text: Then the woman said, “Long ago they used to say, ‘Seek counsel at Abel,’ and that is how disputes were settled.
ult_verse_text: So she spoke, saying, “Speaking, they spoke in former {times}, saying, ‘Inquiring, they shall inquire at Abel,’ and thus they ended.

notes.note: The woman is repeating forms of the verb **spoke** in order to intensify her expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [They surely spoke]

The woman is using the adjective **former** as a noun to mean a certain kind of time. The ULT indicates this by supplying the word **times**. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [in the past]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [saying that inquiring, they should inquire at Abel] or [saying that they should certainly inquire at Abel]

The woman is repeating forms of the verb **inquire** in order to intensify her expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [They shall certainly inquire at Abel]

The woman is quoting a proverb in order to convince Joab that the people of Abel will be able to suggest a wise solution to the problem that has led Joab to put the city under siege. Translate this proverb in a way that will be recognized as a proverb and be meaningful in your language and culture.

The woman is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and thus they ended their disputes]

bsb_verse_text: I am among the peaceable and faithful in Israel, but you are trying to destroy a city that is a mother in Israel. Why would you swallow up the LORD’s inheritance?”
ult_verse_text: I {am} pacified and faithful {ones} of Israel. You are seeking to kill a city and a mother in Israel. Why will you devour the inheritance of Yahweh?”

notes.note: The woman is speaking on behalf of her city, saying what she believes it would say if it could talk about itself. She is actually speaking for herself and her fellow residents of the city. It may be more natural in your language to use a plural pronoun. Alternate translation: [We are pacified and faithful ones of Israel]

The woman is using the adjectives **pacified** and **faithful** as nouns to mean a certain kinds of people. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate these adjectives with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [pacified and faithful Israelites]

The expression **pacified** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [peaceable]

The woman is speaking of Abel Beth Maacah as if it were a living thing that Joab and his soldiers could **kill**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to destroy]

The phrase **city and a mother** expresses a single idea. The word **mother** tells what kind of **city** this is. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [a mother-city] or [a metropolis]

The woman is speaking of Abel Beth Maacah as if it were actually a **mother** in Israel. This was a common image of this culture, which described the towns and villages around a major city as its “daughters.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [an important city] or [a major city]

The woman is using the question form to rebuke Joab. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You should not devour the inheritance of Yahweh!]

The wise woman is speaking as if Joab and his soldiers would actually **devour** or eat up Abel Beth Maacah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [will you destroy]

The woman is speaking of the people of Israel as if they were something that Yahweh had inherited as a lasting possession. She is referring to the Israelites as the people who belong to Yahweh perpetually. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated the similar expression in [14:16](../14/16.md). Alternate translation: [so many of the people of Israel]

bsb_verse_text: “Far be it!” Joab declared. “Far be it from me to swallow up or destroy!
ult_verse_text: And Joab answered and said, “Profane, profane to me if I should devour or if I should destroy!

notes.note: The expression **and said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly. Alternate translation: [And Joab responded]

Joab is using a common expression of his culture to express his horror at the idea he describes. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 2:30](../../1sa/02/30.md). Alternate translation: [Far be it, far be it from me to devour or to destroy!]

Joab is repeating the word **Profane** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [Absolutely profane to me] or [Be it far away from me]

These two phrases **if I should devour** and **if I should destroy** mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine them and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [if I should completely destroy]

bsb_verse_text: That is not the case. But a man named Sheba son of Bichri, from the hill country of Ephraim, has lifted up his hand against the king, against David. Deliver him alone, and I will depart from the city.” “Look,” the woman replied, “his head will be thrown to you over the wall.”
ult_verse_text: The matter {is} not thus, but a man from the hill country of Ephraim—Sheba, the son of Bichri, is his name—has lifted his hand against the king, against David. Give him alone, and let me go from the city.”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [18:21](../18/21.md). Alternate translation: [has sought to harm the king]

Joab is using **me** to represent himself and his soldiers. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and let me and my soldiers go from the city] or [and let us go from the city]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:2](../07/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

The expression **will be thrown** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [we will throw his head]

bsb_verse_text: Then the woman went to all the people with her wise counsel, and they cut off the head of Sheba son of Bichri and threw it to Joab. So he blew the ram’s horn and his men dispersed from the city, each to his own home. And Joab returned to the king in Jerusalem.
ult_verse_text: And the woman came to all of the people in her wisdom, and they cut off the head of Sheba, the son of Bichri, and they threw {it} to Joab. And he blew on the shofar, and they dispersed from the city, a man to his tent. And Joab returned {to} Jerusalem, to the king.

notes.note: In a context such as this, your language might say “went” instead of **came**. Alternate translation: [And the woman went]

The author is saying **all of the people** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [an assembly of the people]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּתְקַע֙ בַּ⁠שּׁוֹפָ֔ר וַ⁠יָּפֻ֥צוּ מֵֽ⁠עַל־הָ⁠עִ֖יר אִ֣ישׁ לְ⁠אֹהָלָ֑י⁠ו וְ⁠יוֹאָ֛ב שָׁ֥ב יְרוּשָׁלִַ֖ם אֶל־הַ⁠מֶּֽלֶךְ
notes.note: The author is making a comment about what happened after the story as a result of the events within the story itself. This signals the end of the story. Use a natural form in your language for expressing the conclusion of a story.
See how you translated the similar expression in [18:17](../18/17.md). Alternate translation: [each one leaving the army and returning to his own home]

bsb_verse_text: Now Joab was over the whole army of Israel; Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and Pelethites;
ult_verse_text: Now Joab {was} over all of the army of Israel. And Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, {was} over the Cherethites and over the Pelethites.

notes.note: See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of the list that begins here and continues to the end of the chapter.

Here, the author is speaking as if these commanders had stood physically **over** or above their troops. He means that they commanded them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly, here and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [commanded … commanded]

bsb_verse_text: Adoram was in charge of the forced labor; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the recorder;
ult_verse_text: And Adoniram {was} over the forced labor, and Jehoshaphat, the son of Ahilud, {was} the recorder.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [8:16](../08/16.md). Alternate translation: [the royal secretary]

bsb_verse_text: and Ira the Jairite was David’s priest.
ult_verse_text: And also Ira the Jairite was a priest to David.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [8:18](../08/18.md). Alternate translation: [a chief official]

bsb_verse_text: During the reign of David there was a famine for three successive years, and David sought the face of the LORD. And the LORD said, “It is because of the blood shed by Saul and his family, because he killed the Gibeonites.”
ult_verse_text: Now {there} was a famine in the days of David three years, year after year. And David sought the face of Yahweh, and Yahweh said, “To Saul and to the house {is} blood, because he killed the Gibeonites.”

notes.note: The author is using the word translated **Now** to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event. Alternate translation: [At another time] or [During one period]

The author is using the phrase **three years, year after year** as a common expression of his culture to mean “for three consecutive years.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [three years in a row] or [for three consecutive years]

The author is using the phrase **sought the face of** as a common expression in of his culture to mean “prayed to” or “asked guidance from.” In this case, David was praying to Yahweh about the cause of the famine. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And David inquired of Yahweh]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Because Saul killed the Gibeonites, to him and to the house is blood]
See how you translated the similar expression in [6:11](../06/11.md). Alternate translation: [and to his household]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:29](../03/29.md). Alternate translation: [is guilt for murder]

bsb_verse_text: At this, David summoned the Gibeonites and spoke to them. (Now the Gibeonites were not Israelites, but a remnant of the Amorites. The Israelites had taken an oath concerning them, but in his zeal for Israel and Judah, Saul had sought to kill them.)
ult_verse_text: And the king called to the Gibeonites, and he spoke to them. (Now the Gibeonites {were} not from the sons of Israel. Rather, they {were} from the remnant of the Amorite. And the sons of Israel had sworn to them, but Saul sought to strike them when he was jealous for the sons of Israel and Judah.)

notes.note: The author is saying **the Gibeonites** as a generalization. He does not mean that David spoke with the entire people group, but with some representatives of it. Alternate translation: [representatives of the Gibeonites]

Here, the author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

The author assumes that readers will know that the Israelites had sworn to protect the Gibeonites and not kill them, as recorded in [Joshua 9](../../jos/09/01.md). You could say that explicitly if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [And the sons of Israel had sworn to them that they would spare their lives]

The author is speaking as if the people of Israel and Judah were actually the **sons** of the patriarch Jacob, who was also known as Israel, and the patriarch Judah. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 2:28](../../1sa/02/28.md). Alternate translation: [the Israelites … the Israelites and Judeans]

The author is not referring to a specific **Amorite**. He means Amorites in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the Amorites]

See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of the term **strike** and its past form “struck,” which mean “kill” or “killed” here and in several other places in the chapter. Alternate translation: [to kill them]

bsb_verse_text: So David asked the Gibeonites, “What shall I do for you? How can I make amends so that you may bless the inheritance of the LORD?”
ult_verse_text: And David said to the Gibeonites, “What shall I do for you, and with what shall I atone, then bless the inheritance of Yahweh?”

notes.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine them and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [How can I thoroughly make amends to you] or [What can I possibly do to make things right with you]

This is an imperative, but David is using it to confirm the response he could expect from the Gibeonites if he performed the actions he has just described. Use a form in your language that indicates this. Alternate translation: [that you would then bless]
See how you translated the similar expression in [14:16](../14/16.md). Alternate translation: [Yahweh’s people, Israel]

bsb_verse_text: The Gibeonites said to him, “We need no silver or gold from Saul or his house, nor should you put to death anyone in Israel for us.” “Whatever you ask, I will do for you,” he replied.
ult_verse_text: And the Gibeonites said to him, “{There is} no silver or gold for us with Saul or with his house. And {there is} not for us a man to kill in Israel.”

notes.note: The Gibeonites are referring to all forms of payment by naming two major forms of money in this culture, **silver** and **gold**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [We will not accept any form of payment as compensation from Saul or from his house]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [with Saul, that is, with his descendants]

The Gibeonites could mean: (1) that there is not a **man** (that is, there is no one) in their people group who is authorized **to kill** anyone **in Israel**. In other words, since they apparently do not have the right to execute Israelites who may have committed capital crimes against them, they are indirectly introducing a request that David execute some of Saul’s descendants. (The next sentence shows that David recognizes they are asking something of him.) Alternate translation: [And we are not allowed to punish any Israelites by executing them]; (2) that the Gibeonites are making a generalization and they expect David to understand that it includes an exception. Alternate translation: [And we do not want to kill anyone in Israel except some of Saul’s descendants to avenge his crime against us]

bsb_verse_text: And they answered the king, “As for the man who consumed us and plotted against us to exterminate us from existing within any border of Israel,
ult_verse_text: And they said to the king, “The man who ended us and who intended against us {that} we should be destroyed from stationing ourselves in all of the border of Israel,

notes.orig_language_quote: אֲשֶׁ֣ר כִּלָּ֔⁠נוּ וַ⁠אֲשֶׁ֖ר דִּמָּה־לָ֑⁠נוּ נִשְׁמַ֕דְנוּ מֵֽ⁠הִתְיַצֵּ֖ב בְּ⁠כָל־גְּבֻ֥ל יִשְׂרָאֵֽל
notes.note: The Gibeonites are describing one event before describing another event that preceded it. If it would be helpful your language, you may wish to relate these events in the order in which they happened, as in the UST. Alternate translation: [who intended against us that we should be destroyed from stationing ourselves in all of the border of Israel and who then ended us]

The expression **we should be destroyed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [to destroy us]

The Gibeonites are using the common expression of their culture, **from stationing ourselves in all of the border of Israel**, to mean “from living anywhere in the territory of Israel.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from living anywhere]

Here, **border** represents the territory of Israel, since that territory is defined by its border. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the territory of Israel]

bsb_verse_text: let seven of his male descendants be delivered to us so that we may hang them before the LORD at Gibeah of Saul, the chosen of the LORD.” “I will give them to you,” said the king.
ult_verse_text: let seven men from his sons be given to us, and we will hang them before Yahweh at Gibeah of Saul, the chosen of Yahweh.”

notes.note: The Gibeonites’ request to **hang** Saul’s descendants was a symbolic action by which they sought to avenge themselves on Saul’s family and restore justice for the harm he had done to them. In this culture, **seven** was a number symbolic of completeness. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [let seven men from his sons be given to us, and we will execute them as a just consequence of Saul’s crime against us]

The expression **be given to us** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [give us seven men from his sons]

Here, the Gibeonites are speaking as if Saul’s **sons** were actually sons he had personally fathered. They mean his descendants, including grandsons and other male relatives. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from his male descendants]

The Gibeonites are using the common expression of their culture **before Yahweh** to mean that Yahweh would witness their act of justice. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [where Yahweh can see that justice has been done]

The Gibeonites are using the adjective **chosen** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the one whom Yahweh chose to be king]

David is stating the pronoun **I** separately, even though the verb translated as **I will give** already includes this meaning. He is doing that because he is making a promise to the Gibeonites. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that David is making a promise. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [I promise that I will give]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [I promise that I will give them to you]

bsb_verse_text: Now the king spared Mephibosheth son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, because of the oath before the LORD between David and Jonathan son of Saul.
ult_verse_text: Now the king had compassion on Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, because of the oath of Yahweh that {was} between them, between David and between Jonathan, the son of Saul.

notes.note: The author is using this possessive form to describe an **oath** that David swore to Jonathan by **Yahweh**. If a speaker of your language would not use a possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. This refers to the oath that Jonathan had David swear to him by Yahweh, as described in [1 Samuel 20:14–16](../../1sa/20/14.md), that he would not harm his descendants. Alternate translation: [the oath sworn in the name of Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: But the king took Armoni and Mephibosheth, the two sons whom Rizpah daughter of Aiah had borne to Saul, as well as the five sons whom Merab daughter of Saul had borne to Adriel son of Barzillai the Meholathite.
