ult_verse_text: But the king took two of the sons of Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, whom she bore to Saul, Armoni and Mephibosheth, and five of the sons of Michal, the daughter of Saul, whom she bore to Adriel, the son of Barzillai the Meholathite.

notes.note: The traditional Hebrew text reads “Michal.” The ULT follows that reading. Some other Hebrew manuscripts and some manuscripts of the Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation) read “Merab.” That was probably the original reading, since [1 Samuel 18:19](../18/19.md) describes how it was Merab who married **Adriel** of Meholah, while the author says in [6:23](../06/23.md) that Michal had no children. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

bsb_verse_text: And he delivered them into the hands of the Gibeonites, and they hanged them on the hill before the LORD. So all seven of them fell together; they were put to death in the first days of the harvest, at the beginning of the barley harvest.
ult_verse_text: And he gave them into the hand of the Gibeonites, and they hanged them on the hill to the face of Yahweh, and the seven of them fell together. And they, they were killed in the days of the harvest, in the first {days}, at the beginning of the harvest of barley.

notes.note: In this verse, the word **hand** is singular in form, but it refers to all Gibeonites as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “hand.” Alternate translation: [into the hands of the Gibeonites]

Here, **hand** represents control or custody. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [into the custody of the Gibeonites]

Here, **to the face of** represents being in the presence of Yahweh. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the presence of Yahweh]
Here, **fell** represents “died.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and the seven of them died]

The author is stating the pronoun **they** separately, even though the verb translated as **they were killed** already includes this meaning. He is doing that in order to introduce background information. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for this same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that the author is introducing background information. Alternate translation: [Now they were killed]

The expression **were killed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Now the Gibeonites killed them specifically]

It might seem that the expression **in the days of the harvest, in the first** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [in the first days of the harvest]

Here the term **days** represents a certain time, since time is made up of days. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [at the start of the harvest time]

The author is using the adjective **first** as a noun to mean a certain kind of day. The ULT shows that by supplying the term **days**. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [in the first part]

If your language would not represent a number in a form such as ** first**, you could represent this number in a form that your language would use or with an equivalent term. Alternate translation: [in the starting days]

bsb_verse_text: And Rizpah the daughter of Aiah took sackcloth and spread it out for herself on a rock. From the beginning of the harvest until the rain from heaven poured down on the bodies, she did not allow the birds of the air to rest on them by day, nor the beasts of the field by night.
ult_verse_text: And Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, took sackcloth, and she spread it for herself against a rock, from the beginning of the harvest until water was poured on them from the heavens. And she did not allow a bird of the heavens to rest on them by day or a beast of the field by night.

notes.note: The author assumes that readers will know that Rizpah spread this sackcloth against a rock to make a shelter for herself while she guarded the bodies of her male relatives. You could say that explicitly if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and she spread it for herself against a rock to make a shelter for herself]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and she remained there from the beginning of the harvest]

Sending rain (**water**) from the sky (**the heavens**) was a symbolic action by which Yahweh showed that justice had been satisfied for the crime of Saul, which had been the cause of the three-year drought and famine. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [until Yahweh sent rain from the sky to show that justice had been satisfied for the crime of Saul]

The word that the ULT translates in the singular as **water** (to match the singular verb **was poured**) is actually plural. In this plural form, in contexts such as this, it can mean “rain.” Alternate translation: [until rain was poured on them]

The expression **was poured** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it was Yahweh. Alternate translation: [rain fell on them] or [Yahweh poured rain on them]

The implication is that the birds would **rest** or land on the dead bodies because they wanted to feed on them. You could indicate this in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [to feed on them]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [or a beast of the field to feed on them by night]

bsb_verse_text: When David was told what Saul’s concubine Rizpah, daughter of Aiah, had done,
ult_verse_text: And it was declared to David what Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done.

notes.note: The expression **it was declared** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And someone declared to David]

bsb_verse_text: he went and took the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan from the men of Jabesh-gilead, who had stolen them from the public square of Beth-shan where the Philistines had hung the bodies after they had struck down Saul at Gilboa.
ult_verse_text: And David went, and he took the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son from the lords of Jabesh Gilead, who had stolen them from the open area of Beth Shan, where the Philistines had hanged them there on the day the Philistines struck Saul at Gilboa.

notes.note: It might seem that the expression **where the Philistines had hanged them there** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [where the Philistines had hanged them]

bsb_verse_text: So David had the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan brought from there, and they also gathered the bones of those who had been hanged.
ult_verse_text: And he brought up from there the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son, and they gathered the bones of the hanged ones.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:1](../02/01.md). Alternate translation: [And he brought]

The expression **hanged ones** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the men who had been hanged]

bsb_verse_text: And they buried the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan in Zela in the land of Benjamin, in the tomb of Saul’s father Kish. After they had done everything the king had commanded, God answered their prayers for the land.
ult_verse_text: And they buried the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son in the land of Benjamin, in Zela, in the tomb of Kish his father. And they did all that the king commanded. And God was entreated for the land after this.

notes.note: The author is using **the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son** also to represent the bones of Saul’s male relatives whom the Gibeonites executed. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son and the hanged ones]

The implication is that the servants buried the bones at the king’s command. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [And they did all of this at the command of the king]

The phrase **And God was entreated for the land after that** is a comment about what happened after the story as a result of the events within the story itself. This signals the end of a story. Use the natural form in your language for expressing the conclusion of a story.

The expression **was entreated** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And the Israelites were able to entreat God for the land after this]

By **this**, the author means that God responded to prayers for the land only after the Gibeonites had been avenged and Saul’s descendants had been properly buried. You could include this information in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [after the Gibeonites had hanged seven of Saul’s descendants]

bsb_verse_text: Once again the Philistines waged war against Israel, and David and his servants went down and fought against the Philistines. But David became exhausted.
ult_verse_text: Now war was to the Philistines again with Israel. And David went down, and his servants with him, and they fought the Philistines. And David wearied.

notes.note: The author is using this phrase to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event.

bsb_verse_text: Then Ishbi-benob, a descendant of Rapha, whose bronze spear weighed three hundred shekels and who was bearing a new sword, resolved to kill David.
ult_verse_text: And Ishbi Benob, who {was} among the children of Rapha, and the weight of his spear {was} 300 {shekels} of bronze in weight, and he was girded {with} a new {weapon}, and he said to strike David.

notes.note: Here, the author is speaking of the **children of Rapha** as if Rapha were actually their physical father. He means they were among the descendants of Rapha, the group of giants called Raphaites. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly, here and in [verses 18](../21/18.md), [20](../21/20.md), and [22](../21/22.md). Alternate translation: [was one of the descendants of Rapha] or [was a Raphaite]

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠מִשְׁקַ֤ל קֵינ⁠וֹ֙ שְׁלֹ֤שׁ מֵאוֹת֙ מִשְׁקַ֣ל נְחֹ֔שֶׁת
notes.note: It might seem that the expression **300 shekels of bronze in weight** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [and the weight of his spear was 300 shekels of bronze]

These 300 **shekels of bronze** equaled about 3 ½ kilograms or nearly 8 pounds. In your translation, you could use the ancient measurement and spell the word “shekel” the way it sounds in your language. You could also use the metric measurement given in the UST or use the measurement that your language and culture customarily use. Alternatively, you could use the ancient measurement and put a modern measurement in parentheses in the text or in a footnote.

The expression **was girded** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and he was bearing a new weapon]

The traditional Hebrew text simply says “new.” The ULT seeks to show what that reading might mean. Some versions are more specific and say “a new sword” or “new armor.” The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation) has a term that means “a club” or “a mace” (a club with an iron coating or head). This suggests that the original text could have named some rare but formidable weapon whose name was not preserved exactly in the traditional text. (The context suggests that Ishbi Benob believed he could kill David because he had such a weapon.) If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.
See how you translated the similar expression in [10:2](../10/02.md). Alternate translation: [and he said to himself, “I will strike David”] or [and he thought he would strike David]

bsb_verse_text: But Abishai son of Zeruiah came to his aid, struck the Philistine, and killed him. Then David’s men swore to him, “You must never again go out with us to battle, so that the lamp of Israel may not be extinguished.”
ult_verse_text: But Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, helped him, and he struck the Philistine, and he killed him. Then the men of David adjured him, saying, “You shall not go out with us to battle anymore, so you do not extinguish the lamp of Israel.”

notes.note: David’s men are speaking of him as if he were a **lamp** providing light for Israel. They mean that he was Israel’s leader who guided them as a lamp would light the way on a path. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [so you do not die and leave Israel without its leader] or [so you do not end your leadership of Israel]

bsb_verse_text: Some time later at Gob, there was another battle with the Philistines. At that time Sibbecai the Hushathite killed Saph, a descendant of Rapha.
ult_verse_text: And it happened after this that {there} was a battle again with the Philistines, at Gob. Then Sibbecai the Hushathite struck Saph, who {was} among the children of Rapha.

notes.note: The traditional Hebrew text reads “Gob” here. The ULT follows that reading. However, a place called Gob is otherwise not known. The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation) reads “Gath.” The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 20:4](../../1ch/20/04.md) reads “Gezer.” So there is some doubt as to the actual name of this place. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

bsb_verse_text: Once again there was a battle with the Philistines at Gob, and Elhanan son of Jair the Bethlehemite killed the brother of Goliath the Gittite, the shaft of whose spear was like a weaver’s beam.
ult_verse_text: And {there} was battle again with the Philistines at Gob. And Elhanan, the son of Jaare Oregim the Bethlehemite, struck Goliath the Gittite, and the wood of his spear {was} like the beam of weavers.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יַּ֡ךְ & אֵ֚ת גָּלְיָ֣ת הַ⁠גִּתִּ֔י וְ⁠עֵ֣ץ חֲנִית֔⁠וֹ כִּ⁠מְנ֖וֹר אֹרְגִֽים
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about the thickness of **the wood of his spear** before the information that Elhanan struck **Goliath the Gittite**. In some languages, that might help emphasize the strength and courage of Elhanan, which the author wishes to highlight here. Alternate translation: [fought Goliath the Gittite. Even thought the wood of his spear {was} like the beam of weavers, Elhanan struck him]

The traditional Hebrew text reads “Jaare Oregim” here. The ULT follows that reading. The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 20:5](../../1ch/20/05.md) reads “Jair.” That may have been the original reading, since the word “oregim” means “weavers” and occurs later in the verse. It may have accidentally been copied here. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

The traditional Hebrew text reads “Goliath the Gittite” here. The ULT follows that reading. The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 20:5](../../1ch/20/05.md) reads “the brother of Goliath the Gittite.” That may have been the original reading, since [1 Samuel 17:1–51](../17/01.md) describes how it was actually David who killed Goliath the Gittite. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

A **beam of weavers** was the thick, strong beam on which weavers hung their fabric. If your readers would not be familiar with this, in your translation you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a general expression. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 17:7](../../1sa/17/07.md). Alternate translation: [was like the thick, strong beam on which weavers hang their fabric]

bsb_verse_text: And there was also a battle at Gath, where there was a man of great stature with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot—twenty-four in all. He too was descended from Rapha,
ult_verse_text: And {there} was battle again at Gath, and {there} was a man of stature, and the digits of his hands and the digits of his feet {were} six and six, 24 {in} number. And he also was born to Rapha.

notes.note: The author is using the possessive form to describe a **man** who was characterized by great **stature** or height. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [a very tall man]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אֶצְבְּעֹ֣ת יָדָי⁠ו֩ וְ⁠אֶצְבְּעֹ֨ת רַגְלָ֜י⁠ו שֵׁ֣שׁ וָ⁠שֵׁ֗שׁ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the number of each type of digit with the name of each body part. Alternate translation: [and he had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot]

The author is repeating the information about the number of digits that this **man of stature had**, presenting it in two different forms to emphasize how striking it is. You may find it appropriate to repeat the information in your translation in order to convey that emphasis, even if this would otherwise be extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. Alternate translation: [were 6 and 6, for a total of 24 digits in all]

The expression **was born** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And he too was a descendant of Rapha]

bsb_verse_text: and when he taunted Israel, Jonathan the son of David’s brother Shimei killed him.
ult_verse_text: And he taunted Israel, and Jonathan, the son of Shimeah, the brother of David, struck him.

notes.note: **Shimeah**, not **Jonathan**, was **the brother of David**. You may have kinship terms that you can use to make this clear in your translation. Alternate translation: [Jonathan son of Shimeah, the nephew of David]

bsb_verse_text: So these four descendants of Rapha in Gath fell at the hands of David and his servants.
ult_verse_text: These four were born to Rapha in Gath. And they fell by the hand of David and by the hand of his servants.

notes.note: The expression **were born** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [were descendants of Rapha in Gath]

Here, **hand** represents the power and capability of David and his servants to defeat these enemies. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And they fell by the might of David and by the power of his servants]
Here the term **fell** means “died”. Alternate translation: [And they died at the hands of David and his servants] or [And it was David and his servants who killed them]

The author is crediting David in part with these victories because he commanded the Israelite soldiers who won them. But he is then crediting the specific **servants** or soldiers who defeated these giant opponents. If the connection between the first part of this phrase and the second part is not clear, you may want to use a different connecting word or phrase to show how the parts relate to one another. Alternate translation: [by the hand of David, and specifically, by the hands of his servants]

bsb_verse_text: And David sang this song to the LORD on the day the LORD had delivered him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul.
ult_verse_text: And David spoke to Yahweh the words of this song on the day Yahweh delivered him from the palm of all of his enemies and from the palm of Saul.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יְדַבֵּ֤ר דָּוִד֙ לַֽ⁠יהוָ֔ה אֶת־דִּבְרֵ֖י הַ⁠שִּׁירָ֣ה הַ⁠זֹּ֑את
notes.note: In this verse, David is introducing the song that follows in the rest of the chapter. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that would be natural for introducing a long quotation of someone’s writing with the story of that person’s life. Alternate translation: [Here are the words to a song that David sang to Yahweh]
David is using the term **day** to refer to a specific time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [at the time when]

Here, **palm** represents power or control. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from the power of all of his enemies and from the power of Saul]

bsb_verse_text: He said: “The LORD is my rock, my fortress, and my deliverer.
ult_verse_text: And he said, “Yahweh {is} my rock and my stronghold and my deliverer, mine.

notes.note: This verse says basically the same thing as the previous verse. See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of how Hebrew poetry was based on the repetition of words, phrases, and ideas. Decide as a team how you will represent Hebrew poetry in your translation.

The terms **rock** and **stronghold** mean similar things. David is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [Yahweh is the place where I go for safety]

David is speaking here of **Yahweh** as if he were a **rock** and a **stronghold**. He means that Yahweh provides safety and protection for him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Yahweh is the one who keeps me safe]

David is saying both **my** and **mine** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that Yahweh is his **deliverer**. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [and my sure deliverer]

bsb_verse_text: My God is my rock, in whom I take refuge, my shield, and the horn of my salvation. My stronghold, my refuge, and my Savior, You save me from violence.
ult_verse_text: God of my rock, I take refuge in him, my shield and the horn of my salvation, my stronghold and my refuge, my savior, you save me from violence.

notes.note: David is using the possessive form to describe **God** as characterized by the quality he represents with the image of a **rock**. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [God who is my rock]

David is speaking of God as if he were a high **rock** that he could climb up to reach safety from danger. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express this as a comparison. Alternate translation: [God who is like a rock to me]

David is speaking of **taking refuge** in God as if God were a place of safety in which he could hide. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I can depend on him to keep me safe]

Here David is speaking of Yahweh as if he were a **shield** that protected him from attack. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [my protector]

David is using the possessive form to describe a **horn** that is characterized by providing **salvation**. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [and the horn that saves me]

David is speaking of God’s power to save him as if it were a powerful **horn** of an animal. A horn was a symbol of strength in ancient Israelite culture because animals use their horns as weapons. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and the one who saves my by his power]

The words that the ULT translates as **stronghold** and **refuge** here are not the same words in the original that it translates as “stronghold” in the previous verse and **take refuge** earlier in this verse. Hebrew had more synonyms for these ideas than some other languages may have. It may be necessary for you to use the same words rather than different ones. However, if you do have a variety of terms for these ideas, it would be appropriate to use different words here than were used in the previous ones.

The terms **stronghold** and **refuge** mean similar things. David is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [my strong refuge]

David is speaking of Yahweh as if he were a **stronghold** and **refuge**, places where people could go to be safe from their enemies. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the one who keeps me completely safe]

David says in [22:1](../22/01.md) that David sang this song “to Yahweh.” Here and later in the song, especially in [verses 26–44](../22/26.md) and [49–51](../22/49.md), David addresses Yahweh directly as “you.” However, in the rest of the song, he speaks of Yahweh in the third person, saying “he,” “him,” and “his.” If it would be more natural in your language, you could use either the second person or the third person consistently throughout the song. The UST models one way to use the second person consistently. If you took the other approach, you could use the third person here and later in the song. Alternate translation: [he saves me from violence]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **violence**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [you keep violent people from harming me]

bsb_verse_text: I will call upon the LORD, who is worthy to be praised; so shall I be saved from my enemies.
ult_verse_text: {To} the one being praised I call, {to} Yahweh, and I am saved from my enemies.

notes.note: The expression **being praised** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [I call to Yahweh, the one whom people praise] or [I call to Yahweh, the one whom I praise]

The expression **I am saved** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and he saves me]

bsb_verse_text: For the waves of death engulfed me; the torrents of chaos overwhelmed me.
ult_verse_text: For the waves of death surrounded me, the torrents of wickedness terrified me.

notes.note: Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but a description of how Yahweh saved David from his enemies. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use a different connecting word. Alternate translation: [You see,] or [Indeed,]

David is speaking of death as if it were a flood with powerful **waves** that could surround and overwhelm him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I was in danger of being killed and did not know how to escape]

David speaks here of **torrents of wickedness** as if wickedness were a flood of rushing water that could overwhelm and destroy him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a wicked person was pursuing me relentlessly, and that terrified me]

bsb_verse_text: The cords of Sheol entangled me; the snares of death confronted me.
ult_verse_text: The cords of Sheol surrounded me, the snares of death confronted me.

notes.note: Here, **Sheol**, the abode of the dead according to Hebrew culture, represents death itself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [The cords of death surrounded me]

David is speaking as if Sheol or death actually had **cords** that it could use to bind him. This suggests he felt trapped in a situation where he thought he would die. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [I thought I was bound to die]

David speaks here of **snares of death** as if death were a hunter that could set traps for people. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [death had me in its clutches]

bsb_verse_text: In my distress I called upon the LORD; I cried out to my God. And from His temple He heard my voice, and my cry for help reached His ears.
ult_verse_text: In my distress I called {to} Yahweh, and to my God I called. And he heard my voice from his temple, and my cry {was} in his ears.

notes.note: Here, **voice** represents what David used his voice to say in his prayer. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And he heard my prayer]
See how you translated the similar expression with “listen” in [12:18](../12/18.md). Alternate translation: [And he granted my request]

By **his temple**, David means God’s temple in heaven. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [from his heavenly temple]

David is using the term **ears** to mean hearing. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and my cry was in his hearing] or [and he heard my cry]

bsb_verse_text: Then the earth shook and quaked; the foundations of the heavens trembled; they were shaken because He burned with anger.
ult_verse_text: Then the earth shook and trembled. The foundations of the heavens quaked and shook themselves, because it burned to him.

notes.orig_language_quote: ו⁠תגעש וַ⁠תִּרְעַשׁ֙ הָ⁠אָ֔רֶץ מוֹסְד֥וֹת הַ⁠שָּׁמַ֖יִם יִרְגָּ֑זוּ וַ⁠יִּֽתְגָּעֲשׁ֖וּ כִּֽי־חָ֥רָה לֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Then, because it burned to him, the earth shook and trembled. The foundations of the heavens quaked and shook themselves]

The terms that the ULT translates as **shook** and **shook themselves** represent two different verbs in the original. Hebrew had more synonyms for this idea, which David also expresses with the verbs translated as **trembled** and **quaked**, than some other languages may have. It may be necessary for you to use the same words rather than different ones. However, if you do have a variety of terms for this, it would be appropriate to use different words for **shook** and **shook themselves**.

The terms **shook** and **trembled** mean similar things. David is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [Then the earth shook violently]

David is speaking as if the **earth** were actually a person who could shake and tremble with fear. This expresses how powerfully God responded to David’s prayer. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Then it was as though a violent earthquake occurred]

David assumes that people listening to this song will recognize, according to the understanding of this culture, that the phrase **the foundations of the heavens** refers to solid places on which the sky rested. You could say that explicitly if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [The bases on which the sky rests]

The terms **quaked** and **shook themselves** mean similar things. David is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [quaked mightily]
See how you translated the similar expression in [6:8](../06/08.md). Alternate translation: [he became very angry]

bsb_verse_text: Smoke rose from His nostrils, and consuming fire came from His mouth; glowing coals blazed forth.
ult_verse_text: Smoke went up from his nose, and fire from his mouth devoured. Coals from him burned.

notes.orig_language_quote: עָלָ֤ה עָשָׁן֙ בְּ⁠אַפּ֔⁠וֹ וְ⁠אֵ֥שׁ מִ⁠פִּ֖י⁠ו תֹּאכֵ֑ל גֶּחָלִ֖ים בָּעֲר֥וּ מִמֶּֽ⁠נּוּ
notes.note: David is saying that when Yahweh came to help him, Yahweh’s power was so great that it was like a volcano. A volcano is an opening in the earth through which gases, smoke-like ash, and very hot, liquid rock come out. The rock can cool and build up over time to form a hill or mountain. David is describing the opening at the top of a volcano, from which **Smoke** and **fire** and **Coals** come out, as if it were the **nose** and **mouth** of the volcano. If your readers would be familiar with what a volcano is, you could express in your translation how David is using a volcano as an image to describe Yahweh’s power. If your readers would not be familiar with what a volcano is, you could describe in more general terms how Yahweh’s power is like fire and smoke.

David is speaking of the fire that comes from a volcano, which represents God here, as if it were a wild animal that **devoured** its prey. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and fire from his mouth completely destroyed everything] or [and fire from his mouth consumed everything]

bsb_verse_text: He parted the heavens and came down with dark clouds beneath His feet.
ult_verse_text: And he lowered the heavens, and he came down, and a dark cloud {was} under his feet.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֵּ֥ט שָׁמַ֖יִם וַ⁠יֵּרַ֑ד וַ⁠עֲרָפֶ֖ל תַּ֥חַת רַגְלָֽי⁠ו
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [And he came standing on a dark cloud, and thus he lowered the heavens]

bsb_verse_text: He mounted a cherub and flew; He soared on the wings of the wind.
ult_verse_text: And he rode on a cherub, and he flew. He was seen on the wings of the wind.

notes.note: The phrase **rode and flew** expresses a single idea. The word **flew** tells more about how he **rode**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [And he flew by riding on a cherub]

David is speaking as if God were actually riding on a **cherub** and flying through the sky. This is part of a poetic description of God’s power and swift action to help David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And he came very quickly]

The expression **was seen** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [He appeared on the wings of the wind]

David is speaking as if the wind actually had **wings** and that it could fly through the sky carrying Yahweh. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [It appeared as if the wind were a great bird that was carrying him]

bsb_verse_text: He made darkness a canopy around Him, a gathering of water and thick clouds.
ult_verse_text: And he set darkness, the booths around him {were} a gathering of waters, clouds of the skies.

notes.note: David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context here if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [And he set darkness as his shelter]

David is speaking as if the darkness were actually **set** like a physical object that could be arranged in place. He means that God caused darkness to surround himself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [It was as if he were dwelling within the darkness of the storm]

The phrases **a gathering of waters** and **clouds of the skies** mean similar things. David is using the two phrases together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [were rainclouds thick with water] or [were clouds that had collected water]

bsb_verse_text: From the brightness of His presence coals of fire blazed forth.
ult_verse_text: From the brightness before him, coals of fire burned.

notes.note: Here, **before him** represents being in God’s presence. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in his presence]

Since David says that these **coals of fire** came **From** this **brightness**, he does not mean that they **burned** in place where they were. He means that they came burning forth. Within the image of a thunderstorm, he is referring to flashes of lightning. Alternate translation: [streaks of flame came out]

bsb_verse_text: He shot His arrows and scattered the foes; He hurled lightning and routed them.
ult_verse_text: And he sent out arrows, and he scattered them, lightning, and he panicked them.

notes.note: Here David is using an image within an image. Within the image of a thunderstorm that represents Yahweh coming powerfully to help him, David speaks of lightning bolts as if they were **arrows**. You might be able to clarify this by combining the two parts of this verse, which mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: [And he sent out lightning bolts like arrows and panicked them so that they scattered]

The pronoun **them** refers in each instance to David’s enemies. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [and he scattered my enemies … and he panicked those enemies]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [yes, he sent out lightning]

bsb_verse_text: The channels of the sea appeared, and the foundations of the world were exposed at the rebuke of the LORD, at the blast of the breath of His nostrils.
ult_verse_text: And the valleys of the sea were seen, the foundations of the world were uncovered, at the rebuke of Yahweh, from the blast of the breath of his nose.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֵּֽרָאוּ֙ אֲפִ֣קֵי יָ֔ם יִגָּל֖וּ מֹסְד֣וֹת תֵּבֵ֑ל בְּ⁠גַעֲרַ֣ת יְהוָ֔ה מִ⁠נִּשְׁמַ֖ת ר֥וּחַ אַפּֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [And at the rebuke of Yahweh, from the blast of the breath of his nose, the valleys of the sea were seen, the foundations of the world were uncovered]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֵּֽרָאוּ֙ אֲפִ֣קֵי יָ֔ם יִגָּל֖וּ מֹסְד֣וֹת תֵּבֵ֑ל
notes.note: The expressions **were seen** and **were uncovered** are passive verbal forms. If your language would not use those forms, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And the valleys of the sea became visible; ground no longer covered the foundations of the world]

bsb_verse_text: He reached down from on high and took hold of me; He drew me out of deep waters.
ult_verse_text: He stretched out from the height, he took hold of me. He drew me out of many waters.

notes.note: David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [He stretched out his hand]
Here, **height** represents “heaven” as God’s dwelling place. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [from heaven]

Here, **many waters** represents the sea, since the sea contains much water. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [out of the sea]

Here, **many waters**, meaning the sea, represents deep trouble or dangerous situations. David uses this image because he had earlier described his enemies as dangerous flood waters. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [out of great trouble]

bsb_verse_text: He rescued me from my powerful enemy, from foes too mighty for me.
ult_verse_text: He delivered me from my strong enemy, from the ones hating me, for they were stronger than me.

notes.orig_language_quote: יַצִּילֵ֕⁠נִי מֵ⁠אֹיְבִ֖⁠י עָ֑ז מִ⁠שֹּׂ֣נְאַ֔⁠י כִּ֥י אָמְצ֖וּ מִמֶּֽ⁠נִּי
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Because they were stronger than me, he delivered me from my strong enemy, from the ones hating me]

bsb_verse_text: They confronted me in my day of calamity, but the LORD was my support.
ult_verse_text: They confronted me on the day of my calamity, but Yahweh was my support.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **calamity**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [on a day that would have been disastrous for me]

bsb_verse_text: He brought me out into the open; He rescued me because He delighted in me.
ult_verse_text: And he brought me out to an open space.

notes.note: Here David is speaking of being rescued as if he had been squeezed into a narrow space and God brought him out to an **open space**. The image suggests that David had been in a dangerous situation with no way to escape, but God enabled him to escape. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And he set me free from danger] or [And he rescued me from my desperate situation]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase **delivered me** describes. Alternate translation: [Because he delighted in me, he delivered me]

bsb_verse_text: The LORD has rewarded me according to my righteousness; He has repaid me according to the cleanness of my hands.
ult_verse_text: Yahweh has rewarded me according to my righteousness. According to the cleanness of my hands, he has given back to me.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **righteousness**, you could express the same idea in another way, here and in [verse 25](../22/25.md). Alternate translation: [according to the way I had been righteous]

David is speaking of his actions as if they were his **hands**, which could be physically clean or dirty. He means that his behavior has been morally pure. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly, here and in [verse 25](../22/25.md). Alternate translation: [According to the innocence of my actions]

David is using **he has returned to me** as a common expression of his culture to mean “he has treated me in the same way.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [he has treated me in the same way]

bsb_verse_text: For I have kept the ways of the LORD and have not wickedly departed from my God.
ult_verse_text: For I have kept the ways of Yahweh, and I have not been wicked from my God.

notes.note: Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but an explanation. If the connection between this statement and the previous one is not clear, you may want to use a different connecting word to show how this statement relates to what comes before it. The meaning is similar in [verses 23](../22/23.md), [29](../22/29.md), [30](../22/30.md), and [32](../22/32.md). Alternate translation: [After all,]

David is speaking of how a person lives as if that were a way or path that the person was walking along. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I have lived as Yahweh commands] or [I have obeyed Yahweh’s commands]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context, specifically in the next verse, if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and I have not been so wicked as to turn away from my God]

bsb_verse_text: For all His ordinances are before me; I have not disregarded His statutes.
ult_verse_text: For all of his judgments {are} before me, and his statutes, I have not turned away from them.

notes.note: Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but an explanation of why Yahweh has rewarded David according to his righteousness. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use a word that introduces an explanation. Alternate translation: [Indeed]

David is speaking of **judgments** as if they were objects that could be physically placed in front of him. This means that he constantly remembers and thinks about God’s laws. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I am always mindful of his judgments]

David is speaking of disobeying God’s **statutes** as if they were objects that he could physically turn away from. He is describing refusing to obey God’s commands. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I have not disobeyed his statutes]

bsb_verse_text: And I have been blameless before Him and kept myself from iniquity.
ult_verse_text: And I have been blameless toward him, and I have kept myself from my iniquity.

notes.note: David is using the possessive form to mean sin that he could have committed. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [from any iniquity that I might have committed]

bsb_verse_text: So the LORD has repaid me according to my righteousness, according to my cleanness in His sight.
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh has given back to me according to my righteousness, according to my cleanness before his eyes.

notes.note: Here, **before his eyes** represents how God sees and evaluates people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in his judgment] or [by his standards]

bsb_verse_text: To the faithful You show Yourself faithful, to the blameless You show Yourself blameless;
ult_verse_text: To the faithful you show yourself faithful; with the mighty blameless, you show yourself blameless.

notes.note: Review whether you decided in [22:3](../22/03.md) to use the second person or third person consistently throughout this song, or whether you chose to use both as they appear in the original text, as shown in the ULT here by the shift from “his” in the previous verse to **you**.

David is using the adjective **faithful** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [To people who are faithful]

The phrase **mighty blameless** expresses a single idea. The word **mighty** expresses to what degree these people are **blameless**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [the mightily blameless] or [the entirely innocent]

David is using the adjective **blameless** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [people who are mightily blameless] or [people who are entirely innocent]

bsb_verse_text: to the pure You show Yourself pure, but to the crooked You show Yourself shrewd.
ult_verse_text: With the purified, you show yourself pure, but with the crooked, you show yourself cunning.

notes.note: The expression **the purified** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [those who purify themselves] or [those who keep themselves pure]

Here David is speaking of people who deliberately do what is wrong as if they were physically **crooked** or bent. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [with those who do evil] or [with those who are dishonest]

bsb_verse_text: You save an afflicted people, but Your eyes are on the haughty to bring them down.
ult_verse_text: And you save a lowly people, but your eyes {are} against the ones being high, you bring {them} down.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אֶת־עַ֥ם עָנִ֖י תּוֹשִׁ֑יעַ וְ⁠עֵינֶ֖י⁠ךָ עַל־רָמִ֥ים תַּשְׁפִּֽיל
notes.note: Here David is speaking as if oppressed people were **lowly**, that is, in a physically low place, and as if proud people were physically **high** and Yahweh brought them **down** to a lower place. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you save people who are being oppressed, but your eyes are against proud people, you humble them]

David is using **eyes against** to represent God’s attention and opposition. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [but you oppose]

bsb_verse_text: For You, O LORD, are my lamp; the LORD lights up my darkness.
ult_verse_text: For you {are} my lamp, Yahweh, and Yahweh lightens my darkness.

notes.orig_language_quote: אַתָּ֥ה נֵירִ֖⁠י יְהוָ֑ה וַ⁠יהוָ֖ה יַגִּ֥יהַּ חָשְׁכִּֽ⁠י
notes.note: Here David is speaking as if Yahweh were actually a **lamp** that gives him light in his **darkness**. This image is rich in meaning. Among the meanings that come out in this context is that Yahweh helps him understand what he should do when he would otherwise be confused or uncertain. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you enable me to recognize what I should do when I could not understand that myself]

bsb_verse_text: For in You I can charge an army; with my God I can scale a wall.
ult_verse_text: For by you, I run {after} a troop.

notes.note: This could mean: (1) that David is saying that by God’s help, he can pursue and overtake a **troop**. He may be recalling how he and his men were able to overtake the Amalekite “troop” ([1 Samuel 30:8](../../1sa/30/08.md)) that had raided Ziklag and rescue their families and possessions. Alternate translation: [I can pursue and overtake a raiding band]; (2) that David is saying that by God’s help, he can directly attack and disperse an opposing group of soldiers. Alternate translation: [I can run through a troop] or [I can attack and disperse an opposing troop]

David is speaking of successfully leading troops to capture a fortified city as if he and they would **leap** over its walls. He may be recalling how he and his soldiers were able to capture the stronghold of Zion in Jerusalem ([5:6–9](../05/06.md)). If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I can surmount the walls of a fortified city]

bsb_verse_text: As for God, His way is perfect; the word of the LORD is flawless. He is a shield to all who take refuge in Him.
ult_verse_text: This God, his way {is} perfect. The word of Yahweh is refined. He {is} a shield to all of the ones taking refuge in him.

notes.note: Here David is speaking of how God acts and directs others as if it were a **way** or path that he was walking along. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [everything he does is faultless] or [he always acts righteously]
Here, **word of Yahweh** represents what Yahweh says by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [What Yahweh says]

The expression **is refined** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [is pure]

David is speaking as if God were actually a **shield** behind which people took **refuge**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [He protects everyone who trusts him]

bsb_verse_text: For who is God besides the LORD? And who is the Rock except our God?
ult_verse_text: For who {is} God except Yahweh? And who {is} a rock except our God?

notes.orig_language_quote: כִּ֥י מִי־אֵ֖ל מִ⁠בַּלְעֲדֵ֣י יְהוָ֑ה וּ⁠מִ֥י צ֖וּר מִֽ⁠בַּלְעֲדֵ֥י אֱלֹהֵֽי⁠נוּ
notes.note: David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [For Yahweh is the only God! And our God is the only rock!]

David speaks of God here as if God were a **rock**. This means that God provides safety and protection, like a large rock that people can hide behind or stand on for safety. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [provides safety]

bsb_verse_text: God is my strong fortress, and He makes my way clear.
ult_verse_text: This God {is} my fortress of strength, and he makes my way perfect,

notes.note: David is using the possessive form to describe a **fortress** that is characterized by **strength**. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [is my strong fortress]

Here David is speaking as if God were actually a **fortress of strength**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [keeps me entirely safe]

This could mean: (1) that God makes the **way** on which a person travels **perfect**, that is, free from obstacles. Alternate translation: [and he removes all the obstacles in my path] or [and he enables me to live the life he has chosen for me without hindrance]; (2) that David is speaking of how a person lives as if that were a **way** or path that the person was walking along. Alternate translation: [and he enables me to live in just the way that he wants people to live]

bsb_verse_text: He makes my feet like those of a deer and stations me upon the heights.
ult_verse_text: making my feet like a deer, and he makes me stand on my high places,

notes.note: David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [making my feet like the feet of a deer]

Here David is comparing his ability to move quickly and surely with the way a deer moves in difficult terrain. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [making my feet secure] or [keeping me from stumbling]

David may be using this possessive form, referring to these as **my** high places, because he is recalling how he had to hide among cliffs when Saul was trying to kill him. It may be more natural in your language to express this meaning with a different form. Alternate translation: [and he keeps me from falling from any high places where I have to go]

bsb_verse_text: He trains my hands for battle; my arms can bend a bow of bronze.
ult_verse_text: training my hands for war, and my arms bend a bow of bronze.

notes.note: David is using his **hands** to represent all of him in the act of fighting in battle. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [training me for war]

bsb_verse_text: You have given me Your shield of salvation, and Your gentleness exalts me.
ult_verse_text: And you give to me the shield of your salvation, and your answer makes me great.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **salvation**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [And the shield you provide for me saves me]

Here David is speaking of God’s power to save him as if it were a **shield** that could protect him from physical attacks. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you protect me by saving me]

By **your answer**, David means God’s response to his prayers requesting help. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and your answer to my prayers]

bsb_verse_text: You broaden the path beneath me so that my ankles do not give way.
ult_verse_text: You enlarge my step under me, and my feet do not slip.

notes.note: Here, David’s **step** represents the place where he would step. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [You enlarge the place where I step under me]

David is speaking as if God had made the area where he needed to walk more spacious. This represents having freedom to move and act without being constrained by enemies. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [You give me room to maneuver]

bsb_verse_text: I devoured and crushed them so they could not rise; they have fallen under my feet.
ult_verse_text: And I devour them, and I shatter them, and they do not arise, but they fall under my feet.

notes.note: Here David is speaking of destroying his enemies as if he were a wild animal that could **devour** them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And I completely destroy them]

David is describing one event before describing another event that preceded it. If it would be helpful your language, you may wish to relate these events in the order in which they happened, as in the UST. Alternate translation: [and they fall under my feet and do not arise]
The implication is that David’s enemies fall and remain dead. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [but they fall down dead]

bsb_verse_text: You have armed me with strength for battle; You have subdued my foes beneath me.
ult_verse_text: And you gird me {with} valor for war; you make the ones rising up under me bow down.

notes.note: Here David is speaking of valor as if it were a piece of clothing with which God **girds** him, like a belt or piece of armor. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you make me valiant]

David means that people who try to rebel against him ultimately **bow down** as a symbolic action by which they show renewed submission to his authority. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [you make the ones rising up under me submit humbly to my authority]

David is using **the ones rising up under me** as a common expression of his culture to mean “those who rebel against my rule.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the ones revolting against my rule]

bsb_verse_text: You have made my enemies retreat before me; I destroyed those who hated me.
ult_verse_text: And my enemies, you give to me the back of {their} neck; the ones hating me, and I destroy them.

notes.note: David is describing a symbolic action in which victorious soldiers would make defeated enemies lie face down on the ground and then step on their necks to demonstrate their complete triumph (as in [Joshua 10:24](../../jos/10/24.md), for example). If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express the meaning plainly in your translation. Alternate translation: [you enable me to step in complete triumph on the backs of their necks]

In this verse, the word **back** is singular in form, but it refers to all the enemies as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use plural forms of “back” and “neck.” Alternate translation: [the backs of their necks]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [you give to me the ones hating me]

bsb_verse_text: They looked, but there was no one to save them—to the LORD, but He did not answer.
ult_verse_text: They look, but {there is} no one saving; to Yahweh, but he does not answer them.

notes.note: David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [they call to Yahweh]

By **he does not answer them**, David means that Yahweh does not help his enemies as they have asked. (The meaning of **answer** in this context is similar to the meaning of “listen” in [12:18](../12/18.md).) You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [but he does not do what they ask]

bsb_verse_text: I ground them as the dust of the earth; I crushed and trampled them like mud in the streets.
ult_verse_text: And I beat them like the dust of the earth.

notes.note: The point of this comparison is that just as the **dust of the earth** consists of tiny pieces, so, in this image, David **beat** his enemies so thoroughly that they broke into small pieces. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [And I beat them into small pieces like the dust of the earth]

David speaks here of defeating his enemies as if he had actually beaten them into small pieces. This compares his total victory over his enemies to the way that dust can be completely scattered. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And I completely destroyed them] or [And I scattered them completely]

Here David is speaking of his enemies as if they were **mud** that he could crush and trample. This metaphor emphasizes his complete victory over them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I completely crushed my enemies and trampled them down] or [I utterly defeated my enemies, destroying them completely]

bsb_verse_text: You have delivered me from the strife of my people; You have preserved me as the head of nations; a people I had not known shall serve me.
ult_verse_text: And you rescue me from the disputes of my people. You keep me as the head of nations. People I did not know serve me.

notes.note: Here David is speaking of his leadership role as if he were the **head** of a body. Just as the head directs the rest of the body, David ruled over other nations. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [as the ruler of nations] or [to govern the nations]

bsb_verse_text: Foreigners cower before me; when they hear me, they obey me.
ult_verse_text: Sons of the foreigner come cringing to me. At the hearing of an ear, they hear me.

notes.note: David is not referring to a specific **foreigner**. He means foreigners in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Sons of foreigners]

In certain contexts, biblical authors and characters use the common expression of their culture **Sons of ** to indicate that a person has a certain characteristic. In this case, these people have the characteristic of being foreigners or people from other nations. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly, here and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [Foreigners]

David is using one part of a person, the **ear** to represent entire people in the act of hearing. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [When they hear]
David means that these people hear specifically about him. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [When they hear about me]

By **they hear me**, David means that they obey him. (The meaning of **hear** in this context is similar to the meaning of “listen” in [12:18](../12/18.md).) You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [they obey me]

bsb_verse_text: Foreigners lose heart and come trembling from their strongholds.
ult_verse_text: Sons of the foreigner fade away, and they come trembling from their fortresses.

notes.note: Here David is speaking of foreign armies as if they were plants that **fade away** and lose their vitality. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [lose strength]

In certain contexts, biblical authors and characters use the expression **son of** to indicate that a person has the characteristic of something. In this case, the people whom David is describing have the characteristic of being soldiers of foreign countries that are resisting his rule. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [foreign soldiers]

bsb_verse_text: The LORD lives, and blessed be my Rock! And may God, the Rock of my salvation, be exalted—
ult_verse_text: Yahweh {is} alive! And blessed {be} my rock, and may the God of the rock of my salvation be exalted,

notes.note: David is using a phrase that expresses a strong feeling, joy. There may be an equivalent word or phrase in your language that you can use in your translation to convey this feeling. If not, you could say what David was feeling, or you could say what made him joyful. Alternate translation: [I rejoice that Yahweh is alive] or [How wonderful that Yahweh lives]

The expression **blessed be** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And I bless my rock]
See how you translated the similar expression in [22:32](../22/32.md). Alternate translation: [the one who keeps me safe]

The expression **be exalted** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and I exalt the God of the rock of my salvation]

David is using the possessive form to describe **God** as characterized by being the **rock** of his **salvation**. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the God who is the rock of my salvation]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **salvation**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the God who is the rock that saves me]

David is speaking of God as if he were a large rock or cliff where David could find safety from his enemies. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the God who saves me by keeping me safe]

bsb_verse_text: the God who avenges me and brings down nations beneath me,
ult_verse_text: the God giving vengeance to me and bringing down peoples under me

notes.note: Here David is speaking of conquering peoples as if they were being brought **down** physically under his feet. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and defeating peoples before me]

bsb_verse_text: who frees me from my enemies. You exalt me above my foes; You rescue me from violent men.
ult_verse_text: and bringing me out from my enemies.

notes.note: By **bringing me out from my enemies**, David means escaping from being confined or restrained by his enemies. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and bringing me out from the confinement of my enemies]

Here David is speaking of his enemies as if they were physically **arising** upward to attack him, and he speaks of God as physically **lifting** him up above them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you make me prevail over those who attack me] or [And you protect me from those who oppose me]

David is not referring to a specific **man of violence**. He means violent people in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [from violent men]

Here David is using the plural **violences** where he could have used the singular form. This suggests that he is using the plural form to emphasize the severity and continuity of the violence that this **man** commits or attempts. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the singular and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [great violence]

bsb_verse_text: Therefore I will praise You, O LORD, among the nations; I will sing praises to Your name.
ult_verse_text: Therefore I thank you, Yahweh, among the nations, and I sing praise to your name,

notes.note: Here, **name** represents Yahweh himself, in light of his fame and reputation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [to you] or [to you, Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: Great salvation He brings to His king. He shows loving devotion to His anointed, to David and his descendants forever.”
ult_verse_text: the one magnifying the salvation of his king and doing covenant faithfulness to his anointed, to David, and to his seed until forever.”

notes.note: Jewish scribes instructed synagogue readers to say “a tower of salvation to his king” when they got to this phrase. That could have been the original reading. (There is a difference of only one letter between these readings in Hebrew.) If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **salvation**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the one saving his king by great deeds]

The expression **his anointed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [to the one he anointed]

Here David is speaking of his offspring as if they were actually **seed**. Just as a seed can grow into a plant that produces more seeds, David’s descendants would continue to come from his family line. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and to his descendants]

bsb_verse_text: These are the last words of David: “The oracle of David son of Jesse, the oracle of the man raised on high, the one anointed by the God of Jacob, and the sweet psalmist of Israel:
ult_verse_text: Now these {are} the last words of David. An oracle of David the son of Jesse, and an oracle of the man raised {to} height, the anointed of the God of Jacob, and the delightful {one} of the songs of Israel.

notes.orig_language_quote: נְאֻ֧ם דָּוִ֣ד בֶּן־יִשַׁ֗י וּ⁠נְאֻ֤ם הַ⁠גֶּ֨בֶר֙ הֻ֣קַם עָ֔ל
notes.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. Hebrew poetry was based on this kind of repetition, and it would be good to show this to your readers by including both phrases in your translation rather than combining them. It may be clearer in your language to connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Review from your work on [chapter 22](../22/01.md) how you decided as a team to represent Hebrew poetry in your translation. Alternate translation: [An oracle of David the son of Jesse, yes, an oracle of the man raised to height] or [An oracle of David the son of Jesse, who was a man raised to height]

The expression **raised** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the man whom God raised to height]

The author is speaking of David’s position of authority as if it were a **height**. He means that God gave David great power and honor. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the man whom God put in an important position]

The expression **the anointed of the God of Jacob** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the one whom the God of Jacob anointed]

The author is using the possessive form to describe **the God of Jacob** that is characterized by **Jacob**, meaning this is the God who chose Jacob and his descendants and who made covenant promises to them. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the God with whom the descendants of Jacob are in a covenant relationship]

The author is using the possessive form to describe **songs** that people in **Israel** heard and sang. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [and the one in whose songs the Israelites delighted]

bsb_verse_text: The Spirit of the LORD spoke through me; His word was on my tongue.
ult_verse_text: “The Spirit of Yahweh spoke by me, and his word {was} on my tongue.

notes.note: These two clauses say basically the same thing as the previous verse. See the discussion in the Introduction to [chapter 22](../22/01.md) of how Hebrew poetry was based on the repetition of words, phrases, and ideas. Recall how you decided as a team represent Hebrew poetry in your translation. Alternate translation: [The Spirit of Yahweh spoke by me, yes, his word was on my tongue] or [The Spirit of Yahweh gave me the words to speak for him]
David is using the term **word** to represent what he said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I spoke his word]

David is using his **tongue** to represent all of himself in the act of speaking. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I spoke what he wanted me to say]

bsb_verse_text: The God of Israel spoke; the Rock of Israel said to me, ‘He who rules the people with justice, who rules in the fear of God,
ult_verse_text: The God of Israel spoke to me, the Rock of Israel said, ‘A righteous one ruling over man {is} ruling {in} the fear of God,
